column2: Before New Yorkers hear the sirens, police officers hear this: "Arrive alive." That's what the dispatcher announces when handing them a job - 1085, officer needs assistance; meet the E.M.T. unit; shots fired; difficulty breathing; sexual attack; car accident - "Arrive alive." Then what? This new series by Ángel Franco of The Times will show what happens after those calls go out, at crimes in progress or crime scenes or crimes under investigation. The series will provide a glimpse behind the police tape; a close-up look at the who, what and when of police calls. Its images will capture investigations into shootings, memorials for murder victims and the reactions of neighbors after the squad cars arrive and the sirens go quiet. As a freelance photojournalist, Mr. Franco spent five years in the late 1970s and early 80s with the officers and detectives of the 46th Precinct in the west-central Bronx, a project described in "Cops, Neighbors and a Camera in Between" (Lens, June 24).

SOKOL--Dorothy, died June 28, 2010 at the age of 96. Beloved wife of Sidney for over 65 years; cherished mother of Eileen Schwartzburg, Jacqueline Fleischman and Monte Sokol. Grandmother of six and great-grandmother of six, she will be dearly missed by us all. She was a valued employee of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. A memorial service in her honor will be held at The Reconstructionist Synagogue of The North Shore, 1001 Plandome Road, Plandome, NY on Wednesday, June 30 at Noon.

DOUGLAS-KIRKWOOD--Rodlyn, died June 24th, 2010. Beloved daughter of Rodney and Evelyn (Micey). Stepdaughter of Olive. Beloved wife of John. Loving mother of Jamel, Yanikk and Lenecia. Cherished sister of Lynrod, Jennifer, Maria, Rose Marie, Petronilla and Kevin. She earned a stellar reputation as an advertising executive in New York and Trinidad and was Creative Director for Christiansen and Belgrave and Corbin Compton Communications. Retired as Director of Visual Arts Foundation (School of Visual Arts), and was a published author, performance artist and oral poet. Loved by many, friend to all, she will be missed dearly. Life Celebration Memorial - July 2, 2010 at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76 St., New York, 2-4pm. Reception - July 2, 2010 Sugar Hill Harlem Inn, 408 Convent Ave. and 147th St., New York, 5-9pm.

GOSS--Mary E. Weber Professor Emerita of the Department of Public Health at the Weill Cornell Medical Center, died unexpectedly at her home on June 23. A pioneering medical sociologist, her 1959 Ph.D. dissertation at Columbia University, under the direction of Professor Robert K. Merton, was an analysis of the organizational roles of physicians. Later published as Physicians in Bureaucracy, her early and influential work helped shape the emerging specialty of medical sociology. It was complemented by her contribution to the 1957 book The Student Physician that described innovative changes to the Comprehensive Care and Teaching Program for fourth-year medical students at Weill Cornell, such as introducing a public health focus on more advanced epidemiologic studies of diseases important to clinicians. As a medical sociologist, often in collaboration with Professor George G. Reader, MD, of Weill Cornell, she subsequently contributed to a wide range of studies on the delivery and effectiveness of medical care that led to her 1972 faculty appointment in the Weill Cornell Department of Public Health. She served a term as Book Review Editor of the American Journal of Sociology, and then was Editor of the Journal of Medical Sociology, now the Journal of Health and Social Behavior, from 1976 to 1978. Along with teaching and administrative responsibilities, her research interests continued until her retirement in 1992. For these and other contributions, she was honored in 2000 with the prestigious Leo G. Reeder Award from the Section of Medical Sociology of the American Sociological Association. Born in Chicago in 1926, she graduated in 1943 from the then Nazareth Academy for Women in LaGrange Park, IL. She then attended the University of Iowa, Iowa City, where in 1947 she received a department honored BA in sociology along with university honors and, in 1948, an MA, also in sociology. Married in 1945 to Albert E. Goss, in 1948 she and he began residency in Amherst, MA where she did fill-in teaching of sociology at Smith College and the University of Massachusetts, Amherst. In January 1951, she entered the Ph.D. program in sociology at Columbia University, in which she was a Gilder Fellow from 1952-1953, and began joint residence in New York City and Amherst. In 1966 she, her surviving husband and young son, Charles A. Goss, entered her long residency in Piscataway, NJ. Charles now resides in Chapel Hill, NC with his wife, Karen, and children Jessica and Derek. Her other immediate survivors comprise her sister, Dorothy Weber Inyard and nephew Gary Inyard of Chicago, brother C. Edward Weber and wife Suzanne, of Milwaukee, and nephews Paul Weber of Spencer, WI and Mark Weber of Eden Prairie MN, and their families. A memorial service will be announced later. Her ashes are consigned to the Weber family plot in the Bohemian National Cemetery in Chicago. Memorializing donations should be made to the Weill Cornell Medical College (please write "Dept. of Public Health in memory of Mary Goss" in the memo line of the check), Office of Development, 1300 York Avenue, Box 123, New York, NY 10065.

INTERNATIONAL Because of an editing error, an article by The Associated Press on Monday about the arrest of some 200 activists during a dawn-to-dusk general strike in Bangladesh led by the opposition Bangladesh Nationalist Party referred incorrectly to the party's leader. The head of the party, former Prime Minister Khaleda Zia, is a woman.

GRABEL--Sylvia Salkind, 90, died peacefully on June 28, 2010. Beloved wife of the late William Grabel. Loving mother of Susan (David) and Amy (Sandy). Cherished grandmother of Rachel (Michael) and Josh. Friend to many, we all love you and will miss you.

CUMMINGS--Eugene, on June 28 at the age of 95. Devoted husband to Bernice; loving father of Charles (Cynthia Hayes) and Bob (Mary Brady); cherished grandfather to David, Katharine, Alexandra and Michael. Services will be held today, Wednesday, June 30, 11:30am, at Riverside Nassau North Chapels, Great Neck, New York.

TAYLOR--William L. The staff of Brooklyn College's former student newspaper, Vanguard, mourn the loss of a valiant campus editor, a great lawyer and life-long advocate of civil rights. Heartfelt sympathies to his family.
STRUHL--Dr. Bernard. Happy Birthday. Your family misses you. Love, Judi

SEEMAN--Helene Zucker. Our deepest sympathies to the family and friends of Helene Zucker Seeman. Our hearts go out to our dear friend, Fred L. Seeman, and to his sons, Ford and Curtis, upon the sudden and tragic loss of their beloved wife and mother. Helene touched the lives and hearts of all who knew her. Love, Peter and Bernadette Kirwin and the staff of the Law Offices of Fred L. Seeman.

John Willis, who spent more than half a century doggedly keeping comprehensive track of American theater productions and film releases and whose encyclopedic records were published in the annual volumes Theatre World and Screen World, died at his home in Manhattan on Friday. He was 93. His death was announced by Ben Hodges, who succeeded him as editor of Theatre World in 2008.

SAN FRANCISCO -- Google plans to stop automatically sending users in mainland Chinese to its uncensored Hong Kong site, in an effort to appease Beijing as it seeks to renew its license to operate in China. The action, experts on China say, amounts to a symbolic gesture that Google hopes will placate the Chinese government, which may be feeling pressure from citizens who are demanding continued access to Google's search engine.

WASHINGTON -- Elena Kagan deflected questions about her own views on gun rights and abortion during her Supreme Court confirmation hearings on Tuesday, instead describing Supreme Court precedents. She declined to say whether terrorism suspects must be warned of the right to remain silent, saying the issue was ''quite likely to get to the courts.'' And Ms. Kagan, the solicitor general and former dean of Harvard Law School, refused to say whether the Supreme Court was correct to take on the 2000 case of Bush v. Gore, telling senators that the issue of when the court should intervene in disputed elections is ''an important and difficult question'' but one that could come before her should she be confirmed.

LOUIS--Arthur, died June 26, 2010. Beloved husband of Kathleen, loving father of Anne and Stephen (Susan), brother of Jerry (Barbara), uncle of Cyndi.

BECKER--Peter Evan, January 31, 1930 to June 28, 2010. Beloved patriarch of his cherished family. Husband to Jean (Glauber); Father to Kenneth and Donald; Father-in-law to Jennifer and Sherry; Gramp to Henry, Gregory, Natalie, and Julie. Gentleman, scholar, mentor, and good friend.

ERBEN--Susan. The Metropolitan Opera mourns the untimely death of our former colleague Susan Erben. A television producer here for 16 years, Sue was a respected co-worker and dear friend to many in our company. We offer our sincere condolences to her family and loved ones. Peter Gelb, General Manager James Levine, Music Director

I love beer with seafood, especially casual summer seafood like lobster rolls, fried clams and steamers. A good white-clam pizza also calls for a refreshing pale ale. Using the pizza as my inspiration, I made clam quesadillas that I seared on the grill. While they were still sizzling hot, with the mellow cheese starting to ooze, I cut them into wedges, which disappeared almost as fast as the frosty mugs of beer.
ROTHMAN--Deborah. Love always, Gary and David

KISLAK--Dr. Jay Ward, died suddenly last Thursday, June 24, at Ballston Beach in Truro, MA. Dr. Kislak was a graduate of Yale College and Yale Medical School and an Infectious Diseases Fellow at the Thorndike Memorial Laboratory of the Harvard Medical Service at the Boston City Hospital. He was Chief of Infectious Diseases at St. Vincent's Hospital in New York City. Dr. Kislak is survived by his wife Barbara, his children Pamela, Valerie and Andrew, and his grandchildren Max, Tabitha, Zachary and Eliza.
NEW YORK An article on Saturday about a mixed-income condominium in Harlem misstated the name of one resident. He is Raymond Daniel Medina, not Ray Medina Hernandez.
SEEMAN--Helene Zucker. Dearest sister Helene, our love for you will go on forever.

FRONT PAGE A capsule summary on Friday for an article about the proposed canonization of a Brooklyn priest misidentified him in some editions. The prospective saint is Msgr. Bernard J. Quinn -- not Nicholas A. DiMarzio, the current bishop of Brooklyn. (The summary correctly referred to ''Monsignor Quinn'' in a second reference.) The article itself referred imprecisely to the significance Monsignor Quinn's canonization would have for Brooklyn. While he is the first person proposed for sainthood by the Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn, as the capsule summary correctly noted, Monsignor Quinn would not be the borough's first saint if canonized. The Orthodox Church in America canonized Rafla Hawaweeny as St. Raphael of Brooklyn in 2000.

One man is dead, shot in the mouth in El Salvador, presumably for speaking ill of a gang. Another man lives in hiding in the Salvadoran countryside, hoping his former gang will not mete out a similar punishment to him. Both men had once fled to the United States, where they sought asylum, saying they faced mortal threats from street gangs in El Salvador. In recent years the immigration courts have seen a surge of thousands of such gang-related claims from Central Americans. They have rarely been granted.

WEEKEND An article on June 18 about programs to teach families to sail misidentified the function of steel railings on a boat used by a family taking lessons offered by the Offshore Sailing School at Liberty State Park. They are intended to protect passengers from falling overboard, not to keep the boat from tipping over.
The Times asks readers how they would lure Lebron James to New York once he officially goes on the free agent market on Thursday. nytimes.com/sports

BUSINESS DAY An article on Tuesday about agreement among the world's biggest economies to address their budget imbalances misstated China's stance on its currency, the renminbi. While the country has indicated it will ease the practice, its policy has aimed to hold down the value of the renminbi as a way of promoting exports; it has not been ''propping up its currency.'' The article also misstated a recommendation of the Group of 20 nations aimed at promoting domestic consumption in China. To do that, China was urged to raise the value of its currency, not lower it.

At the end of the American International Group's annual meeting last month, a shareholder approached the microphone with a question for Robert Benmosche, the insurer's chief executive. ''I'd like to know, what does A.I.G. plan to do with Goldman Sachs?'' he asked. ''Are you going to get -- recoup -- some of our money that was given to them?''
International TWITTER MESSAGES BECOME

Senate Democrats on Tuesday unveiled yet another effort to extend unemployment benefits as part of a pared package that includes an extension of the deadline for homeowners to claim a tax credit. After Republicans blocked a similar effort to extend unemployment benefits last week, the majority leader, Senator Harry Reid, Democrat of Nevada, said he would move on to other legislative business. And, for a day and a half, he did.

THE ARTS A report in the ''Arts, Briefly'' column on Saturday about lifetime achievement awards from the National Endowment for the Arts misstated the action taken by the agency, and because of an editing error, the report misstated the timing. The N.E.A. announced the recipients of the awards on Friday; it will not present them this Friday. The report also referred incorrectly to the winners of the Jazz Masters Awards. They are the 2011 Jazz Masters, not 2010. (The awards are to be presented in January.)

What in the world do they think they were going to get out of this, in this day and age? RICHARD F. STOLZ, a former head of C.I.A. spy operations, on the accusation that Russia deployed 11 spies to live and work in the United States. [A1]

Before New Yorkers hear the sirens, police officers hear this: ''Arrive alive.'' That is what the central dispatcher announces to officers before handing them a job: ambulance run or officer needs assistance; meet the emergency medical technicians unit or shots fired; difficulty breathing; sexual attack; car accident. The new Lens series, Sirens, will take a look at what happens after those calls go out -- at crimes in progress, or crime scenes or active investigations.

Butch Kelley was as on-time dependable as the drumbeats at 52 Park in the South Bronx. In lousy weather or health, he was there to volunteer at the salsa concerts put on by a scrappy group of volunteers that rescued the park from the ravages of abandonment in 1980. ''Whatever we did to create stability, Butch was a part of it,'' said Al Quinones, a member of 52 People for Progress, the community group that has nurtured the park, formally known as Playground 52, back to life. ''He was always the first to say he was down. Whatever was needed, he was down.''

Three silvery domes that had been installed in the new Brooklyn Bridge Park for children to play on -- but which instead scorched their young hands -- have been removed. In their place on Tuesday evening were an empty plot and two mainstream pieces of playground equipment - one for climbing and another for sitting in the shade.

10 P.M. (National Geographic) THE REAL MIDNIGHT EXPRESS In 1978 Alan Parker's ''Midnight Express'' drew on the real-life tale of Billy Hayes (played by Brad Davis), a 23-year-old college student who was sentenced to 30 years in Sagmalcilar, a Turkish prison with horrific conditions, after being convicted of smuggling hashish in 1970. (The film also earned six Oscar nominations and two wins, including one for Oliver Stone for best screenplay based on another medium.) In this Season 4 premiere of ''Locked Up Abroad'' Mr. Hayes (portrayed by Robbie Jarvis, above) discusses the full story of his imprisonment and subsequent 1975 escape, parts of which were modified in his book and the film for legal reasons. WILSON--Louis L.,Jr., Ret. General USAF, died peacefully, June 25, 2010, in Tucson, AZ. Louis was born in Huntington, WV, January 10, 1919. He graduated from Hurricane High School in West Virginia, after which he attended Greenbriar Military School in Lewisberg, WV. He received his appointment to the United States Military Academy, West Point, NY in 1939 and was graduated early, January 1943, due to the War. His initial assignment was with the 385th Fighter Group as a P-47 pilot, flying bomber support leading up to and including D-Day and later flying support for Gen. Patton's drive through France. By the end of the War, he had flown 114 combat missions and was commander of the 367th Fighter Squadron. Following the war, he served many in capacities organizing and commanding various fighter and bomber squadrons within the Strategic Air Command. In 1964 he was assigned to Washington, D.C., serving as deputy director of operational requirements in the Office of the Deputy Chief of Staff for Research and Development, where he worked on conceptual plans for the B-1, F-15, A-10, and advanced versions of intercontinental ballistic missiles. In 1968 he served as Vice Commander of the Space and Missile Systems Organization and in 1970 the Commander of the Space and Missile Test Center in Vandenberg Air Force Base, California. He was appointed inspector general of the Air Force in 1971 and Vice Commander-in-Chief of the U.S. Air Forces in Europe in 1973. Louis finished his military career as the Commander-in-Chief of the Pacific Air Force, 1974-1977. From headquarters in Hickam Air Force Base, HI, he commanded all of the forces of the Pacific basin and organized and executed the evacuation of military and U.S. civilian personnel from Vietnam at the end of that conflict. Lesser known was the evacuation of over 2000 orphaned children, known as Operation Baby Lift, to new adoptive parents in the U.S. During his very distinguished career he had the opportunity to travel the globe and meet dignitaries of many countries. His favorites were Bob Hope and Jane Mansfield, whom he entertained on one of their USO tours. After 35 years of military service, he retired May 31, 1977 to a small ranch in Tucson, AZ where he was able to fulfill his childhood dream of raising horses and cattle. He has been very active in his community, loving the sun, the warmth, his family and his many friends that surround him. Louis L. Wilson, Jr. lived a life of service to his country, his family and his friends. He is honored for his contributions to the safety and integrity of our country and loved for his gentle kindness and loving generosity. He has made a difference. Services by Evergreen Mortuary, Tucson, AZ www.evergreenmortuary-cemetery.com

MURPHY--Patricia J. Manhattan attorney and part time resident of Fort Lauderdale, died June 25 after a short illness. She was 72. An Intellectual Property specialist, Ms. Murphy was counsel for the FCC, RKO General, American Broadcasting Company and publishers Harcourt Brace before co-founding the law firm of Murphy & Zissu in New York City. In recent years, she served as an arbitrator in New York and Florida for the American Arbitration Association. Ms. Murphy graduated from Central Catholic High School in Fort Lauderdale and the University of Florida. She was a former newspaper reporter at the Fort Lauderdale News before attending Georgetown Law School. She was a co-author of The Businesswoman's Guide to 30 American Cities, and in 1983, she was a candidate for Civil Court judge in New York County. She was an avid scuba diver and golfer, and an adventurer who traveled the world in search of new experiences. To celebrate her 72nd birthday, she went skydiving. Ms. Murphy is predeceased by her parents, John and Clara Murphy of Fort Lauderdale. She is survived by her fiance, Eugene Schramm; a son, Jacob Zissu; a daughter-in-law, Aimee Bartol Zissu; and a granddaughter, Sascha. A memorial service will be held in New York on Tuesday, July 6 at 107 West, a restaurant located at 2787 Broadway at 1:00pm. A second memorial service will be held at the former Central Catholic High School in Fort Lauderdale on July 31. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be made in her name to the Susan J. Komen Race for the Cure or St. Baldrick's Cancer Foundation.

SEEMAN--Helene Zucker, on June 27, 2010. Born April 20, 1950. Beloved wife of Fred, loving mother of Ford and Curtis, cherished daughter of Marcia and the late Benjamin Zucker, dear sister of Michele Kanter and Herbert and Cynthia Zucker, devoted aunt of Zoe, Zev, Eric, Blayne, Arthur and Amber. Graduate of Bronx High School of Science, Boston University, and master's degree of Library Science-Expertise in Documentation. Helene began her career at Louis K. Meisel Gallery, Soho, NY. We will forever cherish our precious memories. Service Thursday 11:45am at "The Riverside" 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

At about 10pm EDT, Alex made landfall in a rural part of Mexico between the towns of La Pesca and Punta de Piedra at an intensity of 90kts and 948mb. It was on an intensifying trend, which tends to make the conditions a bit more severe than if it were weakening or steady at the time (the storm is more coupled with the boundary layer and stronger winds can mix down to the surface). There have been several tornadoes already reported in association with Alex, mostly in the Brownsville area. Rainfall is the big problem for northern Mexico and southern Texas. Cameron County (the southern tip of Texas) received anywhere from 5-9" of rain yesterday, and it's not over. An additional foot of rain is possible over these areas as the storm decays. Up by Galveston, nearly 2" of rain fell as of this morning. Unfortunately, I wasn't able to locate any real-time rainfall totals from Mexico, but general reports are claiming 6-12" have fallen so far in coastal areas and 20"+ over the higher terrain further inland.

With "The Twilight Saga: Eclipse" now playing in 4,468 theaters in North America - the widest opening on record - the movie's vampires and werewolves are expectedly setting the box office on fire. "Eclipse" sold $68.5 million on Wednesday (including the 12:01 a.m. showings), breaking a record for the biggest mid-week gross in history, according to Summit Entertainment, the studio behind the series. ("Transformers: Revenge of the Fallen," which sold $62 million on a Wednesday last summer, will now have to make do with second place.) Opening-day audiences were 80 percent female, which has become standard for the "Twilight" series, based on the best-selling books by Stephenie Meyer. The question for "Eclipse" was never about whether it would open big - that was a given - but whether it would generate bang-up repeat business and lure even more fans to the franchise. The answer will come in the days ahead but exit polls signal that "Eclipse" could achieve those goals through strong word of mouth: CinemaScore, the market research company, said audiences rate the film an A, which is higher than the grade given to its predecessor, "The Twilight Saga: New Moon."

Rhubarb grew like weeds in Wisconsin, where I grew up. As young hellions we would pick it, tear off the elephant-ear leaves (which are mildly poisonous) and dip the stalks in sugar to eat. That fibrous green tang remains one of my Proustian tastes of summer. Nowadays I have to buy my rhubarb at the greengrocer, but even at three bucks a pound I consider it a grand find and pounce while I can. I wish I could preserve the taste for the rest of the year, but I'm not a jam maker. So recently I decided to try my hand at making a drinking syrup with it.

Just a few days after the death of their company's namesake choreographer, dancers from the Merce Cunningham Dance Company gave a memorable performance as part of the 2009 River to River Festival, which drew more than 3,000 people to Battery Park City in Manhattan. Now, almost a year later, five choreographers will pay their respects to Cunningham in a program titled "We Give Ourselves Away at Every Moment: An EVENT for Merce," on the Esplanade Plaza at Battery Park City on July 26 at 6 p.m. Lucinda Childs, Bill T. Jones, Susan Marshall, Jon Kinzel and Faye Driscoll will present new dances created for the occasion, as well as existing works inspired by Cunningham's Events pieces. The musicians David Eggar, Geoff Gersh and Kotchy will also perform at the free event, which is also presented by arts>World Financial Center and the Battery Park City Authority and produced by the choreographer Annie-B Parson. "Rather than speeches or prayers, we use his structures to remember him on this day," Ms. Parson said in a statement. "We try them on our work, just for a day, as a way to remember the father of postmodernism."

IT wasn't easy upstaging M.I.A. Or the indie-favorite Interpol, who performed in a loading dock on West 14th Street. But when Die Antwoord, the zef-rap trio from South Africa, took to the stage in a tongue-lashing fury of slick beats and hyperkinetic rhymes, the house seemed to shake. That was quite a feat, considering that the Creators Project -- a 12-hour marathon of cool music, sleek digital art and indie films -- took place Saturday at Milk Studios, an eight-story photo studio in the meatpacking district that morphed into a kind of Lollapalooza for the art-geek fashion crowd.

10 P.M. (ABC) BOSTON MED Picking up where ''Hopkins,'' the Peabody Award-winning documentary series from ABC News, left off, this eight-part report follows the medical staff at three hospitals -- Massachusetts General, Brigham and Women's, and Children's Hospital Boston -- in what Ginia Bellafante, writing in The New York Times, called ''intelligent, emotionally resonant television.'' In this episode a soldier returns from Iraq to reunite with his wife, whom he has not seen in nearly nine months, and to witness the birth of their son, who will need surgery within days to correct a serious heart defect. Also, Jon Daniel, above, a cardiothoracic resident, struggles to balance long work hours with the needs of his young family; and Amanda Grabowski, at Massachusetts General, shows why she has twice been named Harvard Med nurse of the year. 7 A.M. (NBC) TODAY Dev Patel, who starred in ''Slumdog Millionaire,'' promotes his latest film, ''The Last Airbender,'' here and on ''Live With Regis and Kelly,'' at 9 on ABC.

An article on Wednesday about the transformation of the former Domino Sugar refinery in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, into a residential development misstated the number of the 2,200 apartments that will be for the poor and working class. It is 660, not 600. The article also misstated a detail of a last-minute deal with the developer. It agreed to reduce the two planned 40-story towers to 34 floors, not 36. (Two other towers in the project will be 30 stories each.)

SEEMAN--Helene Zucker, on June 27, 2010. Born April 20, 1950. Beloved wife of Fred, loving mother of Ford and Curtis, cherished daughter of Marcia and the late Benjamin Zucker, dear sister of Michele Kanter, Herbert and Cynthia Zucker, Dr. Howard and Jana Seeman, devoted aunt of Zoe, Zev, Eric, Blayne, Arthur, Amber, Susanna and Caroline. Graduate of Bronx High School of Science, Boston University, and master's degree of Library Science-Expertise in Documentation. Helene began her career at Louis K. Meisel Gallery, Soho, NY. In 1978 she co-authored the book "Soho", A Guide to the Community. Reviewed by the New York Times, now classified as a historical documentation of Soho. She later researched and documented a second book entitled "Photo Realism". From 1980 forward she took great pride as director of the Art Acquisition Program at Prudential. In her most recent years she taught the arts at NYU with great enthusiasm. Helene was a shining light to her family and all those who knew her. She loved life and lived it to the fullest. We will forever cherish our precious memories. Service Thursday 11:45am at "The Riverside" 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

What happens when you have misplaced your iPhone or Android? You know the feeling - panic. And so many of us can be seen tightly grasping our phones. Maybe we want to be quick on the draw in case a call comes in. Or maybe the cost of replacing the do-everything smartphone is too high. Or maybe the phones have just become a part of our selves. All of this is why a new product from Zomm may wind up hitting a nerve. A small electronic disc that fits on a key ring, the product, also called the Zomm, connects to a phone via Bluetooth. Separate the two devices by more than 30 feet, and the Zomm first vibrates, then flashes and then screams.

WILSON--Ann M.,Teacher and Director of Admissions at Nightingale Bamford School, New York City, died at her Hamptons home June 15. Ms. Wilson was born July 5, 1931 to Webb Wilson and the former Muriel Smith. After graduation from NBS, Ms. Wilson attended Wheaton Col-lege in Massachusetts, earning a B.A. She returned to NBS as a teacher in 1956, dividing her time between New York and the Hamptons, where she was a member of the Maidstone Club. Private ceremony was held at Cedar Lawn Cemetery in East Hampton, June 25. A second memorial is being planned for the fall at NBS. Donations are suggested for the Nightingale Bamford School, 20 East 92nd Street, New York, NY 10128, or the Nature Conservancy, 142 Sag Harbor Tpke., East Hampton, NY, 11937-4904.

They lived in suburban enclaves, they went to barbecues, they raised all-American kids. Now, they are accused of being Russian spies. (Maybe not particularly good ones, but spies nonetheless.) Yes, we are talking about the 11 ''illegals'' rounded up this week - some as nearby as Montclair, N.J., and Yonkers - and charged in the biggest international spy scandal in years. That got us thinking: How can you tell your neighbors are spies? (Dave Letterman had the same idea for his Top 10 list Tuesday night, but we didn't think his picks were that funny.)

ARNOW--Joan. The board and staff of American Associates, Ben-Gurion University of the Negev mourn the passing of Joan Marianne Arnow, an elegant, gracious and good-hearted philanthropist who partnered with her husband Robert in numerous acts of love and human kindness. In addition to being a generous benefactor of so many art, music and cultural programs and organizations in her own right, Joan was Robert's best friend and stood ably by his side as he provided strong leadership and commitment to Ben-Gurion University in Beer-Sheva, Israel for some 28 years. Deeply committed to her local community as well as to Israel, Joan leaves a legacy of love and compassion that will be sorely missed. We extend our profound condolences to our dear friend Robert and his children David, Peter, Joshua and Ruth, to his entire family, and to all who have been touched by Joan's enriching and benevolent life. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Alexander M. Goren, President Doron Krakow, Executive Vice President Kevin Leopold, New York Regional Director

SWETT--Rachel Barrett, 21, of Manhattan. Died June 22 in Christchurch, New Zealand following a skiing accident on June 17. She is survived by her brothers, Nicholas and William; her parents, Benjamin and Katherine; her grandparents, Steven and Shiela Swett and Mary Ellin Barrett; six cousins; and ten aunts and uncles. A junior at Columbia College majoring in psychology, Rachel had been studying at Canterbury College in Christchurch during a semester abroad. An avid photographer and traveler, Rachel had spent her junior year in High School in Rennes, France, as part of the School Year Abroad Program and had also studied in Paris this past fall at Columbia College's Reid Hall. From kindergarten through 12th grade she attended the Brearley School in Manhattan, where she was known for her love of photography and writing and her spirited point of view towards Physical Education. Rachel loved children and had planned to focus on child psychology at Columbia. Loyal, passionate and loving, with a great sense of humor, Rachel made many friends of all ages who will miss her greatly. A funeral service will take place at the Church of the Heavenly Rest, 5th Avenue at 90th Street, at 11am on Saturday, July 3. A reception will follow at the House of the Redeemer, 7 East 95th Street, between 5th and Madison Avenues. Instead of flowers, contributions may be made to the Brearley School photography program or to the School Year Abroad.

ARNOW--Joan. Mrs. Arnow was a wonderful friend of our organization and generous supporter of our international programs, whose kindness touched the lives of thousands of less fortunate. She will be sorely missed, but her smile and our close friendship will always be remembered. The Chamah Staff New York, Jerusalem, Moscow

I heard a segment on NPR the other day about the George Gershwin classic ''Summertime,'' in which the cultural reporter Sara Fishko noted that the song has been performed in many different summer settings, from the Carolina coast where Gershwin wrote it in the 1930s, to the Woodstock festival in upstate New York where Janis Joplin screeched it out in 1969. But Ms. Fishko really grabbed my attention when she mentioned the somewhat remarkable fact that the song's melody consists of only six notes. (Bonus: It's written in the key of A minor, which means no sharps or flats.) As a not-so-talented pianist, this was too tempting to pass up. So in the spirit of summertime, I purchased the sheet music from Musicnotes.com and printed it on my laser printer. When downloading the sheet music, I noticed a tag that said, ''iPad compatible.''

LEVINSON--George, 74, of Larchmont, NY died on June 30, 2010 at New York Cornell Weill Hospital after an intense battle with cancer. He was the beloved husband of Pat for 45 years. Loving father of daughter Lisa Levinson and son Bruce Levinson (Elana). Cherished and revered by loving friends and colleagues. Highly respected investment advisor. Services will be held at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue, New York City on Friday, July 2 at 11:30am. Burial following at Cedar Park Cemetery, Paramus, NJ. Contributions in his memory may be made to Camp Oasis at the Crohn's & Colitis Foundation of America.

FREEDMAN--Mira Berman. Founder and President, The Bradford Group. Mira Riva Berman beloved wife of Professor Richard Freedman died on June 29. She along with her mother and sister miraculously escaped the holocaust and reached the United States. Ms. Berman, was a child prodigy violinist who gave up a solo career in order to help her family. She was also a writer, author and marketing expert. She established significant advertising agencies such as Allerton Berman and Dean - known for its outstanding creativity particularly for Jewish (UJA) and Israeli causes (Israel Government Tourist Office). Ms. Berman was founder and President of the Bradford Group, and past Executive Director of the Africa Travel Association. Her career in advertising and public relations was marked by remarkable achievements and awards including Advertising Woman of the Year, The International Film and TV Festival's Television's Gold Medal and Grand Award (/Israel 25)/; Society for Accessible Travel & Hospitality's Founder's Award; International Institute for Peace Through Tourism Lifetime Achievement Award; Tanzania Tourism's Outstanding Leadership Award, the ATA Leadership Award. The funeral will take place at the Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave., Thursday, July 1, at 9:30am.

We offer our sincere condolences to her brother, Steven, and all her family and loved ones. Peter Gelb, General Manager James Levine, Music Director

Wendell Logan, a composer of jazz and concert music who more than two decades ago founded the jazz department at the Oberlin Conservatory of Music, long a bastion of high-level classical training, died on June 15 in Cleveland. He was 69 and lived in Oberlin, Ohio. Professor Logan died after a short illness, Marci Janas, a conservatory spokeswoman, said. At his death he was chairman of the jazz studies department and professor of African-American music at the conservatory, which is part of Oberlin College.

Facing a long trip with a van full of kids? VTech's MobiGo Touch Learning System can provide miles of play. It's the second of three new educational game platforms intended for kids, ages 3 to 8. Unlike its competitors (LeapFrog's Leapster Explorer and Fisher-Price's iXL) MobiGo comes with a slide-open touch screen that reveals a rubbery QWERTY keyboard, which is handy for letter recognition games.

The Talking Business column on Saturday, about the effect of a moratorium on deepwater drilling for oil in the Gulf of Mexico, misstated the record of oil spills in the Outer Continental Shelf. From 1964 to 2009, 532,000 barrels of oil were lost as a result of spills, not 1,800 barrels. (The lower figure refers to oil lost as a result of blowouts from 1971 to 2009, not to the overall amount of oil lost in accidents.) The article also misidentified the court with jurisdiction in appeals from the Federal District Court of Judge Martin L. C. Feldman, who issued a preliminary injunction against the moratorium. It is the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit, not the Ninth Circuit.

An obituary and a headline on Tuesday about the Lithuanian politician Algirdas Brazauskas erroneously attributed a distinction to him. He was the first president of Lithuania after the country broke with the Soviet Union; he was not the ''first Lithuanian president.'' (Lithuania had a number of presidents between the end of World War I, when it declared its independence from Germany, and 1940, when it was occupied by the Soviet Union.)

Wu Guanzhong, whose fusion of Western modernism and traditional Chinese painting made him one of China's most forward-looking and admired artists, died on Friday in Beijing. He was 90. His death was confirmed by Fong Yuk Yan, his longtime dealer in Hong Kong.

An article on Wednesday about the leniency shown to big banks during the bailout of the American International Group misstated the year that the federal government bailed out the automaker Chrysler. It was 2009, not 2008.

An article on Wednesday about Google's decision to stop automatically redirecting Chinese users to its uncensored Hong Kong site referred incorrectly to China's president, Hu Jintao, in some copies. He is Mr. Hu -- not Mr. Jintao.

Rafael Nadal's tough straight sets win over Andy Murray was a testament to Nadal's ability to adapt.. He has worked hard to add to his game, beefing up his serve and forehand to keep Murray on the defensive for most of the match. Under the guidance of his uncle Toni Nadal, Nadal has transformed himself from a player who wears down opponents with his consistency, speed and defense, to a player who excels at striking first and moving forward.

I want to start by getting back to a poster from last week who called me out for saying that Riggins, in all his former football-star glory, had so few opportunities. I thought about this a lot. The poster claimed that if there were a job worth having in Dillon, the boosters would actually give it to Riggins. But of course the point here - and the point of the show in general to a large extent - is that there are so few jobs actually worth having there. (And as far as Riggins's squandering opportunities, it simply would not have felt in keeping with his character if he'd stayed in college. Not everyone is cut out for college and not everyone should be expected to go. Part of what is so painfully evocative about "Friday Night Lights'' is that it gives us a sense of an America where very little is possible without an exit from small-time life or an education.)

The rough draft of the Declaration of Independence, written by Thomas Jefferson with edits in the hands of Benjamin Franklin and John Adams, has long fascinated historians, who have used it to track the evolution of the founders' thinking. Now, relying on new technology, scientists at the Library of Congress have confirmed a longtime suspicion that in one spot where Jefferson wrote the word "citizens," he had originally written "subjects" - as in subjects of the British crown - but rubbed it out before the ink dried.
Misha Erwitt was born on Flag Day. That wouldn't normally be a conversation opener, but Mr. Erwitt, 56, has spent more than 20 years compiling images of the American flag.

A beekeeper should try to replace some of the brood comb every year or so.  The brood comb, where the queen lays eggs, is heavy-duty comb - not the light wax that is found in comb honey or beeswax candles.  This thicker comb serves as the nursery for thousands of new bees, and to keep a hive healthy, it should be replaced on a regular, rotating basis.

The Fourth of July weekend is shaping up to be beautiful in New York City - hot and bright, with low humidity. Part of what makes this holiday so appealing for me is the ritual emptying of the city as New Yorkers with someplace to go, go. Folks, you know I love you. But as Dan Hicks once sang, "How can I miss you when you won't go away?''

A study released this week of the four biggest newspapers in the United States said that in the wake of the Sept. 11, 2001, terrorist attacks, there was "a dramatic shift in coverage away from nearly a century of practice recognizing waterboarding as torture."

With the opening of Bier International, at 2099 Frederick Douglass Boulevard, between 113th and 114th Streets, Harlem gets its first beer garden just in time for the holiday weekend. It was bound to happen. Everyone from suit-and-tie clad bankers to skinny hipsters in plaid have flocked to beer gardens popping up in the city, from the meatpacking district to the Lower East Side. Marcus Samuelsson plans to open Red Rooster near Bier International and Ryan Skeen briefly headed the kitchen at 5 & Diamond just down the street. About half of the 20 international brews on tap at the beer garden will be available this weekend.
From our colleagues at Media Decoder.

Suicide bombers struck Pakistan's most important Sufi shrine on Thursday night, a devastating attack by hard-line militants on the moderate, more flexible blend of Islam that is practiced by most Pakistanis, Sabrina Tavernise and Waqar Gillani reported. The bombers attacked in the city of Lahore just before midnight, the peak worship time for the shrine, known as Data Ganj Baksh. Thousands of people were at the shrine at the time, according to the Pakistani police. At least 42 people were killed and more than 170 injured, officials said. The strike on such a revered place of worship is certain to enrage Pakistanis, who are growing weary of violence that has spiked in the past four years.

It's nice to have a golf bag you can comfortably carry, but if you're playing in a fancy event, you don't want your bag to look cheesy, either. Fortunately, a lot of companies are now making lightweight bags that are smart and stylish, too. Start with the Collegiate by Nike ($150, golfsmith.com), which weighs five pounds and has a full-length apparel pocket as well as mesh pockets for a water bottle and accessories. It's functional and its straps have an air cushioning design that is easy on your shoulders.
Tennis at Wimbeldon is a formal affair: Players have to wear white, afternoon tea is served at three p.m. and cheering is polite enough for the Queen Elizabeth to attend.
A look at the new ballets this season at New York City Ballet.

For the Fourth of July weekend, many Americans want to show their Team America spirit by waving little American flags in the air or sporting a U.S.A. emblazoned T-shirt. Now, proud Americans can take it up a notch. Earloomz, a company that specializes in Bluetooth earpieces, will begin selling a number of newly designed earpieces, including ones with American flags.

Earlier today Apple addressed a problem with its antenna and signal strength display on its new iPhone 4 in an open letter to customers. The problem, known at the "death grip" appears to result in worse reception and dropped calls when the phone is held a certain way when the signal strength is low.
NBC's tape-delaying of Wimbledon semifinals matches remains one of the most perplexing practices in television sports.
The Cadillac division of General Motors is changing creative agencies for the second time in six months.

The financial crisis that began in 2008 underlined a number of weaknesses in investors' portfolios, and one of them was the limitations of private equity investments. Many of the wealthy individual investors in those funds were forced to sell other assets to meet demands for additional capital from private equity firms or had to sell their stakes in the funds at deep discounts to get out early.

For many years, chess players and organizers have puzzled over how to make the game more appealing for television, à la poker. So far, no one seems to have come up with a solution. Now there is a tongue-in-cheek suggestion from Geico, the insurance company.

CHARLESTON, W. Va. - Hundreds of West Virginians and dozens of family members and friends gathered here Friday to pay tribute to Robert C. Byrd, the longest-serving senator in history. President Obama, former President Bill Clinton, Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr., and several of Mr. Byrd's colleagues in Congress spoke of his humble roots, voracious appetite for knowledge, inspiring oratory and fierce devotion to his home state.
Each Thursday, Florence Fabricant gives advice on the fine points of entertaining at home and eating in restaurants. Have a dining dilemma? Ask FloFab.

About 5,300 school buses made by the Blue Bird Corporation are involved in three different recalls. They involve a fire hazard, the possibility that the driver's seat may collapse and the possible loss of steering, according to the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration.

It's only natural for humans to try to sort things -- as in the assignment of Hogwarts students to various houses in the Harry Potter books and films. There have been a lot of attempts to categorize the varied assemblage of people with strongly held positions on the scope of, and threat from, the building human influence on the climate system. Convinced and unconvinced. Deniers. Alarmists. Skeptics. I've found at least one category that I think is justified -- stasists -- so I don't utterly reject such attempts.

MONTREAL - The Montreal International Jazz Festival is enormous, and it grows a little bit every year. The 31st edition, with more than 700 concerts over 12 days, ends on Tuesday with a festival first: a Mardi Gras parade through the city, complete with floats from New Orleans and music by Trombone Shorty and Allen Toussaint.
After meeting LeBron James on Thursday, Knicks Coach Mike D'Antoni expressed confidence that his team had made a good pitch to the star free agent.

Gov. David A. Paterson's proposal to tax soda seems to have fizzled as lawmakers eliminated the controversial measure while cobbling together a state revenue bill. The penny-an-ounce tax on soda and other sweet drinks would have helped shrink New York's ballooning deficit and, its supporters say, cut down on obesity.

They say war isn't real until you're getting shot at or shooting at someone, but the true reality of war doesn't hit until you lose one of your own. This terrible knowledge is shared amongst the comrades, family and friends of some 5,517 Americans who have lost their lives fighting for their country in Iraq and Afghanistan over the past eight years. For the first time since the war began, I now regrettably count myself amongst those who personally know the terrible cost of war. A friend, First Lt. Joe Theinert of Sag Harbor, N.Y., was killed in an ambush in Kandahar Province, Afghanistan, on 4 June.

Following is the third and final set of responses from Kai Wright, the author of "Drifting Toward Love: Black, Brown, Gay and Coming of Age on the Streets of New York" (Beacon Press, January 2008), who is responding to readers' questions about gay youth in New York City, the challenges they face and the future lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender community they are creating.

A coalition of environmental organizations sent President Obama a letter on Friday pleading for him to intervene in the stalled Senate negotiations on climate and energy legislation. The groups, which have been largely supportive of the president's energy policies, expressed concern that time was running out for any action on climate change this year. Only the president's personal and persistent attention can break the stalemate, they say.

Only last week, Carlyle Leslie Owen Dale, a legal permanent resident from Jamaica who had worked in New York for three decades, seemed at risk of dying in an immigration jail in Louisiana while his court appeals against an order of deportation languished.

Michael Steele, chairman of the Republican National Committee, drew fierce criticism on Friday after declaring at a party fund-raiser that the United States was on the wrong side of history with its conflict in Afghanistan, a military fight he called "a war of Obama's choosing."

That Tel Aviv, not a huge city but a high-octane one, has become the new gay mecca of the Mediterranean is something of an open secret, both in the Middle East and increasingly, outside it, too. Unfailingly sunny and tirelessly tolerant, its energy level is at once intense and beguilingly relaxed. In the run-up to Tel Aviv's Gay Pride, which fell on June 11 this year, there were not one but two New York-based gay tours to Israel - Steele Travel's Milk & Honey tour and one promoted by Chelsea's own gay adult-entertainment impresario Michael Lucas, whose nine-day journey covered Israel from top (the Golan Heights) to bottom (Eilat), and, like Steele's, allowed time for a foray into Tel Aviv's full-throttle after-hours gay scene.

JaMarcus Russell trained with Tom Martinez for two months before being selected No. 1 over all in the 2007 draft. Perhaps the pre-eminent quarterback instructor in the nation, Martinez trains a dozen quarterbacks in the league; he has mentored Tom Brady since his teenage years.

As a climate change prevention strategy, carbon capture and storage is nowhere near ready for prime time. On the storage side of the equation, major questions remain on how and where to sequester the billions of tons of gas produced by power plants and industry every year. Another stumbling block, known as the parasitic energy cost, is the amount of energy needed to strip carbon out of power plant emissions. Carbon capture technologies being tested today, like amine scrubbing, exact an energy penalty as high as 30 percent, a vast and perhaps untenable expense to utilities and society.

I had no sooner posted a piece on the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities report about states' dire fiscal future than the Mercatus Center at George Mason University got in touch with its own take. The center is a policy research organization that leans libertarian and conservative (the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities leans liberal), and it has a tough-love argument.
In the Sunday Style Field Notes article "For Sale: One White Dress, Yet to Be Worn," I write about how some brides are putting their wedding dresses up for sale even before they walk down the aisle.

Robert (Surrob) Negron, who photographed the city's street basketball players and created hundreds of collages of public figures he admired, was remembered on Wednesday night at McCall's Bronxwood Funeral Home. Mr. Negron died on June 22, after collapsing during a game of pickup basketball in Manhattan. He was 46.

A former Bloomberg administration official will run a newly formed campaign to defeat state lawmakers who oppose same-sex marriage in New York, in the latest attempt to ratchet up pressure on elected officials to legalize such unions.

The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration has released a projection of where the oil from the gulf spill would be most likely to travel. It says that much of the western coast of Florida has less chance of being oiled than the Florida Keys and the Miami and Fort Lauderdale areas do. But those areas would probably see scattered tar balls if they are oiled -- not a large slick, the agency says.

Even as heat-trapping emissions from industry are declining in much of the developed world, those from transport continue to rise relentlessly. Flying in particular is a growth industry - in terms of both business and emissions.

I've lived twice as long as Mozart, and I look it. Yet it's not unusual these days to be told I can't buy a beer until I show an ID. "Nuts" is the four-letter word I will use to describe this lunacy. Carding someone with white hair and liver spots all over his hands is a waste of everyone's time - mine, those behind me waiting for a beer and the poor counter person following management's orders.

1:16 p.m. | Updated There's still thinking in many quarters that if the United States acts to restrict its emissions of carbon dioxide, the long-lived greenhouse gas at the heart of the climate challenge, the fast-growing developing countries of the world will voluntarily follow. Global data on emissions of carbon dioxide vividly illustrate the wishful nature of such thoughts when considered against powerful underlying trends.

The really bad economic news these days is not from the private sector. Manufacturing companies continue to see higher orders, although the rate of growth has slowed. And today's job report shows that private sector employment is rising, although not as rapidly as earlier in the year.
The unemployment rate fell to 9.5 percent in June, even as the economy shed around 125,000 jobs -- in large part because of the loss of temporary census jobs.
In a major blow to the 2010 Lilith Tour, the female-centric music festival has announced the cancellation of 10 of its planned dates in July and August.

The economy lost 125,000 jobs in June, driven primarily by the elimination of 225,000 temporary Census positions. In just the private sector, payrolls increased by 83,000, a modest gain over employment in May.

Microsoft Word lets you format your text with many choices of fonts and styles, as well as in the form of numbered lists, bullet points, indented text and other conventions of modern word-processing. But when a document becomes too cluttered and unwieldy with a lot of formats, there's a quick and easy way to strip the styles from the text so you can start over. Just select the text and press the Control key and Space bar to convert the selection to plain, unformatted text.

HEIBERG--Rose Christine Graves, 96, Rockville Centre, June 23, 2010. Registered Nurse, School Board, clean air activist, Literacy Volunteers. Christie loved genealogy, outdoors, travel; was curious, resourceful. Mother of Robert, Karen Chrisman, Margaret Kollitides, Nancy; seven grandchildren; predeceased by her husband Robert M., and son Donald.

ARNOW--Joan. Yeshiva University, Albert Einstein College of Medicine, and Benjamin N. Cardozo School of Law mourn the loss of Joan Arnow, a caring and generous philanthropist. We thank Joan, her husband, Robert, and her brother and sister-in-law, Alan and Elaine Weiler, for their leadership and philanthropic partnership with Yeshiva University, Einstein, and Cardozo; their perpetuation of shared values that strengthen the Jewish community and society at large. Joan's father, the late revered Jack D. Weiler, played a historic role in the founding of Einstein and its Jack D. Weiler Hospital, and was a Benefactor of Einstein and of Yeshiva University. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Robert, Alan and Elaine, Joan's children and grandchildren, and the entire family. Joan, who was beloved by all who knew her, will be sorely missed. Yeshiva University Richard M. Joel, President Albert Einstein College of Medicine Ruth L. Gottesman, Chairperson, Board of Overseers Benjamin N. Cardozo School of Law Leslie Payson, Chair, Board of Overseers

Our heartfelt condolences go out to the entire Arnow and Weiler families. Lawrence B. Benenson Bill Benenson Fred Benenson Richard Kessler James Stifel Lloyd Stabiner

GOODMAN--Robert A.,on July 1, 2010. Founder of Robert A. Goodman & Co., LLP. Beloved husband of the late Lois. Devoted father of Beth and Debra. Cherished grandfather of Lamby. Services Friday, 12:45pm at "The Riverside" 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. In lieu in flowers, donations may be made to Hospice and Palliative Care of Westchester, 311 North St., Suite 204, White Plains, NY 10605.

SWETT--Rachel Barrett, 21, of Manhattan. Died June 22 in Christchurch, New Zealand following a skiing accident on June 17. She is survived by her brothers, Nicholas and William; her parents, Benjamin and Katherine; her grandparents, Steven and Shiela Swett and Mary Ellin Barrett; six cousins; and ten aunts and uncles. A junior at Columbia College majoring in psychology, Rachel had been studying at Canterbury College in Christchurch during a semester abroad. An avid photographer and traveler, Rachel had spent her junior year in High School in Rennes, France, as part of the School Year Abroad Program and had also studied in Paris this past fall at Columbia College's Reid Hall. From kindergarten through 12th grade she attended the Brearley School in Manhattan, where she was known for her love of photography and writing and her spirited point of view towards Physical Education. Rachel loved children and had planned to focus on child psychology at Columbia. Loyal, passionate and loving, with a great sense of humor, Rachel made many friends of all ages who will miss her greatly. A funeral service will take place at the Church of the Heavenly Rest, 5th Avenue at 90th Street, at 11am on Saturday, July 3. A reception will follow at the House of the Redeemer, 7 East 95th Street, between 5th and Madison Avenues. Instead of flowers, contributions may be made to the Brearley School photography program or to the School Year Abroad.

Here it is July 1, the beginning of a new month. Will it be a hot one? Probably, predicts Stephen Fybish, who tracks weather statistics from his apartment on the Upper West Side. He says that a wet March tends to be followed by ''unusual heat sometime between June and September.'' Seven of the 15 warmest Julys on record in New York followed the wettest Marches - and 2 of the 4 warmest Junes and 2 of the 4 warmest Augusts.

SWETT--Rachel Barrett. The staff of R & H / Imagem and the Irving Berlin Music Company mourns the passing of Rachel Swett. We send condolences to her brothers, Nicholas and William, her parents, Benjamin and Katherine, and her family, including our dear friend, her maternal grandmother, Mary Ellin Barrett.

WASHINGTON -- There is only one question left in the debate over the Supreme Court nomination of Elena Kagan: How many Republican votes will she get? Or, more precisely, will as many Republicans vote for Ms. Kagan as the nine who backed Justice Sonia Sotomayor? As her confirmation hearings concluded Thursday with testimony from outside witnesses, Ms. Kagan, the solicitor general and former dean of the Harvard Law School, seemed a shoo-in. The Senate is overwhelmingly Democratic, and even Ms. Kagan's toughest Republican critics were charmed.

LANDER--Dorothy (Schulein), born October 8, 1921 in New York City, died June 16, 2010 of a stroke. Daughter of Solomon and Edna (Rosenshine) Schulein, wife (50+ years) of (late) Hon. Benjamin Lander, Dorothy graduated from Ethical Culture and Duke University. Since 1968, she taught English to immigrants via English In Action. She attended Art Students League of New York and volunteered or contributed to many educational, environmental, artistic, social, and spiritual organizations. Loved by family and friends, she was an independent, intelligent, intuitive, empathic and vital woman, active until passing. An avid swimmer, she enjoyed theater, opera, concerts, museums, and poetry. She is survived by sister Joan Schulein Lipkin, Nancy (Robert) Schulein, 13 nieces and nephews, Kern family, and many friends. A gathering will be held July 11. Contributions in her name to The English-Speaking Union of the U.S. For more info, 212-818-1200 or EIA@ESUUS.Org.

COHEN--Elias A. Although 58 years have passed since our beloved founder, Elias A. Cohen, passed away on July 2, 1952, he is still remembered with love and reverence by the thousands of deserving boys and girls who were privileged to come to his Tranquillity Farm and Camp for a few fun filled weeks each summer since July 1, 1919. In the spirit of Noblesse Oblige his devoted family, his many loyal friends and a grateful Alumni are all helping to perpetuate his Tranquillity Camp as a living monument to this great American humanitarian. We are proud to announce that Tranquillity is now celebrating its 92nd year. Tranquillity Camp, Inc. Earlton, NY Richard Lawrence, President COHEN--Elias A. Ever present in our thoughts, we lovingly recall our E. A. Cohen who left us 58 years ago on July 2, 1952. The Cohen Family The Elias A. Cohen Foundation

Because of an editing error, a picture caption on Thursday with an article about the uncertain futures faced by the top American civilian officials in Afghanistan in the aftermath of the American military command shakeup referred incorrectly to the location where one of them, Richard C. Holbrooke, the Obama administration's special representative to the region, was shown walking with Maj. Gen. Richard P. Mills, a Marine commander. It was in Marja, about 380 miles southwest of Kabul -- not ''near Kabul.''

KROTINGER--Esther Joy. June 19, 2010. Age 88. Beloved sister of the late Ruth K. Silverman of New York, NY and Nathan J. Krotinger of La Mirada, CA. Dear aunt of Ellen Jane Silverman of New York City, Eve Krotinger of Sacramento, CA and Michelle Krotinger of Los Angeles, CA. Memorial service held at Shomri-Hadas, Borough Park, Brooklyn and burial service at Beth David, Elmont, NY. A graduate of Hunter College, Esther Joy worked in accounting for Chock Full O' Nuts and Butterick Marketing Fashion Co. An arts and theater patron, she was also actively involved with the Women's City Club of New York, Central Park Conservancy, New York City Department of Parks & Recreation and New York Public Library. Esther Joy was an extremely loyal and generous person. She will be greatly missed by all who knew her.

ARNOW--Joan. The Board and staff of New York Public Radio mourn the passing of Joan Arnow, wife of Robert and sister to our esteemed Board member Alan Weiler. Joan epitomized this city in her curiosity, interests, generosity and responsiveness to friends and strangers alike. Her philanthropy improved WNYC and WQXR, and we strive to uphold her ideals in our daily work. We mourn with the entire Weiler-Arnow family. Laura Walker, President and CEO Herb Scannell, Chairman, Board of Trustees

ROBINSON--Herb. The Board of Directors of the City College Fund mourns the passing of its esteemed Chairman, and dear friend. Herb has been a sturdy son and a generous supporter of CCNY since his graduation in 1937. He will be sorely missed.

STECKEL--Henry, 87, died peacefully on June 30, 2010. Beloved husband of Hilda, father of Lena (Matt), Andy (Liz) and Dan (Amy), and grandfather of Alice, Jophie, Zoe, Abby, Nate, Sophie and Ava. He was generous, resourceful, compassionate and loving, and we will miss him greatly. In lieu of flowers, we encourage donations to the Leukemia and Lymphoma Society.

Arizona Diamondbacks Manager A.J. Hinch did something odd after his pitcher Edwin Jacksonthrew a no-hitter last Friday: He defended his decision not to pull Jackson from the game. When a starter has not allowed any hits, a manager ought to feel comfortable leaving him in the game. But the recent trend of limiting pitch counts to preserve arms makes Jackson's 149-pitch performance stand out. For example, the Nationals' emerging phenom, Stephen Strasburg, was pulled from a potential no-hit bid in the minors this year. It wasn't that long ago when the complete game, no matter how many pitches it took, was the mark of a good outing.

A music column on Wednesday about Miley Cyrus, the pop singer and star of the ''Hannah Montana'' series on the Disney Channel, misstated the timing of the end of the series. The fourth and final season is scheduled to start this month and end in the spring; it does not end this summer.

ROSENBLUTH--Claire, June 30 at age 93. Beloved widow of the late J. Wm. ("Bill"), "Clairesie," "Grammy," and "GG" loved and was beloved by all, but especially by her children, Susan (Spencer) Sherman and Lawrence (Laurel) Rosenbluth, her grandchildren, Sabrina (Rob); Gregory (Cindy); Cristine (Kelly); and Meredith (Stewart), and her eight great-grandchildren, Elizabeth; Katie; Hailey; Caroline; Charlotte; Emily; Clay; and Owen. We and all who knew her will miss her and forever remember her devotion, love, smile, generosity of spirit, elegance, grace and indescribable courage. Services were private.

Hurricane Alex, was downgraded Thursday morning to a tropical storm, but it continued to halt progress on containment work in the Gulf of Mexico and threatened to disperse oil farther into the marshes along the Mississippi Delta. Although Mexico and southern Texas bore the full brunt of the storm, 10-foot waves rose at the site of the spill hundreds of miles to the east and winds blew at about 29 miles an hour, idling the vessels used for skimming and ferrying supplies back and forth.

Steven C. Krane, who was the youngest president of the New York State Bar Association and an expert on legal ethics, died on Tuesday in Manhattan. He was 53 and had homes in Manhattan and Pound Ridge, N.Y. The cause was a heart attack, said David A. Lewis, a lawyer at the firm Proskauer Rose, where Mr. Krane was a partner and general counsel.

A picture caption on Wednesday with an article about the Supreme Court confirmation hearing for Elena Kagan referred incorrectly to several people shown listening to the proceedings. Most of them were her family members; they were not all former students.

An article on June 25 about progress in speech recognition technology misidentified the company that used the technology to identify increased use of the phrase ''cash for clunkers.'' The company was a customer of Verint, which supplies speech analysis software to call centers; it was not Aetna Insurance. (Verint would not identify the customer.)

KACHLINE--Clifford S.,88, retired Historian of the National Baseball Hall of Fame and Museum in Cooperstown, NY, died Monday, June 28. He previously held positions as the Public Relations Director for the North American Soccer League and Associate Editor of The Sporting News. He was a founding member of the (SABR) Society of American Baseball Research and served as the organization's first full-time Executive Director. He was a lifetime member of the Baseball Writers Association of America (BBWAA) and a Past President of the St. Louis Chapter. He was active in Rotary and was recognized as a Paul Harris Fellow. Donor-directed, tax deductible memorials may be made to the Cooperstown Rotary Foundation Inc., PO Box 993, Cooperstown, NY 13326 or to a charity of your choice in Clifford's name.

WESTIN--Florence Isles. The Kaplan family mourns the loss of its friend and longtime colleague Florence Isles Westin. For more than 50 years Florence was the design inspiration for Joseph A. Kaplan & Sons, manufacturers of JAKSON shower curtains. She was a brilliant designer and a good friend. The Kaplans send their deepest condolences to her entire family. The Kaplan Family

CONRAD--Esther F. (Nollman), died Friday, May 14 in Ann Arbor MI. Married for 60 years to Bob Conrad ( August 14, 1919 - February 18, 2010). Esther was a beloved wife, mother, sister, aunt, and friend. She is survived by her son Fred and daughter-in-law Elizabeth Brooks (of Ann Arbor) and son Dan and daughter-in-law Sarah Wilcox (of San Francisco), grandchildren Allison and Jeffrey of Ann Arbor, and Paul and Ted of San Francisco. She is also survived by her sister-in-law, Mildred Nollman of Foxborough MA, eight nieces and nephews, and their families. Esther Nollman was born in Boston MA June 2, 1921. She was predeceased by her two older brothers Bernard and Harris, and sister-in-law Ruth. She was known throughout her life as "Red" because of her beautiful red hair. Esther graduated from Boston Latin School, and earned a bachelor's degree from Boston Teachers' College and certificate in retail from Simmons College in Boston. She began her professional life as a buyer for the Boston-based department store Filene's. She married Robert Conrad in 1950, and moved to New York City. Esther began a second career as a teacher of young children in the late 1950s, teaching for approximately 20 years at Downtown Community School and the Corlears School. For the next 15 years, she taught learning disabled adults at the Para-Educator Center at New York University where she derived great satisfaction from helping her students learn to live independently. She was much loved by her students and colleagues in both parts of her career. Esther loved music, theater, and travel, and the Boston Red Sox. She was devoted to her husband, her two sons, and their families. She will be remembered for her warm and lively dinner parties and especially the much-anticipated Thanksgiving dinners she and Bob hosted. She will also be remembered for her kindness. A long illness claimed Esther shortly after the death of Bob; she truly will be missed by everyone who knew her. Memorial contributions in Esther Conrad's name may be made to the Boston Symphony Orchestra's Youth and Education Fund, c/o Sabrina Karpe, Friends of the BSO, 301 Massachusetts Ave., Boston MA 02115.

An article on Thursday about a House committee's vote to lift a ban on United States citizens' traveling to Cuba referred imprecisely to action that President Obama took in 2009 on travel restrictions. While Mr. Obama indeed allowed Cuban-Americans with family members in Cuba to travel to the country, he did so by lifting all restrictions on travel -- not by opening up travel for the first time. (Cuban-Americans were already allowed to make limited visits.)

Up a candlelight-flickered staircase, through a darkroom cobwebbed with clotheslines bearing ruby-lit pictures, past a writer's desk strewn with photographic proofs, guests at a film screening in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, stepped into the past on Wednesday night: a Swinging '60s photo studio where a Britpop band rocked out while a gaggle of actors with Twiggyesque doe eyes struck poses in the center of the room, vying for their moment in front of a photographer's lens. It was the New York opening of Future Cinema, an English company that screens films, and it was held at at the Shangri-La Studio on Sutton Street. The film was ''Blow-Up,'' the 1966 film by Michelangelo Antonioni, set in London and starring an Austin Powers prototype - an ennui-ridden fashion photographer named Thomas (David Hemmings).

ARNOW--Joan. Yeshiva University, Albert Einstein College of Medicine, and Benjamin N. Cardozo School of Law mourn the loss of Joan Arnow, a caring and generous philanthropist. We thank Joan, her husband, Robert, and her brother and sister-in-law, Alan and Elaine Weiler, for their leadership and philanthropic partnership with Yeshiva University, Einstein, and Cardozo; their perpetuation of shared values that strengthen the Jewish community and society at large. Joan's father, the late revered Jack D. Weiler, played a historic role in the founding of Einstein and its Jack D. Weiler Hospital, and was a Benefactor of Einstein and of Yeshiva University. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Robert, Alan and Elaine, Joan's children and grandchildren, and the entire family. Joan, who was beloved by all who knew her, will be sorely missed. Yeshiva University Richard M. Joel, President Albert Einstein College of Medicine Ruth L. Gottesman, Chairperson, Board of Overseers Benjamin N. Cardozo School of Law Leslie Payson, Chair, Board of Overseers

This week brings questions about an après-rock meal, dining with children and adventurous eating. Send your food queries to dinejournal@nytimes.com. Q. I usually like to see my rock concerts downtown, or in gentrified Brooklyn. I know the dining options in these neighborhoods well. But every so often, a band like the Pixies or the Smiths will show up at the Hammerstein Ballroom, and a dinner nearby will be in order. My Sunday column is from Gaza, where I argue that Israel should not just ease the trade restrictions but lift them. The problem with closing off Gaza, quite aside from the injustice of collective punishment, is that it tends to foster just the extremism that most threatens Israel and the entire Middle East. The constituencies for moderation and peace -- civil society and the business sector -- have been nearly destroyed and silenced, while Hamas appears to have been strengthened.

Some twirled and two-stepped with finesse, others bumbled across the dance floor like awkward teenagers at a high school formal. Still others spun with seeming aplomb - right before thwacking into a fellow dancer. Thursday was the third evening of the annual Midsummer Night Swing festival, which includes 15 nights of dancing to live music outdoors in Damrosch Park, in the southwest corner of Lincoln Center's grounds. Around 6:30 p.m., about 50 stood - in pairs or alone - before a stage overhung by an alabaster bandshell. Two dance instructors expounded on the basics of the Texas two-step, the countrified dance genre that was the night's feature.

10 P.M. (Cinemax) TAKING WOODSTOCK (2009) The setting is what was officially known as the Woodstock Music & Art Fair in August 1969. But most of the concert takes place out of sight of the camera in this film from Ang Lee, which focuses instead on the transformative effects of that landmark event on an assortment of people. In the forefront is Elliot Tiber (Demetri Martin, above), an interior decorator living in Greenwich Village, on whose memoir the film is based. Elliot returns to the Catskills to help his parents (Henry Goodman and Imelda Staunton), Jews who immigrated from Russia, keep their failing motel afloat. He also paves the way for Max Yasgur (Eugene Levy), the owner of the dairy farm where the festival was held, and Michael Lang (Jonathan Groff), its primary creator, to strike a deal. Writing in The New York Times, Stephen Holden said: ''For all its sincerity, 'Taking Woodstock' lacks the passion of Mr. Lee's finest films, 'Brokeback Mountain,' 'Lust, Caution,' 'Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon' and 'The Ice Storm.' I would add, however, that given a subject that has become synonymous with overblown mythmaking, its modesty becomes it.'' 10:30 A.M. (13) RELIGION & ETHICS NEWSWEEKLY Fred de Sam Lazaro interviews Desmond Tutu, the Nobel Peace Prize winner and retired Anglican archbishop, about South Africa since the end of apartheid.

Only last week, Carlyle Leslie Owen Dale, a legal permanent resident from Jamaica who had worked in New York for three decades, seemed at risk of dying in an immigration jail in Louisiana while his court appeals against an order of deportation languished. But on Friday, for the first time in five years, Mr. Dale, 61, woke up listening for the voices of his grandchildren instead of to orders shouted inside the federal detention center.

Blockbuster, the money-losing movie-rental chain, said bondholders agreed to let the company defer a $42.4 million payment on its 11.75 percent notes until Aug. 13 as the company considers options for recapitalization. The company, which has lost more than $1 billion in the last three years amid store closings and declining sales, said holders of about 70 percent of the $675 million in senior secured notes agreed to the forbearance. Blockbuster is working with creditors on a possible recapitalization as its business loses ground to competition. Blockbuster has about $900 million in long-term debt, including the 11.75 percent notes due in 2014. Trading in Blockbuster shares was halted Friday, and the company said it would be delisted from the New York Stock Exchange.

Schedule information on Friday with an art review of ''Contemporary Art From the Collection,'' at the Museum of Modern Art, misstated the closing date. It is Sept. 12, 2011 -- not Sept. 12 this year. The review referred incorrectly to the performance piece by Alison Knowles called ''The Identical Lunch'' that will be part of the exhibition. When it begins in January it will be during the run of the show, not after the exhibition has closed. In the piece, which will run twice a week from Jan. 13 to Feb. 4, Ms. Knowles will serve the same meal to one table of eight visitors to the second-floor cafe who have registered in advance. She will not be serving it to all visitors to the cafe.

Earlier this year, we started a recurring feature here at Bucks where we highlight others online who present novel cost-saving strategies we wish we had thought of. In our first installment, we detailed a creative tip for keeping thieves from trying to steal your important possessions. In this second installment, here are some tips we've found online for turning your possessions into cash and for saving on your commute that go beyond craigslist and public transportation. How to trade in your old iPod (or other gadget): In a recent WalletPop post, ''Trade in that old iPod for a new one, or a little cash,'' Julia Scott details how she used Target's NextWorth-powered electronic device trade-in program site to find out that her old iPod was worth $23, and she points readers to other sites for trading in old gadgets, including BuyMyTronics.com and TuneCycle (Apple's in-store trade-in program didn't offer her anything for her old device, but she said it does offer discounts on new devices if you trade in your old device at a store). Though my old iPod is just sitting somewhere in my house because it no longer works, I wish I had thought of this trick.

Elena Kagan's confirmation hearings this week were the first of the Tea Party era. When Republicans pressed Ms. Kagan on the Constitution's commerce clause and whether she was a legal progressive, they were speaking not just about academic abstractions, but about the very ideas that animate the rebellious, conservative movement. The Tea Party is often called ''loosely organized,'' but the unifying philosophy for groups across the country is a belief that the nation can solve its problems -- primarily its economic problems, which is what its supporters care most about -- if lawmakers stick to a strict interpretation of the Constitution.
