COXE--Susie S.,82, of East Hampton, NY, formerly of Hobe Sound, FL, died quietly at home Thursday, July 1, of Progressive Supranuclear Palsey (PSP), a rare neurological condition. Born December 8, 1927 in New York City to Emma Pattison and James Bond Skidmore, Susie Coxe was an avid competitor in golf, tennis, bridge, and paddle tennis. She won the National Paddle Tennis Mixed Doubles Championship in 1970 as well as a host of other golf and tennis tournaments throughout her life. She was the loving wife of the late Eckley B. ("Buzz") Coxe IV, mother of two children, David Taylor Harris Jr. and Catherine Harris Shraga, and sister of Patricia S. Kyle. A graduate of the Westover School and Vassar College, she was a long-time member of Maidstone Club in East Hampton, the Jupiter Island Club in Hobe Sound, and The Colony Club in New York, NY. She also belonged to the Field Club and The Round Hill Club in Greenwich, CT, where she lived with her first husband, David T. Harris from 1950 to 1972 and volunteered at the Greenwich Hospital for many years as well as serving as president of Hortulus, a local garden club. She served as a volunteer in New York City in the 1970s at Memorial Sloan Kettering and as a docent at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. She is survived by her children, her sister, two grandchildren, Taylor Harris of Minneapolis, MN and Patricia Harris of Atlanta, GA, and three stepchildren: Alexander B. Coxe, of Chicago, Ill.; Sandra Coxe Ankarcrona of London, England, and Audrey Coxe Cadwallader of Darien CT. The funeral service will be held at St. Luke's Church in East Hampton, NY on Friday, July 9 at 4pm with a reception to follow. A memorial service in Hobe Sound, FL will be held later in the year. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to The Eloise H. Troxel PSP Brain Bank, c/o Mayo Clinic Jacksonville, 4500 San Pablo Road, Jacksonville, FL 32224; Memorial Sloane Kettering Cancer Center, PO Box 27106, New York, NY 10087; or to the Jupiter Island Medical Clinic, 100 Estrada Square, Hobe Sound, FL 33455.

There's nothing worse than showing up on time for a doctor's appointment and then having to wait because the physician is running late. Because insurers tend to pay a certain amount for each patient doctors see and each procedure they perform rather than for the time spent with a patient, doctors have an incentive to see as many patients as they can and often double-book patients for 10-to-15-minute appointment time slots.

POSTERIOR A pitcher's gluteus maximus is the biggest muscle in his body, said Jeff Cooper, a former head athletic trainer for the Philadelphia Phillies. Strasburg twists the muscle upward during the leg kick, allowing it to load tremendous energy. Unwinding it, along with the untwisting of the pitcher's trunk, brings the shoulder forward and the arm soon thereafter, like a whip. ''Strasburg keeps his hips from rotating until the very last moment, which is a big key for that high ball velocity,'' said David Stodden, an associate professor at Texas Tech University's department of health, exercise and sport sciences. ''It's very good forward momentum.''

MEYERS--Hyman, 98, of Palm Beach Gardens, FL, formerly of Richmond, VA, died on July 2, following complications after surgery. He was the former chairman and CEO of Heilig-Meyers, a national home furnishings chain. He was predeceased by his wife Florence and his brother Sidney. He is survived by a sister, Amy, two sons, Stanley (Janet S.) and Donald (Prema), of Richmond, and one daughter, Janet Meyers (Mark Pollak), of Bethesda, MD, and five grandchildren. Funeral services will be held Monday, July 5, in Richmond.

"A wild patience has taken me this far," is a line from the great American poet Adrienne Rich, and it perfectly describes how Rafael Nadal plays tennis. Watching his straight set win over Tomas Berdych, I was struck by how Nadal plays with unbridled energy and passion, but he's also calm and contained mentally. In his match with Murray in the semifinals, and again on Sunday against Berdych, there was a sense of inevitability to each match. The scores of each set were close, but you just knew that Rafa wouldn't get broken, and that at some point Murray and Berdych would blink.

When I was 17 years old, I had the honor of being the youngest person in the history of New York Hospital to undergo surgery for a herniated disc. This was at a time in which operations like this kept people in the hospital for over a week. The day after my surgery, I awoke to find a friend of mine sitting in a chair across from my bed. I don't remember much about his visit. I am sure I was too sedated to say much. But I will not forget that he visited me on that day, and sat there for I know not how long, while my humanity was in the care of a morphine drip.

OWEN--Jane Blaffer 1915 - 2010. Jane Blaffer Owen CBE, of Houston, was the daughter of Robert Lee Blaffer and Sarah Campbell Blaffer and wife of Kenneth Dale Owen, a descendant of Robert Owen. Her father helped start Exxon and on her mother's side, the former Texaco. She was the proud mother of three daughters; Jane Dale Owen, Caroline Campbell Owen Coleman and Anne Dale Owen-Pontez. She attended the very first Kinkaid School. She graduated from the Ethel Walker School in Connecticut. She studied at Bryn Mawr, The Washington School of Diplomacy and The Union Theological Seminary in New York, and later, studied under the late Theologian Paul Tillich. She once commented, "To whom much is given, much is expected," "People don't understand generosity...to give is to receive." Armed with her gifts, extraordinary intelligence, grace, charm and her own innate sense of style, she began her quest. This free spirit with an untethered generosity turned her sights on New Harmony, IN. She married Kenneth Owen in 1941 and he introduced her for the first time to his New Harmony birth place, a faded town on the Wabash that once held the dreams of generations past. It was founded as a utopian society in the hopes of creating "a community of equality." New Harmony became her pallet and unfettered she set about to preserve its history, restore its homes and bring some of the greatest minds and artists to its door. With renewed dreams, she had hopes for a better world for all humanity. Of course she did it with a dash of her own verve. With passion for people from all walks of life; she provided an atmosphere of vitality and acceptance. With her charm, vision, and insatiable drive she tried to create a more interdependent world. It began in 1958, when she started the R.L. Blaffer Foundation to preserve and promote the historical and educational attributes of New Harmony. She commissioned Philip Johnson to build The Roofless Church where one could see the sky and embrace people of all faiths while aspiring towards a more united and peaceful world. Jacques Lipchitz fashioned the bronze Madonna and Child at its center. She created a park for Theologian Paul Tillich in a wooded glade to cherish his desire that his ashes be scattered in New Harmony. She convinced The Eli Lilly Foundation to build an athenaeum as a visitor center in New Harmony. Richard Meyer was her choice. Steven de Staebler was prodded to produce three granite pieces to set in the wheat fields, "The Pieta, Angel Gabriel and The Vision on St. Benedict." She encouraged Jeff Sparks from Indianapolis to start the Heartland Film Festival in Indianapolis, Kent Schuette, Purdue architectural school, to replicate the ancient labyrinth from the Chartres Cathedral. Frances Lepaux, Cannon of the Cathedral of Chartres dedicated Labyrinth for meditation, and prayer. Imminent British sculptor Simon Verity created the Fountain of Orpheus placed at its apex. She was awarded the prestigious Louise DuPont Crown Shield Award, The National Preservation's highest accolade and honored by The National Trust for Historic Preservation. She received The Sachem Award from Indiana Governor Mitch Daniels to recognize a lifetime of excellence and virtue she shared this inaugural award with college coaching legend John Wooden and Rev. Theodore Hesburgh CSC, President Emeritus of the University of Norte Dame. With all her acclaim she lived a modest simple life; she was often seen in her hat and golf cart chauffeuring visitors and guests around New Harmony. In Houston she was a major supporter of Blaffer Gallery and University of Houston's G. Hines College of Architecture. She was honored for her lifetime support of the arts and architecture. She and Dean Joe Mashurn, collaborated with Ben Nicholson, CAI, and a class of University of Houston architecture students to build Frederick Kiesler's lifelong wish to realize "The Grotto for Meditation," now standing at the University of Houston. She founded the English Speaking Union, she was the first president of the Allied Arts Council, a founder of the International Seaman's Center of Houston, Trustee of C.G. Jung Educational Center, Sustaining Trustee of the Univeristy of Houston Moores School of Music. Served on the board of The Houston Symphony and The Contemporary Arts Association. She holds Honorary Doctorates of Arts and Humanities from USI, Kenyon College, Ball State University, Butler Theological Seminary and Purdue University Doctor of Letters. She was one of two persons in Texas to have received Commander of The British Empire, bestowed by her majesty, Queen Elizabeth II. It was befitting that Jane Owen's heart should stop on the longest and brightest day of the year at her home in Houston surrounded by family. She will be greatly missed by her family and many, many friends. No one will forget her joy of life, boundless energy and her positive attitude that gave us such hope and a belief that all things are possible and that miracles can happen. Jane is survived by her sister, Joyce von Bothmer of New York; daughters: Jane D. Owen of Palm Beach, Anne D. Owen-Pontez of Houston and husband Hal Pontez; devoted grandchildren: Erik O. Arneberg, Ingrid A. Grados, James O. Coleman and Abigail Owen-Pontez; and Great-Grandchildren: Sarah Grados and Jane Owen-Coleman. The memorial service is to be conducted at half-past ten o'clock in the morning on Saturday, the 10th of July, at St. Martin's Episcopal Church, 717 Sage Road in Houston, where the Rev. Dr. Russell J. Levenson, Jr., Rector, and the Very Rev. J. Pittman McGehee, former Dean of Christ Church Cathedral, are to officiate. In lieu of customary remembrances, charitable donations may be directed to: Dr. W.K. Alfred Yung, M.D. Anderson Cancer Center, P.O. Box 4486, Houston, TX 77210-4486; St. Martin's Episcopal Church, 717 Sage, Houston, TX 77056; R. L. Blaffer Foundation, P.O. Box 514, New Harmony, IN 47631. Services in Houston are with Geo. H. Lewis & Sons The Funeral Directors Since 1936, 713.789.3005.

Rankings reflect sales, for the week ended Saturday, June 19th 2010, at many thousands of venues where a wide range of general interest books are sold nationwide. Bunker Hill Monument |Championing an Unsung Hero BOSTON -- Richard Tourangeau, a veteran ranger at the Bunker Hill Monument, dutifully answers a daily torrent of questions about the famous battle that unfolded there. But he would much rather talk about Sarah Josepha Hale.

THE NEWSElena Kagan, the solicitor general and President Obama's nominee to replace the retired Justice John Paul Stevens on the Supreme Court, vowed that her approach to judging would be ''a modest one,'' ''properly deferential'' to Congress and the president. BEHIND THE NEWS On the first day of her confirmation hearings before the Senate Judiciary Committee, Ms. Kagan offered cautious and measured opening remarks, pledging ''even-handedness and impartiality.'' Her use of ''modest'' echoed a promise of ''judicial modesty'' made by Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. during his confirmation in 2005.

A report last Sunday about the marriage of Perivush Shahzad and Sameer Ansari described incorrectly Shaadi.com, the Web site through which the couple met. It is a dating site for South Asian couples, not only for Muslims.

Ahuriri's transition from seedy port to charming suburb has been decidedly slow. For decades the small seaside neighborhood on the northwest coast of Napier, New Zealand, was dominated by its wharf, cavernous warehouses left empty as the wool industry declined, and rough-and-tumble pubs frequented by local dock workers. But in 2000, with the demolition of a vacant building and the construction of an apartment block, the area started to turn. A row of those wool warehouses on the quay was converted into bars and restaurants that these days heave with 20- and 30-something revelers on warm nights. KIRSTEN MATTHEW

Blame Miuccia for bringing back lip gloss. The tangerine sheen Pat McGrath painted on models for Prada's spring runway show made its way into ads for the brand and even onto mannequins in its store windows. Luckily, beauty companies are offering a slew of pigmented yet high-shine shades that flatter us regular folk. Here are some of the best popsicle-colored shades for summer. 1. Estee Lauder just released ''Pure Color Gloss'' by Tom Pecheux -- six limited-edition, nonsticky shades that range from nude to purple. The latter, ''Plum Desire,'' has the most shine and pigment and the least sparkle. It's $20 at esteelauder.com.

YOORS--Annabert, age 83, of New York died peacefully on June 27, 2010. Annabert was born in The Hague, Holland, in 1926 where she lived until the end of the Second World War. She immigrated to New York City in 1951. She was an active human being, collaborating with her husband, artist Jan Yoors, in the creation of his monumental tapestries. Annabert is survived by her daughter, Lyuba Yoors and her children, Joshua, Peter, Sarah and Hannah; By her son Vanya Yoors, his wife Christi- na and their children, Jonathan, Anna, Jennie and Matthew; By her lifelong friend Marianne Yoors and her son Kore Yoors. A service will be held at the graveside at the Green River Cemetary in East Hampton on Wednesday June 30.

A brief report in the Inside the List column on June 20 about the Apple App Store's offering of ''Ulysses Seen,'' a graphic-novel version of James Joyce's ''Ulysses,'' included an outdated account of Apple's handling of its illustrations. While the company initially rejected some images from the book because they contained nudity, it reversed this decision after the Book Review had gone to press.

GREENE--Ruth, of Goshen, NY, died on June 30, 2010. At the age of 95. Beloved wife of the late Wallace B. Greene, Loving mother of Stephen A. Greene and his wife Marilyn, Cherished Grandmother of Lisa (and Eric) Mirsky and Jennifer (and Robert) Susser, doting Great-Grandmother of Jack and Michael Mirsky and Ben and Charlie Susser. A graduate of New York university School of Business, Ruth opened and operated maternity shops in the Hudson Valley. A prodigious Sportswoman, Ruth was an avid Golfer, Tennis player and fisherman, frequently taking the family fishing on the St. Lawrence River in the Thousand Islands. Ruth had a great sense of humor and lived life to fullest, enjoying concerts at Carnegie Hall and operas at the Metropolitan Opera House. She radiated enthusiasm for everything she tackled, which was contagious to all who knew her. She will be greatly missed by her family and all her friends whose lives she touched. A Memorial Service will be held at a later date. Please call "Bernheim-Apter-Kreitzman" 1-800-938-6372 for addition information. Donations may be made to "EIES of New Jersey" (eiesnj@aol.com)

AS a cinema enthusiast who grew up enamored of directors from Nicholas Roeg to George Lucas, Christopher Nolan said, ''I'm mindful of the great filmmakers I carry with me.'' That mélange of influences manifests itself in many ways in ''Inception.'' But as with any dream, who's to say exactly where it came from? ''Who knows?'' Mr. Nolan said. ''These things aren't always conscious. Sometimes these things are suggested to you, and afterwards you go: 'Oh, yeah. Maybe he's got a point.' I try not to be conscious in my influences. I try and just do what feels right.'' Here, at least, are a few of the filmmakers he knowingly drew upon for ''Inception.'' DAVE ITZKOFF Stanley Kubrick The influence of the director of ''2001: A Space Odyssey,'' above with Keir Dullea, is readily apparent in a ''dream-gravity'' sequence during ''Inception'' that tracks Joseph Gordon-Levitt through an environment of rotating rooms followed by a period of total weightlessness. ''Kubrick to me always had a wonderful sense of calm and specificity in everything he did,'' Mr. Nolan said. ''Every detail had a specific meaning and purpose. That's something I always try to aim for in my filmmaking. It's not a specific thing. It's an approach of saying: 'Why is this thing here? What are we doing with this detail, this element?''' Ridley Scott Mr. Nolan spoke admiringly of Mr. Scott's science-fiction thriller ''Alien,'' which he said is most memorable not for its chestbursting shock scenes but for ''the naturalism of it that was shocking at the time.'' He added: ''It's like Ken Loach in outer space. Hand-held camera, overlapping dialogue, bickering and incredibly naturalistic performances. That's the bit that everybody forgets.'' Also, he said, ''you couldn't really aim higher than his work in 'Blade Runner,'''-- above, with Harrison Ford -- ''in terms of putting the audience into an alternate reality and allowing them to experience a different world for a couple of hours.''
Art Robin Pogrebin

OXENBERG--Howard, born July 27, 1919 died peacefully on the night of June 25, 2010 surrounded by the family he loved. He is survived by his children Starr Oxenberg, Robert Oxenberg, Catherine Van Dien and husband Casper, Christina Oxenberg, Ashley Harcourt and husband Scott, and grandchildren, Mari, Luna, India, Celest and Maya, and one great-grandchild, Magnolia. Born in New York, Howard always knew he was destined for a rich and colorful life. He had natural movie star good looks and a shrewd mind. He started off in life without much but with tremendous courage to overcome any obstacle. He taught himself to become a champion swimmer and was a member of the Aquacade. His athleticism earned him a college scholarship and also saved him from the front lines of battle in WWII as he was assigned by the Navy to teach hundreds of sailors how to swim. Howard created many successful ladies clothing lines and was the first to mass market maternity dresses. He sold his businesses at age 50 and retired to the good life. He taught himself to ski and play tennis and was soon dominating both sports with his grace and agility and refusal to ever be second best. Howard owned homes in New York City, Southampton, and Palm Beach and devoted himself to a social circuit of fine friends, parties, back-gammon, and traveling. Anyone who knew Howard knew he was the life of the party with his wide smile and easy laugh and desire to cheer. He lived a life quite unique and as he said so often, "I'm one in a million." And that he was.
Film Stephen Holden

BRILL--Morty. Aged 91. To know him was to love him, he was a true friend to all. Father, grandfather, uncle and companion. Services Sunday, July 4, 12 noon, Riverside Memorial Chapel, Mt. Vernon, NY, interment to follow.

HOGE--Sarah (nee Collins) of Southampton, NY, died peacefully at home on June 20th at 90. Predeceased by her beloved husband Hamilton, she is survived by her daughters Cecile, Cynthia, Daphne, son Hamilton, and six grandchildren. All of whom she loved very much and who miss her dearly. A woman of great warmth and ability, she had been the Director of Special Events at the Museum of Modern Art for 18 years. Family and friends were of the utmost importance to her. She will be greatly missed.

The ''In the Region'' article in New Jersey copies last Sunday, about the inhibiting effects of high property taxes on residential real estate in West Orange, misstated the amount in extra taxes owed over the life of a 30-year mortgage on a $350,000 house if it were in West Orange rather than Livingston. The amount would be $103,000, not $48,000. (The $48,000 figure represents the extra equity that would accrue to the homeowner over 30 years if the house were bought in Livingston rather than in West Orange.)
International POLITICAL STRUGGLE STRAINS

A letter to the editor last Sundayabout two men convicted of the murder of a guard at Angola prison in Louisiana in 1972 contained outdated information about the case of one of them, Albert Woodfox. While a federal district court judge overturned his conviction in 2008, that decision, under appeal by the State of Louisiana, was reversed by the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit after the Book Review had gone to press.

An article last Sunday about the designer Tobias Wong, using information from his family and friends, gave conflicting assessments of his health. As the article noted, he had a variety of sleep disorders, including chronic sleepwalking and sleep terrors; thus, it was not the case that he did not have a history of health problems. An accompanying picture caption misattributed a quotation tattooed on Mr. Wong's arm. The artist Jenny Holzer -- not Mr. Wong -- wrote ''Protect Me From What I Want.'' And another caption misidentified the Wong Kar-wei movie that was the source of a still that Tobias Wong edited to put himself into. It is ''2046,'' not ''In the Mood for Love.''

FARHI--Jean-Pierre, on July 3, 2010. Beloved husband of the late Carol Ruskin Farhi. Devoted father of Jacques, Paul and Jane Farhi; father-in-law of Dina Farhi, Vivian Young and James Barron; adored grandfather of Simon, Talia Sadres, Nicholas, Samuel and Mariel; and great-grandfather of Jacob and Gabriel. Funeral service will be held on Tuesday, July 6, at 10 am at Riverside Chapel, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

MEYERS--Hyman, 98, of Palm Beach Gardens, FL, formerly of Richmond, VA, died on July 2, following complications after surgery. Born in Goldsboro, NC, he graduated in 1932 from the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill. He served as an Air Force Captain during World War II, receiving the Bronze Star Medal. He was the former chairman and CEO of Heilig-Meyers, a national home furnishings chain. He was predeceased by his wife Florence and his brother Sidney. He is survived by a sister, Amy, two sons, Stanley (Janet S.) and Donald (Prema), of Richmond, and one daughter, Janet Meyers (Mark Pollak), of Bethesda, MD, and five grandchildren. Funeral services will be held Monday, July 5, in Richmond.

An article last Sunday about the market for large apartments in New York City misstated the street number for the building on East 74th Street where Irene and Oleg Davie recently bought a five-bedroom apartment. It is at 255 East 74th -- not 225.

I've lived twice as long as Mozart, and I look it. Yet it's not unusual these days to be told I can't buy a beer until I show an ID. ''Nuts'' is the four-letter word I will use to describe this lunacy. Carding someone with white hair and liver spots all over his hands is a waste of everyone's time - mine, those behind me waiting for a beer and the poor counter person following management's orders. Last year at a Nets game at the Izod Center, I went to buy sausages while my son, Jack, headed for the beer counter. Jack, who is in his early 40s and starting to gray, soon joined me in the sausage line, explaining his wallet was in the car and he couldn't buy beer without an ID. After we got our food, I went to the beer line, showed my ID and left with two drafts. At halftime I headed back for another round, and this time a lady at the counter asked me to take my New York State driver's license out of the plastic window in the wallet and hand it to her.

LIVING ROOMS As we find ourselves in an era of diminishing resources, could ''less'' become ''more'' again? If so, the mid-20th-century building boom might provide some inspiration. Economic austerity was only one of the catalysts for the trend toward efficient living. The phrase ''less is more'' was actually first uttered by a German, the architect Ludwig Mies van der Rohe, who like other people associated with the Bauhaus emigrated to the United States before World War II and took up posts at American architecture schools. These designers, including Walter Gropius and Marcel Breuer, came to exert enormous influence on the course of American architecture, but none more so than Mies.

An article last Sunday about frustrations among residents of Bayou La Batre, Ala., over hiring efforts for cleaning up the oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico referred incorrectly to Social Security benefits for the town's immigrants. Legal immigrants who have worked for 40 quarters (10 years) in Social Security-covered employment can receive Social Security benefits. It is not the case that all noncitizen immigrants are automatically ineligible for Social Security.

ALLSOPP--Lillian Billie Cuffeea, 90, of Bronx, NY, passed away at home on May 14 surrounded by family. She will be missed by all who knew her. Memorial funds in her honor have been established at the Stratford Richardson YMCA, 1946 West Blvd, Charlotte, NC 28208 and the Children's Hospital at Montefiore, c/o The Division of Pediatric Hematology-Oncology, 3415 Bainbridge Avenue, Bronx, New York 10467.

On the Screen Part amateur ecological journal, part personal meditation, Out Walking the Dog investigates natural scenes and urban mysteries witnessed in the course of what is for many a routine ritual: the daily dog walk. Each walk provides a moment of calm reflection, said Melissa Cooper, who started the blog in October. It is a chance to forget her work in the theater and focus on the animals that share her city, all those ''raucous'' crows, wild coyotes and raccoon ''rumbles.''

''The bankers have shown that despite the crisis, they are not able to show selfrestraint. This law will do it for them.'' Arlene McCarthy, a European Parliament member from the Labour Party of Britain, who helped negotiate the new rules that place restrictions on how bankers' bonuses are paid. ''Those who claim there's an easier way or a soft option -- that's not the real world.'' Brian Cowen, prime minister of Ireland, which faces more cuts on top of the ones it has already experienced because of its severe economic downturn.

He was a charming infantryman with a slicing wit, a troubled kid for whom college didn't work. Then he drove over a roadside bomb in northern Iraq. On Easter Sunday 2009, Brendan Marrocco of Staten Island became the first service member of the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan to lose all four limbs in combat and survive.

An article on June 13 about rearranging pieces of classical music referred incorrectly to arrangements of Samuel Barber's popular Adagio for Strings. While several flute arrangements of the Adagio have been published, Barber did not write any of them.

A review of cookbooks on June 6 referred incorrectly to the Ballymaloe House restaurant and the Ballymaloe Cookery School in County Cork, Ireland. The school is at a separate location from the restaurant, not ''at Ballymaloe House,'' and while the chef Darina Allen is part of the family that owns and operates the restaurant, it is not ''hers.''

''Blood. Sweat. Tears.'' That's how Robin Placke of Staten Island described her photograph of a friend wiping his brow as he tended rows of kebabs, top right. ''This was captured at a friend's barbecue,'' Ms. Placke wrote in submitting the picture to nytimes.com. ''Eric worked the grill all day while we patiently (with cold beers in hand) waited for his famous kebabs.'' It is one of the dozens of barbecue photographs that readers have sent in since Memorial Day as part of a summer-long project. There are pictures of food, like Elizabeth Janovic's ''steak on the fire escape'' (with red peppers), at right; Stewart Milch's mouthwatering rows of sweet corn, ''waiting to be topped with mayo, Parmesan, lime juice and cilantro,'' top; and Robert Fernandez's ''prosciutto- wrapped sea scallops on a Weber kettle,'' bottom far right. Then there are pictures of people, like the scene, above, inMorningside Park, which Gabrielle Marie Lopez described as ''one of the few places where grilling is permitted all summer long (in designated areas only of course). ''Every other weekend,'' Ms. Lopez said, ''we tow our charcoal grill-on-wheels to the park for a day of grilling, eating and scrimmage football with friends.'' Online, view more reader photographs or submit your own, along with your best barbecue stories and recipes: nytimes.com/aroundthegrill

ARNOW--Joan. The Board of the Jewish Media Fund mourns the loss of our beloved Board member, Joan Arnow, whose spirit, generosity and warmth will continue to inspire us. Our deepest condolences to her husband, Bob and to the remarkable Arnow and Weiler families. Geoffrey Stern, Chair Eli N. Evans, President

The Dutch designer Wieki Somers was among those who exhibited their work at the Galerie Kreo stand at Design Miami Basel last week. She showed pieces from her poetic ''Frozen in Time'' series, in which objects appear to be coated with a delicate, glossy layer of ice (which is actually a liquid resin). At the same time, a rather more sober exploration by Somers was on display in Hornu, Belgium, at Grand Hornu Images, as part of the exhibition ''In Progress,'' which asks 10 design firms to rethink the idea of progress. (The exhibition runs through Sept. 12.) Somers chose to create three still-life vignettes made of human ashes. Yes, human ashes. In her statement for the exhibition, Somers questions peoples' seemingly unquenchable thirst to consume, and proposes that they might in turn become some of the objects they love to buy, thereby creatively upcycling some of the 465,000 liters of human ashes that are produced each day. With the technological miracle of 3-D printing, Somers says, ''we may offer Grandpa a second life as a useful rocking chair or even as a vacuum cleaner or a toaster. Would we then become more attached to these products?''

COXE--Susie S.,82, of East Hampton, NY, formerly of Hobe Sound, FL, died quietly at home Thursday, July 1, of Progressive Supranuclear Palsey (PSP), a rare neurological condition. Born December 8, 1927 in New York City to Emma Pattison and James Bond Skidmore, Susie Coxe was an avid competitor in golf, tennis, bridge, and paddle tennis. She won the National Paddle Tennis Mixed Doubles Championship in 1970 as well as a host of other golf and tennis tournaments throughout her life. She was the loving wife of the late Eckley B. ("Buzz") Coxe IV, mother of two children, David Taylor Harris Jr. and Catherine Harris Shraga, and sister of Patricia S. Kyle. A graduate of the Westover School and Vassar College, she was a long-time member of Maidstone Club in East Hampton, the Jupiter Island Club in Hobe Sound, and The Colony Club in New York, NY. She also belonged to the Field Club and The Round Hill Club in Greenwich, CT, where she lived with her first husband, David T. Harris from 1950 to 1972 and volunteered at the Greenwich Hospital for many years as well as serving as president of Hortulus, a local garden club. She served as a volunteer in New York City in the 1970s at Memorial Sloan Kettering and as a docent at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. She is survived by her children, her sister, two grandchildren, Taylor Harris of Minneapolis, MN and Patricia Harris of Atlanta, GA, and three stepchildren: Alexander B. Coxe, of Chicago, Ill.; Sandra Coxe Ankarcrona of London, England, and Audrey Coxe Cadwallader of Darien CT. The funeral service will be held at St. Luke's Church in East Hampton, NY on Friday, July 9 at 4pm with a reception to follow. A memorial service in Hobe Sound, FL will be held later in the year. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to The Eloise H. Troxel PSP Brain Bank, c/o Mayo Clinic Jacksonville, 4500 San Pablo Road, Jacksonville, FL 32224; Memorial Sloane Kettering Cancer Center, PO Box 27106, New York, NY 10087; or to the Jupiter Island Medical Clinic, 100 Estrada Square, Hobe Sound, FL 33455.

Now that there's a Red Wing concept store in Berlin, you can buy Filson in Paris, and scarves from Brooklyn's Hill-Side have made it to Amsterdam and Trieste, it's clear that the fetishization of American ''heritage'' style is no longer just for American men. And few shops in Europe are more faithfully dedicated to heirloom denim and classic work wear than the new Stockholm shop Mr. Mudd and Mr. Gold. The name alone, taken from a Townes Van Zandt classic, is like Carhartts incarnate. The shop, in Sodermalm, the city's answer to Brooklyn and the only party of town that could be called gritty, is outfitted almost entirely in unfinished knotty pine boards; they line the walls and form blocky benches and tables for merchandise that includes Mr. Freedom work shirts, Quoddy moccasins, Pendleton blankets and Wesco motorcycle boots. And true to the cult of craftsmanship, the narrative behind every company the store does business with is highlighted on its Web site. The expertly focused selection of brands includes plenty of international origin - canvas satchels from Brady Bags of England, founded in 1877; Grunden rain gear (Sweden, 1926); jeans by The Real McCoy's (Japan, 1990) - but the effect is nonetheless a mashup of styles that feels unmistakably American. Easy rider meets California gold miner meets New England stevedore, all crammed into your dad's tool shed, circa 1976. This is a more complete of the story than the one that appeared in print.

Following is the third and final set of responses from Kai Wright, the author of ''Drifting Toward Love: Black, Brown, Gay and Coming of Age on the Streets of New York'' (Beacon Press, January 2008), who is responding to readers' questions about gay youth in New York City, the challenges they face and the future lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender community they are creating.We are no longer accepting questions for this feature. To try a more positive tack: Mr. Wright, perhaps you could address how you see gay experiences as being inflected by race and class, and why you chose to write about the subset of the gay youth population that your title implies?

LERSE--Ursula, (Ulla), 85, of Riverside Drive, New York, died on June 26, 2010 while swimming in Candlewood Lake near her country house in New Milford, CT. Born in Dusseldorf, Germany, Ulla was a lover of music, and the visual and performing arts. She was the beloved wife of the late John Lerse and is survived by her sister Lotte Hoffman, her nieces Carol (and Russ Jennings) Hoffman and Janice Hoffman, her nephew Peter (and Pam) Hoffman, her grandnephews Jeremy, Adam and Daniel Hoffman, and her cousins Zandy, Victoria, and Tomas (and Gail) Mangold. A Celebration of Ulla's Life for family and friends will be held August 8 at The Leonard Nimoy Thalia at Symphony Space, 95th and Broadway. Donations may be made in her memory to DOROT, The Nature Conservancy, or Symphony Space.

FRUGAL TRAVELER Seth Kugel takes a very bumpy 36-hour ride to chilly La Paz, Bolivia, encounters a nightmarishly touristy scene in the city's Witchcraft Market and escapes for the weekend to the sunny city of Cochabamba.

Elise Boulding, a sociologist, pacifist feminist and scholar who wrote extensively about conflict resolution in both personal and global relations and who helped establish the academic field known as peace studies, died June 24 in Needham, Mass. She was 89. The cause was liver failure, her daughter, Christine, said; her mother also had Alzheimer's disease, she said.

Thanks to Jeroen Koolhaas and Dre Urhahn, one of Rio's bleakest neighborhoods now has a permanent rainbow. As part of their project ''O Morro'' (which literally translated means ''the hill'' but really signifies the presence of ''the slum''), the Dutch artists have enlisted the community to transform the facades of 34 houses (about 7,000 square meters!) into a colorful community art project. Local residents who picked up a brush received a small salary (the painting took about a month) and an education in the production process. Koolhaas and Urhahn, who have been painting favelas for the past two years as part of a greater initiative to transform the hillside slums into places that residents are proud to live in, plan to return to Brazil to finish painting the entire hill. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

ENDERS--Howard "Hank", Professor Emeritus of Film and Dramatic Writing at SUNY Purchase, died at 83 on June 18. A passionate, inspiring teacher for 30 years, he was loved by many for caring guidance and mentorship and the openness and directness of his unique personality. A writer/producer/director, with no formal college education, he created groundbreaking TV documentaries, winning Emmy, George Foster Peabody and Writers Guild awards, among others, and the Robert F. Kennedy Journalism Award for Outstanding Coverage of the Problems of Poverty and Discrimination. At the close of WWII, as a writer on the Army paper The Daily Pacifican, he with fellow staffers issued a formal statement of objection to the military's censorship policies and discriminatory attitudes. This remained his proudest achievement. Survived by his wife, the former Valerie Medvene Dushkin, children, Georgiana, Eric, Emily and Jody; grandchildren, Nathaniel and Elizabeth Odom, and stepsons, Peter and Samuel Dushkin. A scholarship fund for young writers has been established in his name. Contributions can be made to: Purchase College Foundation/In Memory of Howard Enders, and sent to Purchase College, SUNY, 735 Anderson Hill Road, Purchase NY 10577.

Though less known for its wine than heavyweights like Napa Valley, Pennsylvania has arrived. In the last five years, the number of wineries in Pennsylvania has grown to more than 130, and the number of visitors has doubled, to one million last year. Seventy of the wineries are connected along 11 wine trails, and the tasting experiences range from renovated barns to country estates. For the most part, tasting prices are reasonable, and at least for now, the crowds are minimal. A survey of a few offers a hint of the varied tastings available this summer.

It's a long way from the McLaren F1 and the Mercedes-Benz SLR McLaren to a tiny city car, but Gordon Murray, the legendary engineer whose Formula One racecars have won 50 grand prix, likes a challenge. The latest offering from Gordon Murray Design is not a fire-breathing supercar, but a green-themed urban people mover in two versions - one with a 3-cylinder gas engine and the other electric with a lithium-ion battery pack. The design offers seating for three, with the passengers behind the centrally located driver, and is smaller than the Smart.

The new Web site shortomatic.com lets you transfer any digital image onto a pair of board shorts. We cooked up these with the help of our art department, but you don't need to be a graphic designer to use the simple step-by-step service, which is a spinoff of the popular, punnier yogamatic.com (custom-designed yoga mats). At $99 (plus shipping), the shorts aren't cheap, but they're hand-sewn, made of super-soft polyester microfiber - and using your own image really does lend this summer staple some idiosyncratic pop. Only a men's style is available now, in sizes 24 through 38, but a shorter option for beach bunnies will go on sale next month. Several years ago, Dr. David Rowlands, a senior lecturer with the Institute of Food, Nutrition and Human Health at Massey University in New Zealand, set out to study the role of protein in recovery from hard exercise. He asked a group of male cyclists to ride intensely until their legs were aching and virtually all of their stored muscle fuel had been depleted. The cyclists then consumed bars and drinks that contained either mostly carbohydrates or both carbohydrates and protein. Then, over the next few days, they completed two sessions of hard intervals. One took place the following morning; the next, two days later. Dr. Rowlands found that the cyclists showed little benefit during the first interval session. But during the second, the men who ingested protein had an overall performance gain of more than 4 percent, compared with the men who took only carbohydrates, ''which is huge, in competitive terms,'' Dr. Rowlands says. Other researchers' earlier studies produced similar results. Protein seems to aid in the uptake of carbohydrates from the blood; muscles pack in more fuel after exercise if those calories are accompanied by protein. The protein is also thought to aid in the repair of muscle damage after hard exercise. Dr. Rowlands's work, which was published in 2008, was right in line with conventional wisdom.

MORIN--Robert B.,veteran motion picture, TV production and syndication/distribution Executive, died Saturday, April 24th. He was 83. A pioneer in worldwide syndication/distribution, he was best known for his achievements as head of 20th Century Fox Worldwide syndication. He set records syndicating the hit series M*A*S*H. As head of Lorimar TV Distribution he guided successes "Dallas", and "Eight is Enough". At MGM-TV, he made an innovative first-run network deal for the famous "Tom and Jerry" cartoons. He spent the late 60's in Rome, working for RKO. Morin retired in 1989 to Southern California. He leaves behind his beloved wife Audrey, three surviving children, seven grandchildren and two great grandchildren.

Erg Chebbi, Morocco, June 24, 2009. ''I didn't know there were sand dunes that would take over an hour to climb. I found this to be true when my friend Vân and I set out at 4 a.m. to climb a mini-mountain of sand to watch the sun rise over the Sahara Desert. We were in Morocco, just 20 miles west of the Algerian border. We slept the night under the stars, in a Bedouin camp about a two-hour camel ride from the town of Merzouga. It has been a dream of mine since I was a child to ride a camel in the Sahara, and all the effort it took to get here was worth it.'' Morgan Paar, New York

In the wake of the Deepwater Horizon spill, hotels and travel sites been steadily offering oil-free guarantees to encourage tourists to plan vacations to Gulf Coast states. One of the latest comes from Marriott, which announced on Thursday that through Labor Day, for hotels on the Gulf Coast it will offer a refund of 50 percent of the room rate for each day that the beach is officially closed and a full refund to guests who cancel before their arrival.

SHILEN--Lucy, 93, January 13, 1917 - June 27, 2010, died peacefully at home with her family in Brooklyn. Born Ludwika Adanowicz, Poznan, Poland. Arrested by the Nazis in Warsaw in 1944 with her mother Maria and sister Barbara, they were sent to Mauthausen, Austria, and forced to work in a camp brick factory as slave laborers. Liberated in May 1945, Lucy met her husband, the late Sgt. Ronald Shilen, in Linz. Loved by all, Lucy was compassionate and touched others with her kindness. She was also a great cook, an avid swimmer and a passionate gardener. Lucy is survived by her son, Mark, daughter-in-law Lorrie Bonaventura, grandson Alex, sister Barbara, and many nieces and nephews in France, Poland and the US. We will miss her always. Memorial: July 31, 11am, Plymouth Church, Brooklyn Heights, Mass in Poland. In lieu of flowers, Donations: www.kidney.org.

World Cup Semifinal: Uruguay vs. Netherlands2:30 p.m. EasternTV: ESPN, UnivisionTwo teams with deep World Cup traditions meet in a semifinal in Cape Town. Uruguay has won the tournament twice - in 1930 and 1950 - but has not reached this stage in 40 years. The Netherlands, famed for decades for elegant play, reached consecutive finals in 1974 and 1978 but has never won the Cup. Diego Forlán and Luis Suárez have led Uruguay with three goals each, but Suárez is unavailable for this match; his intentional goal-line handball - cynical or brilliant, depending on your view - saved his team in the dying seconds of regulation time against Ghana but earned him a red card and a one-game suspension. The gritty play of Mark van Bommel in the Netherlands' midfield gives Robin van Persie, Arjen Robben and Wesley Sneijder the freedom to attack. Sneijder, an eagle-eyed playmaker, has scored four goals.

"Ah, Sissinghurst," people say, "the garden." And of course the extraordinary place where I live is famous as a garden. In the 1930s, my grandparents, the poet Vita Sackville-West and the diplomat and writer Harold Nicolson, made a garden here in the ruins of a great Elizabethan summer palace. In effect (but not pedantically), they recreated the old house's vanished rooms and corridors with living things - irises and dahlias, roses and magnolias all contributing to a poignant and poetic half-remaking of the past.

MELTZER--Lillian, passed away on July 2, 2010 at the age of 100. She was the beloved wife of the late Herman and loving mother of the late Michael. She was admired and loved by all who knew her. She will always be remembered by her family and friends. She is survived by her son Robert, grandson Erik (wife Michelle), greatgrandson Lukas, sisters Betty and Midge and her brother Duke. Lil was a remarkable loving woman. She will be missed by all. Her memory will live on. Memorial service on Tuesday, 1pm, at "The Riverside" 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

8 P.M. (TCM) STAR OF THE MONTH: GREGORY PECKIn 2003, just weeks before Gregory Peck's death, the American Film Institute named his character Atticus Finch, a lawyer and father fighting racial injustice in 1930s Alabama, in ''To Kill a Mockingbird'' (1962), as the top hero on its list of 100 Heroes and Villains in American cinema. (Above, Peck with Mary Badham.) The role, Peck's favorite, also earned him an Oscar for best actor; in 1967 he received the Jean Hersholt Humanitarian Award from the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences and in 1969 the Presidential Medal of Freedom. This monthlong tribute to the man whose on-screen decency carried over from real life begins with five films adapted from novels, starting with John Huston's ''Moby Dick'' (1956), in which Peck plays Captain Ahab. The lineup continues with ''To Kill a Mockingbird'' at 10; ''The Keys of the Kingdom'' (1944), in which a crusading priest struggles to build a mission in China, at 12:15 a.m.; ''The Yearling'' (1946), about a Florida farmer who allows his son to have a pet deer, at 2:45 a.m.; and ''The Paradine Case'' (1947), in which a married lawyer falls for the woman he's defending on murder charges, at 5 a.m. 7 P.M. (13, 49) PBS NEWSHOUR Paul Solman speaks with Christine Lagarde, the French finance minister, about the global financial crisis.

FRIEDMAN--Geraldine (Gerry) Gewirtz, 89, died suddenly and peacefully at her Manhattan home, July 3. The widow of prominent surgeon, Dr. Eugene Friedman, she became a pre-eminent journalist in the jewelry, watch, fashion and table top fields. She was a founder of the Women's Jewelry Association. A graduate of Vassar College, her interests included the health field where she served on the Board of Mt. Sinai's Martha Stewart Wellness Center. She is survived by her sons John and Robert of New York, their wives, Jane Furse Friedman, and Dr. Elissa Gretz Friedman, and four devoted granddaughters, Elizabeth, Meredith, Kathryn and Caroline. Funeral service at Central Synagogue, Lexington Ave. and 55th St. Wednesday, July 7 at 10:30am. In lieu of flowers, please make contributions in honor of Gerry Gewirtz Friedman to Vassar College, Development Office, Box 14 124 Raymond Ave., Poughkeepsie, NY 12604.

The United States Women's Open begins Thursday, and if you want a glimpse into life on the women's professional tour, Christina Kim's new book, ''Swinging From My Heels'' (Bloomsbury), takes you inside that world with dozens of funny, sincere and insightful tales. Though framed as a diary chronicling the 2009 season, the book, co-authored by Alan Shipnuck of Sports Illustrated, is also a narrative of Kim's life. Brash and bawdy, Kim has a lot to say and knows how to tell a story. She also brings some of her famous golfer friends along for the ride. Kim does not carefully dance around any subject, she charges right in - as anyone who has seen her play, or dress, would expect. But some of the best parts are the subtle things, like the tedium and pressure of a job so rife with failure. Here is Kim driving for six hours from a Rhode Island charity event to a L.P.G.A. tournament in Rochester, N.Y., and trying to get there early because she didn't yet have a caddie to carry her bag for the competition.
If you were set free in a golf pro shop and could have anything you wanted, what would you take? A new driver? Irons? A new bag or pricey wedge?

It's tales like these that really make me miss Sun Microsystems. Before being swallowed by Oracle, Sun had plotted its most daring chip project to date. The company intended to take on Intel by building its own variant of Intel's chips for servers. The Sun chip would have been a no-frills, low-power version of Intel's products aimed at companies like Facebook, Yahoo and Google that need thousands of servers to display Web pages.

An article on March 12 about the death of Juanita Goggins, a civil rights trailblazer who in 1974 became the first black woman elected to the South Carolina legislature, erroneously attributed a distinction to her. While she was a member of the South Carolina State Advisory Committee to the United States Commission on Civil Rights, she was not in fact the first black woman appointed to the United States Commission on Civil Rights. (Frankie Freeman was the first woman -- and the first African-American woman -- appointed to that commission.)

Knock, Knock. Who's there? Apple TV? Apple TV who? In September 2006, Steven P. Jobs, Apple's chief executive, announced news of the company's latest offering: the Apple TV. Mr. Jobs had high hopes for his latest creation, so high that he told his audience that he hoped the Apple TV would be a fourth leg to the Apple business among PCs and iPods and iPhones. When the Apple TV was unveiled a few months later in early 2007, Mr. Jobs reiterated these comments in an interview with USA Today:We've got two strong legs on our chair today - we have the Mac business, which is a $10 billion business, and music, our iPod and iTunes business, which is $10 billion. We hope the iPhone is the third leg on our chair, and maybe one day Apple TV will be the fourth leg.Yet it wasn't long before Apple downgraded its hopes of a living room accessory and fourth leg to its business, and Mr. Jobs started referring to the poor Apple TV as a ''hobby.''

On the latest cover of Men's Health magazine, Kellan Lutz, a Calvin Klein model and actor in the ''Twilight'' movie series, stands shirtless in jeans while a big headline in the upper left-hand corner blares ''Beach Muscle Now!'' The tiny type in the opposite corner reads: ''Kellan wears Calvin Klein Jeans.'' Magazines usually include such credit lines inside the magazine, often running the name of the brand worn on the cover - the clothes, makeup and accessories - on the contents page.

Forget the frenzy of the consumer market, the jazzy advertising and the retail-shelf-space wars. Cisco Systems intends to hawk tablet computers in the more sedate world of the office. On Tuesday, Cisco revealed its plans to begin selling a tablet computer named Cius -- like ''see us'' -- early next year. Cisco pigeonholed the product as a ''collaboration tool'' for businesspeople, saying it's well suited to conducting video conferences and running business software like Cisco's very own WebEx application. The typical collection of Cisco equipment resellers and partners will sell, um, Ciuses.

She was a vivacious young queen when she first saw New York City in 1957, regal in white gloves but as dazzled as any tourist taking in the Statue of Liberty and the skyline of Manhattan from the deck of a rumbling Staten Island ferry. She wanted her first sight of the magical city ''as it should be approached,'' she said -- from the harbor. Cheering throngs lined Broadway for miles, showering Queen Elizabeth II with affection as blizzards of ticker tape engulfed her entourage. She waved from President Dwight D. Eisenhower's bubble-top limousine, a tiny woman suspended in time. She spoke at the United Nations, surveyed the romantic city from atop the Empire State Building and dined that evening at the Waldorf-Astoria in a diamond tiara.

LOVETT--Radford Dow, passed away at the age of 76 on July 4, 2010 in Jacksonville, Florida. Mr. Lovett was born in Jacksonville on September 6, 1933. He graduated from the Bolles School in 1951 and from Harvard College in 1955. Following college, Mr. Lovett served two years as a lieutenant in the United States Army Artillery in Wiesbaden, Germany. Mr. Lovett began his business career in 1958 with Merrill Lynch in New York City. Subsequently, he was made Managing Director of the Capital Markets Group and in 1975 President of the Investment Banking Division. He also served as a Director of several public corporations, including Winn-Dixie Stores, Inc., Florida Rock Industries, Inc., First Union Corporation, Florida Rock Properties, Inc. and American Heritage Life Investment Corporation. Mr. Lovett left Merrill Lynch in 1978 to return to Jacksonville to manage the Lovett family businesses with his brother, William Lovett. Most notably he was President of the Piggly Wiggly Corporation; Chairman of Commodores Point Terminal Corporation; and Chairman of Southcoast Capital Corporation. Outside of his professional life, Mr. Lovett was active in community and civic affairs, and served as a Director of St. Vincent's Medical Center Foundation, Jacksonville Zoo and Gardens, and Coastal Conservation Association. He was an active outdoorsman, who particularly enjoyed fly fishing and turkey hunting. In recent years, he spent fulfilling and happy summers with his family in Sun Valley, Idaho. Rad was a true gentleman - gracious, kind, and loyal. At the same time, he was adventurous and enthusiastic, a person who searched for and found the humor and good in all situations. He retained his dignity and positive outlook, even during his struggle with Frontotemporal Dementia. He was a devoted husband, father, and grandfather, and will be greatly missed. Rad is survived by his wife, Susan; two daughters, Katharine Loeb (David) and Lauren Fant (Jay); five sons, W. Radford Lovett (Lindley Tolbert), Philip Lovett (Beatrice Liu) of New York City, Nicholas Rogers (Taylor), Ted Rogers, and Peter Rogers of Los Angeles; his brother, Laurence Lovett of Venice, Italy; and ten grandchildren. Rad was married to Katharine Howe of Jacksonville from 1955 until her passing in 1991. Family and friends will celebrate his life and honor his memory at 11am on Wednesday July 7, 2010 at Christ Episcopal Church in Ponte Vedra Beach, Florida. In lieu of flowers, the family suggests memorial contributions be made in Radford D. Lovett's name to either: Jacksonville Zoo and Gardens, 370 Zoo Parkway, Jacksonville, FL 32218; or Association for Frontotemporal Dementias, Radnor Station Building 2, Suite 200, 290 King of Prussia Road, Radnor, PA 19087. Please visit our online Tribute at: quinn-shalz.com. Services under the direction and care of Quinn-Shalz, A Family Funeral Home & Cremation Centre, 3rd Street at Ponte Vedra Blvd., (904) 249-1100, www.quinn-shalz.com.

For the first time since the 1970s, a majority of Manhattan's population is non-Hispanic white, according to an analysis of census estimates. The white share of the population, which had dipped to about 40 percent as recently as the 1990s, climbed to nearly 51 percent last year. The rest of the borough's residents were 24 percent Hispanic, 14 percent black and 11 percent Asian.

RUSSO--Giovanni. The untimely death at 45 of Giovanni Carrieri Russo due to a long a courageous battle against cancer, on June 21, 2010, is being mourned by his family and by the graphic arts and fashion communities of the United States, Europe, and Asia. As one of the most innovative young graphic designers of the 1990s, Giovanni quickly made a name for himself in the magazine world with his redesign and repositioning of Travel and Leisure. At the age of 29, he became the creative director of The Gap, responsible for formulating a global campaign that revived the brand. He opened No11 in 1998, a full service advertising and design agency working with a wide range of clients from Fortune 500 companies to boutique brands including MaxMara, Victoria's Secret, L'Oreal, and a diverse spectrum of disciplines including strategy and positioning, advertising, publication design, packaging, television, video and new media. Giovanni married Florence Sicard, herself a noted art director, in 1997. Their three children, Alessandro, 11, Louis, seven, and Eva, three, are living testament of Giovanni's & Florence's love. For the last 10 years, Giovanni also found a new love, surfing, and this most elegant of men, when not working in New York, Milan, and Paris, could be found on the beach in Montauk, living a quiet and deeply fulling life with his beautiful family. Giovanni is survived by his mother Maria De Leo Russo and the sister of Teresa C. Russo and her husband Donald Nocerino his nephews Michael and Matthew and his sister Rosella C. Russo and her husband Gary Lindabery. Giovanni is predeceased by his beloved father Franco Carrieri Russo. The service will take place on Tuesday July 6th from 8am-930am at Greenwich Village Funeral home 199 Bleecker Street a mass will follow at 10am at Our Lady of Pompei at 25 Carmine Street.

In decades past, the words on this page would have been produced by melting lead to shape it into lines of type that would make up the newspaper's columns -- a process that was universal in the printing industry. That so-called hot type process was a direct descendant of the method of printing from movable type invented by Gutenberg more than 500 years ago.

It's nice to have a golf bag you can comfortably carry, but if you're playing in a fancy event, you don't want your bag to look cheesy, either. Fortunately, a lot of companies are now making lightweight bags that are smart and stylish, too. Start with the Collegiate by Nike ($150, golfsmith.com), which weighs five pounds and has a full-length apparel pocket as well as mesh pockets for a water bottle and accessories. It's functional and its straps have an air cushioning design that is easy on your shoulders. Another five-pound bag is the TaylorMade Pure-Lite ($150, sportsauthority.com), which comes in some bright but tasteful colors, has seven pockets, a velour-lined valuables pouch and a useful bungee towel cord. Both the Nike and the TaylorMade models are stand bags.

GUANGZHOU, China -- Premier Wen Jiabao has promised to use an ''iron hand'' this summer to make his nation more energy efficient. The central government has ordered cities to close inefficient factories by September, like the vast Guangzhou Steel mill here, where most of the 6,000 workers will be laid off or pushed into early retirement. Already, in the last three years, China has shut down more than a thousand older coal-fired power plants that used technology of the sort still common in the United States. China has also surpassed the rest of the world as the biggest investor in wind turbines and other clean energy technology. And it has dictated tough new energy standards for lighting and gas mileage for cars.

After announcing the end of his 25-year-old talk show last Tuesday, Larry King waited all of half an hour before daydreaming about the next line on his resume. He mused about giving speeches and doing stand-up, then said he could see himself appearing on an HBO comedy special, a forte of Mr. Maher's.

My column on Monday made a disparaging reference to Jimmy Carter's famous "malaise" speech (in which, yes, he never actually used the word "malaise"), citing it as an example of the pessimism bubble that inflated in late-1970s America. Recently a narrative has sprung up, on the "crunchy" right as well as on the left, that argues that Carter was prescient rather than over-pessimistic, and that America would be better off today if we'd heeded his indictment of consumerism and self-indulgence, rather than spurning him for the go-go optimism of Ronald Reagan. This is not a crazy idea, since in many ways the speech's moral critique of American life was powerful, timely, and as applicable today as it was then. (Here's a snippet: "In a nation that was proud of hard work, strong families, close-knit communities, and our faith in God, too many of us now tend to worship self-indulgence and consumption. Human identity is no longer defined by what one does, but by what one owns.") You can debate whether it's appropriate for a chief executive to play the prophet, but if Carter had stopped talking halfway through the address, confined himself to calling for moral renewal, and stayed away from economic policy, the "malaise" speech would look like a plausible indictment of the excesses of late-modern America - excesses that are very much still with us today, and contributed in varying ways to our current economic dislocations.

Passport fees are increasing effective July 13, the State Department recently announced. The cost of getting a brand-new passport for someone 16 or older has jumped 35 percent, to $135 from $100, and for those under 16 has increased by nearly 25 percent, to $105 from $85. If you've already got your passport, you're not immune: the cost of renewing your passport for those 16 and over has increased 47 percent, to $110 from $75.

Whenever I travel abroad, one of my first pit stops is the local farmacia. I'm always in the market for old-school apothecary products or those nifty Birkenstock-like house sandals you can only find in German drug stores. Recently, I hit the mother lode at A Vida Portuguesa, a general store tucked on a side street in Lisbon's Chiado neighborhood. The shop, housed in a former soap factory, features traditional, handcrafted products from all over the country, from toothpaste (the national brand, Couto, comes in a smart-looking orange tube) to countless tinctures and pomades (in handsome green glass bottles). Some of the products, like the pretty Claus Porto soaps, are more popular, while the Bordalo Pinheiro ceramics are harder to come by. Perhaps this amazing archive of authentic Portuguese products is a serious stand against the globalization and fast retailing that seems to have taken over the rest of the E.U. But for me, well, I'm just a sucker for all that hip retro packaging.

"For a designer, the black dress is like a white page for a writer," philosophizes Guillaume Henry, the newest creative director at the 65-year-old French couture house Carven. (If only the white page showed such promise for chicness or had the same slimming effect.) Henry, a 31-year-old Givenchy graduate, took things in a new direction this spring, when he marked his debut with a ready-to-wear collection. Cocktail dresses, slinky tailored skirts and roomy taffeta coats - all staples of the elite midcentury Parisian wardrobes that Carmen de Tommaso (aka Madame Carven) once outfitted - have been updated and made accessible to a younger generation that's more practique than aristo.

Since "The Alchemist" was first published in 1988 that quasimystical Paulo Coelho novel has inspired countless band names and vision quests, and has been translated into more than 60 languages -- with perhaps one significant omission that its publisher now intends to remedy. On Tuesday HarperOne, the HarperCollins imprint that releases Mr. Coelho's novels in the United States, said it would publish a graphic-novel adaptation of "The Alchemist" in December that turns the highly allusive work into slightly more concrete illustrated panels.

Christine Vachon, along with her partners at Killer Films, has produced a startling number of art-house hits, from "Swoon" to "Kids," "Happiness" to "Boys Don't Cry." A champion of director-focused films that often tell stories of lives at the fringes of society, the 48-year-old producer is known for her "whatever it takes" attitude to get projects from script to screen. In 2005, Killer Films was honored with a retrospective at the Museum of Modern Art. On her roster this summer is Ruba Nadda's "Cairo Time," which will be out in theaters next month, followed up by "Cracks," the directorial debut of Jordan Scott. Vachon is currently shooting the HBO miniseries "Mildred Pierce," with her frequent collaborator, the director Todd Haynes ("Far From Heaven").

While gulf resorts suffer, Mr. Stelter reports, beach towns on the Atlantic, like Tybee Island, are benefiting from vacationers taking a detour.

A production of Rossini's "Barber of Seville" at La Scala that has been delayed by an opera workers' strike has now lost its director, Agence France-Presse reported. The Milanese opera house said on Monday that Jean-Christophe Spinosi, the French conductor, had withdrawn as director of the opera and will be replaced by Michele Mariotti, the Italian conductor. In a statement on its Web site La Scala said, "Due to the impossibility of maintaining a serene and constructive work relationship, Jean-Christophe Spinosi has decided by mutual agreement  with the Teatro alla Scala management to withdraw from  the current production."

PARIS -- Shortly after 11 a.m. I left my hotel and rounded the corner into the Place Vendôme, crowded with tourists in shorts and sandals, and, streaming slowly past the Ritz, a line of black sedans delivering guests to the Giorgio Armani couture show, in the far corner of the square presided over by Napoleon's statue. The sun was glaringly bright, adding to the contrast between the regular folks and the fashion people. Near the curb I watched a cameraman squat low to photograph a woman as she scrambled out of her car. Not the most favorable position - for her. More photographers waited in the shadows of the corner and along a short length of black carpet, set off by velvet ropes, by the entrance.

The federal government has just finished construction on a zero-energy office building, the nation's largest, and is hoping that commercial developers will follow its lead. The 222,000-square-foot Research Support Facility is on the Department of Energy's National Renewable Energy Laboratory campus in Golden, Colo. Just over 800 employees will occupy the building once it officially opens in late August.

Ever since Ringo Starr vowed, on a well-known cover of Buck Owens's hit "Act Naturally," that he'd become "the biggest fool to ever hit the big time," the renowned rock 'n' roll drummer has done all right for himself. As a member of the Beatles and as a solo artist, Mr. Starr has sold more than a few records, won some Grammy Awards and even had a minor planet named for him. But on Wednesday Mr. Starr will reach a very special milestone: he turns 70 years old.

How would you like to own a company that can afford to offer its employees the chance to earn a bonus of $50,000 toward a new car? I know I would. And that's one of the reasons I think Hilcorp is one of the elite role models out there demonstrating how well open-book management can work.

What happens to the city's carriage horses after they retire from clopping along the streets has long been a subject of mystery and contention. Opponents of the carriage-horse industry claim that when horses get too old and infirm to work, stables routinely sell them at auctions frequented by meat buyers, effectively sending them off to their deaths. Stable owners say that, quite to the contrary, their horses are retired to farms to live out their lives in green splendor, or are occasionally sold to good homes.

NEMET--Tom, who died on July 4, 2010, lived the American Dream. He built a successful car dealership, he helped defeat proposed legislation that would have crippled the imported auto industry, and he enjoyed a full life with his immediate and extended family. To these three passions that animated his life, he brought grace and dignity. Founded nearly a century ago, Nemet Motors developed under Tom's leadership to become The Nemet Auto Group. Tom had a simple philosophy for selling cars: Treat your customers with respect, give them a good deal, and stand by them when in need. He served over 11,000 customers a year, but never let a day go by without thinking about how he could continue to grow the business. He knew that the Nation's Capital could have a profound impact, for good and for bad, in the life of a dealer. He lobbied Presidents, Senators, and Representatives, always sharing the same message: Because competition is the lifeblood of the nation, the best laws and regulations must be built on the foundation of free trade. In making the case for his industry, he never failed to remind politicians that his business was built around the porters, the mechanics, the sales personnel, and the others in the dealership whose livelihood depended on his ability to compete fairly. He founded Auto Dealers and Drivers for Free Trade as a means of providing financial support to Members of Congress who shared his vision. In the early years, before Honda, Nissan, and Toyota were household names, Tom worked with others in the industry to block proposed legislation and regulations that would have kept lower-priced cars and trucks beyond the reach of ordinary consumers. He fought hard as well to make sure that banks and other lenders would offer reasonable credit terms, so that a car or a truck would never be beyond the reach of someone who worked hard every day. But beyond his many accomplishments in building a business and helping the imported auto industry prosper, nothing mattered more in Tom's life than his family. He worked to bring family members into the business or to pursue their own dreams. He was passionate about his extended family as well. Conversations with colleagues never ended without him asking about their sons and daughters, and their jobs, their schoolwork, their aspirations. With his family by his side, Tom Nemet lost an 18-month battle with cancer on Sunday. He is survived by his loving wife Mary, sons Kyle, Todd, Ross and daughter Robyn and son in law Scott, and daughter in law Suzanne. Loving grandfather of Harrison, Jordan, Joshua, Matthew, and Rachel. Funeral to be held Wednesday, July 7th 2010 at 12pm at Schwartz Brothers-Jeffer Memorial Chapel 114-03 Queens Boulevard, Forest Hills, New York 11375 (718) 363-7600. Interim to follow at Beth David Cemetery Elmont Cemetery 300 Elmont road, Elmont, New York 11003.

FRIEDMAN--Geraldine (Gerry) Gewirtz, 89, died suddenly and peacefully at her Manhattan home, July 3. In lieu of flowers, please make contributions in honor of Gerry Gewirtz Friedman to Vassar College, Development Office, Box 14 124 Raymond Ave., Poughkeepsie, NY 12604.

DURBAN, South Africa -- The referees for the semifinals were announced today, and the full list of candidates to officiate the final four games was posted. Ravshan Irmatov of Uzbekistan, who refereed the opening game of the World Cup, will try to keep the Netherlands and Uruguay honest in Cape Town on Tuesday. He'll be assisted by his usual crew of Rafael Ilyasov, also from Uzbekistan, and Bakhadyr Kochkarov of Kyrgyzstan. The fourth official will be Yuichi Nishimura of Japan.

If you are a woman who exercises, get ready to do some math. Last week, researchers at Northwestern Medicine in Chicago announced a new formula for calculating a woman's maximum heart rate, a measure commonly used by athletes to pace themselves and monitor their progress. In a study of nearly 5,500 healthy women, scientists discovered that a decades-old formula for calculating heart rate is largely inaccurate for women, resulting in a number that is too high.

Our deepest sympathy to his daughters and their families. Lloyd Frank, Chair Joseph E. Smith, Treasurer Everette E. Dennis, Executive Director and Chief Operating Officer

KOPLEWICZ--Joseph, 94, beloved husband of Roma, who passed in 2004, dearest companion of Janet Whitehill, loving father to Edith and Harold, adoring father in law to Linda Sirow, proud grandfather to Joshua, Adam, Sam, and Alex, and beloved uncle, grand uncle and great grand uncle died July 4, 2010. His extraordinary strength, courage, and resilience saw him through the Warsaw Ghetto Uprising and 14 concentration camps, and his unwavering spirit and intelligence guided him when, in May of 1949, he immigrated to the United States penniless with his beloved Roma to begin their life again. Joe truly embodied the American dream. With energy and joy he built a business, raised a family, helped those in need and touched the hearts of all who knew him. His death on July 4th is fitting as he was proud and loved being an American citizen. His sparkle will forever remain with his family and friends. Services will be held at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, Wednesday, July 7, at 9:30am. In lieu of flowers, please make contributions to the Roma and Joseph Koplewicz Fund at the U.S. Holocaust Memorial Museum, 100 Raoul Wallenberg Place, S.W., Washington, DC 2004-2126.

Donations may be made to the American Jewish World Service and the Pancreatic Cancer Action Network.

10:30 P.M. (13); 11 P.M. (49) PROMISED LAND In this ''POV'' presentation the filmmaker Yoruba Richen travels to South Africa, where legal battles over land threaten to once again divide the country along racial lines. On one side are black families and members of a tribe, seeking the return of thousands of acres from which they were expelled decades earlier. On the other side are white owners with bills of sale who believe they should not be made to pay individually for the collective crimes of apartheid. At the heart of the argument: a deal made by the African National Congress upon taking power in 1994 to redistribute a third of the land within 10 years. The documentary (a scene is shown above) is a joint production by the National Black Programming Consortium, American Documentary/POV and the Diverse Voices Project. 8 P.M. (Fox) HELL'S KITCHEN The chefs must don blindfolds for a taste test before Gordon Ramsay shuffles the teams and unleashes some theatrics.

In sports it can be good to be selfish. Around the Ajax youth academy a story is often told of the young Johan Cruyff. For those who do not know, Cruyff is considered the best player the Netherlands has ever had. Internationally he ranks among the greats, just slightly behind Maradona and Pele. The story goes that when Cruyff received the ball with two men on him the youth coach would tell him to pass off to other players. Cruyff had his own ideas about the game so often he would take on and beat the first, then the second and maybe a third defender, with the coach yelling at him the entire time to pass the ball.

Sullivan and his wife, Kathleen, of Bergenfield, NJ, the late Glenn B. Sullivan; nephews, Robert and Kyle Gordon of Chicago. Also leaves his former wives Carol M. (Arnold) Sullivan of Chicago and Mary (Burke) McQueen of New York. James was an Investment Banker and worked on the floor of the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, HSBC, Citibank, and Solomon Brothers. He was a member of the Power Ten, Chicago Athletic Club, U.S. Rowing Association, and Retired Seniors RSVP Program. A faithful caregiver to his dog, Molly, and was devoted to his family and friends, he will be greatly missed. Visiting hours are on Thursday, July 8, from 6 to 9pm at Cartier's Funeral Home, 151 So. Main St. (Rte 126), Bellingham, MA. To sign guestbook visit www.cartiersfuneralhome.com

HONG KONG -- Halifax Fan began manufacturing industrial fans in 1965; its factory in West Yorkshire, England, with fewer than 75 workers, produces heavy-duty machinery for customers like power plants, food processors and pharmaceutical makers. But in recent years, the company noticed more and more of its products were being made for use in Asia. ''I thought, 'This isn't going to last long. Asian makers will copy us and we'll lose all that business,''' said Malcolm Staff, 46, the company's managing director. ''We needed to be closer to where our customers are.''

HAR BRACHA, West Bank -- Twice a year, American evangelicals show up at a winery in this Jewish settlement in the hills of ancient Samaria to play a direct role in biblical prophecy, picking grapes and pruning vines.

ROSENBERG--Alan D.,on July 2, 2010. Beloved husband of Patricia. Loving brother of Fred. Great friend to many. Director of Shelters for the Homeless. He dedicated his career to helping the poor and underprivileged. Wise, witty and generous. Great thinker, skier and athlete. His strong character was an inspiration to those who knew him. His memory will be cherished forever. Visitation Wednesday 2-4 and 7-9pm. Religious service Thursday 11am Clavin Funeral Home, 7722 4th Ave, Brooklyn. Following services, continued celebration of his life will take place at 542 48th St, Brooklyn.

CLARK--Georgia Welch, 81, passed away peacefully in her home on July 3. Georgia was born in Corpus Christi, TX. She attended Mills College and received her BA Degree from the University of Texas and MA in Political Science from the University of Chicago. Georgia is survived by her husband of 61 years, former U.S. Attorney General Ramsey Clark; her daughter Ronda; her son Tom Clark II, U.S. Department of Justice; granddaughters Whitney, Taylor, and Paige Clark; and her brother Michael Welch of Oceanside, CA. Her beauty, wisdom and limitless love inspired all who knew her. Her steadfast support and love - filled labors for her daughter Ronda, who was born incapable of caring for herself, and for her husband Ramsey, in pursuit of his ideals, made the lives they have lived possible.

World Cup Semifinal: Uruguay vs. Netherlands2:30 p.m. EasternTV: ESPN, UnivisionTwo teams with deep World Cup traditions meet in a semifinal in Cape Town. Uruguay has won the tournament twice - in 1930 and 1950 - but has not reached this stage in 40 years. The Netherlands, famed for decades for elegant play, reached consecutive finals in 1974 and 1978 but has never won the Cup. Diego Forlan and Luis Suarez have led Uruguay with three goals each, but Suarez is unavailable for this match; his intentional goal-line handball - cynical or brilliant, depending on your view - saved his team in the dying seconds of regulation time against Ghana but earned him a red card and a one-game suspension. The gritty play of Mark van Bommel in the Netherlands' midfield gives Robin van Persie, Arjen Robben and Wesley Sneijder the freedom to attack. Sneijder, an eagle-eyed playmaker, has scored four goals. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.
