The White House has announced that it wants to move ahead with a long-ignored trade pact with South Korea. The deal was reached by former President George W. Bush, but with President Obama planning to visit South Korea for a summit meeting of the Group of 20 major economies in November, he has now committed to resolving the outstanding issues and submitting the treaty for ratification after the fall elections. This is good news, to be sure. But it is hardly enough at a time when protectionism is rising around the world.

FRANKFURT -- The financial services version of the Hapsburg Empire is looking tattered these days. Austrian banks, which became some of the most profitable in Europe by expanding east of the Danube after the end of the Cold War, now reflect the economic problems that Eastern Europe faces as it slowly recovers from a sharp economic downturn and tries to pay down a pile of private-sector debt.

NEWTOWN SQUARE, Pa. - Justin Rose barely had time for the victory in the AT&T National at Aronimink Golf Club to sink in before he was headed to the airport to catch a chartered jet from Philadelphia to head across the pond to Limerick, Ireland, for the J.P. McManus Invitational Pro-Am. It's a charity fund-raiser that features a stunning array of the world's best golfers, including Tiger Woods, Lee Westwood, Ernie Els, Jim Furyk, Luke Donald, Rory McIlroy, Graeme McDowell and Padraig Harrington. In all, 56 touring pros will each team up with three amateurs in the two-day event with a purse of $1 million at the Adare Manor Hotel & Golf Resort. The tournament, played every five years since its inception in 1990, has raised 55 million euros for various charities in its four playings.

GREENBERG--Edna of Boynton Beach, Florida, beloved wife of George Greenberg for over 60 years, devoted mother of Stuart Greenberg, Melanie and Elliot Steinfeld, adoring and proud grandmother to Hannah. A loving daughter to the late Max and Gertrude Schwartz. Edna had a full and wonderful life and will be deeply missed by all those she touched.

The remains of Bobby Fischer, the American chess champion, were exhumed Sunday night in the cemetery of Laugardaelir Church in Iceland, according to a report in The Reykjavik Grapevine. The exhumation was ordered by the Icelandic Supreme Court last month to determine if Fischer is the father of Jinky Young, a 9-year-old Filipino girl.

HONG KONG -- Next to a children's amusement park and upstairs from two huge nightclubs in Shenzhen, the creative minds of Tecatech are at work designing remote controls, headphones and the packaging for your next set of sunglasses. Founded in Britain in 1998, the company was the country's first product design firm to set up permanent offices in China. After setting up an office in Hong Kong in 2004 and working there for about a year, Andy James Lee, Tecatech's founder and design director, realized he was going to mainland China almost daily to meet with manufacturers and other business contacts.

They were among the last words he will perhaps ever utter in this country. Expressed, said his lawyer, without irony or bitterness. ''God bless America.'' With those few syllables, Ahmad Wais Afzali, dressed in a flowing white robe with black and beige trim, entered the security line at Kennedy International Airport with his wife, Fatima, on Monday morning. In their hands: one-way tickets out of the country where they had grown up and made a life.

OWEN--Adrienne Meyers, of New York, NY, died peacefully on July 4th at 76. Predeceased by her beloved long-term companion Jerry Widoff, she is survived by her sons John and Andrew Owen, her sister Renee Meyers, her daughters-in-law Cindy and Kobi and her cherished granddaughter Alysha. All of whom she loved very much and who miss her dearly. Adrienne was a graduate of the Calhoun school, received a Bachelor of Arts from Sarah Lawrence College and a Masters of Art Therapy from New York University. During her life she was both an Artist (Sculptor) and a Board Certified Art Therapist. Adrienne dedicated her work to helping those in need. She spent the last decades of her career working for the Bowery Residents Committee, a non-profit day treatment and support center. Adrienne was an avid supporter of the arts and was a long-time member of the Board of Maverick Concerts of Woodstock, NY. Adrienne's life was filled with many, many long-lasting friendships. She will be greatly missed. A celebration will be held in September.

LADERMAN--Dr. Peter, 89, of White Plains, NY, passed away on July 3, 2010. Devoted husband for 64 years of Leonore Morey Laderman. Loving and cherished father of Carol, Stephen and Gerald, father-in-law of Michael Siegfried, Elizabeth Laderman and Sharon Laderman and grandfather of Jonathan, Daniel, Matthew, Benjamin, Jessica, Lauren, Eric and Jacob. Respected by friends, colleagues and patients. His kindness and compassion will be missed by all.

On this week's New York Tech Talk podcast, Bettina Edelstein speaks with Ramesh Raskar, an M.I.T. Media Lab associate professor, about a system he and his students developed that uses a cellphone screen, a small plastic device and software to test vision and calculate eyeglass prescriptions. According to Dr. Raskar, the results are as reliable as a more conventional method of testing eyesight. The system, called the Near-Eye Tool for Refractive Assessment, is inexpensive to produce and use, and because cellphones are so widespread it has the potential to help millions of people around the world with impaired vision, Dr. Raskar says.

Time has not been kind to the defense of M. Night Shyamalan that I penned four summers ago, just before the release of his first true stinker of a movie, "Lady in the Water." Not that I would take those arguments back, exactly: I'm still happy to defend all of his pre-"Lady" work, the much-derided "The Village" included, against the many critics who soured on Shyamalan earlier on. But if you describe someone as "a filmmaker of rare talent and creativity," as I did, and then they follow your vote of confidence by releasing "Lady," "The Happening," and now "The Last Airbender" (currently the worst-reviewed movie of the summer, below "Furry Vengeance" and "Sex in the City 2") on an unsuspecting public ... well, let's just say I wouldn't blame anyone who cited Shyamalan as exhibit A in the case against my critical acumen.

Dance New Amsterdam, the large dance space in Lower Manhattan, faces possible eviction on July 14 from its city-owned home at 280 Broadway because the organization owes more than half a million dollars in rent, Catherine Peila, the executive director, said Wednesday. "With the high rent and the recession, we didn't earn enough money to pay the rent," Ms. Peila said in an interview. "The arts community should really be revved up: we serve 8,000 students, we employ 250 people a year, and we moved to Lower Manhattan to revitalize the area." In a statement released Wednesday, the organization, founded in 1984, said it wanted to maintain its mission of teaching dance, commissioning choreographers and presenting performances to the public. It is seeking a meeting with Fram Realty, which leases the building for $68,945 a month, and with city agencies to work out an agreement for lower rent to match current market rates and for a nonprofit tax abatement, Ms Peila said. A representative of Fram Realty could not be reached for comment. Over the years, Dance New Amsterdam has presented Mark Morris, Urban Bush Women and David Dorfman, among other artists.

As if Betty White needed any more good news these days, it looks like she'll have enough work to keep her busy to the ripe old age of 89. On Wednesday, the TV Land cable channel said it was ordering a second season of "Hot in Cleveland," its hit comedy series about a dithering N.B.A. superstar who can't decide which multimillion-dollar offer he wants to accept - wait, scratch that: "Hot in Cleveland" stars Valerie Bertinelli, Jane Leeves and Wendie Malick as three women who move to the Rust Belt from Los Angeles, and Ms. White as their saucy landlady. The debut episode of the show's current 10-episode season on June 16 drew 4.75 million viewers. TV Land said the show's second season would be 20 episodes, with production to begin in October and a premiere tentatively scheduled for January.

In New York, it is 9/11. In Madrid, it is 3/11. In London, it is 7/7. And Wednesday, 7/7/10, marked the fifth anniversary of the terrorist attack by four bombers, their weapons concealed in backpacks, who took their own lives and those of 52 travelers on three subway trains and a double-decker bus. Oli Scarff of Getty Images recorded the moment at the 7 July Memorial in Hyde Park. The posts at left in the photograph are the bottoms of stainless-steel pillars, each more than 11 feet high. The memorial consists of 52 pillars arranged in patterns recalling the four locations of the attack. Visitors can walk around and through this open-air hypostyle hall, which was designed by the architectural firm Carmody Groarke and the Arup engineering firm. It was dedicated last year, on the fourth anniversary.

J.M.W. Turner's final painting of Rome, "Modern Rome - Campo Vaccino" (1839), was bought by the J. Paul Getty Museum at a Sotheby's auction in London on Wednesday evening for $44.9 million. The price, which includes Sotheby's fees, is a record for the artist at auction, outstripping an 1841 view of Venice, "Giudecca, La Donna della Salute and San Giorgio," which sold in April 2006 at Christie's in New York for $35.9 million. "This painting transcends even Turner; it's his best, it's Turner at the top of his game," Scott J. Schaefer, the Getty's curator of paintings, said in a telephone interview from London after the sale. "Turner often suffers from condition problems, but this painting has been behind glass for about 150 years. It's never been touched." The painting, which is in its original frame and had been on loan to the National Galleries of Scotland in Edinburgh since 1978, depicts the Italian capital bathed in a cloudy light. It has been on the market only once before, in 1878, when it was bought in London by the fifth Earl of Rosebery, who briefly served as prime minister after Gladstone. It has remained in the family ever since.

In a case study we've just published, Elizabeth Olson writes about a culture clash involving Coca-Cola and Honest Tea. Not long after Coke invested in Honest Tea -- a small, entrepreneurial maker of organic teas and kids juices -- executives with the multinational noticed that the smaller company's packaging featured the phrase "no high fructose corn syrup." The executives construed the phrase as an implicit rebuke of Coke products. "We got a strong request to change the wording," said Seth Goldman, co-founder and chief executive of Honest Tea.

Much like the dreams of millions of "American Idol" viewers who hoped to see a certain latter-day Janis Joplin manquée win that singing competition in May, at least seven dates on the show's "American Idol Live!" summer tour have evaporated, The Associated Press reported. When the tour, which features the Top 10 "American Idol" contestants from the 2010 season, was announced, it was to run from July 1 (in Auburn Hills, Mich.) to Sept. 16 (in Portland, Me.). But a revised schedule posted on the Web site of the tour promoter Live Nation listed seven canceled dates in August and September, including stops in Omaha, Neb.; Kansas City, Mo.; Toronto; and Cleveland. A concert scheduled for Sept. 14 at the CONSOL Energy Center in Pittsburgh was still listed.

Our three-ring circus continued over the weekend with mixed success. I followed up the inspiration from the classroom and interviewed the Boakye family of Ntonso, famous adinkra patternmakers. Paul Boakye did not speak much English, but his brother Gabriel translated. They were happy to hear about the possible use of adinkra in math education, but it took us a great deal of time to actually have a conversation about geometry.

The WSJ's economics blog has an interesting piece about how failing to extend unemployment benefits may actually end up increasing the deficit in the longer run, by pushing marginal older workers into disability. But this is actually a much broader point. There's a quite good case to be made that austerity in the face of a depressed economy is, literally, a false economy -- that it actually makes long-run budget problems worse.

The federal government has opened a new Web site for all news related to the oil spill and will soon phase out the site that it jointly ran with BP from the start of the Gulf of Mexico disaster in April. The government official in charge of handling the spill, Adm. Thad W. Allen of the Coast Guard, said in a news release that the new site, www.RestoreTheGulf.gov, "is designed to serve as a one-stop repository for news, data and operational updates related to administration-wide efforts to stop the BP oil leak and mitigate its impact on the environment, the economy and public health."

The producers of "Weeds" have been a bit ambiguous about where exactly Nancy Botwin, the drug-dealing mom played by Mary-Louise Parker, and her family will be fleeing for the show's coming sixth season. Could one of their destinations be a sleepy Northeastern resort town still haunted by a toothless old shark who chewed up its tourists in 1975? Maybe, maybe not, but either way, Richard Dreyfuss - who's really making the most of the 35th anniversary of his starring role in "Jaws" - will be joining the "Weeds" ensemble for at least four episodes of Season 6, press representatives for the Showtime comedy said on Wednesday. A news release described the character played by Mr. Dreyfuss (whose film credits also include "Close Encounters of the Third Kind," "American Graffiti" and "The Goodbye Girl") as "an unexpected character from Nancy's past." The new season of "Weeds," which has its debut on Aug. 16, will also feature as guest stars Alanis Morissette and Jennifer Jason Leigh, as well as Linda Hamilton, Peter Stormare and Mark-Paul Gosselaar, but not the show's co-star Elizabeth Perkins, who previously announced she was leaving the series.

Will Saletan has an excellent piece on Elena Kagan's role, as a Clinton administration legal advisor, in doctoring the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists statement on partial-birth abortion to make it more congenial to the pro-choice side of the argument. He makes the essential point, which is that this incident reflects badly on Kagan, worse on the ACOG - but worst of all on the various judges who then assumed, in decision after decision, that the ACOG statement could be treated as The Scientific Answer to the partial-birth abortion question, pure and undefiled by any crass political considerations. "This is the scandal's real lesson," Saletan writes. "Judges should stop treating the statements of scientific organizations as apolitical. Such statements, like the statements of any other group, can be loaded with spin ...  All of us should be embarrassed that a sentence written by a White House aide now stands enshrined in the jurisprudence of the Supreme Court, erroneously credited with scientific authorship and rigor."

"Seven years ago, the sociologists Kei Nomaguchi and Melissa A. Milkie did a study in which they followed couples for five to seven years, some of whom had children and some of whom did not. And what they found was that, yes, those couples who became parents did more housework and felt less in control and quarreled more (actually, only the women thought they quarreled more, but anyway). On the other hand, the married women were less depressed after they'd had kids than their childless peers. And perhaps this is because the study sought to understand not just the moment-to-moment moods of its participants, but more existential matters, like how connected they felt, and how motivated, and how much despair they were in (as opposed to how much stress they were under): Do you not feel like eating? Do you feel like you can't shake the blues? Do you feel lonely? Like you can't get going? Parents, who live in a clamorous, perpetual-forward-motion machine almost all of the time, seemed to have different answers than their childless cohorts."

As if his lederhosen don't invite enough Brüno comparisons, Bernhard Willhelm wants to talk about kinky sex. The German-born, Paris-based designer's latest men's collection was inspired by "the sexuality of my generation" - by fetishes (he mentioned "Spandex") and the online communities (from Facebook to the nude photo-rating site TangoTime) where people feel increasingly safe to flaunt them. "It seems like people live out that sexuality only on the Internet," Willhelm says. "But in real life they don't really feel it." Set in Paris en plein air amid traffic signs, fluorescent-colored smoke bombs, and a knee-high blanket of white soap suds, Willhelm's presentation late last month  - with its gas-masks, skeleton prints, and a Japanese happi coat emblazoned with the word "SEXSI!" - sought to reflect this online-only realm of carnal intrigue. In some cases, Willhelm even printed out photos from Internet dating profiles and laminated them onto clothes.

Thomas Keller plans to open a second Bouchon Bakery in New York next March. It will replace the Dean & DeLuca at 1 Rockefeller Plaza (48th Street). Sébastien Rouxel, the pastry chef for Bouchon uptown, will take on this project, too, where all the baking will also be done in-house. Tiffany Jones will be the chef de cuisine for both Bouchons, in charge of savory items. World Cup Semifinal: Germany vs. Spain2:30 p.m. EasternTV: ESPN, UnivisionA surplus of attacking skill will be on display when Spain and Germany meet for this semifinal match in Durban. Germany's Miroslav Klose, 32, with 14 goals in his Cup career, needs just one more to tie Brazil's Ronaldo for the all-time record. Mesut Oezil, 22, and Thomas Mueller, 20, have complemented Klose's veteran craft with youthful vigor, but Mueller is suspended for this match. Germany's field-devouring attack is contrasted by the meticulous passing and probing of Spain. Fernando Torres scored the winning goal for Spain when these teams met in the Euro 2008 final, but the striker has played below his capacity in this Cup. David Villa has picked up the slack, scoring five goals so far to bring his career total to 43 goals in 63 games for Spain.

Nick Fitzhugh and Pete Muller are in South Africa for the World Cup to produce a documentary series and film about the cultural importance and significance of soccer in black South Africa. Based in Alexandra -- a four-square-kilometer township in Johannesburg inhabited by about 1.5 million people -- the series centers around five people whose lives have been defined by soccer. They are sharing some of their stories with us.

What goes on inside your brain when you exercise? That question has preoccupied a growing number of scientists in recent years, as well as many of us who exercise. In the late 1990s, Dr. Fred Gage and his colleagues at the Laboratory of Genetics at the Salk Institute in San Diego elegantly proved that human and animal brains produce new brain cells (a process called neurogenesis) and that exercise increases neurogenesis. The brains of mice and rats that were allowed to run on wheels pulsed with vigorous, newly born neurons, and those animals then breezed through mazes and other tests of rodent I.Q., showing that neurogenesis improves thinking.

Ángel Franco, a staff photographer at The New York Times who is creating a series called "At the Sirens' End," responded to the call. What he found when he arrived was in a way surreal: the scene of the crime - if it was a crime at all (the police wouldn't say one way or the other whether the victim had been pushed) - was 15 stories in the air. All one could do was look up, unless you were an emergency services officer donning body armor to go into the apartment. A pair of small, black, high-top sneakers marked the spot where the victim, a women, had fallen to earth. All the police would say about her condition was that she still had a pulse when they arrived. She had been rushed to a hospital. Neighbors filled in the picture a bit. Her name was Wanda. She was sweet, slight and sociable. When Mr. Franco returned to the building later, he found a touching memorial already taking form.

FOR the first time in more than a decade, New York's beekeepers are claiming their summer perches on the city's rooftops. Bowing to a citywide campaign, the Department of Health and Mental Hygiene recently removed honeybees from the Health Code's register of ''venomous insects'' and other prohibited animals. Not surprisingly, the New York City Beekeepers Association saw a sizable bump in enrollment for its spring classes. Yet without support from City Hall, it's doubtful that we can return to anything like the pre-ban era, when hives could be found at city schools, on the roof of the American Museum of Natural History and even inside Radio City Music Hall.

A Sports of The Times column on Saturday, about Luis Suárez's saving the World Cup for Uruguay when he used his hands to block a shot, misidentified the round in which Diego Maradona's so-called Hand of God goal took place in the 1986 World Cup. It was during the quarterfinals, not the semifinals.

An article on Friday about Japan's Hayabusa space probe misstated the mission's precedents. The Hayabusa was the first spacecraft to visit an asteroid and return to Earth, and it was the longest round-trip mission to outer space and back. But it was not Earth's first visitor to an asteroid or the longest space mission yet. The article also erroneously attributed a distinction to Japan in placing a satellite in orbit. It was the fourth nation to do so, following the Soviet Union, the United States and France -- not the third. (It was third, after the United States and the Soviet Union, in placing a geostationary satellite in space.) The article also misstated, in some editions, the tardiness of the Hayabusa capsule's return; it was three years behind schedule, not two.

EMIL--Arthur D.,died peacefully on July 6, 2010. Active and vigorous throughout his life, Arthur had joined a new law firm just after his 85th birthday, played in a golf tournament with his daughter and sister three weeks ago, and spent the weekend before his death surrounded by family at his home in Rye, New York. Born in Brooklyn on Avenue M in 1924, Arthur was a graduate of Lawrenceville School, Yale University '45W, and Columbia Law School. During WWII, he served in the US Navy aboard a Destroyer Escort in the North Atlantic. An ardent sailor, Arthur was a member of the New York Yacht Club and the American Yacht Club. With his ocean racing sloop "Artemis", he competed in many off shore and distance races such as the Admiral's Cup and the SORC. In his younger days, Arthur had a single digit handicap in golf; he was an enthusiastic member of the Century Country Club. Known for his philanthropic efforts, Arthur was a member of the Executive Committee of Montefiore Medical Center, and served as president of the American Federation of the Arts, co-chairman of the board of trustees of the Brooklyn Academy of Music, and on numerous other philanthropic boards. Arthur practiced law for 60 years, specializing in providing counsel to remarkable entrepreneurs and their ventures. In some instances he joined his clients in their projects, including a collaboration with the legendary restaurateur Joe Baum in which the Baum and Emil families operated the Rainbow Room and Windows on the World. Arthur was a visionary real estate developer whose projects included the conversion of the Police Building in lower Manhattan, the restoration of the Guaranty Building in Buffalo, and the development of Harbor Plaza in Stamford. Arthur's greatest commitment in life was to his family. His first wife, Jane Allen Emil, with whom he had three children, died in 1973. Arthur married Lydia Moffat dePolo on July 6th, 1976 and welcomed her daughter into the family. He is survived by his wife Lydia, his children David, Jennie, and Suzanne, and stepdaughter Adrianne, their spouses, and their children, Catherine and Andrew Emil, Andrew Deutschman, Jane and Anna Pleskunas, Key and Carina Becker, and his sister Judy Emil Tenney. A true lover of the long shot, never afraid to risk it all, Arthur's vitality, strength and generosity will provide enduring inspiration to his family and his friends. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Children's Library at Northside Center for Child Development, New York, NY, or the Children's Hospital at Montefiore Medical Center, Bronx, NY.

BUTLER--Robert N.,MD, 84, died on July 4. His friends at The Atlantic Philanthropies mourn the loss of a towering pioneer who did so much to make the world recognize what may be the most important development of the last century: the transformation of human longevity. More than 30 years ago, he won the Pulitzer Prize for his book, "Why Survive? Being Old in America." He was the first head of the National Institute of Aging. He founded the first department of geriatrics in the country. He identified and indelibly labeled the social malady of "ageism." He created, built and grew the International Longevity Center which now has offices in 12 countries, an achievement that The Atlantic Philanthropies has been pleased to support over many years. Throughout, Bob worked ceaselessly to teach the public to reject the crude canard of "greedy geezers" and recognize that for the most part, older adults are not dependent, lusting for handouts, but independent, eager to give back to society. As he wrote 40 years ago, "Older people are as diverse as people in other periods of life, and their patterns of aging vary according to the range they show from health to sickness, from maturity to immaturity, activity to apathy, useful constructive participation to disinterest, from the prevailing stereotype of aging to rich forms of creativity." Tall, restless, white hair waving in the wind, he personified those words. We are proud of our long association with him, his work and his lasting contributions to the world. The Atlantic Philanthropies

An article on Saturday about the rising popularity of the International Baccalaureate, a two-year curriculum for high school students, misspelled the surname of a student participating in the program at Greely High School in Cumberland, Me. The student, a junior, is Maggie Bower -- not Bauer.

BUTLER--Robert N. The family of Robert N. Butler, M.D. mourns deeply his loss, both for us and for the world. We loved him as a father, grandfather and father-in-law. He was a remarkable man with boundless energy, unending generosity, and unwavering commitment to a once ignored field, aging. He was forever the optimist. A memorial service in appreciation of Robert Butler's life will be held in early fall. The family requests that contributions be made to the International Longevity Center-USA (ILC) to support the vision he created and the work he began. Send to 60 East 86th St, NY, NY 10028. Butler, with whom we have been associated since 1982 when he was appointed the first Brookdale Professor of Geriatrics and Chairman of the Brookdale Department of Geriatrics at the Mount Sinai School of Medicine. Tiger Woods's quick turnaround trip across the Atlantic to a pro-am in Ireland did not end well. His spotty play, a less-than-cordial interview session and his abrupt departure Tuesday from the town of Adare to fly to Florida less than a week before he will return to Scotland for the British Open Championship at St. Andrews raised questions about his mental preparedness for the season's third major championship. After Woods bettered his jet-lagged opening round by 10 strokes when he shot 69 Tuesday in his second round of the J.P. McManus Invitational Pro-Am - sort of an abbreviated 36-hole Irish version of the old Bing Crosby National Pro-Am - he submitted to questioning from the assembled news media.

TRACHTENBERG--Inge (nee Wachenheimer) of Englewood, NJ on July 3, 2010, beloved wife of Mike and mother of Michael, David and Shoshanah, of blessed memory, passed away at age 86 after a long illness which she endured with characteristic dignity and boundless courage. Her strength, generosity, kindness and love enriched her family which included eight grandchildren and five great-grandchildren as well as her community in which she was a forceful, visionary and dedicated leader. The author of three books and numerous short stories and poems, she opened a window to her soul and taught us how, with love and compassion, we can survive and even flourish through unspeakable horrors, whether they are engendered by the Holocaust or by family illness. Truly a role model for the modern woman, her life has been an inspiration and she will live on through the memory of all who had the good fortune of knowing her.

KREPS--Juanita, PhD, passed away on July 5 in Durham, NC after a lengthy illness. Born Blair Juanita Morris on January 11, 1921 in Lynch, Kentucky to the late Elmer and Cenia Blair Morris. She received a BA from Berea College (1942), and her MA (1944) and PhD (1948) in Economics from Duke University. After serving on the faculties at Denison University, Hofstra University, and Queens College (NY) she joined the Department of Economics at Duke where she attained the rank of Professor and was appointed James B. Duke Professor of Economics in 1972. At Duke Dr. Kreps also served as Dean of the Women's College and Assistant Provost (1969-72) and was named Vice President in 1973. Dr. Kreps' publications include: "Principles of Economics" with Charles Ferguson); "Sex in the Marketplace: American Women at Work; Lifetime Allocation of Work and Income: Essays in the Economics of Aging; and Sex, Age," and "Work: the Changing Composition of the Labor Force," as well as numerous articles in scholarly journals. During the presidency of Jimmy Carter, Dr. Kreps served as United States Secretary of Commerce, the first woman and the first economist to hold this position. She was instrumental in directing the Commerce Department towards a more active role in the promotion of international trade, initiating an historic trade agreement between the United States and China in May, 1979. Dr. Kreps served on the Boards of Trustees of Berea College, the University of North Carolina at Wilmington, and the Duke Endowment, and chaired the Board of Trustees of Educational Testing Services. She was also a member of the Board of Directors of a number of corporations, including the New York Stock Exchange, J.C. Penney, Eastman Kodak, R J Reynolds Nabisco, Citicorp, United Airlines, AT&T, Armco, Zurn Industries, John Deere and Company, Chrysler Corporation, and TIAA-CREF. Dr. Kreps was a recipient of the North Carolina Public Service Award and the Duke University Medal for Distinguished Meritorious Service. She was a Fellow of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences and a member of Phi Beta Kappa. Dr. Kreps was preceded in death by her husband Dr. Clifton H. Kreps, Jr., Wachovia Professor of Banking at the University of North Carolina Chapel Hill, and by her daughter Sarah Blair Kreps. She is survived by her daughter Laura Anne Kreps and partner Phillip Martin of Durham, NC; her son Dr. Clifton H. Kreps III and wife Patricia Cotter Kreps of Kirksville, MO; her son-in-law Kenneth Finnerud of Winston-Salem, NC; and her grandchildren, Alexandra and Eric Finnerud and Quincy and Caroline Kreps. Funeral services will be held at the Chapel of the Cross Episcopal Church, 304 E. Franklin St., Chapel Hill, NC at 2pm on Friday, July 9. Memorial tributes may be sent to Planned Parenthood of North Carolina or to the Chapel of the Cross.

BUTLER--Robert N.,MD. The trustees, faculty, and staff of The Mount Sinai Medical Center are deeply saddened by the passing of Dr. Robert N. Butler at age 83. A pioneer in the field of geriatrics, Dr. Butler founded Mount Sinai's Department of Geriatrics and Adult Development in 1982, the first such department at a U.S. medical school. Prior to Mount Sinai, he was, from 1975 to 1982, the founding director of the National Institute on Aging of the National Institutes of Health. He was also founder of several other organizations, including the Alzheimer's Disease Association, the American Association of Geriatric Psychiatry, the American Federation for Aging Research, the Alliance for Aging Research, and the International Longevity Center-USA, of which he was also CEO and President. A prolific writer of science and medicine, Dr. Butler received the 1976 Pulitzer Prize for General Non-Fiction for his book, "Why Survive? Being Old in America." We extend our heartfelt condolences to his children, grandchildren, and the entire Butler family. Peter W. May, Chairman of the Boards of Trustees, The Mount Sinai Medical Center Kenneth L. Davis, M.D., President and CEO, The Mount Sinai Medical Center

Arthur Rhodes will leave tickets for five people at the All-Star Game on Tuesday in Anaheim. His mother will be there, and two sisters, a niece and his 16-year-old daughter, Jade. Five women supporting a 40-year-old rookie All-Star. A boy will be there, too. Rhodes, a left-handed reliever for the Cincinnati Reds, is sure of it. Rhodes's son, Jordan, was 5 when he died in December 2008 of an undisclosed illness. Whenever Rhodes pitches, he scratches the initials ''J R'' in the dirt of the mound. He will do so again at the All-Star Game.

BUTLER--Robert N.,M.D., gerontologist, psychiatrist, public servant, and Pulitzer Prize-winning author and international leader in research and advocacy on a broad array of social and health issues in aging. In 1975, Dr. Butler was founding director of the National Institute on Aging. In 1982 he founded the Department of Geriatrics and Adult Development at the Mount Sinai Medical Center, the first department of geriatrics in a U.S. medical school, and served as chairman until 1995. In 1995 he became president and CEO of the International Longevity Center-USA. Our deepest sympathies to his family. Mentor and inspiration to us, he leaves an enduring mark on the field of geriatrics, gerontology, and palliative medicine. Albert L. Siu, M.D. Professor and Chairman Diane E. Meier, M.D. Director, Hertzberg Palliative Care Institute R. Sean Morrison, M.D. Vice Chairman, Research Rosanne Leipzig, M.D. Vice Chairman, Education Brookdale Department of Geriatrics and Palliative Medicine Mount Sinai School of Medicine

GOODMAN--Mark, died in Paris at age 78 of cancer. The son of Jack and Libby Goodman he grew up in New York. At Havard he was the recipient of a Sheldon Fellowship which allowed him to travel to Europe for a year and he then settled in Paris where after working in the family business he became an artist and had several exhibitions in Paris and New York. OWEN--Adrienne Meyers, of New York, NY, died peacefully on July 4th at 76. Predeceased by her beloved long-time companion Jerry Widoff, she is survived by her sons John and Andrew Owen, her sister Renee Meyers, her daughters-in-law Cindy and Kobi and her cherished granddaughter Alysha. All of whom she loved very much and who miss her dearly. Adrienne was a graduate of the Calhoun school, received a Bachelor of Arts from Sarah Lawrence College and a Masters of Art Therapy from New York University. During her life she was both an Artist (Sculptor) and a Board Certified Art Therapist. Adrienne dedicated her work to helping those in need. She spent the last decades of her career working for the Bowery Residents Committee, a non-profit day treatment and support center. Adrienne was an avid supporter of the arts and was a long-time member of the Board of Maverick Concerts of Woodstock, NY. Adrienne's life was filled with many, many long-lasting friendships. She will be greatly missed. A celebration will be held in September.

KOPLEWICZ--Joseph. The Board and staff of the Child Mind Institute are deeply saddened by the loss of Joseph Koplewicz, the father of our organization's president, Dr. Harold S. Koplewicz. Joseph, 94, died on the evening of July 4. A man of enormous courage and integrity, Joseph lived a life of uncommon bravery. He was, until his death, among the last survivors of the Warsaw Ghetto Uprising. Joseph was a man who kept beating the odds. He became the quintessential, self-made American. He embodied the American dream and fell in love with the United States for the freedom, hope, and opportunities it gave him and his beloved wife, Roma. Joseph touched the hearts of all who knew him with his sparkle, energy, and love of life. Everyone at the Child Mind Institute will always be grateful for Joseph's faith in and commitment to children's mental health as well as for the support and love he gave Harold. He was a remarkable supporter of the Child Mind Institute, as well as the NYU Child Study Center and the U.S. Holocaust Memorial Museum. We extend condolences to his son Harold and his wife Linda Sirow; his daughter Edith; his dear friend Janet; grandsons Joshua, Adam, and Sam Koplewicz and Alex Usi. Brooke Garber Neidich Chair Child Mind Institute Debbie Perelman Vice Chair Child Mind Institute

LEIFER--Edgar, M.D. We mourn the loss of Dr. Edgar Leifer, beloved physician, scientist and friend. Professor emeritus of clinical medicine and special lecturer in the Department of Medicine at Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons, and longtime devoted physician at NewYork-Presbyterian/Columbia, he was part of our medical center's family for more than 60 years. Dr. Leifer was the kind of knowledgeable, exacting and consummately humane physician that makes an enormous imprint on all patients, physicians and hospitals. An exceptional scientist and one of the nation's first radiobiologists, he pioneered the use of labeled carbon compounds in the study of metabolism and contributed landmark research on hepatitis and lassa fever. A widely respected internist, his grateful patients established a professorship in his honor. We offer our deepest condolences to his son, Dr. Dana Leifer, neurologist at NewYork-Presbyterian/Weill Cornell, and the entire Leifer family. Poised as we are for the most comprehensive financial reform in this country since the Great Depression, it is time to fess up to the fact that it likely would not have occurred without a concerted effort by the Obama administration and the Democratic-controlled Congress to demonize Goldman Sachs. There are good reasons, of course, why politicians have seized on Goldman for easy political gain. Among them are: the perceptions that Goldman figured out a way to benefit from the misery of others; that while many Americans were hurting from a recession partly of Goldman's making, the firm continued to rake in billions in profits and pay out billions more in bonuses; that Goldman seems unable to recognize that but for an 11th-hour rescue by the American taxpayers, in September 2008, it would have gone the way of Lehman Brothers, Bear Stearns and Merrill Lynch; and that Goldman has proved repeatedly that it prefers putting its own interests ahead of those of its prized clients and the rest of us. Another likely reason is that the politicians simply looked at the recent public polling data, which put Goldman's reputation below that of BP and Toyota, and realized that nothing spells political gold these days quite like bashing Goldman Sachs.

Ringo Starr is turning 70 on Wednesday. It feels as though youth itself is now 70 years old. I wasn't yet 6 when the Beatles played their last live performance atop the Apple Corps building on Savile Row in London, January 1969. They split four years before I got my first Beatles album. Still, I can keep track of my teenage years by Beatles songs I happened to be enthralled with at the time. Forty years after they broke up, my 6-year-old son is learning to play ''Eleanor Rigby'' on the piano.

LOFGREN--Lars Borje, M.D.,a psychoanalyst who practiced in Sweden and the United States, died June 28, 2010, in Molnlycke, Sweden. He was born in Gavle, Sweden, on August 26, 1920. He pursued his medical studies at the University of Uppsala, where he met and married Ingeborg Agnes Hellner, a law student, in 1943. A Freudian, he underwent analytic training in Sweden and with Erik Erikson in Stockbridge, Massachusetts from 1958 to 1960. Upon his return to Sweden, he became president of the Swedish Psychoanalytic Association and hosted the International Psychoanalytic Congress in Stockholm in 1963. In 1964, he returned with his family to Stockbridge to join the staff at the Austen Riggs Center. He served as Associate Clinical Professor in the Department of Psychiatry at the Yale University School of Medicine from 1968 to 1973. He was associated with the Mount Zion Hospital in San Francisco from 1969 to 1972 and after that was Associate Professor of Psychiatry at UCLA and the Brentwood VA Hospital from 1972 to 1976, when he entered private practice. He and his wife retired to Oregon in 1984. There, he served on the board of directors of the Oregon Shakespeare Festival and the Rogue Valley Symphony Orchestra, for whom he was a tireless fundraiser. They returned to Sweden in 1996. Dr. Lofgren was an early leader of Group Relations conferences as practiced by the Tavistock Institute in both the United States and Sweden. He was a founding member of GREX in San Francisco, SCOLA in Los Angeles, and AGSLO in Sweden, all organizations devoted to this approach of studying group and organizational dynamics from a psychoanalytic perspective. In addition, he wrote extensively on a number of psychoanalytic topics for The Journal of the American Psychoanalytic Association and The International Journal of Psychoanalysis. Dr. Lofgren will be remembered by many whose lives he touched throughout his long life as a superb healer, teacher, and mentor; a lover of jokes, good food, good wine, and music; and a loyal friend. He and Ingeborg, who died in 2007, were extraordinarily devoted to each other during their 64-year marriage; they rarely spent time apart and shared a deep love of both nature and the fine arts. He is survived by his three children, Sten B. Lofgren of Concord, Massachusetts and his domestic partner Sally Lopez, Hans B. Lofgren and his wife Tijana of Pixbo, Sweden, and Lotta M. Lofgren of Charlottesville, Virginia, as well as six grandchildren. Lars was a formidable force in the lives of all who knew him; he will be missed by all. There will be a memorial service and interment in Molnlycke, Sweden, at 11am on August 6. C.E.B. Begravningsbyra (c.e.b-begravningsbyra@telia.com) is handling the services.

They were juicy and smoky but not cooked. ''I had the idea in my head for several years,'' he said. In May, he introduced to the menu of his Manhattan restaurant a salad of grilled watermelon and heirloom tomatoes, lightly dressed with olive oil, aged balsamic vinegar and garnished with tiny leaves of fresh opal basil and fresh green basil.

AN ALLERGIC REACTION Q For people like myself with food allergies, going out for dinner requires a bit more research, like viewing the menu online and calling ahead. I also try to choose dishes that would be easy for the kitchen to accommodate -- for example, by leaving off the sauce. But how do I handle a waiter's rudeness when he or she tries to belittle my request in a voice loud enough to catch the attention of the rest of my dinner companions? (''Oh, it only has a little butter -- what's the worst that can happen?'') I'm dying for a witty retort, without having to lay out a medical explanation, to keep the attention from being on me.

MACREERY--John B.,93, of Redding, CT, after a brief illness and surrounded by loving family. He was born in Elmira, NY on March 21, 1917, the son of William Frank Macreery and Margaret Coughlin Macreery. He finished four of the five years required for his architectural degree at Cornell University when he enlisted in the Army Air Force. His World War ll service was in the Eighth Air Force in Great Britain as a First Lieutenant and navigator on a B-17. He completed 28 missions, one of which was a 9++ hour special mission to bomb a marshaling area at Crailsheim, Germany, for which he received the Distinguished Flying Cross and, subsequently, three oak leaf clusters. When the War ended in Europe in 1945, he returned to the United States and married Ruth Koegel. Four children were born of this marriage. For a short time he lived with his new wife in Watkins Glen, NY, where he managed the lumber and supply business his father had started before the War. When that business terminated he and his family moved to Granite Springs, NY, where his wife's family had a home and started a lumber and supply business there. He was accepted in the Columbia University School of Architecture and after finishing his final year received his architectural degree. He worked for the White Plains architectural firm, Perkins and Will, then started his own practice, designing a number of homes in Northern Westchester, including additions to his homes in Granite Springs and Waccabuc, NY, where he was a member of the Waccabuc Country Club for 55 years, serving on the board of governors. John served for years as a volunteer at Northern Westchester Hospital. He is survived by his wife, his four children, Katherine M. Weyhrauch, William Frank Macreery ll, John Brian Macreery and Kevin Owens Macreery, seven grandchildren and six great-grandchildren. He was predeceased by his parents and his sister Margaret M. Flynn. He was devoted to his family, to his golf and his friends at Waccabuc and Meadow Ridge. He will be sorely missed by all. The date of services for him to be determined.

KOPLEWICZ--Joseph, 94, beloved husband of Roma, who passed in 2004, dearest companion of Janet Whitehill, loving father to Edith and Harold, adoring father in law to Linda Sirow, proud grandfather to Joshua, Adam, Sam, and Alex, and beloved uncle, grand uncle and great grand uncle died July 4, 2010. His extraordinary strength, courage, and resilience saw him through the Warsaw Ghetto Uprising and 14 concentration camps, and his unwavering spirit and intelligence guided him when, in May of 1949, he immigrated to the United States penniless with his beloved Roma to begin their life again. Joe truly embodied the American dream. With energy and joy he built a business, raised a family, helped those in need and touched the hearts of all who knew him. His death on July 4th is fitting as he was proud and loved being an American citizen. His sparkle will forever remain with his family and friends. Services will be held at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, Wednesday, July 7, at 9:30am. In lieu of flowers, please make contributions to the Roma and Joseph Koplewicz Fund at the U.S. Holocaust Memorial Museum, 100 Raoul Wallenberg Place, S.W., Washington, DC 20024-2126.

Now that London's cycling subculture has reached the level of a populist movement, bike cafes like Container Cafe, Lock 7 and the summer pop-up Rapha Cycle Club are the city's latest hip hangouts. A recent addition is Look Mum No Hands, a bar, cafe and workshop in a lofty garage space on busy Old Street in Shoreditch. If you've visited any other haunts in East London, you can imagine the place: Edison light bulbs, a staff sporting asymmetrical haircuts, old tires and bike parts hanging from exposed ceiling pipes. Vintage bikes and heirloom tomatoes dress up the window displays, and a scattering of desks and built-in benches fill up most of the room.

Nick Fitzhugh and Pete Muller are in South Africa for the World Cup to produce a documentary series and film about the cultural importance and significance of soccer in black South Africa. "In the Gospels Jesus is always talking to the crowds in parables, which he later 'explains' to his disciples. The dynamic is odd in a couple of ways: either the parables are obvious, and the explanations seem almost patronizing, or they are opaque, and the explanations only compound their opacity. (Or could it be-and I confess to relishing this possibility-that the explanations illustrate Christ's wry sense of humor, which is nowhere else evident?) In any case, the notable point is just how little the explanations amount to, how completely the ultimate truths of the parables-just like dreams and poems-remain within their own occurrence ... 'If that's what he means,' says the student to the poetry teacher, 'why doesn't he just say it?' 'If God is real,' says the parishioner to the preacher, 'why doesn't he simply storm into our lives and convince us?' The questions are vastly different in scale and relative importance, but their answers are similar. A poem, if it's a real one, in some fundamental sense means no more and no less than the moment of its singular music and lightning insight; it is its own code to its own absolute and irreducible clarity. A god, if it's a living one, is not outside of reality but in it, of it (though in ways it takes patience and imagination to perceive). Thus the uses and necessities of metaphor, which can flash us past our plodding resistance and habits into strange new truths. Thus the very practical effects of music, myth, image, which tease us not out of reality but deeper and more completely into it."

KOPLEWICZ--Joseph. The NYU Child Study Center expresses its deepest condolences to the family of Joseph. The respect and love that our founding director, Dr. Harold Koplewicz, expressed for his father and late mother Roma left a deep impact on his colleagues and friends. A resilient survivor, Joseph was devoted to his family and deeply appreciative of his friends and his remarkable life. Our thoughts and prayers are with his children, Harold and Edith, his daughter-in-law Linda Sirow, his grandchildren, Joshua, Adam, Sam, and Alex, and his companion, Janet Whitehill.

BUTLER--Robert, MD. It is with great sorrow that we struggle with the death of Dr. Robert Butler. His intellect, compassion and determination made him an extraordinary man, who dramatically touched the lives of countless people all over the globe. He will be especially missed by his four daughters, Chris, Carol, Cindy and Alex and their families. We will all miss you very much. With love, Herta and family.
KOPLEWICZ--Joseph. We are so grateful for the five plus years we shared. You were a partner, confidant, friend, parent and grandparent. You will be deeply missed. Janet and the Whitehill Family

An article on June 21 about Swype, software for quickly entering text into smartphones, described incorrectly a competing product, ShapeWriter, which uses keyboard patterns to predict words. It can enter any word, not just common ones. And an accompanying picture caption misstated Cliff Kushler's role in creating software that predicts words being typed on a phone. As the article noted, he and a partner created T9, one such program; he did not invent the prediction technology.

The Antiques column on June 25, about books on antiques and related topics including ''Lost Rights: The Misadventures of a Stolen American Relic,'' omitted part of a comment by the dealer David Schorsch in citing a quotation in that book. On the issue of whether dealers are obligated to disclose an antique's provenance to potential buyers, Mr. Schorsch did indeed say ''It's none of their business where it came from.'' But that quotation was part of a broader description of business practices. He said: ''Nowhere in the rules of antique furniture does it say you have to tell someone where an object came from. It's none of their business where it came from. Some people do, but you don't have to.''

EMIL--Arthur. The Board of Directors and residents of the Police Building mourn the passing of our dear neighbor, Arthur Emil. It was Mr. Emil's vision and creative mind that is responsible for the wonderful residence and cherished community that is the Police Building. He served as our Board President for many years and never ceased to remain involved. We will sorely miss him and his invaluable counsel. Our heartfelt sympathy goes out to his wife, Lydia, and to his children and grandchildren.

If you're looking for an external hard drive with faster data-transfer speeds, you've probably considered models that use the U.S.B. 3.0 standard. The latest U.S.B. spec touts a theoretical maximum data transfer rate of 5 gigabits a second, compared with a maximum rate of 480 megabits a second for U.S.B. 2.0 drives. Most makers of hard-drives put it more simply: U.S.B. 3.0 drives should be 10 times faster than U.S.B. 2.0 models.

VIDAL--Sara E. The family of Sara E. Vidal mourns her passing on June 28, 2010 of natural causes, taken to glory at 62 as she slept. Services at West End Presbyterian Church and RG Ortiz Funeral Home celebrated a legacy of service to others. Burial was July 2nd in Evergreen Cemetery. Survivors include brothers Eliezer, David and Josue; sisters Raquel Vidal, Paula Damiani and Hulda Martinez; sisters and brothers-in-law Watuza, Marlene, Benjamin and Fernando, nieces Lydia, Lisa, Elizabeth, Katalyn, and Aristomelia; nephews Eric, Junito, Andrew, Alejandro, Daniel, and other relatives and friends. As Sara would say, "God is good!" and "Thank you Jesus!" for her life.

The Executive Committee Stephen J. Riker, Vice Chairman Gary Rosenberg, Vice President-Finance

An Editorial Notebook on Tuesday about the Beatles incorrectly reported the longevity of American 20-somethings alive at the time of the Beatles' last concert in 1966. Slightly more than half are still alive, not less.

SWEELEY--Michael M. The Trustees and staff of Caramoor Center for Music and the Arts in Katonah, Westchester, mourn the passing of Michael Sweeley, President Emeritus. After beginning his relationship with the Caramoor International Music Festival in 1955 as artistic advisor to Lucie Rosen, Caramoor's founder, along with her husband, Walter, Michael Sweeley became Caramoor's first Executive Director, serving in that position until 1988. His impeccable and sophisticated taste was essential to the development of Caramoor's reputation during the early years of the Festival. The Festival program offerings were expanded greatly during his tenure and concerts in the Music Room of the Rosen House were added in fall and spring. His vision and foresight made possible the creation of the Orchestra of St. Luke's as the resident orchestra of the Festival, a relationship that endures after thirty years. Caramoor continues to strive to uphold the high artistic standards set by Michael Sweeley. Judy Evnin, Chairman Michael Barrett, Chief Executive

SMITH--Margaret D. New York Medical College is shocked and saddened by the tragic death of our friend and colleague, Dr. Margaret D. Smith, senior associate dean and professor of clinical medicine. A respected rheumatologist and skilled educator, she headed the program in internal medicine at St. Vincent's Hospital Manhattan for many years, demonstrating a deep commitment to medical residents and students. We extend heartfelt condolences to her family, and especially to her husband, Dr. Matthew Ferguson, a retired member of our faculty. Ronald F. Poe, Chairman, Board of Trustees Karl P. Adler, M.D., President and CEO Ralph A. O'Connell, M.D., Provost and Dean, School of Medicine

SMITH--Dr. Margaret Dennis. The Organized Medical Staff of St. Vincent's Hospital mourns the tragic loss of Dr. Margaret Dennis Smith an extraordinary member of our staff since 1993. This accomplished physician and educator served as: Program Director of Internal Medicine, Professor of Clinical Medicine and Senior Associate Dean of the New York Medical College at St. Vincent's Manhattan and Chairperson of the GME Committee. The Medical Staff sends its deepest condolences to Dr. Smith's husband, Dr. Matthew Ferguson and to their children. She will be deeply missed. Armand Cacciarelli, MD for the Officers and Members of the Medical Staff of St. Vincent's Hospital

LIMATO--Ed. The Board and Staff of the Elton John AIDS Foundation mourn the loss of our dear friend Ed Limato. We were honored by his generosity and commitment to EJAF's work in the fight against HIV/AIDS and grateful for his devoted friendship and philanthropic leadership within the Hollywood business community. We send our sincere condolences to his family. Sir Elton John, Founder and Chairman David Furnish, Director Scott Campbell, Executive Director

EMIL--Arthur D. The Board of Directors, Advisors, Staff, children and families of Northside Center for Child Development mourn with great sadness the passing of Arthur D. Emil. In 2008 Arthur received Northside's highest honor, the Mamie Award, in recognition of his devotion, support and founding of the JAE Children's Library, the heart of Northside. For 35 years Arthur enabled thousands of children to find a place to read and grow. His compassion for children and families will always be remembered and he will live on in the hearts of Northside forever. Our deepest sympathy is extended to his wife Lydia; his children David, Jennie (our wonderful board member), Suzanne, and Adrienne; and the entire Emil family. We thank him so very much for all he and his family have done for Northside. He will be sorely missed.

DIEBOLD--Dorothy Roosen, July 6, 2010. Dorothy Orizondo Roosen Diebold, age 105, went to meet her Heavenly Father at her beloved home, Toplands Farm, in Roxbury, CT on Tuesday, July 6, 2010. She was preceded in death by her husband, Albert Richard Diebold, mother Clarita Orizondo Roosen, father Herman Dudley Roosen, sisters Clarita Roosen and Helen Roosen Curran, brothers Berend Roosen and Robert Roosen, and grandson Albert Richard Diebold III. Long a fixture of New York City, Palm Beach, Boca Grande, Florida, and Roxbury, Connecticut, Mrs. Diebold is survived by her children Albert Richard Diebold, Diane Diebold Terni, and Dudley George Diebold and wife Honoria Hine Diebold; her grandchildren Deborah Diebold de Naveja and husband Juan-Maria Naveja de Anda, Linda Gavel Webb and husband Arthur Heberer III, Daphne Diebold Stoughton and husband James Stoughton, Frank Gavel, Jr., and wife Laurie McKee Gavel, Stephen Gavel, and Caitlin Diebold and husband Kevin O'Connell; and great-grandchildren Juan-Maria Naveja Diebold, Thomas Gavel, Charles Webb, Rebecca Gavel. In addition, Mrs. Diebold leaves behind her dear friends Shirley Gilbert and Olive Simpson, as well as many wonderful nurses and staff in Roxbury and Boca Grande, who gave her kind and loving care for years. Born in Brooklyn, New York on February 3, 1905, the former Dorothy Roosen attended the Ogontz School in Pennsylvania, where she excelled in field hockey and book binding and earnestly studied the works of John Glasworthy, before making her debut in New York City and marrying Albert Richard Diebold there in 1931. A stalwart of the St. James Church altar guild in New York City, as well as that of Christ Church in Roxbury and St. Andrew's Church in Boca Grande, Mrs. Diebold was an award winning needle-pointer, who made many beautiful pieces for her churches, including the magnificent kneelers that are used to this day. She was an active member of the Colony Club for many years. A scratch golfer, Mrs. Diebold particularly enjoyed playing the game at the Washington Club with her mother, when both were well along in years. She was a member of the Red Cross Ambulance Corps in New York City during World War II and followed her husband to Washington, DC, when he served in the U.S. Army there during the conflict. She was a great supporter of many charitable causes in Florida, Connecticut, and elsewhere, including the Roxbury Land Trust, The Christian Herald Association, Roxbury and Boca Grande Fire, Ambulance, Library and Churches and many, many others. Known as a formidable grande dame and arbiter of social correctness, Mrs. Diebold was also an amazingly gracious hostess and supremely generous and thoughtful friend, who appreciated the special essence of everyone she met. She taught her grandchildren to call her Mumsie and somewhere along the line, everyone started calling her Mumsie. Mumsie will be eulogized on Friday, July 9, 2010 at 11am, Christ Church Roxbury, CT and all who loved her are welcome. Burial will be private. In lieu of flowers, please consider making a memorial contribution to Christ Church, Roxbury or the Roxbury Volunteer Fire Department.
LEIFER--Dr. Edgar. Thank you Dr. Leifer for being my doctor for 40 years. You were an outstanding doctor. All of your patients will miss you. Fay Allen

SWEELEY--Michael M.,died on June 30 at the age of 85 after a long illness. Born in Twin Falls, Idaho, he was descended from early Western settlers. He attended UC Berkley for a short time and then served in the army in WWII. A lifelong love of music sent him to Juilliard after the war, where he received a BS and MS in music criticism in 1949. His gift for writing and knowledge of music brought him assignments in the field of music publicity and development. After acting as tour manager for Maryla Jonas, the polish pianist, on her last transcontinental tour, he went to work for the impresario Sol Hurok. Michael managed public relations for many of the major classical artists and international touring companies represented by Hurok, including, The Royal Ballet, The Old Vic, The D'Oyly Carte Opera Co., The Kirov Ballet, and La Comedie Francaise. In 1955, Lucie Bigelow Rosen, wishing to expand the Caramoor Music Festival in Katonah, NY into a professional undertaking, borrowed Michael from the Hurok office. Michael became Executive Director and worked with Mrs. Rosen in this endeavor until her death in 1968, at which time he left the Hurok office and devoted his full time to developing Walter and Lucie Rosen's dream of making their home at Caramoor into a Center for Music and the Arts. The summer music festival was expanded from four weekends to nine weeks of classical orchestral concerts, opera, dance, chamber music, recital, etc. The Rosen House, with its collection of fine and decorative arts, along with the gardens, was opened to the public. Educational programs were begun. Michael remained the Executive Director of Caramoor for more than thirty years and helped develop it into a major international arts institution. When Michael retired from Caramoor, he pursued his love of travel for some years. Predeceased by his father, Judge Everett M. Sweeley, his mother, Hazel Browne Sweeley, and his devoted sisters, Jean B. Sweeley and Anna L. Sweeley, there are no immediate survivors. Burial will be with his family in Twin Falls, Idaho.

BUTLER--Robert N. The New York Academy of Medicine extends its condolences to the family of Robert N. Butler, MD, friend and esteemed NYAM Fellow. Bob's vision and commitment to healthy and productive aging and his pioneering leadership changed the paradigm for research, health care and social policy nationally and internationally in profound ways. His brilliance and compassion will truly be missed. Thomas Q. Morris, MD, Chair Jo Ivey Boufford, MD, President The New York Academy of Medicine

Yes, it is hot outside -- something you'll be reading about on City Room throughout the day. And most of the heat news, alas, will be cast in negative terms -- brownouts, stalled trains, beach overcrowding, people passing out. But aren't there some benefits to the heat? We thought it over and came up with some definite upsides. Here, therefore, is our list of what we call gain from the current heat wave socking the New York area:Bragging rights over that annoying friend who did time in a Turkish prison. ''You call that hot?''

BERMINGHAM--John C.,90, long-time community leader in Wharton, NJ and accomplished artist, died July 4 of natural causes. Services July 10, St. Mary's Church, Dover NJ, 10am. Offer condolences: at www.BerminghamFH.com

TRACHTENBERG--Inge (nee Wachenheimer) of Englewood, NJ on July 3, 2010, beloved wife of Mike and mother of Michael, David and Shoshanah, of blessed memory, passed away at age 86 after a long illness which she endured with characteristic dignity and boundless courage. Her strength, generosity, kindness and love enriched her family which included eight grandchildren and five great-grandchildren as well as her community in which she was a forceful, visionary and dedicated leader. The author of three books and numerous short stories and poems, she opened a window to her soul and taught us how, with love and compassion, we can survive and even flourish through unspeakable horrors, whether they are engendered by the Holocaust or by family illness. Truly a role model for the modern woman, her life has been an inspiration and she will live on through the memory of all who had the good fortune of knowing her.

PITTS--Lydia M. The Board and staff of the Community Service Society of New York (CSS) mourn the loss of a Trustee, friend, and ally in our fight against poverty in New York City. An expert in public finance and urban economics, Lydia Pitts served for 12 years on the CSS Board. In 1993, the Equitable Life Assurance Society, where she was Vice President and Counsel, presented her with the Equitable Community Leadership Award on behalf of her work with and dedication to the Community Service Society. Our deepest sympathy goes to her family. She will be missed.

SALWEN--Ethel, of Brooklyn, New York and San Francisco, CA died at the age of 95, of natural causes Saturday July 3, 2010 at Rhoda Goldman Plaza where she resided in San Francisco. Born in Brooklyn, New York on August 20, 1914 to Ida Cohen and Jacob Mandelbaum of Ukraine. Ethel received her BS from City College. She married Raphael Salwen, and they had four children, Stephanie, Trudy, Ellen and Jeffrey. She was extremely active in all aspects of Jewish community. She also transcribed books into Braille for the visually impaired. Her true passion was her art work, creating works in clay, stone and painting and teaching sculpture at Brooklyn College. She is survived by her daughter Ellen Salwen, Ph.D. of San Francisco, CA and her son Jeffrey Salwen, M.S. of Malibu, CA. A ceremony will be held by the graveside 10:30am on July 8, 2010 at Beth David Cemetery Elmont, Long Island. Donations can be made in her name to the Jewish Federation of America.

(TCM) TCM SPOTLIGHT: TEEN MOVIES Turner Classic Movies extols the allure of sand and surf with an all-night festival that begins with ''Gidget'' (1959), starring Sandra Dee (above, with James Darren, center, and Cliff Robertson) as a small but mighty California girl who dreams of riding endless waves with a gang of surfers, including the very groovy Moondoggie, played by Mr. Darren. An article on Wednesday about the visit to New York of Queen Elizabeth II misstated the age of her husband, the Duke of Edinburgh, in some editions. He is 89, not 88. And an accompanying picture caption referred incorrectly to the last time the queen addressed the United Nations, in 1957. It was five years after she became queen, not four years. (Though she was formally coronated in June 1953, she became queen in February 1952 upon the death of her father.)

ETHE--Glenn of Plainview, NY, died suddenly July 4, 2010 52 years old. Beloved husband of Joanne for 26 years, adored father of Mark, and Lauren, loving son of Esther. Predeceased by his father William "Bill". Devoted brother of Ron (Stephanie) and Cindy (Mike). Cesare Siepi, the renowned Italian bass acclaimed for his vocally suave, swashbuckling portrayal of Mozart's Don Giovanni, died on Monday in Atlanta, where he had lived for 25 years. He was 87. His death was confirmed by his wife, Louellen, who said he had been in failing health.

LEIFER--Edgar, Ph.D.,M.D. Columbia University Medical Center mourns the passing of Dr. Edgar Leifer, Professor Emeritus of Clinical Medicine at Columbia. Dr. Leifer received a Ph.D. in physical chemistry in 1942 and an M.D. in 1946 both from Columbia. After serving in the U.S. Army in the post-war phase of the Manhattan Project, he returned to Columbia for his house staff training. In 1951 he joined the medical faculty at Columbia as an expert in radiochemistry and evolved into an iconic clinician and clinical educator with a half-century of devoted service to his patients, students, the Department of Medicine at the College of Physicians and Surgeons (P&S) of Columbia and its Alumni Association. We extend our sincere condolences to his family. Gifts in memory of Dr. Leifer can be made to the Edgar Leifer Professorship of Medicine at Columbia University and sent to the P&S Alumni Association, 630 West 168th Street, Suite 2-250, New York City 10032. Dr. Leifer's funeral service will be held on Thursday, July 8, 2010, at 9:30am, at Temple Emanu-El, 1 East 65th Street, New York City. Lee Goldman, M.D., Executive Vice President for Health and Biomedical Sciences and Dean of the Faculties of Health Sciences and Medicine

KOPLEWICZ--Joseph. The Board and staff of the Child Mind Institute are deeply saddened by the loss of Joseph Koplewicz, the father of our organization's president, Dr. Harold S. Koplewicz. Joseph, 94, died on the evening of July 4. A man of enormous courage and integrity, Joseph lived a life of uncommon bravery. He was, until his death, among the last survivors of the Warsaw Ghetto Uprising. Joseph was a man who kept beating the odds. He became the quintessential, self-made American. He embodied the American dream and fell in love with the United States for the freedom, hope, and opportunities it gave him and his beloved wife, Roma. Joseph touched the hearts of all who knew him with his sparkle, energy, and love of life. Everyone at the Child Mind Institute will always be grateful for Joseph's faith in and commitment to children's mental health as well as for the support and love he gave Harold. He was a remarkable supporter of the Child Mind Institute, as well as the NYU Child Study Center and the U.S. Holocaust Memorial Museum. We extend condolences to his son Harold and his wife Linda Sirow; his daughter Edith; his dear friend Janet; grandsons Joshua, Adam, and Sam Koplewicz and Alex Usi. Brooke Garber Neidich Chair Child Mind Institute Debbie Perelman Vice Chair Child Mind Institute

An article on Saturday about the underlying strength of Israel-Turkey business and military ties despite Turkish outrage over the Israeli military's deadly raid on a Gaza aid flotilla on May 31 misspelled part of the name of a Turkish school where a Soli Ozel, a professor quoted in the article, teaches international relations. It is Istanbul Bilgi University, not Istanbul Biligi University. The article and an accompanying picture caption also misstated the name of a trade group that had reported a slowdown in some partnerships and investment ventures between the two countries after the flotilla raid. It is the Israel Turkey Business Council, not the Israeli Turkey Business Council.

GROSSMAN--May Rosalind, age 87, died on Friday, July 2, 2010, in Hackensack, New Jersey. She was born May Bramson on June 1, 1923, in Joliet, Illinois. May was a working mother, holding various administrative assistant positions at real estate firms, insurance companies and PS 53 in the Bronx before retiring. Upon retiring, she gave her free time to various charitable organizations, including Casa de los Ninos, where she cared for babies in Tucson, Arizona; she also taught English as a second language. May is survived by her devoted husband of 54 years Fred, her beloved sons Jon and Charles, beloved daughters-in-law Lisa and Donna, and precious grandchildren Jonathan, Matthew, and Rebecca. A memorial service will be held at a date to be determined later. A donation in her honor may be made to the Alzheimer's Association.

EMIL--Arthur D. The Board of Directors, Advisors, Staff, children and families of Northside Center for Child Development mourn with great sadness the passing of Arthur D. Emil. In 2008 Arthur received Northside's highest honor, the Mamie Award, in recognition of his devotion, support and founding of the JAE Children's Library, the heart of Northside. For 35 years Arthur enabled thousands of children to find a place to read and grow. His compassion for children and families will always be remembered and he will live on in the hearts of Northside forever. Our deepest sympathy is extended to his wife Lydia; his children David, Jennie (our wonderful board member), Suzanne, and Adrienne; and the entire Emil family. We thank him so very much for all he and his family have done for Northside. He will be sorely missed.

MACREERY--John B.,93, of Redding, CT, after a brief illness and surrounded by loving family. He was born in Elmira, NY on March 21, 1917, the son of William Frank Macreery and Margaret Coughlin Macreery. He finished four of the five years required for his architectural degree at Cornell University when he enlisted in the Army Air Force. His World War ll service was in the Eighth Air Force in Great Britain as a First Lieutenant and navigator on a B-17. He completed 28 missions, one of which was a 9++ hour special mission to bomb a marshaling area at Crailsheim, Germany, for which he received the Distinguished Flying Cross and, subsequently, three oak leaf clusters. When the War ended in Europe in 1945, he returned to the United States and married Ruth Koegel. Four children were born of this marriage. For a short time he lived with his new wife in Watkins Glen, NY, where he managed the lumber and supply business his father had started before the War. When that business terminated he and his family moved to Granite Springs, NY, where his wife's family had a home and started a lumber and supply business there. He was accepted in the Columbia University School of Architecture and after finishing his final year received his architectural degree. He worked for the White Plains architectural firm, Perkins and Will, then started his own practice, designing a number of homes in Northern Westchester, including additions to his homes in Granite Springs and Waccabuc, NY, where he was a member of the Waccabuc Country Club for 55 years, serving on the board of governors. John served for years as a volunteer at Northern Westchester Hospital. He is survived by his wife, his four children, Katherine M. Weyhrauch, William Frank Macreery ll, John Brian Macreery and Kevin Owens Macreery, seven grandchildren and six great-grandchildren. He was predeceased by his parents and his sister Margaret M. Flynn. He was devoted to his family, to his golf and his friends at Waccabuc and Meadow Ridge. He will be sorely missed by all. The date of services for him to be determined.

EMIL--Arthur. Oded Aboodi, his family and colleagues mourn the passing of Arthur D. Emil beloved husband, father and grandfather. A true friend and gentleman, he will be remembered as an honorable person by everyone he touched personally and professionally and as a man of extraordinary intelligence, warmth, humor and generosity. We will all miss him.

In this week's "Your Money" column, I review five of the toughest questions that children ask about money. You'll have a chance to pick over the answers I outlined and nominate better ones in separate posts, one for each question, which are linked below.
In his Wealth Matters column this week, Paul Sullivan writes about how artists, musicians and actors manage the wealth they accrue, especially when their earnings do not come in steadily.

Younger children probably don't know the difference between $8,000 and $80,000 in this context, so you may be able to settle the issue by letting them know that you make enough for them not to need to worry about running out of money anytime soon.
When children ask this question, they often don't know what the word "rich" actually means. That gives you an opening to help them define it.
This is ultimately not that far removed from the question about why a child doesn't have an iPhone. It just reckons with much bigger numbers.

This is a particularly tough one, since you can't say for sure that, for instance, you won't have to move and the kids won't have to change schools. If you go without work for years instead of months, anything is possible.

Less than a month into his new gig as the chief executive of EMI Group, Roger Faxon already has some ideas for shoring up the struggling music label, according to The New York Post.

Meatopia - which styles itself as the "Woodstock of Edible Animals" - will bring together more than 30 chefs on Saturday dishing up barbecue with meats that have been sustainably raised by local farmers. It's the first time the event, on Governors Island this year, is open to the public. Tasting tickets (ranging from $26.62 to $154.74) are available online for the extravaganza, which runs from 11:30 a.m. to 4:30 p.m. Half the net proceeds will benefit Just Food NYC and Slow Food NYC.

Among the comments from readers about the "Unhappy Helicopter Parents" post was one that approached the question from a global point of view. I am highlighting it below because it is a perspective I have not really considered before, despite having given much thought to why this generation brings so much guilt and intensity and determination to parenting.
Chrysler is recalling about 22,300 of its 2010 trucks and sport utilities due to a brake problem, according to the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration.
