Someday, the Yankees believe, Cliff Lee will wear their uniform. They just might have to wait, after all.

When I watch Spain play at this World Cup, I get the feeling of what it must have been like to attend a dinner party with Oscar Wilde as a guest. You contemplate your leg of lamb and glass of Cote du Rhone, just waiting, waiting to get a word in, as the world's greatest wit holds forth. He coins aphorisms about the lamb and the tablecloth. He rattles off a couplet on the merits of jogging inebriated while wearing a bowler hat. He discourses for an hour on the Byzantine empire and Racine and then when he's done, throws in an epistle in Latin with the ease of a waiter dropping a napkin.

A suicide bomber attacked a group of tribal elders gathered near the headquarters of the civilian government in Mohmand, Pakistan, Jane Perlez and Ismail Khan report. More than 60 people were killed and more than 100 were wounded, a senior Pakistani security official said. The bomber detonated a car laden with explosives in the bazaar at Yakaghund, the administrative center of Mohmand, a tribal area, where elders were gathered over tea before a scheduled meeting with the assistant political agent, the security official said. The blast blew a crater nearly five feet deep, and victims were trapped in the rubble of scores of destroyed shops.
In her column, We Made It Ourselves, Charlotte Druckman writes about restaurants and small businesses with interesting house-made treats.
Mark Bittman brings an unconventional seasoning combination — ripe plums and fresh tarragon — to ceviche.

Lenox, Mass. - Tanglewood holds a special place in the formation of professional musicians in this country. Its training arm, the Tanglewood Music Center, takes in more than 100 of the young musical elite as fellows every summer. Room, board and tuition are covered, with money to run the program coming from donors and ticket revenues from concerts offered by the Tanglewood Festival.

GDANSK, Poland -The foundation that runs the Wikipedia Web site plans to add 44 employees in the next year - roughly doubling the size of its current professional staff - and to raise $20 million to support a much-enhanced vision for the volunteer-created encyclopedia that nearly anyone can edit.
Randy Kearse, who served more than 13 years in federal prison, has used the business skills he honed as a drug dealer to sell thousands of his self-published books in the streets and in the subway.

Organizers have canceled the Great Jazz on the Great Hill concert, scheduled for 2 to 5 p.m. on Saturday in Central Park, because of thunderstorm predictions. Cheryl L. Duncan, a spokeswoman for the concert, said the performers -- including Jimmy Heath, Ray Mantilla, Dion Parson and Brianna Thomas -- had been informed of the cancellation about midday on Friday, soon after the decision had been made. There is no rain date. The concert was being presented by Jazzmobile in collaboration with the Central Park Conservancy at the Great Hill, at 106th Street and Central Park West. An allied children's workshop preceding the concert has also been canceled.

The rumor that Thierry Henry would be joining the Red Bulls of Major League Soccer has been around longer than the French team's stay in South Africa for the 2010 World Cup. This will not be on TV a la LeBron James, but can we call this "Le Decision"?
Op-Ed Columnist Nicholas D. Kristof responds to a reader's question about his favorite philosophy book.
ESPN is planning to introduce a campaign that seeks to burnish the cable channel's brand rather than to encourage viewers to watch specific programs.

A crash involving a city bus, an ambulance and a car injured 15 people, 6 seriously, in Harlem Friday. The ambulance, operated by the Fire Department, was en route to a reported injury on Randalls Island around 11:45 a.m. when it collided with an M100 bus at West 125th Street and Seventh Avenue. The bus driver and 10 passengers were among the injured, said Deirdre Parker, a spokeswoman for New York City Transit. The Police and Fire Departments had no immediate word on how the accident occurred, though the police said no criminality was suspected. All of the injured were taken to Harlem Hospital Center; none of the injuries were life-threatening, according to fire officials.

The seven-member commission assembled by President Obama to investigate the BP spill has hired Richard A. Sears, a longtime Royal Dutch Shell scientist, engineer and offshore drilling expert, to be its chief technical adviser. Mr. Sears is on loan to the Massachusetts Institute of Technology as a visiting scientist at the university's Laboratory for Energy and the Environment.

The New York Transit Museum laid off two full-time and two part-time employees this week, in accordance with required payroll reductions across the Metropolitan Transportation Authority and its agencies. The museum is financed by donations and revenue from admissions and sales in its store, but its staff members are officially employed by the M.T.A. The M.T.A. is facing a financial crisis and recently made significant service cuts. At the museum, the full-time staff has been reduced to 18 from 21, through the layoffs and one vacancy going unfilled. Aaron Donovan, an M.T.A. spokesman, said that operations and hours would not be affected. The museum had 566,169 visitors last year at its two locations, in Brooklyn  and at Grand Central Terminal.

LAS VEGAS - President Obama wrapped up a two-day campaign swing Friday morning with a full-throated defense of his economic policies and a warm-hearted embrace for the Senate Democratic leader, Harry Reid of Nevada, a one-time boxer who is counting on the president to help him fight his way through a tough re-election race.

"Avatar" will be back on 3-D Imax screens in August, and it will be longer than ever. Imax and 20th Century Fox on Friday said they planned to re-release James Cameron's science fiction epic for a two-week run beginning Aug. 27. The film, which already had a running time of 162 minutes, will include eight minutes of new material. Fox executives had been mulling a re-release ever since "Avatar," which came out last Dec. 18, got nudged off of Imax screens in March by Walt Disney's "Alice in Wonderland." The blockbuster has sold about $2.7 billion in tickets worldwide.

The police are searching for a suspect who they believe assaulted two women early Monday morning in Riverside Park on the Upper West Side, leaving one seriously injured. They released a sketch of the man on Friday.

The Old Course at St. Andrews, site of this week's British Open, is hardly a typical golf course, so perhaps it is fitting that "Play Away Please, The Tale of the Sale of Golf's Greatest Icon" (Mainstream Publishing) is not your typical golf book. When the starter's box at the Old Course, one of golf's most recognizable structures, was put up for auction during a 2001 renovation, the author, John Peter Hagen, decided to bid on it. It was a dream and a belief in the power of a symbol - the decades-old little box had sent off all the great golfers of the 20th century, countless duffers, and presidents and kings, too. And from it, at the start of every round, came three stately words: Play Away, Please.

In his review of David Mitchell's new novel, "The Thousand Autumns of Jacob de Zoet," James Wood raises an eyebrow at the vogue for historical fiction among literary novelists:

"Loving sports, by definition, requires a certain suspension of disbelief and logic. We are all pouring our hearts and souls into cheering for men (and women) who do not care about us, who are not like us, who are not the type of people we would ever associate with (or even meet) in real life ... And we trust that they will at least pretend. We trust that they will recognize the ultimate ludicrousness of this whole enterprise, that these are grown men wearing tank tops, throwing a ball up and around, running on wood, that this all exists because we allow it to exist, that the illusion must be maintained. We trust that they understand how good they have it, how much we give them, against our own self-interest. We trust that they are not laughing at us. That trust felt broken tonight. Not because LeBron James went to the Heat, even though he referred to his destination as 'South Beach,' not 'the Miami Heat and their fans.' Not because LeBron James didn't go to the Knicks, even though of all the cities he mentioned enjoying during this free agent 'courtship,' New York was the one he omitted. Not even because LeBron was so, so cruel to Cleveland, not once thanking the fans who made him into what he was ... No, tonight, it felt like everyone involved - LeBron, ESPN, Bing, the University of Phoenix, Stuart Scott, the man who once chastised fans for having the audacity to boo, Jim freaking Gray - treated the millions of people watching like stupid, mindless consumers, empty lemmings ready to follow Sport into the abyss ... It felt like a break, the moment when the tide crested, when we looked at the games, and their players, and ourselves, and wondered: Why in the world are we watching these awful people?"

• Casey Stoner, who won the 2007 MotoGP championship while riding for Ducati, will join Honda's factory team for the 2011 season. The most surprising element of the plan may be that Honda plans to retain its current riders, Dani Pedrosa and Andrea Dovizioso, and compete with three riders. Long-standing rumors suggest that Valentino Rossi will join the Ducati team, but official confirmation has been elusive, even as Rossi, the six-time MotoGP champion, ventured onto a track for the first time since he fractured his leg in a frightening crash in early June. He put in 26 laps.

Alice Dunn is 3 months old. Her mother, Lillian, is on maternity leave right now from the New York City Department of Health, where she works in the Physical Activity and Nutrition Program. Usually Lillian loves going out and about with Alice, who likes to smile at strangers and is fairly easy-going in public.
After weeks of sparring with the media over First Amendment issues, the Pentagon has agreed to allow a Miami Herald reporter it expelled from Guantánamo Bay in May back onto the naval base.

Ever since Dealbreaker posted a draft of Ray Dalio's "Principles," Bridgewater Associates' unofficial handbook, the hedge fund manager has taken some heat in certain corners of the news media for his philosophies. (The Financial Times's columnist Lucy Kelly, for example, called Mr. Dalio "deluded, insensitive, emotionally illiterate, simplistic, breathtakingly smug, weird and plain wrong.")

First-half performance figures are showing the same pattern for hedge funds as for more mainstream investors -- the most successful were in fixed income, the least successful in stocks, Reuters reported.

Sarah Lewis and Daniel Belasco got the idea for the latest SITE Santa Fe Biennial, which they co-curated, seven years ago. It was while working for Robert Storr, the curator on the fifth SITE biennial (this one is the eighth), that they came across animated works by Kara Walker and Raymond Pettibon. "It was the first time Walker activated her silhouettes, and she did it in an eight-minute piece called 'Testimony,'" Lewis recalls. "It was parallel to Raymond Pettibon's 'Repeater Pencil.' We looked at those works and both thought they exemplified a new aesthetic, of artists activating their paintings, drawings or other works with high-tech means, but to create something homespun. And that's when we decided we should do a show about that very aesthetic."

It's going to be a few more months before an actor playing Ray Charles on a Broadway stage is told to hit the road, Jack, and begs like a man in a trance to be set free. On Friday, the producers of "Unchain My Heart," a musical based on the life of Mr. Charles, the soul and R&B performer, said they were delaying the production's opening until next spring. It had originally been announced to open at the Barrymore Theater on Nov. 7; in a statement, the producer Stuart Benjamin said there were "logistical reasons" for the change of date. "Unchain My Heart" is directed by Sheldon Epps from a book by Suzan-Lori Parks ("Topdog/Underdog") and is to star Brandon Victor Dixon ("The Scottsboro Boys") as Ray Charles.

France's PSA Peugeot Citroen and China Changan Automobile Group plan to invest $1.2 billion to set up a joint venture to make small, low-emission cars in China, The Associated Press reported.

The bulky, retro-styled Chrysler PT Cruiser - its fans found it positively alluring, its detractors called it bulbous and cheaply made - becomes an automotive legend on Friday when the final PT comes off the line at Chrysler's plant in Toluca, Mexico.

The United States Women's and Junior Championships start Saturday in St. Louis. As with the United States Championship, the venue will be the Chess Club and Scholastic Center of Saint Louis. The championships will run concurrently.
A small Wisconsin mobile phone carrier has figured out a clever way to lower the cost of its phone service while providing its customers with discounts on retail goods and services.

Three years ago, the Italian energy giant Eni began what is now a summer tradition: from June 1 to Sept. 1, the company sets the thermostat in its corporate office buildings 1 degree Celsius (1.8 degrees Fahrenheit) higher than it had in summers before 2007. It also allows employees to "take off their ties" - that is, wear lighter, more casual clothes to work.

It's arguably the biggest news to come from southern Connecticut since a certain highly coveted N.B.A. free agent announced there that he was leaving his home state and heading for South Beach - or, at least, the newest news. The creative team of Stew and Heidi Rodewald said on Friday they will contribute to a third entry in a series of musical adaptations for Shakespeare on the Sound, and are creating music and songs for a production of "Much Ado About Nothing" for next summer. As with Shakespeare on the Sound's 2009 staging of "A Midsummer Night's Dream," which featured a score by Stew, and the company's current "Othello," for which Stew wrote the music with Ms. Rodewald,  "Much Ado About Nothing" will be directed by Joanna Settle, the company's artistic director, press representatives  said in a news release. The set designer Andrew Lieberman and the costume designer Tilly Grimes will also return for "Much Ado About Nothing," which will be presented at Pinkney Park in Rowayton, Conn., and Baldwin Park in Greenwich, Conn. Casting for the romantic rivals Beatrice and Benedick, among other characters, has not yet been announced.

A radical reimagining of Manhattan's 34th Street, which would include the first bus lane in the city to be physically separated from other vehicles, will receive more than $18 million in federal funds, the United States Department of Transportation said on Thursday.

"Cover Run: The DC Comics Art of Adam Hughes" arrives at No. 2 on the hardcover list this week. This collection features Mr. Hughes's cover illustrations of shapely characters like Wonder Woman, Catwoman and Power Girl, as well as sketches and commentary. Mr. Hughes, who in 2003 won the comics industry's Eisner Award for best cover artist, answered questions about his work by e-mail.

At a dingy basement rock show in in Ridgewood, Queens, on Thursday night, a member of the band Run DMT stepped from behind the mikes and toward the crowd. As the guitars shrilled, he began to smear red paint violently across his face. He then lofted a bottle of pancake syrup over his head and poured it down his body, squirting it into his ears. Next, he stuck Monopoly money to the ooze, and capped off the performance by sucking down a whole mango. The audience cheered.

BUTLER--Robert. The Faculty, Administration, Advisory Council, Alumni Association, and students of the Columbia University School of Social Work note with sadness the death of Dr. Robert Butler on July 4, 2010 at the age of 83. A leader and expert in the field of aging, Bob transformed treatment of the elderly. Our solace is that he goes to join his beloved life partner, Dr. Myrna Lewis, our much loved deceased alumna, who promised that she would be "waiting for him sitting on the handle of the Big Dipper" with a smile on her face. Sincerest condolences are extended to his daughters Carol, Christine, Cynthia and Alexandra, also an alumna of the School, and the entire Butler family. Dr. Jeanette C. Takamura, Dean

RACE--Bradford. The Association for a Better New York mourns the loss of Bradford Race. Brad was a great friend of New York and a longstanding ABNY member. He will be greatly missed. William C. Rudin, Chairman Jennifer M. Hensley, Executive Director

RACE--Bradford J. The board and staff of Dia Art Foundation mourn the loss of Bradford J. Race, a Dia trustee since 2002. Brad was instrumental in the realization of Dia:Beacon, and we will miss his wise counsel and tireless efforts on Dia's behalf, and particularly, his deep love for the institution.

SMITH--Margaret. In Loving Memory of Dr. Margaret Smith. Beloved wife, mother, sister, grandmother, aunt, friend, physician. She was magnificent; a super-sized soul in a size-small body who lit up absolutely everything she touched. She loved deeply and gave generously, filling the world with life and beauty. Words cannot express how much she will be missed. Please join her family in celebrating her extraordinary life: Vigil Prayer Service, 5-8pm, Friday, July 9, 2010; St. Francis Xavier Catholic Church 46 West 16th Street, New York, NY 10011. Funeral Mass 3pm Saturday, July 10, 2010 St. Francis Xavier Catholic Church. Funeral reception to be held immediately following mass at St. Francis Xavier. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in her memory to Medicine Sans Frontiers or The Arthritis Foundation. For more information, go to www.love-infinity.com.

Jim Bohlen, whose snap decision to sail to Amchitka Island, Alaska, to protest an underground nuclear test led to the creation of the environmental organization Greenpeace, died Monday in Comox, British Columbia. He was 84 and lived in Courtenay, British Columbia. The cause was complications of Parkinson's disease, his daughter, Margot Bradley, said.

PREISS--Byron April 11, 1953 - July 9, 2005 A true visionary; humble; a kind man. Ray Bradbury once said that if you enjoy living, it is not difficult to keep your sense of wonder. You lived these words as a faith and passed them down to us. Life was your museum. Morality was your compass. Humor was your gift. We can only hope to live your legacy as we continue our journey. And so we must ask, what would you be doing now? Always missing, eternally loving. Your girls, Sandi, Karah, and Blaire

A little more than four months ago, a faulty boiler in a furniture store ignited a fire that raged for hours in Jackson Heights, Queens, destroying eight mom-and-pop shops in a squat landmark building at the corner of 37th Avenue and 84th Street. By the time firefighters tamed the flames, all that was left was charred wood and fallen bricks. Salvage workers recovered a box with 18 hundred-dollar bills in it from the register of a party favors store, and they rejoiced. At least something had been saved, one of them said at the time. But it turns out the bills were fake, good luck charms that the store's owner, Maria Solano, had been handing to her customers since the dawn of the new year, she said.

RACE--Bradford. The School of American Ballet mourns the loss of our devoted Board member, Brad Race. Among his other contributions, Brad was instrumental in helping the School build the Lincoln Kirstein Wing's two floating glass studios in 2009. His loyalty and commitment to SAB will always be remembered. We extend our deepest sympathies to his beloved wife, Nancy Miller. Robert Fribourg, Chairman of the Board Peter Martins, Chairman of Faculty Marjorie Van Dercook, Executive Director

A picture caption on Saturday with a Sports of the Times column, about Luis Suárez of Uruguay having used his hands to block a shot by Ghana in a quarterfinal match of the World Cup, referred incorrectly in some editions to the effect his actions had on the outcome. His block resulted in a penalty kick that Ghana missed; it did not ''all but eliminate Ghana.'' (Uruguay won in a shootout.)

RAUSEN--Aaron, MD, 80, of New York City and Westport, CT, died July 7, of pancreatic cancer. Dr. Rausen, known as "Paca" to his grandchildren, was born in Jersey City, NJ, June 29, 1930, the son of David and Ruth Rausen. He grew up in New York City. He attended Stuyvesant High School in New York City, Dartmouth College from 1947-1950 and left prior to graduation to attend State University of New York on a full tuition scholarship where he received an MD degree in 1954. Dartmouth awarded Dr. Rausen the Spirit of '51 award and an honorary degree. Dr Rausen dedicated his professional life to finding the causes of, treating, and curing cancer, leukemia, AIDS and blood disorders in children. In 1990, he was named The Founding Director of The Stephen D. Hassenfeld Children's Center for cancer and Blood Disorders at New York University Medical Center. His passion, dedication, curiosity and unwavering conviction that giving up is not an option greatly contributed in the reversing of the 80%-20% death to cure ration among childhood blood disorders within his lifetime. He continued to research, teach and treat patients until his death. Among Dr. Rausen's extensive board memberships, he served as a director of the American Cancer Society, The National Childhood Cancer Foundation, The Children's Oncology Society of New York, The Ovarian Cancer Research Fund, and The Ronald McDonald House. Paca was truly a renaissance man. A voracious reader, a formidable squash opponent who loved music and a loyal friend and mentor, he enhanced our lives and the world. He met his wife Emalou Watkins, a well-known fashion designer, in August of 1966 at a dinner party, which was hosted by his former girlfriend whose intention was to introduce them. They were married in April of 1968. Aaron was a devoted husband, father and grandfather who loved his family with all his heart. He is survived by his wife of 42 years, his children David of Fort Collins CO, Susan of Darien and New York City and Elisabeth of Quincy MA, and grandchildren Alfred (Freddy), Katherine (Kricket), and Annabelle. Dr. Rausen's younger brother, Milton, died of Polio in 1943. Among Dr. Rausen's extensive board memberships, he served as a director of the American Cancer Society, The National Childhood Cancer Foundation, The Children's Oncology Society of New York, The Ovarian Cancer Research Fund, and The Ronald McDonald House. Paca was truly a renaissance man. A voracious reader, a formidable squash opponent who loved music and a loyal friend and mentor, he enhanced our lives and the world. A private burial service will be held at New Montifiore Cemetery on Long Island. Shiva will be conducted at 17 Nolen Lane Darien, CT 06820, 347-835-7074 at sun down on July 14 and 15. A memorial service will be held 5pm, Monday, July 19 at The Yale Club of New York City. In lieu of flowers, memorial gifts can be made in the form of donations to the Aaron R. Rausen Endowed Chair of Pediatric Hematology/Oncology at NYU School of medicine and its associated research fund. Contact: Colby Collier. VP of Development NYU Langone Medical Center, 1 Park Ave. NY, NY 10016.

WILSON--K.C.,64, died Tuesday, July 6, at his home in Versailles, KY after a short illness. Born in Miami, Wilson, a professional actor, was a veteran of Broadway, regional theatre and television including "The Passion of Dracula" in New York and national tours of "1776" and "Grand Hotel". He lived in New York for 25 years before moving to Kentucky. Memorial donations to Hospice of the Bluegrass, 2312 Alexandria Drive, Lexington, KY 40504.

An article on Thursday about a Guantánamo Bay detainee who pleaded guilty to terrorism charges misstated the outcome of a case against a former Guantánamo Bay detainee, Salim Hamdan, on a charge of providing material support for terrorism. Mr. Hamdan was found guilty of that charge in 2008 following a trial before a military commission. He did not plead guilty.

WILES--Harold E.,63, of Miller Place, NY, passed at North Shore University Hospital, on Wednesday evening, July 7, 2010. Harold was born in Brooklyn, NY in September of 1946, the son of Edith and Meyer Wiles. He was a passionate and loyal member of the Local 3 Electrical Union in New York City for 44 years. He retired in October of 2008. He is survived by his sons, Eric and Michael Wiles, Michael's wife, Ilana, and his seven month old granddaughter, Mazzy Rose. He is also survived by his sister and brother-in-law, Judith and Joseph Cohen; his nephew, Adam Cohen and wife Robyn; their children, Reyna and Aaron; his niece, Lisa Cohen and her husband Win Thin; their children, Anna, Daniel, and Gabriel; and his niece, Elyssa Cohen. Lastly, he is survived by his former wife and close friend, Toby Wiles. Funeral Service Friday, July 9, 2010, 10am at I.J. Morris, Dix Hills, NY. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to The American Heart Association.

FORLINES--John Arthur, Jr. of Granite Falls, NC on July 6 at the age of 92. A pioneering figure in community banking, John Forlines was Chairman and CEO of The Bank of Granite until he retired in 2006. He served as Chairman of the North Carolina Bankers Association, was inducted into the North Carolina Business Hall of Fame and the North Carolina Bankers Hall of Fame. A graduate of Duke University (1939), he served two terms as Trustee at Duke, was a past president of the Duke Alumni Association, served on the board of DUMC, and was a member of the Duke Athletics Advisory Board. He was awarded the Duke University Medal for Distinguished Meritorious Service in 2008. A WWII veteran, John's passion for civic service and education matched his business acumen. He was a former President of the North Carolina Chamber of commerce, Chairman of the State Board of Community Colleges and on the Board of Directors of Lenoir-Rhyne University Business Council, the Governor's Business Council on the Arts and Humanities and was a leader in the founding of Caldwell County's Hospice and Palliative Care. He was inducted into the Order of the Long Leaf Pine, the state of North Carolina's highest accolade, awarded the Ernst&Young Entrepreneur of the Year Award, and the Terry Sanford Lifetime Achievement Award. Preceded in death by his wife, Julia Dunn Forlines, and his sister, Ruth Forlines Dailey. Survived by sister Martha Lane Forney of Shelby, NC, children Judith Tarleton (husband Jim), Joy Crosby (husband David) and Jane Forlines of Hickory, NC, and John A. Forlines III (wife Anne) of Locust Valley, NY, as well as grandchildren Phillip Couch, Laurel and John David Crosby, Justin and Julia Greenhill, and Megan, Molly and Jack Forlines. The family will receive friends at Greer-McElveen Funeral Home in Lenoir, NC on Friday from 6-8. Memorial service at First Presbyterian Church in Lenoir at 11am Saturday, July 10. In lieu of flowers, memorial tributes may be sent to Caldwell Community College and Technical Institute (the Foundation of CCCTI, P.O. Box 600, Lenoir, NC 28645) or Caldwell County Hospice and Palliative Care (902 Kirkwood, Lenoir, NC 28645).
CARRAGHER--Owen B. All of us at Podell, Schwartz, Schechter & Banfield, LLP mourn the passing of our colleague Owen Carragher, Sr. and extend our sympathies to the family he loved and who loved him.

LITT--Charlotte (nee Sturtz) 93, of Harrison, NY, died July 7. Wife of the late Herbert Litt. Bronx born, survived by brother Sidney, four children, Eric and Janice, Elan, Arni, Alix and Steven Prince, five grandchildren, seven great- grandchildren. Hunter College graduate; playwright, songwriter, professional dancer, dog trainer, bird trainer; the life of the party. Hostess to Hadassah, Ort, UJA, founding member of Harrison JCC, and with "Herbie" active in the Democratic Party. Always ahead of the times, she marched on Washington for women's rights. Mom will be greatly missed. A private service will be held.

FUCHSBERG--Rosalee. A blessed memory past at age 86 at home with boundless courage and dignity surrounded by her family on July 6, 2010. Her strength, generosity, kindness and brilliant talents enriched all who knew her. Beloved wife of the late Meyer Fuchsberg; adored mother of Adele and Bill; Marsha and Doug; loving grandmother of Lenny, Elizabeth, David, Meredith, Michael, Megan, Anitra, Julius and Elyssa. Loved great-grandmother of Stephen, Max, Adam Jay, Myla, Elle and Aaron. Respected older sister of George and Dora; Pearl and Ralph. Her memory will live on through all who knew her.

Because of an editing error, an Associated Press article on June 26 about a tornado in Bridgeport, Conn., quoted incorrectly from comments by a woman who was affected. The woman, Lizzette Alvarez, said ''The roof came off in front of my house,'' not ''in front of her house.''

EMIL--Arthur D.,died peacefully on July 6, 2010. Active and vigorous throughout his life, Arthur had joined a new law firm just after his 85th birthday, played in a golf tournament with his daughter and sister three weeks ago, and spent the weekend before his death surrounded by family at his home in Rye, New York. Born in Brooklyn on Avenue M in 1924, Arthur was a graduate of Lawrenceville School, Yale University '45W, and Columbia Law School. During WWII, he served in the US Navy aboard a Destroyer Escort in the North Atlantic. An ardent sailor, Arthur was a member of the New York Yacht Club and the American Yacht Club. With his ocean racing sloop "Artemis", he competed in many off shore and distance races such as the Admiral's Cup and the SORC. In his younger days, Arthur had a single digit handicap in golf; he was an enthusiastic member of the Century Country Club. Known for his philanthropic efforts, Arthur was a member of the Executive Committee of Montefiore Medical Center, and served as president of the American Federation of the Arts, co-chairman of the board of trustees of the Brooklyn Academy of Music, and on numerous other philanthropic boards. Arthur practiced law for 60 years, specializing in providing counsel to remarkable entrepreneurs and their ventures. In some instances he joined his clients in their projects, including a collaboration with the legendary restaurateur Joe Baum in which the Baum and Emil families operated the Rainbow Room and Windows on the World. Arthur was a visionary real estate developer whose projects included the conversion of the Police Building in lower Manhattan, the restoration of the Guaranty Building in Buffalo, and the development of Harbor Plaza in Stamford. Arthur's greatest commitment in life was to his family. His first wife, Jane Allen Emil, with whom he had three children, died in 1973. Arthur married Lydia Moffat dePolo on July 6th, 1976 and welcomed her daughter into the family. He is survived by his wife Lydia, his children David, Jennie, and Suzanne, and stepdaughter Adrianne, their spouses, and their children, Catherine and Andrew Emil, Andrew Deutschman, Jane and Anna Pleskunas, Key and Carina Becker, and his sister Judy Emil Tenney. A true lover of the long shot, never afraid to risk it all, Arthur's vitality, strength and generosity will provide enduring inspiration to his family and his friends. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Children's Library at Northside Center for Child Development, New York, NY, or the Children's Hospital at Montefiore Medical Center, Bronx, NY.

EMIL--Arthur. To the loving tribute to Arthur Emil that appeared yesterday, we would like to add one critical fact that did not make it into that first account. Arthur had one request regarding his obituary, that in addition to his many accomplishments, he was especially proud of the fact that he was a lifetime, card carrying member of the Diner's Club. We mourn his passing and will miss him and his wonderful humor deeply. The Becker, Deutschman, Emil and Pleskunas families

10 P.M. (BBC America) THE GREAT FOOTBALL GIVEAWAY In 2000 Paul Clarke, an advertising executive, and his wife, Sarah, were visiting Malawi on a holiday when they noticed children playing with makeshift soccer balls made of layers of plastic bags bound together with string. The Clarkes vowed to return with real soccer balls. Since founding their charity, the Great Football Giveaway, in 2006, they have hand-delivered tens of thousands of soccer balls to impoverished children in Malawi, Uganda, Angola, Rwanda and Congo. This documentary tells the couple's story while celebrating the joy found in the simple act of kicking a ball around. ''I accepted that I'm not a doctor who can administer anti-retroviral drugs, I can't build wells and I'm not an engineer,'' Mr. Clarke has said of his endeavors. ''But I could find a way to help put smiles on kids' faces'' -- and perhaps save lives at the same time. With the help of the Clarkes' charity, a soccer program is being used to help rehabilitate child soldiers in Congo. 7 P.M. (National Geographic) NAT GEO AMAZING! Starting with ''Killer Swarms and Urban Penguins,'' this new series explores some of nature's surprising wonders.

An article on Monday about the visit of Queen Elizabeth II to New York City referred imprecisely to a ferry she rode during a visit in 1957. While the ferry transported her between Staten Island and Manhattan, it was an Army ferry, not the Staten Island Ferry. The article also referred incorrectly to her attendance at the Kentucky Derby. She has done so just once, in 2007 -- not ''frequently.''

KOPLEWICZ--Joseph. The Board and staff of the Child Mind Institute are deeply saddened by the loss of Joseph Koplewicz, the father of our organization's president, Dr. Harold S. Koplewicz. Joseph, 94, died on the evening of July 4. A man of enormous courage and integrity, Joseph lived a life of uncommon bravery. He was, until his death, among the last survivors of the Warsaw Ghetto Uprising. Joseph was a man who kept beating the odds. He became the quintessential, self-made American. He embodied the American dream and fell in love with the United States for the freedom, hope, and opportunities it gave him and his beloved wife, Roma. Joseph touched the hearts of all who knew him with his sparkle, energy, and love of life. Everyone at the Child Mind Institute will always be grateful for Joseph's faith in and commitment to children's mental health as well as for the support and love he gave Harold. He was a remarkable supporter of the Child Mind Institute, as well as the NYU Child Study Center and the U.S. Holocaust Memorial Museum. We extend condolences to his son Harold and his wife Linda Sirow; his daughter Edith; his dear friend Janet; grandsons Joshua, Adam, and Sam Koplewicz and Alex Usi. Brooke Garber Neidich Chair Child Mind Institute Debra Perelman Vice Chair Child Mind Institute

May, Chairman, Boards of Trustees, The Mount Sinai Medical Center Kenneth L. Davis, M.D., President and CEO, The Mount Sinai Medical Center

An obituary on Monday about Louis Moyroud, one of the creators of the first practical phototypesetting machine, misstated the role that the 15th-century inventor Johannes Gutenberg played in the development of movable type. He invented a method of printing from movable type that sped up book production in Europe; he did not invent movable type itself. (It originated in Asia centuries earlier.)

KANE--Donald Harris, 74, passed away after a courageous struggle with lung cancer. A graduate of Cornell and Columbia, Don practiced as an attorney in San Francisco. He was pre-deceased by his wife Regina, but is survived by his soul mate Duffy Murphy of 10 years, his son David and daughter-in-law Shelley, granddaughter Jordan Kratzer, many cousins and by Duffy's family members. Contributions in Don's memory may be sent to the FAU/ LLS Foundation, 5353 Parkside Dr., Jupiter, FL 33458.

TASSO--Paula Helen Hollmen, 87 of New York, NY, died peacefully on July 7, 2010. Originally from Detroit, Paula was a graduate of Wayne State University and worked with Walter Reuther and the UAW in the 1940's before moving to New York. During her life she was a political activist working for the environment and both racial and economic justice. Paula worked with the Women's International League for Peace and Freedom for 16 years as both WILPF's United Nations Representative and also as a member of the National Board. She was twice invited to the former Soviet Union to present workshops on The Bruntland Report for an international environmental study. She later covered the U.N. Nuclear Disarmament Committee. Paula wrote a regular United Nations column for Peace & Freedom. Predeceased by her beloved husband, Charles A. Tasso, she is survived by her children David and Kaarli Tasso, sister Kaarli Bowers, nieces Anila and Amy Bowers and grandniece Kate Bowers. In lieu of flowers, please make contributions to the Women's International League for Peace and Freedom, 565 Boylston St., 2nd flr, Boston, MA 02116.

Funeral services at Beth Moses Cemetery, Friday, July 9, 2010 at 11:30am. Gitenstein. Dear sister of Judith Ann Gitenstein, Henry Joshua Gitenstein (Harriet), and the late Ross George Gitenstein. Loving aunt of Eric and Maxwell Gitenstein, and friend to many. Siegel.

An article last Friday about the lobbyist Tony Podesta described incorrectly the Securities and Exchange Commission's jurisdiction over Prosper Marketplace, a lender represented by Mr. Podesta. Under an administrative settlement with Prosper, notes issued by Prosper are already considered investments subject to S.E.C. registration; the company is not ''worried about the prospect of coming under the jurisdiction'' of the S.E.C. (As part of the financial regulatory overhaul, however, Congressional negotiators agreed to a one-year study examining how such lenders should be regulated.)

A chart in some editions on Monday with an article about Miroslav Klose of Germany and his career World Cup goals misstated the number of goals he scored for his team in 2006. It was five, not six. (He also scored five in 2002 and four in 2010. The chart correctly noted that his overall total is 14.)

Jim Bohlen, whose snap decision to sail to Amchitka Island, Alaska, to protest an underground nuclear test led to the creation of the environmental organization Greenpeace, died Monday in Comox, British Columbia. He was 84 and lived in Courtenay, British Columbia. The cause was complications of Parkinson's disease, his daughter, Margot Bradley, said.

TRACHTENBERG--Inge (nee Wachenheimer) of Englewood, NJ on July 3, 2010, beloved wife of Mike and mother of Michael, David and Shoshanah, of blessed memory, passed away at age 86 after a long illness which she endured with characteristic dignity and boundless courage. Her strength, generosity, kindness and love enriched her family which included eight grandchildren and five great-grandchildren as well as her community in which she was a forceful, visionary and dedicated leader. The author of three books and numerous short stories and poems, she opened a window to her soul and taught us how, with love and compassion, we can survive and even flourish through unspeakable horrors, whether they are engendered by the Holocaust or by family illness. Truly a role model for the modern woman, her life has been an inspiration and she will live on through the memory of all who had the good fortune of knowing her.

As in every season, the selection of All-Stars has led to much discussion and debate among fans and columnists. Players like Joey Votto, Kevin Youkilis and Jered Weaver were initially left off their leagues' rosters, and curious alternatives like Omar Infante, Ryan Howard and Ty Wigginton made the teams. Some of this debate stems from the bizarre edict from the major league office that a 35-man roster must have a utility player. (My preferred option would be to name two or three emergency players and allow them to enter the game only in case of an injury or extra innings.) The rest of the debate falls along the definition of who has had the best season.
MANNING--Richard. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Richard Manning, associated with The New York Times from April 1, 1963 until retiring on January 1, 1992.

CALAMANDREI--Mauro, of New York, New York died on Wednesday (July 7) at the age of 85 after a brief illness. He was born on March 5, 1925 in Florence, Italy and served bravely in the anti-fascist Italian underground during WWII. He earned his first Ph.D. at the University of Florence in 1947. In 1949 he became one of the very first Italians to be awarded a Fulbright scholarship to study in the US. While he was studying at the University of Chicago he was invited to join the Committee on Social Thought. And earned a Ph.D. for his research re Roger Williams and the History of American Religion in 1953. Early in his career, Mauro taught at the Juilliard School of Music, Middlebury College and the University of Florence. Soon he discovered his true love and passion and began writing articles and books about politics, art and culture in the United States. He wrote numerous books and articles over the years but was best known for his years as the American Correspondent for the Italian magazine L'Espresso. And more recently for his articles for the prestigious newspaper Il Sole 24 Ore. After 62 years in the United States, Mauro became a United States citizen in 2009. Mauro was an esteemed writer and intellectual, with a warm, welcoming, generous personality, who was much loved by many friends. Mauro died surrounded by loving family. He is survived by his sister Anna Bagnoli and niece Emanuela Bencini in Florence, Italy; his long time companion Pauline Pinto, his daughter Camilla, son-in-law David Rudofsky and grandson Marcello, Camilla's mother Judith and uncle Philip Schneider. A memorial service to celebrate his life will be held on Sunday, July 11 at 4pm at the Frank Campbell Chapel at 1076 Madison Avenue (81st street), NYC.

BARBER--Sherburne F.,Southbury, CT. Professor Emeritus of City College of New York died July 4th at age 102. He is survived by his wife, three sons, and five grandchildren. For more details visit www.munsonloveterefuneral home.com

Until the 1950s a wide variety of lampposts stood along New York streets, from cast-iron Gilded Age masterpieces to humble Depression-era wood beams -- a 1934 city catalog listed 76 styles. But in the wave of postwar urban renewal, the city embarked on a wave of consolidation, trading its diversity for a monoculture based on stark octagonal aluminum poles anchored to the ground by plain boxes. Fortunately, a few of the old lampposts survived, and in recent years they've been joined by a small army of newly cast replicas. In addition, the Department of Transportation continues to commission new designs; recently, it introduced a sleek and shiny model in Downtown Brooklyn. As the city's lamppost culture comes back to life, it's worth taking a look at some of the iconic forms that illuminated New York's past. 1. Fulton, Fulton Mall, Brooklyn

You get reminded of the fun you had when you were first learning the basic rules but you need to concentrate in new ways. SHONTZ--Hilary Morton, filled with grace and courage, passed away on July 7, 2010, after a long illness. Hilary was born on February 5, 1958, in New York City. She moved to the Cathedral Close of St. John the Divine in 1972, where her family lived for 25 years. Hilary attended Spence School and Colby College, and married David in 1986. After working as an executive recruiter, and an event planner for the Metropolitan Opera, Hilary chose to stay home to raise her two children, Harry and Jamie, whom she treasured above all else. Hilary is survived by her two children, Harry and Jamie, her husband David, her sisters, Polly, Sophia and Maria, and her parents James and Pamela. All of her family and all of her friends will always be thankful for the years they shared, the happiness she brought to their lives, and the dignity with which she faced her long struggle. She will be in their hearts forever. There will be a memorial service on Monday, July 12, 2010, at 10:30am. at The Cathedral of St. John the Divine, 1047 Amsterdam Avenue (at 112th Street) in New York City. In lieu of flowers, anyone who wishes may make a donation to The Interfaith Center of New York, 475 Riverside Drive, Suite 540, New York, NY 10115. (www.interfaithcenter.org).

A friend recently mentioned to me that he was considering using Mint.com but was worried whether he should trust the site with his bank account information. To take advantage of Mint.com's money tracking services, you need to enter your bank account user names and passwords so Mint.com can keep track of how much you're spending and saving. This raises the question of how safe sharing that data is and how easy it may be for someone to get that information from Mint.com and then use it to log into your accounts and swipe out your money.

At a dingy basement rock show in in Ridgewood, Queens, on Thursday night, a member of the band Run DMT stepped from behind the mikes and toward the crowd. As the guitars shrilled, he began to smear red paint violently across his face. He then lofted a bottle of pancake syrup over his head and poured it down his body, squirting it into his ears. Next, he stuck Monopoly money to the ooze, and capped off the performance by sucking down a whole mango. The audience cheered. It was a typical evening, guests said, at the house-turned-concert space on Wyckoff Avenue known as Silent Barn.

RAUSEN--Aaron, MD, 80, of New York City and Westport, CT, died July 7, of pancreatic cancer. Dr. Rausen, known as "Paca" to his grandchildren, was born in Jersey City, NJ, June 29, 1930, the son of David and Ruth Rausen. He grew up in New York City. He attended Stuyvesant High School in New York City, Dartmouth College from 1947-1950 and left prior to graduation to attend State University of New York on a full tuition scholarship where he received an MD degree in 1954. Dartmouth awarded Dr. Rausen the Spirit of '51 award and an honorary degree. Dr Rausen dedicated his professional life to finding the causes of, treating, and curing cancer, leukemia, AIDS and blood disorders in children. In 1990, he was named The Founding Director of The Stephen D. Hassenfeld Children's Center for cancer and Blood Disorders at New York University Medical Center. His passion, dedication, curiosity and unwavering conviction that giving up is not an option greatly contributed in the reversing of the 80%-20% death to cure ration among childhood blood disorders within his lifetime. He continued to research, teach and treat patients until his death. Among Dr. Rausen's extensive board memberships, he served as a director of the American Cancer Society, The National Childhood Cancer Foundation, The Children's Oncology Society of New York, The Ovarian Cancer Research Fund, and The Ronald McDonald House. Paca was truly a renaissance man. A voracious reader, a formidable squash opponent who loved music and a loyal friend and mentor, he enhanced our lives and the world. He met his wife Emalou Watkins, a well-known fashion designer, in August of 1966 at a dinner party, which was hosted by his former girlfriend whose intention was to introduce them. They were married in April of 1968. Aaron was a devoted husband, father and grandfather who loved his family with all his heart. He is survived by his wife of 42 years, his children David of Fort Collins CO, Susan of Darien and New York City and Elisabeth of Quincy MA, and grandchildren Alfred (Freddy), Katherine (Kricket), and Annabelle. Dr. Rausen's younger brother, Milton, died of Polio in 1943. Among Dr. Rausen's extensive board memberships, he served as a director of the American Cancer Society, The National Childhood Cancer Foundation, The Children's Oncology Society of New York, The Ovarian Cancer Research Fund, and The Ronald McDonald House. Paca was truly a renaissance man. A voracious reader, a formidable squash opponent who loved music and a loyal friend and mentor, he enhanced our lives and the world. A funeral service will be held at 10:30am on Sunday, July 11 at New Montifiore Cemetery on Long Island. Shiva will be on Tuesday July 13, 11am-5pm and 7-9pm at 176 Compo Road South, Westport, CT and 5-9pm on July 14 and 15 at 17 Nolen Lane, Darien, CT 06820. A memorial service will be held 5pm, Monday, July 19 at The Yale Club of New York City. In lieu of flowers, memorial gifts can be made in the form of donations to the Aaron R. Rausen Endowed Chair of Pediatric Hematology/Oncology at NYU School of medicine and its associated research fund. Contact: Colby Collier. VP of Development NYU Langone Medical Center, 1 Park Ave. NY, NY 10016.

(TCM) FILMED IN MONUMENT VALLEY A night of movies from out West, all directed by John Ford, begins with ''My Darling Clementine'' (1946), which stars Henry Fonda (above with Cathy Downs) in a retelling of Wyatt Earp's feud with the Clantons after they steal his cattle and kill his brother. In the courtroom drama ''Sergeant Rutledge'' (1960), at 10, a black sergeant (Woody Strode) is accused of raping and killing a white woman. At midnight John Wayne plays a Civil War veteran in search of his niece, who was captured by American Indians, in ''The Searchers'' (1956). At 2:15 a.m. ''She Wore a Yellow Ribbon'' (1949) follows a cavalry officer (John Wayne) as he tries to stymie an Indian uprising in the days before his retirement. In ''Stagecoach'' (1939), at 4:15 a.m., Wayne portrays a fugitive who hitches a ride on a stagecoach rambling through perilous Apache territory. 10:30 A.M. (13) RELIGION & ETHICS NEWSWEEKLY A profile of Lincoln Electric, an arc-welding manufacturer that has not laid off an employee for economic reasons for 60 years. Also, an interview with the ''Mutts'' cartoonist Patrick McDonnell, and an exploration of the moral implications of the Gulf of Mexico oil spill with Paul Root Wolpe, director of the Emory Center for Ethics at Emory University.

FORLINES--John Arthur, Jr. of Granite Falls, NC on July 6 at the age of 92. A pioneering figure in community banking, John Forlines was Chairman and CEO of The Bank of Granite until he retired in 2006. He served as Chairman of the North Carolina Bankers Association, was inducted into the North Carolina Business Hall of Fame and the North Carolina Bankers Hall of Fame. A graduate of Duke University (1939), he served two terms as Trustee at Duke, was a past president of the Duke Alumni Association, served on the board of DUMC, and was a member of the Duke Athletics Advisory Board. He was awarded the Duke University Medal for Distinguished Meritorious Service in 2008. A WWII veteran, John's passion for civic service and education matched his business acumen. He was a former President of the North Carolina Chamber of commerce, Chairman of the State Board of Community Colleges and on the Board of Directors of Lenoir-Rhyne University Business Council, the Governor's Business Council on the Arts and Humanities and was a leader in the founding of Caldwell County's Hospice and Palliative Care. He was inducted into the Order of the Long Leaf Pine, the state of North Carolina's highest accolade, awarded the Ernst&Young Entrepreneur of the Year Award, and the Terry Sanford Lifetime Achievement Award. Preceded in death by his wife, Julia Dunn Forlines, and his sister, Ruth Forlines Dailey. Survived by sister Martha Lane Forney of Shelby, NC, children Judith Tarleton (husband Jim), Joy Crosby (husband David) and Jane Forlines of Hickory, NC, and John A. Forlines III (wife Anne) of Locust Valley, NY, as well as grandchildren Phillip Couch, Laurel and John David Crosby, Justin and Julia Greenhill, and Megan, Molly and Jack Forlines. The family will receive friends at Greer-McElveen Funeral Home in Lenoir, NC on Friday from 6-8. Memorial service at First Presbyterian Church in Lenoir at 11am Saturday, July 10. In lieu of flowers, memorial tributes may be sent to Caldwell Community College and Technical Institute (the Foundation of CCCTI, P.O. Box 600, Lenoir, NC 28645) or Caldwell County Hospice and Palliative Care (902 Kirkwood, Lenoir, NC 28645).

Joshua Henry, a co-star of ''American Idiot,'' will play Haywood Patterson in the Broadway production of ''The Scottsboro Boys,'' the Kander and Ebb musical that begins previews on Oct. 7 at the Lyceum Theater. Brandon Victor Dixon, who won praise for the role when the show made its debut in February at the Vineyard Theater, Off Broadway, is to play Ray Charles in ''Unchain My Heart: The Ray Charles Musical.'' ''The Scottsboro Boys'' uses the style of a minstrel show to tell the true story of young black men convicted in 1930s Alabama on false charges of raping two white women. Mr. Henry, who plays the flamboyant Favorite Son, among other parts, in Broadway's ''American Idiot,'' will join 10 cast members from the Vineyard production, including Colman Domingo and Forrest McClendon. Before it arrives on Broadway, ''The Scottsboro Boys'' will play July 31 through Sept. 25 at the Guthrie Theater in Minneapolis. On Friday, ''Unchain My Heart'' producers said that the musical would delay its opening to next spring from Nov. 7, for ''logistical reasons.''

GEISLER--Barry, 77, died peacefully at home in New York City with his wife Lisa Stark, his children, family and friends at his side on Thursday, July 8, 2010 of prostate cancer which was first diagnosed in 1992. Considered the founding father of "age group running" for youth in the United States, Mr. Geisler, a father of six, began coaching his children in 1963. His sons were accomplished age group runners, including his oldest son, Barry, who ran a marathon in 3:17 at age 12. The gratification he received running with and teaching his children led him to work with other children who wanted to run. Mr. Geisler started children's age group cross country races in 1964 for boys and girls. At that time there were no middle distance races for girls in the country. In 1966 he started the first national age group cross-country championship in Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx which became the premiere running event for children for decades. Barry was an early member of the New York Road Runners Club and was its President in 1971-72 and founder of its Age Group Program. His greatest running achievement was as founder and coach of the Millrose Athletic Association's Age Group Track Team from 1980-1995. In the 1980's the children won more major individual and team awards than any other team in the nation. He was the coach of All American champions Nnenna and Shola Lynch. A proud son of the Bronx, Barry was the first child of Else Kunze and Arthur Geisler. He was born on December 25, 1932. Nine children followed. He served with the 101st Airborne Division in the Korean War. Barry worked in meat distribution and packing for more than forty years. He retired as a shop steward with Amalgamated Butchers Wholesale Local 174 in the Bronx at Hunts Point. Coach Geisler is survived by his wife Lisa and his children, Barry, Jr., Yonkers, NY; Eric, Nanuet, NY; Lee, Sarasota, FL; Ronald, Poughkeepsie, NY; Gina Daley, Pleasant Valey, NY; Jessica Toreno, Spokane, WA; 17 grandchildren and five great-grandchildren. He also is survived by his siblings Beverly Traver, Elizabeth Hogan, Judith Hornbeck, Joseph Conrad, and Daniel, Kenneth and Leonard Geisler. Services were held on Friday, July 9th at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel in New York City. Burial followed at Roosevelt Memorial Park in Trevose, PA. Shiva will be held at the residence. Friends are invited to visit Saturday, July 10 from 3-7pm and on Sunday, July 11 from noon to 5pm. In lieu of flowers, contributions to the Prostate Cancer Foundation (PCF) 1250 Fourth St, Santa Monica, CA 90401, would be appreciated.

A truly astounding thing happened Thursday night: with LeBron James's ''The Decision'' universally expected to be a cultural low point, the moment sports stardom turned into pure narcissism and sports journalism turned into pure schlock, it managed to come in under expectations. People expected James's hour-long circus to be horrendous; it was worse. Outside of a small giddy patch in South Florida where James's decision was greeted by clinking of mojito glasses, the rest of the landscape is strewn with the wreckage.

LINSLEY--Julia W. The employees of Fiduciary Trust Company International mourn the loss of our friend and colleague Julia "June" Linsley. June joined Fiduciary Trust in the early 1960s and for more than 30 years ably managed investments for clients. She was an astute investor, highly regarded by her colleagues and loyal clients and fondly remembered for her grace and wit. An ardent supporter of the arts and education, June was a firm believer in life through service, a philosophy that she brought to work each day. We extend our deepest sympathies to her family. A picture caption on Thursday with an obituary about Juanita M. Kreps, who was President Jimmy Carter's secretary of commerce from 1977 to 1979, referred incorrectly to Mr. Carter. When the photograph of Ms. Kreps with Mr. Carter was taken, in December 1976, he was the president-elect; he was not yet president.

An article in the Square Feet pages on Wednesday about the new Expo light rail line under construction in Los Angeles described two stations near the University of Southern California incorrectly. They will be at street grade, not underground, although the train will travel below street level between the two stations, Jefferson/USC and Expo Park/USC. (A third street-grade station will also be near the university.)

LEFKOWITZ--Morris, 97, beloved husband of the late Lillian nee Herman Shuter, survived by devoted companion Leona Schneider, sister Mary Mintz, twin sons Michael and Gary (Dolores), stepsons Eli (Renni) Shuter and Bruce (Janis) Shuter, eight grandchildren and 10 great-grandchildren. Sunday's World Cup final was rendered a mere formality on Friday as Paul the Psychic Octopus chose Spain to beat Netherlands in the tournament final. Working from his aquarium tank in Oberhausen, Germany, the sage cephalopod, whose record in predicting international soccer matches since 2008 stands at 10-1, made its choice before a bank of cameras from several television networks. On Thursday The Lede blog explained that the multitalented mollusk's accurate prophecy that Spain would defeat Germany to advance to the final had resulted in death threats from outraged German fans.

Sometimes it's useful to step back slightly from the current fray and ask what we've really learned about macroeconomics over, say, the past year and a half. Here's how I see it: in early 2009 there was a broad divide between two policy factions. One, of which I was part, declared that we were in a liquidity trap, which meant that some of the usual rules no longer applied: the expansion of the Fed's balance sheet wouldn't be inflationary -- in fact the danger was a slide toward deflation; the government's borrowing would not lead to a spike in interest rates. The other side declared that we were in imminent danger of runaway inflation, and that federal borrowing would lead to very high interest rates.

In Spain earlier this month, the Catalonian assembly narrowly rejected a proposed ban on the Muslim burqa in all public places - reversing a vote the week before in the country's upper house of parliament supporting a ban. Similar proposals may soon become national law in France and Belgium.  Even the headscarf often causes trouble.  In France, girls may not wear it in school.  In Germany (as in parts of Belgium and the Netherlands) some regions forbid public school teachers to wear it on the job, although nuns and priests are permitted to teach in full habit.  What does political philosophy have to say about these developments?   As it turns out, a long philosophical and legal tradition has reflected about similar matters.

Visitors to Rome often marvel at the astonishing integration of ancient structures into the city's modern fabric. Shops, an embassy and a gelateria all sit atop the ruins of a first-century stadium; apartments lean on the Theater of Marcellus; even the mayor's office claims a Republican-era records hall as its foundation. LINSLEY--Julia W. The employees of Fiduciary Trust Company International mourn the loss of our friend and colleague Julia "June" Linsley. June joined Fiduciary Trust in the early 1960s and for more than 30 years ably managed investments for clients. She was an astute investor, highly regarded by her colleagues and loyal clients and fondly remembered for her grace and wit. An ardent supporter of the arts and education, June was a firm believer in life through service, a philosophy that she brought to work each day. We extend our deepest sympathies to her family. Board of Directors
MURRAY HILL CO-OP $799,000
COS COB COLONIAL $1,695,000

PAGE--Robert W.,Sr. Robert W. (Bob) Page died peacefully after a long illness at his home in Georgetown. He held numerous positions of great sensitivity and responsibility throughout his highly varied public service career, including Assistant Secretary of the Army for Civil Works, Chairman of The Panama Canal Commission. He was also a member of President Reagan's Export Council and President George H. W. Bush's Domestic Policy Council. Mr. Page was a veteran of WWII, serving in the Navy in the Pacific theater of operations and was involved in covert assignments in the Middle East and Central America. He was one of the original Navy Seals known at that time as UDT or Underwater Demolition Teams and received honorable discharges from The Navy, Marines and The Army (Airborne). Mr. Page was a pioneer in modern American civil engineering planning and project management. He served in several capacities with Kellogg Rust, Inc., including chairman and chief executive officer, 1982 - 1987; president and chief executive officer with M.W. Kellogg Co., 1981 - 1983; and president and chief executive officer for Kellogg Rust, Inc., 1983 - 1984. From 1976 to 1981, he was president and chief executive officer with the Rust Engineering Co. He was president and chief executive officer for George A. Fuller Co., 1972 - 1976, and vice president of construction for Rockefeller Family and Associates, 1967 - 1972. He was assistant general manager for the Bechtel Corp., 1962 - 1967, and vice president for the Southeast Drilling Co., 1961 - 1962. He also held positions with Bechtel, ARAMCO, McDermott International, and was a member of the Turkish American Business Council. In 1988, he was honored as the National Association of Professional Engineers "Man of the Year" in Construction. Mr. Page graduated with an Engineering Degree from Texas A&M University. He served as an Assistant Professor of Engineering at The American University of Beirut in the 1950s and more recently taught at The American University in Washington, DC and The Massachusetts Institute of Technology in Boston, MA. and was an adjunct professor at Georgetown University, MBA School. He was the author of well received novels, "Ambush Ever Lies", "Chain" and "The Vow". He is survived by his wife of 57 years, Nancy Eaton Page, sons David Benfer Eaton Page of Cleveland, OH, Mark Tyler Page of Little Compton, RI and daughter, (Meg) Margaret Penrose Page of Rockville, MD, and three granddaughters, Keegan Taylor Page and Addison McKenna Page the daughters of Mark Page, and Riley Page McIlvaine the daughter of Meg Page. A private service will be held in Rye, NY in late July; a memorial service in Washington, DC in September.

As I was running up the outdoor steps to my doctor's office on Staten Island recently, I saw the succulent trailing tendrils of purslane growing nearby. As far as I could see across the dry, scorched lawn, purslane was the only plant thriving in the brutal summer heat. Purslane sprawls low to the ground on thick red stems that radiate out from its center, resembling a wee jade plant. When I first started reading about this amazingly tenacious edible, I confused it with all sorts of common ground cover, like sedum. But after discovering patches of it growing in cracks in the sidewalks in Park Slope, Brooklyn, and in friends' backyards, I now find its meandering magenta-colored stems and flat paddle-shaped leaves unmistakable.

RAUSEN--Aaron R.,M.D. 1930-2010. The Board of Directors, Staff, and Supporters of the Ovarian Cancer Research Fund are profoundly saddened by the passing of Aaron R. Rausen, one of our earliest Scientific Advisory Committee Members. Dr. Rausen, a noted Pediatric Oncologist helped guide OCRF through its infancy. His thoughtful recommendations and guidance helped ultimately to secure our robust contribution to the national effort to overcome the most lethal gynecologic cancer. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his family, close colleagues and patients. Faith Kates Kogan, President Sol Schreiber, Esq., Founder & Co-Chair, Carmel J. Cohen, M.D., Chair

PITTS--Lydia M. The Board and staff of the Community Service Society of New York (CSS) mourn the loss of a Trustee, friend, and ally in our fight against poverty in New York City. An expert in public finance and urban economics, Lydia Pitts served for 12 years on the CSS Board. In 1993, the Equitable Life Assurance Society, where she was Vice President and Counsel, presented her with the Equitable Community Leadership Award on behalf of her work with and dedication to the Community Service Society. Our deepest sympathy goes to her family. She will be missed.

Following the lead of restaurants, many resorts and hotels have recently begun cultivating their food in-house, managing produce and herb gardens, bee boxes and even full-fledged farms to supply their kitchens. While locavore lodging is not new to eco-resorts, it has cropped up in unlikely - less rural - settings. Some of the food on the menu doesn't have to travel far to reach your plate at the new LEED-certified Ritz-Carlton, Charlotte, which this spring installed two beehives that work in symbiosis with its green roof, planted with succulents, herbs and vegetables. Their first harvest is currently featured in honey ice cream served in the lobby.

RENTSCHLER--Frederick Brant, II, distinguished executive in the food products and airline industries, philanthropist and proud patriot died July 6, 2010 in Scottsdale, Arizona from complications related to non-Hodgkin lymphoma. He was 70 years old. Born August 12, 1939 in New York City, Fred was raised in Cincinnati, Ohio. He received his undergraduate degree in Economics and History from Vanderbilt University, and earned an MBA in Marketing from Harvard Business School. He was also awarded a Doctor of Laws, causa honoris, from the University of Wyoming. Proud to serve his country, he was Captain in the U.S. Marine Corps from 1960-1965 and Deputy Director of the White House Fellows Program in 1971 and 1972. During his professional career, he held several executive roles including President and Chief Executive Officer of Northwest Airlines (1991), Beatrice Company (1987-1989), Beatrice U.S. Foods (1985-1987), and Hunt-Wesson, Inc. (1980-1984). He was also President of Armour Dial (1977-1980). Fred served on several boards of directors, most recently on International Game Technology, Reno, NV, and on the Board of Trustee's of Vanderbilt University, Nashville, TN. He held various board positions with the Salk Institute for Biological Studies, La Jolla, CA, since 1980 and was named Chairman of the Board from 1995-2002 he was named Director Emeritus in 2005. He was a Trustee of the Scottsdale Healthcare Systems, Scottsdale, AZ, since 1985 and in 2003, was named Director Emeritus. He also was a Director of the Frederick B. and Pamela A. Rentschler Foundation. Additionally, he served as Trustee on other boards including the Woods Hole Oceanographic Institute, Canned Foods Inc., Esmark, Inc., The Heard Museum, and the Paradise Valley Country Club. After retiring to his home in Scottsdale, AZ, in 1991, Fred and his wife, Pam, split their time between Arizona and their working cattle ranch in the Madison River Valley in southwest Montana. Retirement found Fred actively pursuing golf, fly fishing, horseback riding, art collecting, reading and enjoying the fellowship of good friends and family. He was a gracious host, eager to share with friends the majestic Western landscape and the warm and friendly lifestyle at Corral Creek Ranch. He is survived by his beloved wife, Pamela Abney Rentschler; his canine best friends, Madison and Valley; his twin brother, Charles E.M. Rentschler, and numerous nephews, nieces and godchildren. A celebration of Life Service will be held Saturday, July 17, 2010, 11:00am, St. Patrick's Catholic Community Church, 10815 North 84th Street, Scottsdale, AZ, 85260. In lieu of flowers, the family requests contributions to: MVMC Foundation (Madison Valley Medical Center), P.O. Box 993, Ennis, Montana, 59729.

PERAZA--Lynn Lepofsky, known for her generosity and willingness to help others, died at her home in New York City on June 27, 2010. She was born in Philadelphia on March 2, 1950. Daughter of Dorothy and Philip Lepofsky, Lynn was predeceased by her beloved father Philip. She is survived by her husband John as well as her mother Dorothy Lepofsky, brother Steve (Carri), dear sisters-inlaw Mary Ellen Fey, Margaret Manganelli (Al), doting aunt and friend to many. She was a vibrant woman, artist, jewelry designer, professional chef, extensive traveler, passionate gardener and had a true love for fishing. She will be missed by many for whom she was both friend and inspiration. Her memory will live on. Lynn was cremated at her request. The family plans a memorial service in Montauk in the fall. The family asks that memorial/donation contributions in her memory be sent to charities of your choice.

Little more than a year after the death of Michael Jackson, a travel company is offering fans a chance to embark on a pilgrimage by taking a world tour of destinations billed as the King of Pop's favorites. The tour, offered by the London-based company STA Travel, spans all the continents save Antarctica. It starts in London and the Hamleys toy shop, which Mr. Jackson frequented. Also included are Bahrain, where the pop star went in 2005 after his acquittal on child molestation charges; Sydney, Australia, where he married Debbie Rowe; a hamlet outside Budapest, site of a life-size marzipan Jackson statue; and his memorial site in Los Angeles.

Siegel.

RAUSEN--Aaron, MD, 80, of New York City and Westport, CT, died July 7, of pancreatic cancer. Dr. Rausen, known as "Paca" to his grandchildren, was born in Jersey City, NJ, June 29, 1930, the son of David and Ruth Rausen. He grew up in New York City. He attended Stuyvesant High School in New York City, Dartmouth College from 1947-1950 and left prior to graduation to attend State University of New York on a full tuition scholarship where he received an MD degree in 1954. Dartmouth awarded Dr. Rausen the Spirit of '51 award and an honorary degree. Dr Rausen dedicated his professional life to finding the causes of, treating, and curing cancer, leukemia, AIDS and blood disorders in children. In 1990, he was named The Founding Director of The Stephen D. Hassenfeld Children's Center for cancer and Blood Disorders at New York University Medical Center. His passion, dedication, curiosity and unwavering conviction that giving up is not an option greatly contributed in the reversing of the 80%-20% death to cure ration among childhood blood disorders within his lifetime. He continued to research, teach and treat patients until his death. Among Dr. Rausen's extensive board memberships, he served as a director of the American Cancer Society, The National Childhood Cancer Foundation, The Children's Oncology Society of New York, The Ovarian Cancer Research Fund, and The Ronald McDonald House. Paca was truly a renaissance man. A voracious reader, a formidable squash opponent who loved music and a loyal friend and mentor, he enhanced our lives and the world. He met his wife Emalou Watkins, a well-known fashion designer, in August of 1966 at a dinner party, which was hosted by his former girlfriend whose intention was to introduce them. They were married in April of 1968. Aaron was a devoted husband, father and grandfather who loved his family with all his heart. He is survived by his wife of 42 years, his children David of Fort Collins CO, Susan of Darien and New York City and Elisabeth of Quincy MA, and grandchildren Alfred (Freddy), Katherine (Kricket), and Annabelle. Dr. Rausen's younger brother, Milton, died of Polio in 1943. Among Dr. Rausen's extensive board memberships, he served as a director of the American Cancer Society, The National Childhood Cancer Foundation, The Children's Oncology Society of New York, The Ovarian Cancer Research Fund, and The Ronald McDonald House. Paca was truly a renaissance man. A voracious reader, a formidable squash opponent who loved music and a loyal friend and mentor, he enhanced our lives and the world. A funeral service will be held at 10:30am on Sunday, July 11 at New Montifiore Cemetery on Long Island. Shiva will be on Tuesday July 13, 11am-5pm and 7-9pm at 176 Compo Road South, Westport, CT and 5-9pm on July 14 and 15 at 17 Nolen Lane, Darien, CT 06820. A memorial service will be held 5pm, Monday, July 19 at The Yale Club of New York City. In lieu of flowers, memorial gifts can be made in the form of donations to the Aaron R. Rausen Endowed Chair of Pediatric Hematology/Oncology at NYU School of medicine and its associated research fund. Contact: Colby Collier. VP of Development NYU Langone Medical Center, 1 Park Ave. NY, NY 10016.

YES, the clothing was cute at Chloë Sevigny's showing of her resort collection for Opening Ceremony, but it was the models' lipstick, courtesy of MAC Pro Violetta, that commanded the most attention. Part '80s punk, part '70s Parisian couture, the electric purply-pink hue managed to make red seem rather dull. Needless to say, the summer's coolest lipstick shade isn't for shrinking violets. ''When it comes to color, you should be able to see it from outer space,'' said Dick Page, the artistic director of Shiseido, who used his own take on the hue, in Fuchsia, for the Marc by Marc Jacobs spring collection. It has since become one of Shiseido's best sellers. And, according to Mr. Page, anyone can wear it. ''Once you get into color like this, it becomes like an accessory,'' he said. ''It's the same as a purse or a pair of shoes. Skin tone? It's beyond that.''
