Classical Steve Smith

ZAGOROFF--Dimiter Slavtcho (Mitko), died June 9, 2010 in a bicycle accident in the Swiss Alps. Before the accident, he had spent a blissful morning with his wife Polly revisiting much-loved sites from his European youth. He died as he had lived, taking risks and hoping for the best. Born on February 17, 1935 in Sofia, Bulgaria, Mitko came to the United States in 1950. He graduated from MIT in 1957 with a BS and an MS in Mechanical Engineering. He was an inventor with the mind of an inventor, always curious and always at work. Mitko developed the Turb-O-Torch, the Shrinkfast Heat Gun, and Pop & Lock truck accessories. At the time of his death, he had launched a new venture, Visc-O-Matic, a tail gate assist. Mitko lent his engineering expertise on many of Christo and Jeanne-Claude's early projects, including the Air Package in Kassel, Valley Curtain and Running Fence. Mitko leaves his wife, Polly Burr Drinkwater, of Lincoln, MA, his son, Dimitri, of Oakland, CA, his former wife, Elizabeth Zagoroff of Cambridge, MA, his stepchildren Theodora Gordon Hanson and Nathan Gordon, both of Cape Porpoise, ME, and his sister, Radka Donnell Vogt of Zurich, Switzerland.

THE NEWS Three British men were found guilty in a London court of plotting to commit murder, in a case that centered on a 2006 conspiracy linked to Al Qaeda to blow up airliners bound for the United States and Canada. BEHIND THE NEWS The verdict followed the longest and costliest terrorism prosecution in British history, officials said, with 8 of the 10 defendants convicted over three trials. The bombing method the plotters chose -- injecting ingredients of liquid explosive into plastic soft-drink bottles using a syringe -- led to restrictions on the liquids and creams passengers could take on commercial flights. Those measures remain in force worldwide.

TALBERT--Kathleen Aletha, May 20, 1950-July 8, 2010 of New York City and Bethel, NY. Born in East Hampton, CT, she graduated from the Hartford Art School as a sculpture major in 1972. She utilized her art background as she expanded her career in the food and wine industry. After such varied stints as running her own bakery, working at Windows on the World and Hilton International, and Food and Wines from France, she founded Talbert Communications and built it into a respected PR firm with clients in wine and spirits, lifestyle, and entertainment. She leaves her partner of 27 years, Ruth Halligan; her sister, Lee of Austin, TX; a brother, Resden of Columbus, Ohio and a sister LuAnn, of Hartford, CT. A special thanks to people who have supported Kathleen and TalbertComm during this last year: Rachel, Amy, Liz, Michelle, Ana, Lacey, Erica, Ella and Avi. Thanks to Dr. Paula Klein and the team at St. Vincents Cancer Center for their compassion and care. Friends and family will gather on Wednesday, July 14, at Reddens Funeral Home, 325 West 14th Street, New York City, from 6:00pm to 8:00pm to share stories. No flowers. Donations in Kathleen's memory may be made to Living Beyond Breast Cancer, 354 West. Lancaster Avenue, Suite 224, Haverford, PA 19041.

POSMANTER--Esther, left this life peacefully on July 6, 2010 at age 90 in Port Orange FL. Born in Philly, raised in the Bronx, she was a vital part of the Pelham Parkway Community. For many years Etta was the Director of The Bronx Council for the Aged which provided help to local seniors. Pre-deceased by husband Sid and son Stephen she leaves behind family and friends who dearly loved her. She lived her life as if every day was her birthday and always told everyone "remember, if you're not having a good time, you only have yourself to blame". She will be deeply missed. "Let it be good". Visit legacy.com

PILLON--Florence Hamilton. April 8, 1922 to June 16, 2010. Wonderful and caring mother to Meredith, Melissa, Melinda, Michelle and Charles, loving grandmother to David, Lawrence, Madison and Jessica and devoted wife to the late Charles George Pillon, III, Florence died peacefully in her sleep in Providence on June 16. A fashion model in New York the 1940s, Florence became a best-selling real estate broker in Connecticut in the 1980s. Beautiful, a fantastic cook, inveterate shopper, wonderful gardener and friend to all, she will be greatly missed. Born in Baltimore, Florence grew up in Teaneck, New Jersey where she attended high school and married her high school sweetheart, Charles, the captain of the football team. Her beauty and style were recognized and she began modeling at the salon of Hattie Carnegie one of America's first fashion designers where she met socialites and film stars. In Charlottesville, where Charles attended the University of Virginia and its Law School, Florence gave birth to the first two of their five children. Moving to Chappaqua, New York in the early 1950s, Florence kept a beautiful home and continued to raise five children. She was a member of the Junior League and a fund raiser for the American Heart Association. She was also an enthusiastic supporter of and constant escort to swim meets, piano, dance and French lessons as well as tennis and golf games. In the 1970s, Florence began a new chapter in her life: successful real estate broker. She held positions at New Canaan Real Estate and Prudential Connecticut Realty. She was named one of Connecticut's best-selling brokers just before retiring at the age of 80. Besides cooking, shopping and gardening, she enjoyed antiquing and was a connoisseur of early American crafts and furniture. Florence leaves behind many friends and her loving family. A memorial service will be announced in the coming weeks.

KOPLEWICZ--Joseph. The Board and staff of the Child Mind Institute are deeply saddened by the loss of Joseph Koplewicz, the father of our organization's president, Dr. Harold S. Koplewicz. Joseph, 94, died on the evening of July 4. A man of enormous courage and integrity, Joseph lived a life of uncommon bravery. He was, until his death, among the last survivors of the Warsaw Ghetto Uprising. Joseph was a man who kept beating the odds. He became the quintessential, self-made American. He embodied the American dream and fell in love with the United States for the freedom, hope, and opportunities it gave him and his beloved wife, Roma. Joseph touched the hearts of all who knew him with his sparkle, energy, and love of life. Everyone at the Child Mind Institute will always be grateful for Joseph's faith in and commitment to children's mental health as well as for the support and love he gave Harold. He was a remarkable supporter of the Child Mind Institute, as well as the NYU Child Study Center and the U.S. Holocaust Memorial Museum. We extend condolences to his son Harold and his wife Linda Sirow; his daughter Edith; his dear friend Janet; grandsons Joshua, Adam, and Sam Koplewicz and Alex Usi. Brooke Garber Neidich Chair Child Mind Institute Debra Perelman Vice Chair Child Mind Institute

GORDON--Gilbert, (1911-2010) Activist lawyer, died July 6 in Deerfield Beach, FL. Fought discriminatory housing covenants as lawyer for the American Jewish Congress. As Village Attorney of Skokie, Illinois, fought to prevent American Nazi Party from marching in Jewish community, organized Skokie Caucus Party alliance of Democrats, Independents and Republicans to beat the Daley machine. Predeceased by his wife, Debora, founding principal of the Lorraine Hansberry Child Parent Center, Chicago's groundbreaking school for family literacy. Survived by sons Michael and Jonathan and three grandchildren.

DIEBOLD--Dorothy Roosen, July 6, 2010. Dorothy Orizondo Roosen Diebold, age 105, went to meet her Heavenly Father at her beloved home, Toplands Farm, in Roxbury, CT on Tuesday, July 6, 2010. She was preceded in death by her husband, Albert Richard Diebold, mother Clarita Orizondo Roosen, father Herman Dudley Roosen, sisters Clarita Roosen and Helen Roosen Curran, brothers Berend Roosen and Robert Roosen, and grandson Albert Richard Diebold III. Long a fixture of New York City, Palm Beach, Boca Grande, Florida, and Roxbury, Connecticut, Mrs. Diebold is survived by her children Albert Richard Diebold, Diane Diebold Terni, and Dudley George Diebold and wife Honoria Hine Diebold; her grandchildren Deborah Diebold de Naveja and husband Juan-Maria Naveja de Anda, Linda Gavel Webb and husband Arthur Heberer III, Daphne Diebold Stoughton and husband James Stoughton, Frank Gavel, Jr., and wife Laurie McKee Gavel, Stephen Gavel, and Caitlin Diebold and husband Kevin O'Connell; and great-grandchildren Juan-Maria Naveja Diebold, Thomas Gavel, Charles Webb, Rebecca Gavel. In addition, Mrs. Diebold leaves behind her dear friends Shirley Gilbert and Olive Simpson, as well as many wonderful nurses and staff in Roxbury and Boca Grande, who gave her kind and loving care for years. Born in Brooklyn, New York on February 3, 1905, the former Dorothy Roosen attended the Ogontz School in Pennsylvania, where she excelled in field hockey and book binding and earnestly studied the works of John Glasworthy, before making her debut in New York City and marrying Albert Richard Diebold there in 1931. A stalwart of the St. James Church altar guild in New York City, as well as that of Christ Church in Roxbury and St. Andrew's Church in Boca Grande, Mrs. Diebold was an award winning needle-pointer, who made many beautiful pieces for her churches, including the magnificent kneelers that are used to this day. She was an active member of the Colony Club for many years. A scratch golfer, Mrs. Diebold particularly enjoyed playing the game at the Washington Club with her mother, when both were well along in years. She was a member of the Red Cross Ambulance Corps in New York City during World War II and followed her husband to Washington, DC, when he served in the U.S. Army there during the conflict. She was a great supporter of many charitable causes in Florida, Connecticut, and elsewhere, including the Roxbury Land Trust, The Christian Herald Association, Roxbury and Boca Grande Fire, Ambulance, Library and Churches and many, many others. Known as a formidable grande dame and arbiter of social correctness, Mrs. Diebold was also an amazingly gracious hostess and supremely generous and thoughtful friend, who appreciated the special essence of everyone she met. She taught her grandchildren to call her Mumsie and somewhere along the line, everyone started calling her Mumsie. Mumsie will be eulogized on Friday, July 9, 2010 at 11am, Christ Church Roxbury, CT and all who loved her are welcome. Burial will be private. In lieu of flowers, please consider making a memorial contribution to Christ Church, Roxbury or the Roxbury Volunteer Fire Department.

An article on June 20 about mineral deposits in Afghanistan and other third world countries and the practical and political difficulties of extracting them and profiting from them described deposits of coltan incorrectly. Coltan is a mineral, not an element.

Q.My husband and I are taking our grandson to Washington for his 10th birthday in the fall. He will be in fifth grade and will be studying United States history. Do you have suggestions on how we can make this an educational as well an entertaining experience for him? Angela Fee, Portland, Ore.A.What an exciting trip for a 10-year-old! In her ''36 Hours in Washington, D.C.'' (Jan. 18, 2009), Helene Cooper, a White House correspondent for The Times, offered sightseeing, dining and lodging options that should prove useful (the column is available at our destination guide, at nytimes.com/travel).

BARING-GOULD--Lucile Marguerite Moody, known as "Ceil", died on June 27, 2010, at the age of 96 after several years of declining health. She was born on April 4, 1914 in Mablehurst, Wisconsin, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert James Moody. After her family moved to Minneapolis, Minnesota, she attended St. Mary's Hall and then the University of Minnesota where she earned a BBA degree. It was there that she met William Stuart Baring-Gould whom she married in 1936. Mrs. Baring-Gould and her husband moved to New York City where he was originally employed by Hearst Publishing (later by Time, Inc.). In 1952 Mrs. Baring-Gould and her family moved to Pound Ridge, NY, where they had purchased a 200 year-old Colonial farmhouse. In 1962 Mrs. Baring-Gould co-authored with her husband "The Annotated Mother Goose". The book was reviewed on the front page of the "New York Times Book Review" and became a bestseller. Mrs. Baring-Gould was committed to her community of Pound Ridge and was active in government there. She was the first President of the Pound Ridge League of Women Voters and a member of the Board of Directors of the New York State League of Women Voters. She was the first woman elected to any town office when she was elected to the Town Council in 1968. She served as Deputy Town Supervisor for seven years. After the death of her husband and son, she turned her interests toward real estate in the 1970s. She became a licensed broker with the firm Houlihan/Lawrence, Inc. and was a member of Sotheby's International Realty. Her endeavors in real estate resulted in a number of local and national awards, ranging from membership in the Million Dollar Club every year for thirty-two years, the Gold Award for top sales in Westchester County, and the Realtor of the Year Award for Westchester County. She was President of the Westchester Women's Council of Realtors and was on the Executive Committee of the Westchester Board of Realtors. Mrs. Baring-Gould was active on the board of directors of several organizations, among them the Westchester Lighthouse for the Blind, the Seven Springs Foundation, and the Pound Ridge Nature Conservancy (now the Pound Ridge Land Conservancy) where she was Chairperson for ten years. Mrs. Baring-Gould moved from New York to Atlanta to be near her daughter and family, living at Canterbury Court. She was one of the founders of the Canterbury Court Book Club. Although Mrs. Baring-Gould was preceded in death by her son, William Drake Baring-Gould II, in 1966, and her husband, William Stuart Baring-Gould, in 1967, she is survived by her daughter, Judy Baring-Gould Orthwein, and son-in-law, Adolphus Busch Orthwein, Jr., and by her grandchildren, Adolphus Busch Orthwein III and wife Ellen, William Drake Orthwein and wife Tabitha, and Pam Orthwein Jensen and husband Colby. She is also survived by seven great-grandchildren. In lieu of flowers memorial contributions may be made to The Pound Ridge Land Conservancy, P.O. Box 173, Pound Ridge, NY 10576, or to the Hiram Halle Memorial Library, 271 Westchester Avenue, Pound Ridge, NY 10576. A memorial service for Mrs. Baring-Gould will be held later this summer.

To the Sports Editor: The definition of a LeBron: a mega-unit of media saturation from which not even the nonobserver may escape. Also, a nearly infinite positive value inversely proportional to the unimportance of the displayed entertainment. Not to be confused with similar, but lesser, measures of public dominance, though may become such, which operate within the negative range of exhibition, often associated with downfall, such as a Lohan. Fred Gravez

June 27: The Veuve Clicquot Polo Classic drew thousands of spectators to the scorching grounds of Governors Island. The event benefited American Friends of Sentebale, a branch of a charity that Prince Harry, one of the players, helped found to aid the children of Lesotho. One side of the field was for ticketholders and had a V.I.P. tent for celebrities. The other side, where these photos were taken, was free and offered a delightful fashion spectacle. Many women wore short dresses and picture hats, at times bringing to mind the black and white Ascot scene in ''My Fair Lady.'' But the crowd was so dense, the field also suggested the sands at Coney Island.

To The Sports Editor: What would it take to be a beautiful game? How about if the players would stop flip-flopping about and screaming for phantom fouls; if coaches would moderate their sideline antics and act as responsible adults; if the referees would become smarter and demand the introduction of modern techniques to minimize the risk of making monumental mistakes? Mostly though, wouldn't it be a beautiful game if Thierry Henry had admitted to the handball and asked the referee to disallow the goal that got France into the World Cup; if the German goalkeeper Manuel Neuer had accepted that he was beaten by the goal scored by England's Frank Lampard; if Argentina's Carlos Tévez had admitted that he was offside when he headed in a goal against Mexico?

McWILLIAMS--Iris Dornfeld, New York, NY, novelist and widow of Carey McWilliams, the longtime editor of The Nation magazine, died yesterday at her home after a long period of declining health. Iris Dornfeld was born in Roseville, California on December 18, 1912, the daughter of Percy and Etta Hewitt Dornfeld. She attended Sacramento State College, transferring to Mills College, where she graduated in 1935. She worked as a teacher and in the theater before marrying Carey McWilliams in 1941. Their son, Jerry (deceased 1990), was born in 1942. The family moved to New York in 1950. Iris Dornfeld was the author of Jeeney Ray, published in 1962 by Viking Press, and of Boy Gravely, published by Knopf in 1965. Both novels achieved considerable critical success: Jeeney Ray was subsequently made into a movie for television. Her husband died in 1980. She is survived by her daughter-in-law, Nancy McWilliams of Flemington, NJ, widow of her stepson Wilson Carey McWilliams (deceased 2005), and two step-grandchildren, Susan McWilliams Barndt (Claremont, CA) and Helen McWilliams (Allson, MA). Memorial contributions may be made to the Gay Mens' Health Crisis, Inc. or to the Coalition for the Homeless, both in New York City. Memorial Services will be Thursday, July 15th, 4pm at "The Riverside", 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

GERRI RIEDMAN, 57 Co-manager, Baglady, Merrick, N.Y. ''Whatever I like, that's what I buy, because I think that there's somebody out there who's going to like it also.'' THE GOODS ''Mad Men''-era pocketbooks and accessories, like a black-and-white purse ($10) and a pair of vintage white gloves ($4). TREASURED ITEM A black blazer Ms. Riedman hangs at the front of her booth, which she purchased for $1 at a thrift store. She uses it to display vintage brooches, and won't sell it. STRATEGY Be willing to negotiate. ''I don't go for the big sale. If I buy something for a few dollars, if I get a few dollars more than that, I'm happy.'' MEMORABLE CUSTOMERS Transgender patrons who share her taste in jewelry. ''They really go for the outlandish, as do I.'' THEY create oddball titles for themselves, like ''architecturologist'' or ''antiquinaire.'' They are attracted equally to unusual things and the freedom of self-employment. Some have day jobs, some have stores, some simply pack up their wares and roam from flea to flea. Each Saturday morning before sunrise, after scouring auctions, barn cleanouts and demolition sites, they load their vans with paintings and guitars and large metal insects and head for Fort Greene.

BUTLER--Dr. Robert served as a member of the advisory board of the Open Society Institute's Project on Death in America (PDIA) from its inception in 1994 until its close in 2003. This was George Soros's first US-based philanthropic initiative and received $5 million dollars a year over nine years. The mission of PDIA, which Dr. Butler helped create, was to transform the culture and experience of death and dying in the United States. Dr. Butler worked tirelessly with the other members of the advisory board to plan and develop each of the various program initiatives including the PDIA Faculty Scholars Program and the Social Work Leadership Development Program. Both of these initiatives have significantly contributed to the development of the current leadership of palliative care in the US. Dr. Butler was the founder of the National Institute on Aging at the National Institute of Health and advocated for the aging before Congress and the United Nations. He helped start and led the American Association for Geriatric Psychiatry, the Alzheimer's Disease Association and the International Longevity Center. Dr. Butler's leadership and constant advocacy on behalf of the elderly guaranteed their representation across all of PDIA's project initiatives, including the development of palliative care programs in nursing homes. In an interview with Dr. David Clark, the author of the History of the Project on Death in America, Dr. Butler summarizes, "Death will always be with us, pushed around a bit to be sure, with one fatal disease superseded by another. For every birth, someone long ago happened to notice, there is one death. We cannot and will not change that fact. But we can change the way people are cared for at the end of life, and we can substantially reduce the burden of illness. It is not, after all, death that people seem to fear the most, and certainly not in old age, but a life poorly lived. Something can be done about that." Dr. Butler's life was certainly well lived and his contributions to improving the lives of our aging population live on as his legacy. Aryeh Neier President Open Society Institute Kathleen M. Foley, M.D. Director, Project on Death in America Medical Director, International Palliative Care Initiative Mary V. Callaway Associate Director, Project on Death in America Director, International Palliative Care Initiative

CALAMANDREI--Mauro, of New York, New York died on Wednesday (July 7) at the age of 85 after a brief illness. He was born on March 5, 1925 in Florence, Italy and served bravely in the anti-fascist Italian underground during WWII. He earned his first Ph.D. at the University of Florence in 1947. In 1949 he became one of the very first Italians to be awarded a Fulbright scholarship to study in the US. While he was studying at the University of Chicago he was invited to join the Committee on Social Thought. And earned a Ph.D. for his research re Roger Williams and the History of American Religion in 1953. Early in his career, Mauro taught at the Juilliard School of Music, Middlebury College and the University of Florence. Soon he discovered his true love and passion and began writing articles and books about politics, art and culture in the United States. He wrote numerous books and articles over the years but was best known for his years as the American Correspondent for the Italian magazine L'Espresso. And more recently for his articles for the prestigious newspaper Il Sole 24 Ore. After 62 years in the United States, Mauro became a United States citizen in 2009. Mauro was an esteemed writer and intellectual, with a warm, welcoming, generous personality, who was much loved by many friends. Mauro died surrounded by loving family. He is survived by his sister Anna Bagnoli and niece Emanuela Bencini in Florence, Italy; his long time companion Pauline Pinto, his daughter Camilla, son-in-law David Rudofsky and grandson Marcello, Camilla's mother Judith and uncle Philip Schneider. A memorial service to celebrate his life will be held on Sunday, July 11 at 4pm at the Frank Campbell Chapel at 1076 Madison Avenue (81st street), NYC.

ORB--John A.,1919-2010. John Orb, former chief executive officer of Smith Barney and pioneer in retail sales and investment banking, died in San Francisco Saturday June 26th surrounded by friends and family. He was 91. He died after a long illness, his family said. Mr. Orb was born in Chicago, Illinois on February 9, 1919. The following year after his father died, his mother and he relocated to San Antonio, Texas where he was reared. When Mr. Orb was thirteen years old, they moved across the Atlantic to Europe. Mr. Orb returned to the United States to attend the Taft School, a private boarding school in Watertown, Connecticut, and a pivotal experience in his life. After graduating, Mr. Orb attended Yale University where he earned his degree in 1941. Following his academic career, Mr. Orb enrolled in The United States Army Air Corp flying program. In 1942, he was commissioned as a Second Lieutenant in The United States Army Air Force and earned his wings. During World War II, Mr. Orb rose to the rank of Lietenant Colonel and was awarded the Distinguished Flying Cross for his bravey leading a formation of B-26 fighter planes suffering intense anti-aircraft fire to demolish a bridge near Roccasecca, Italy. He distinguished himself through his aggressiveness, superior tactical skill, leadership, and bravery to precisely destroy a target that withstood a number of previous assaults. After the war, Mr. Orb returned to his native Chicago. He became an account executive at Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner and Smith where he established the Chicago office and rose to become Manager and Group Vice-President. In 1968, he transferred to the New York office where he eventually became Executive Vice-President and Director. Mr. Orb was responsible for the sales, investment banking and marketing divisions. His management style was honed in the partnership phase of Merrill where he learned the art of sharing responsibilities and being held accountable for results. He retired in 1974. Mr. Orb came out of retirement to join Smith Barney, the investment banking and brokerage firm and the principal subsidary of the holding company Smith Barney Inc., in 1975 as executive vice president and a director. He was elected President and Chief Operating Officer in 1977. In 1982, Mr. Orb served as Chief Executive Officer for both Smith Barney Inc. and Smith Barney, Harris Upham -- the 12th senior partner or chief executive in the firm's 114th-year history. In 1983, he became chairman of both companies. Mr. Orb entered Smith Barney during a crucial period in the company's long history when the firm sought to add a retail brokerage structure to its primarily institutional brokerage business. Through the years, Mr. Orb instrumented the firm's expansion to a full-service organization by building its product line and marketing efforts. He pioneered a new era with the well-known marketing campaign, "Smith Barney makes money the old-fashioned way. We earn it," which became renowned in marketing and advertising history. John's talent, belief and persistance altered the course of the firm as it entered a new era of retail sales and investment banking. Mr. Orb's support of The Taft School spanned eight decades as a student, father, grandfather, volunteer, and trustee. Mr. Orb attributed much of his success to his experience at The Taft School. The school acknowledged his years of contribution with a Citation of Merit in May of 2010. Mr. Orb also served on the Board of Trustees of Outward Bound, as President of the Bond Club of New York, and as a supporter of The Isabel O'Neil Studio in New York. In his later years, Mr. Orb found time to enjoy his favorite pursuits including fly-fishing, hunting, golf and travelling. Mr. Orb is survived by his beloved wife, Susan C. Orb, of San Valley, Idaho. He is pre-deceased by his former wives, Elizabeth Nevins Orb, Jean "Teel" Tennant Orb, and Phyllis McKee Orb; and by three of his children, Joan Orb Garrison, Thomas Derek Tennant and John Chadwell Tennant. His loss impacts his entire family including his children from his first marriage, Linda Orb Drake and John Alexander Orb IV; the members of his second family, Julie Tennant Sargent, Tracy Tennant Isham, A. Foster Tennant; the extended family of his third marriage, Charolette McKee Worcester, Catherine McKee Donovan, Joseph Vincent McKee, and Charles Russell McKee; and by the members of his later family, George Robert Carter IV and Anne Strong Carter. Mr. Orb is survived by twenty-two grandchildren and nine great-grandchildren. John's strong moral integrity and his inherent optimism contributed to an abundant family, numerous friends, and admiring colleagues all of whom will greatly miss him. A memorial service is planned for the Fall in Sun Valley. Details to be announced at a later date. In lieu of flowers, donations in Mr. Orb's honor can be made to "The John A. Orb Merit Scholarship Fund," The Taft School, 110 Woodbury Road, Watertown, CT 06795-2100; Outward Bound, P.O. Box 62121, Baltimore, MD 21264-2161; or The Isabel O'Neil Studio, 315 E. 91st Street, 2nd Floor, New York, NY 10128-5301.

SUMMER STUDIES When Ellen told Mary about the secret lake she swore her to silence but Mary invited Jerome who couldn't even swim and Luanne came with him and it was funny that summer the way that scarce resources collided with the whole system of who was cool, or not the old rule being that who was cool would get to stay that way by jumping into the lake and who was not would have to stay hot and dirty by simple omission of information. But that dry summer the rumors spread: someone was giving out maps, someone was giving tutorials in every twist and bobby-pin turn you had to take in the red dirt road that got you there. When you got near you could hear through the trees splashes and cries of people who might not even be friends. And the clear water, like the social milieu that summer was quite frankly stirred up, confused thanks to the leaky lips, Ellen said, of certain persons who would let anyone in. - TONY HOAGLAND, author of ''Unincorporated Persons in the Late Honda Dynasty'' COME LIVE WITH ME Heat exists as energy in transit, something spontaneous, volatile, elementary, ''something which may be transferred from one body to another'' (James Clerk Maxwell, ''Theory of Heat''). Notice how it moves from an object with a high temperature to an object with a lower one, a process of thermal contact, the sun burning through the coldest morning sky. Heat increases and flows across boundaries. It is ancient, fluctuating, vibrational, like these summer days that are so combustible and these nights when stars enlighten the skies. I remember the time you touched me near the stove and the flames sparked in my body, love. - EDWARD HIRSCH, author of ''The Living Fire: New and Selected Poems''

IN 1970, when Helmut Newton came down with the flu and was unable to shoot an ad for Gitanes cigarettes, his wife, June, then an Australian actress with no formal photography training, stepped in and did it. ''I knew I was in business,'' she later recalled, ''when a check arrived in the mail addressed to Helmut.'' For the next four decades, June (who also served as Newton's art director) photographed under the name Alice Springs -- a pseudonym chosen blindfolded, with a pin in hand and a map of Australia before her. She shot stories for French Vogue and Elle, and ads for Jean Louis David, but her intimate portraits of everyone from Robert Mapplethorpe (center right) to Brigitte Nielsen (right) to the Hells Angels set her apart. ''Her pictures of people are totally innocent,'' her husband once said. ''I don't know of anyone else who takes the same kind of portraits.''

Each player is sized according to the percent of all Facebook status updates, wall posts, comments, shares, and ''likes'' containing the player's name from June 11 to July 8. Vuvuzelas aside, this World Cup, which comes to a close Sunday with the final match between Spain and the Netherlands, was really not so different than those of the past. European and South American teams retained their global dominance. England fizzled. Referees were lambasted, goal-line technology clamored for (mostly by those on the short end of the calls) and players once again dived all over the field, feigning injury in hopes of securing a precious free kick. Yet there was a key difference this year. Never before were fans across the planet so connected to each other through the Internet. And connect they did. Millions of people used Facebook, the world's largest social networking site, to voice both ecstasy and woe throughout the tournament about their favorite players. Below, the players Facebook users talked about, worldwide, during the tournament. One potential sign that soccer may have arrived in the U.S.? An American, Landon Donovan, is near the top of the world's list.
Television Ginia Bellafante

TASSO--Paula Helen Hollmen, 87 of New York, NY, died peacefully on July 7, 2010. Originally from Detroit, Paula was a graduate of Wayne State University and worked with Walter Reuther and the UAW in the 1940's before moving to New York. During her life she was a political activist working for the environment and both racial and economic justice. Paula worked with the Women's International League for Peace and Freedom for 16 years as both WILPF's United Nations Representative and also as a member of the National Board. She was twice invited to the former Soviet Union to present workshops on The Bruntland Report for an international environmental study. She later covered the U.N. Nuclear Disarmament Committee. Paula wrote a regular United Nations column for Peace & Freedom. Predeceased by her beloved husband, Charles A. Tasso, she is survived by her children David and Kaarli Tasso, sister Kaarli Bowers, nieces Anila and Amy Bowers and grandniece Kate Bowers. In lieu of flowers, please make contributions to the Women's International League for Peace and Freedom, 565 Boylston St., 2nd flr, Boston, MA 02116.

Passport fees are increasing effective July 13, the State Department recently announced. The cost of getting a brand-new passport for someone 16 or older has jumped 35 percent, to $135 from $100, and for those under 16 has increased by nearly 25 percent, to $105 from $85. If you've already got your passport, you're not immune: the cost of renewing your passport for those 16 and over has increased 47 percent, to $110 from $75. Travelers heading to Mexico and Canada by land or sea and those heading to the Caribbean by sea can save a few bucks by using a passport card, which for adults will cost $55 (a $10 increase) and for children will cost $40 (up $5). Among the other changes that could affect travelers: a new fee of $82 for appending pages to your passport, which will undoubtedly affect mainly globetrotters whose visas and stamps are overflowing, and an increase in the fee for reporting a birth abroad ($100 from $65). The fee hikes are among several consular fees being increased after what the department called an exhaustive study of the true cost of providing consular services.

Temperatures reached a record 103 degrees in New York City on Tuesday. The heat also strained the electric grid all over the country, with utilities reporting scattered outages. Suppose the summer peak load also included plug-in electric cars? The consumption from a charging E.V. can cause a home's load to double, so it's worth considering the potential for electric cars to cause brownouts when more of the cars are eventually on the streets. Also, because E.V.'s are relatively expensive, their ownership is likely to be concentrated in more affluent areas, which means some neighborhoods could feel the power strain more than others.

8 P.M. (National Geographic) DRUGS, INC. This four-part mini-series on drugs in America begins with an examination of how cocaine is produced and distributed -- from peasant farmers who make cocaine paste to a trafficker linked to Mexican cartels to a dealer in Miami. At 9 the series continues with a look at the stimulant methamphetamine, which is made from a common cold remedy. This episode documents a raid on a suspected meth lab and the physical damages caused by the drug. 10 A.M. (CNN) FAREED ZAKARIA GPS Guests include George Osborne, Britain's chancellor of the Exchequer, on his country's recent fiscal austerity; and Anjem Choudary, who was born in England and is a proponent of radical Islam.

June 27: The Veuve Clicquot Polo Classic drew thousands of spectators to the scorching grounds of Governors Island. The event benefited American Friends of Sentebale, a branch of a charity that Prince Harry, one of the players, helped found to aid the children of Lesotho. One side of the field was for ticketholders and had a V.I.P. tent for celebrities. The other side, where these photos were taken, was free and offered a delightful fashion spectacle. Many women wore short dresses and picture hats, at times bringing to mind the black and white Ascot scene in ''My Fair Lady.'' But the crowd was so dense, the field also suggested the sands at Coney Island.

JANULIS--Dr. Peter T.,84, passed away Wednesday July 7, 2010 in Delray Beach, Florida. The cause of death was heart failure. Born in Newark, New Jersey, he was a son of the late Theodore and Helen Janulis of Pompano Beach, Florida. In addition to his parents, he was preceded in death by his brother, Dr. Alex Janulis. Dr. Janulis received his undergraduate and medical degrees from Cornell University in Ithaca, New York and New York City. His internship and residency in Psychiatry were also served at the Weil Cornell Medical College, after having served in the United States Navy during World War II. He practiced psychiatry for forty years in New York City, and was an Associate Clinical Professor at Cornell Medical College until retirement to Delray in 1993. He was a man of uncompromised commitment, integrity and honor who will be deeply missed but will continue on in our hearts, minds and love for each other. He was beloved husband to Lyn Janulis, cherished father to Lori, Karen and Ted and loving grandfather to Jennifer, Julian, Matthew, Elizabeth, Catherine, Peter, Helena and Christina. Friends and family are invited to pay their respects at the Pelham Funeral Home, located at 64 Lincoln Avenue, Pelham, New York on Sunday July 11th from 3-5pm and Monday July 12th from 9:30-11am. A memorial service will be held at a later date in Delray Beach, Florida. Memorial condolences may be made, if wished, to Class of 1951Scholarship. Fund, Weil Cornell Medical College - 1300 York Avenue, New York, New York 10021, or Bethesda Heart Institute - Boynton Beach, Florida 33435.

To the Sports Editor: I propose that the All-Star Game be played annually on July 4. There are no national televised events on July 4. It is traditionally a local day of festivities. An article last Sunday about summer internships for students referred imprecisely to the source of two statistics used in comparing student participation in internships in 1992 and 2008. While the National Association of Colleges and Employers did indeed conduct a survey in 2008 that found that 50 percent of graduating students had participated in internships, it did not conduct a survey in 1992 that found that 17 percent of graduating students had held internships. The 1992 study was by Northwestern University. The article also misstated the name of the organization that provided an internship to Kathryn Ciano, a George Mason University law student. It is the Fox Business Network, not Fox Business News.

The day after the couture shows is typically when magazines do their photo shoots, snagging the dresses they want to tell a story and often working around a house's client schedule. There is something of a church-and-state divide in couture, with clients in private appointments with a saleswoman on the couture side of a house - separate salon, separate entrance - and editors giving their interpretations of the clothes. Toward the end of Yves Saint Laurent's career, when he was still doing couture collections, I would sometimes accompany a few friends who were regular clients - Nan Kempner, among them - on their appointments at YSL. It was fascinating to watch them go through the clothes. They saw them in a completely different way than I did. They were buying pieces for a wardrobe. For them the process was like a slow, ongoing conversation.

ZAGOROFF--Dimiter Slavtcho (Mitko), died June 9, 2010 in a bicycle accident in the Swiss Alps. Before the accident, he had spent a blissful morning with his wife Polly revisiting much-loved sites from his European youth. He died as he had lived, taking risks and hoping for the best. Born on February 17, 1935 in Sofia, Bulgaria, Mitko came to the United States in 1950. He graduated from MIT in 1957 with a BS and an MS in Mechanical Engineering. He was an inventor with the mind of an inventor, always curious and always at work. Mitko developed the Turb-O-Torch, the Shrinkfast Heat Gun, and Pop & Lock truck accessories. At the time of his death, he had launched a new venture, Visc-O-Matic, a tail gate assist. Mitko lent his engineering expertise on many of Christo and Jeanne-Claude's early projects, including the Air Package in Kassel, Valley Curtain and Running Fence. Mitko leaves his wife, Polly Burr Drinkwater, of Lincoln, MA, his son, Dimitri, of Oakland, CA, his former wife, Elizabeth Zagoroff of Cambridge, MA, his stepchildren Theodora Gordon Hanson and Nathan Gordon, both of Cape Porpoise, ME, and his sister, Radka Donnell Vogt of Zurich, Switzerland.

A restaurant review in some copies last Sunday about the Belford Bistro in Belford, N.J., misstated the schedule for the town's ferry service. Ferries run 12 times a day between Belford and New York City on weekdays, and not at all on weekends; they do not run once a day.

Most dream vacations to Alaska revolve around wilderness hikes or cruises past mountains and glaciers. But changes in downtown Anchorage offer visitors a few reasons to linger in the state's most populous city. The city's grid pattern, with lettered streets running perpendicular to numbered avenues, seems inspired by the game Battleship. In the heart of the grid, within a block of the G Street strip that stretches between Third and Fifth Avenues, new shops and restaurants have cropped up. Their arrival happens to coincide with a revitalization project called Destination Downtown, headlined by a sleek expansion of the Anchorage Museum, where new exhibitions, a planetarium and a science discovery center were unveiled in May. INGRID K. WILLIAMS

FOR anyone who still puts pen to paper, there is Connor, a luxury stationer that has just opened at the Plaza Hotel. ''Most stationery houses have gone down-market,'' said Justin Felber, who founded the company with his fellow Strong alumnus, Henri Richter-Werner. ''We wanted to go up.'' Which means: an archive of hundreds of vintage and antique monograms, as well as die cuts hand-engraved into steel by master craftsmen in Paris and updated each season like a fashion collection; cards made of 100 percent cotton, which won't bleed when written on with a fountain pen; envelopes lined by hand with tissue paper; and cashmere carrying pouches made by Loro Piana -- all of it encased in Italian silk linen boxes wrapped with two ribbons like an old steamer trunk. It comes with a price: cards range from $10 to $20 a piece, with a minimum of 100 to a box. ''We cater to people looking for something special,'' Mr. Richter-Werner said.

SHONTZ--Hilary Morton, filled with grace and courage, passed away on July 7, 2010, after a long illness. Hilary was born on February 5, 1958, in New York City. She moved to the Cathedral Close of St. John the Divine in 1972, where her family lived for 25 years. Hilary attended Spence School and Colby College, and married David in 1986. After working as an executive recruiter, and an event planner for the Metropolitan Opera, Hilary chose to stay home to raise her two children, Harry and Jamie, whom she treasured above all else. Hilary is survived by her two children, Harry and Jamie, her husband David, her sisters, Polly, Sophia and Maria, and her parents James and Pamela. All of her family and all of her friends will always be thankful for the years they shared, the happiness she brought to their lives, and the dignity with which she faced her long struggle. She will be in their hearts forever. There will be a memorial service on Monday, July 12, 2010, at 10:30am. at The Cathedral of St. John the Divine, 1047 Amsterdam Avenue (at 112th Street) in New York City. In lieu of flowers, anyone who wishes may make a donation to The Interfaith Center of New York, 475 Riverside Drive, Suite 540, New York, NY 10115. (www.interfaithcenter.org).

HABIAN--Doris M. Born July 8, 1923 passed away peacefully on Friday, June 25, 2010 with her daughter, Lynn at her side at Hospice in Palm Beach Gardens, FL. The cause was a brain hemorrhage which she suffered on June 20, 2010. Formerly of Manhasset and Bridgehampton, Long Island, NY, she last resided in Palm Beach Gardens, PGA National Resort and Spa Community. She was a graduate of Finch College and Katherine Gibbs School in New York City. While at Katherine Gibbs, she developed a close friendship with stage actress, Leora Dana, attending such theatre productions as Point of No Return at the Alvin Theatre staring her and Henry Fonda. They graduated together. In the forties, she worked for the President of American Airlines at LaGuardia Airport, where she later met her husband, George Habian, an award winning inventor, writer and Executive Engineer who owned patents on airplane polishing equipment and was a designer/draftsman at The Port Authority of NY and NJ at The World Trade Towers. Mr. Habian predeceased Doris in 1985 from cancer. Doris was a lady of great style, independent and cultured, with a love of home and children. She was an accomplished pianist and equestrian. She and her husband loved Opera and were members of the American Airlines Glee Club and the Rockefeller Choristers. She was a very loving, unselfish person, who put everyone's needs before her own. She was a friend and guiding light to her two children. "Two kids could not have asked for a better Mother with regard to instilling values, getting a proper education and preparing two people for their course in the world." (Quote from her son, Bruce.) She leaves behind a daughter, Lynn Diane (International Concert Pianist) formerly of Palm Beach, FL, and a son, Bruce George (lawyer) of NYC and Water Mill, Long Island, NY. She was mother-in-law to Joy Fedden-Habian (Architect) and Robert Harris Grogan (former well known retired Wall Street bank lawyer). Also, grandmother to the Habian girls, Laura Grace and Christina George. Services were held on Thursday, July 1, 2010 at Quattlebaum Funeral Home in West Palm Beach, FL. During the viewing a slide show was given encompassing the early, middle and later years of her life. A Mass followed at the Historic Catholic Church of St. Ann in West Palm Beach, FL. The original church was constructed in 1895. The current church (1913) is a gem to this day, with stained glass windows from Mayer's of Munich that are simply breathtaking. During Holy Communion of the Mass, Maurice Ravel's Pianoforte Solo 'Pavane pour une infante defunte' was performed. The Sanctuary window is dedicated to Henry Flagler who died the year the church was built. President John F. Kennedy attended his last Sunday Mass at St. Ann's on November 17, 1963. A service at The Chapel of Holy Rood Catholic Cemetery preceded the burial at the family Crypt in Westbury, Long Island, NY on July 8, 2010, which was arranged by Fairchild Funeral Home of Garden City, Long Island, NY. We will love and remember her forever. Donations in her memory may be made in her name, Doris M. Habian, to Palm Beach Gardens Hospice and Palliative Care Unit, 3360 Burns Road, Palm Beach Gardens, FL 33410, (561/888) 848-5200. Please give the family address to Hospice so they will be aware of your generous contribution. The Habian Family, P.O. Box 425, Jupiter, FL 33468-0425.
Dance Claudia La Rocco

LITT--Charlotte (nee Sturtz) 93, of Harrison, NY, died July 7. Wife of the late Herbert Litt. Bronx born, survived by brother Sidney, four children, Eric and Janice, Elan, Arni, Alix and Steven Prince, five grandchildren, seven great- grandchildren. Hunter College graduate; playwright, songwriter, professional dancer, dog trainer, bird trainer; the life of the party. Hostess to Hadassah, Ort, UJA, founding member of Harrison JCC, and with "Herbie" active in the Democratic Party. Always ahead of the times, she marched on Washington for women's rights. Mom will be greatly missed. A private service will be held.

SEATTLE - Like many Yankees, Phil Hughes awoke Friday thinking that Cliff Lee would be a teammate by nightfall. Hughes was thrilled, but he started to wonder how he would fit in. ''Obviously, we're not going to go with a six-man rotation in the second half,'' Hughes said. ''Something's got to give. You kind of do the math and figure it won't be the top three guys, so where do we fall into that picture? That's kind of the way this game is. It's not always about feel-good stories and keeping the guys that were around in spring training. Sometimes, it happens. I'm happy that everything stayed the same.''

JOHN MUIR WILDERNESS, CALIFORNIA, JULY 31, 2009 Chris Albert jumped into a lake near Temple Crag in the eastern part of the Sierras during a trip with his father and brother Micah (who took this photo). They stopped at this spot by chance, the morning they were heading home after seeing a nearby glacier. Then they saw the water, Mr. Albert said, and decided they all wanted to jump in. ''The first time you jump in, it's the kind of cold where it takes your breath away,'' said Mr. Albert, 39, an accountant from Wasco, Calif., who spends his spare time hiking and backpacking. ''At first you jump in and you jump back out it's so cold. But after a while, you get used to it and you can stay in.'' As told to Monica Drake

TRACHTENBERG--Inge (nee Wachenheimer) of Englewood, NJ on July 3, 2010, beloved wife of Mike and mother of Michael, David and Shoshanah, of blessed memory, passed away at age 86 after a long illness which she endured with characteristic dignity and boundless courage. Her strength, generosity, kindness and love enriched her family which included eight grandchildren and five great-grandchildren as well as her community in which she was a forceful, visionary and dedicated leader. The author of three books and numerous short stories and poems, she opened a window to her soul and taught us how, with love and compassion, we can survive and even flourish through unspeakable horrors, whether they are engendered by the Holocaust or by family illness. Truly a role model for the modern woman, her life has been an inspiration and she will live on through the memory of all who had the good fortune of knowing her.

Cory Vaughn, a slugging outfielder and son of the former major league All-Star Greg Vaughn, is the new star of the Brooklyn Cyclones. Here is a little scouting report on him: He slides into base on his left hip, and when patrolling right field, in the shadow of the famous Coney Island Parachute Jump, he is loath to dive on his right side. These are medical practices rather than baseball tactics. Mr. Vaughn, a diabetic, receives insulin constantly through a port in his right leg, attached to a small, squarish pump he must keep in the right pocket of his baseball pants.
In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began. The ''time on the market'' is from the most recent listing to the sales agreement. Manhattan

FERGUSON--Theresa Jean (Renz), 48, of Manhattan, died July 5, 2010. She was CEO and Creative Design Director of Trenz Apparel Incorporated. She worked in the fashion industry for many years prior to creating her own company. She was born and raised by Joan and Robert Renz in Hauppaugh, Long Island. She was a 1985 graduate of FIT. She was married to Michael Ferguson in November 2004 at St. Paul The Apostle Church. Surviving her are her parents, Joan and Robert Renz; two sisters, Patricia and Marie (Michael); brother William (Mary); and four nephews and one niece. Vigil Mass at St. Paul The Apostle Church, Between 59th/60th St. and Columbus Ave, on Monday July 12th at 2pm. Reception to follow at The Princeton Club, 15 West 43rd Street at 3:30pm.

SHAPAZIAN--Robert Michael. Died on June 19th from lung cancer at his home in Los Angeles, CA. He was the director of the Lapis Press founded by the artist Sam Francis and was the founding director of the Gagosian Gallery in Beverly Hills. Robert attended the University of California, Berkeley and received his M.A. and Ph.D. in English from Harvard University. He was a member of the Photographic Committee at the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York, at the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art, and a life member of the Institute for Modern Russian Culture. For his work at the Lapis Press, Robert was named Chevalier in the Order of Arts and Letters by Jack Lang, French Minister of Culture. He received the distinguished LMP Award in American Book Publishing as well as many prizes for book design. Among the artists Robert brought into the Gagosian Gallery were Cecily Brown, Kristen Calabrese, Mark Licari, and Robert Therrien. Upon resigning from the Gallery in 2006, Robert volunteered in many community programs assisting disadvantaged youth. Under the auspices of Inside Out Writers Program, he taught a writing workshop for incarcerated girls at Central Juvenile Hall in Los Angeles. He worked with the Sherry Lansing Foundation and was a member of the Advisory Board at the Center for Juvenile Law and Policy at Loyola Law School, and at Lamp Community assisting mentally ill homeless in Los Angeles. Throughout his life, Robert loved to travel, often to remote regions in Africa, the Middle East and India. He was a guest lecturer at the American University in Cairo, Egypt. He sponsored the education of several children in Africa, India, and the Philippines. He will be missed for his great sense of humor, keen wit, and his boundless energy and enthusiasm.

Things I saw on the beach one morning: an empty vodka bottle, four blackened cigar stubs, numerous cigarette butts, two different broken flip-flops, a large jagged piece of broken glass (this I picked up and carried to the nearest trash receptacle), an abandoned striped beach towel - soaked now by the high tide - and a fresh pile of dog feces. There is always a fresh pile of dog feces, even though there are signs on all entrance paths to the beach stating that from June 1 to Sept. 15 dogs are not allowed on the beach. I have reached the conclusion that for some people the beach - at least this one, in Ocean City, N.J. - is seen as a giant receptacle available for their own personal disposal purposes, even though, like most beaches, our beach has numerous trash and recycling bins set up at convenient intervals.

GREENWALD--John, 1942-2010. Journalist, artist, devoted husband to Rita Lipman, brother, cousin, and uncle. Never expected to survive from his bout of meningitis 12 years ago, John committed himself to living a creative life in his art and in his writing of 500 newspaper columns on popular culture. On July 8th his myriad of health issues finally claimed him. John grew up in the Bronx, graduating from SIA (High School for Industrial Art). For 40 years John worked as a newspaper and magazine reporter, film critic, local radio celebrity, editor, executive, and teacher to all his colleagues at the Army Times, at the seven Journal suburban Washington, DC area newspapers, the American Legion Magazine, the Lowell Sun, and briefly for the Waterbury Republican American. After his bout with meningitis, he focused on painting, drawing, and his media columns. He actively exhibited his art in the Lowell, MA area. John leaves his wife, Rita, to whom he was devoted, his brother Mark, his cousins, nieces and nephews, and his many appreciative fans and friends who enjoyed his artwork, writings, and good company. His artwork can be viewed at johngreenwald.com. A celebration of his life will be held in Lowell at a later date.

A review on June 20 about ''Russia Against Napoleon,'' a history by Dominic Lieven, referred incorrectly to the city of Moscow, which the regime of Czar Alexander I abandoned during Napoleon's invasion in 1812. It was not Russia's capital at the time, St. Petersburg was.

SO a cartoonist walks into a dance studio. It sounds like the setup to a surreal joke, and for Art Spiegelman the experience of collaborating with the venerable dance company Pilobolus has certainly had its off-kilter moments. Pilobolus, which takes its name from a fungus, has lately become known for finding co-conspirators in unusual places; last year it enlisted the head writer of ''SpongeBob SquarePants'' to work on a piece. But while Mr. Spiegelman is known for many things, especially his Pulitzer Prize-winning graphic novel, ''Maus,'' contemporary dance isn't one of them. Still, he and Pilobolus began working together last year, and the upshot, ''Hapless Hooligan in 'Still Moving,' '' will be seen in New York when the troupe begins its new season at the Joyce Theater on Monday. Though, as Mr. Spiegelman details below, the process could be awkward at times, it couldn't have been all bad. Reviewing the world premiere at Dartmouth College last month in The New York Times, Alastair Macaulay described a ''dizzying overlap of cartoon, film, silhouette theater, and live dance,'' creating an effect so strange ''it's as if we're being given a fleeting glimpse of the inner workings of the universe.'' STEPHANIE GOODMAN

The Mets were in the sweepstakes for Cliff Lee, but they never got close to making a deal with the Mariners. He acknowledged that ''pitching is always a commodity that you seek'' but said he thought that his starting pitchers were doing fine and that there were other areas that the Mets might be better advised to address.

One thing I've argued many times on this blog is that when assessing the record of fiscal policy, you have to make allowance for the fact that things are different when you're in a liquidity trap.* Estimating the average effect of fiscal shocks in all regimes, as opposed to those rare occasions when you're in a liquidity trap, tells you little about how things work now. That's why I really liked the Almunia et al work on fiscal policy in the 1930s, which tried to focus on a period resembling where we are now.

In 1983, Diane Von Furstenberg sold her cosmetics business, flew to London and promptly ensconced herself at Claridge's. "I felt I had made it," she said recently at a cocktail party. "I was young and kicky." Older now but kicky as ever, she's designing 20 rooms for the hotel, bringing her unapologetically exuberant style to an Art Deco landmark. The three rooms completed so far - the others, each unique, will be done by the end of the year - include headboards blooming with Chinese roses and floors covered in silk leopard-print rugs, along with finishing touches like custom-made cashmere blankets and zebra-print bathrobes. Amid all the floral and jungle textiles, she's also created quiet corners where guests can primp surrounded by handmade dressing tables and leather traveling trunks.

The biofuel concept: If you just burn plant materials, you put out a lot of bad pollutants. But if you heat the materials in a container without oxygen ("pyrolysis"), you leave most of the carbon as "biochar," which makes an excellent soil additive (in fact Amazon Indians built up rich soils over hundreds of years using biochar). The gas that is given off by pyrolysis can be processed into clean-burning fuel. All of which sounds great, but skeptics point out that Africa is a prime target for biofuel land grabs, which destroy small farms and forest preserves. Hence the importance of using agricultural residues like corn cobs, and researching the impact.

The Iowa-born designer Tim Hamilton is not one to shy away from his roots. "My vision comes from where I grew up and the experiences I've had," Hamilton says. Nevertheless, the all-American boy-makes-good clichés don't quite ring true. Hamilton may have Midwestern roots and a C.V. that includes stints at Ralph Lauren and J. Crew, but his sympathies are more British punk than Ivy League preppy - it's not hard to imagine Joe Strummer, circa 1980, suiting up in one of Hamilton's rapier-thin blazers. (His women's line, which he introduced last fall, is equally sharp.) And his references tend to be peppered with black humor. His spring 2011 men's collection, which was scheduled to be staged during the recent men's shows in Paris but was canceled at the last minute due to budgetary constraints, was inspired by the Belgian artist Michaël Borremans's somber portraits of workers in their uniforms. "The surfaces were very chic and painterly," Hamilton explains. "But they all looked depressed - that's where the dark part comes in." The Moment caught up with Hamilton to talk about his love of British youth culture and why the Corn Belt is more avant-garde than you might think.

A hotel in Cyprus said that it might sue Jennifer Lopez after the singer withdrew from a scheduled performance for fear that the show would be construed as making a political statement, Agence France-Presse reported. Ms. Lopez was to perform at the Cratos Premium hotel and casino complex in Turkish-occupied northern Cyprus on July 24, an event that Greek Cypriots had said would further polarize the country, which has been divided since the 1970s and whose northern region is recognized only by Turkey. Ms. Lopez's representatives said last week that she would not perform the concert, citing their "sensitivity to the political realities of the region." But Murat Bozoglu, the chief executive of the company that runs Cratos Premium, told Agence France-Presse that Ms. Lopez's contract for the show had not been canceled. "If she does not show up for the concert, we will begin a procedure in the courts to claim $35 to $40 million in damages," Mr. Bozoglu said.

A new CNN correspondent, Amber Lyon, and a new CNN contributor, Philippe Cousteau, wore hazardous-materials suits as they swam in the contaminated waters and tried to convey the grimy oil residue they were seeing. The murky live shots from underneath the sea made more than a few viewers chuckle, but they were memorable, and sometimes that's the point.

You could certainly make the argument that New York's upper classes hardly want these days for personal attention, surrounded as they are by helicopter pilots who fly them to the Hamptons and private stylists who make haircut house calls. But even with today's apparently recession-proof forms of conspicuous consumption, it would be hard to find a servant with the all-encompassing talents - the cradle-to-grave service - of Isaac H. Brown. Mr. Brown, who died 130 years ago, was the longtime sexton at Grace Episcopal Church in Greenwich Village, an official title that belied his real role as the amanuensis to, and the arbiter of fashion in, Knickerbocker society. Working at the church from 1845 until his death in 1880, he was a handyman to the smart set: planning their weddings, arranging their soirees and seeing to their funerals when they died.

KOZA--Sam, 93. Esteemed musician and trumpeter, including 1939 World's Fair, Ballet Russe, and Broadway (South Pacific, Music Man and all the greats). Proud member of the Goldman Band for over fifty years, and Aqueduct and Belmont bugler for 28 years. Passed away peacefully July 10 surrounded by loving family. Beloved husband of Blanche. Survived by his adoring children Patrice and Mitchell, son and daughter-in-law Isadore and Antoinette, devoted grandfather of Blaine, Alexandra and Maxine. Services at Zion Memorial Chapel, 785 E. Boston Post Road, Mamaroneck, N.Y. Tuesday July 13 at 10:30am.

LOS ANGELES - It appears that New York, not Los Angeles, will be the battleground for a supersize legal contest between the Marvel Entertainment unit of the Walt Disney Company and heirs of the comic book genius Jack Kirby. When last seen in these pages, the Kirby heirs and Marvel had squared off in the federal courts of both New York and Los Angeles. Marvel first filed suit in the Southern District of New York, asking the court to confirm Disney's ownership of comic book characters like the Incredible Hulk and the X-Men, despite Mr. Kirby's work on them. The Kirbys fired back in the Central District of California, asserting, among other things, the right to reclaim copyrights to many of those characters.

GILBERT--Marcella, nee Paymer, of Sarasota, FL, and Manhattan, died on July 10, after a brief illness, just short of her 92nd birthday. Adored wife of Philip, who predeceased her, and devoted companion to Robert Caress. Loving mother to Maggie (Dr. Kenneth) Pinsker and Jon (Carlyn). Proud grandparent to Joanna, Emily, Jeffrey and Erica. Cherished sister and sister-in-law to Edwin Paymer and Evelyn Messinger. Marcella was a gifted teacher who inspired her students at Rockland Community College and "Pelican Cove University" in Sarasota. She was committed to causes that fostered civil rights and social justice and worked tirelessly for them. A ceremony will be held at the graveside at 11:00am on Tuesday, July 13, at Mount Hope Cemetery, Hastings on Hudson, NY.

I have played at the Old Course in St. Andrews on a windy day. Last week on a visit to Aruba, where the Caribbean trade winds gust mightily across the lone 18-hole golf course on the island, I learned some more lessons about playing in the wind. The traditional advice is to take more club and use a three-quarter swing. This is to avoid swinging too hard and imparting the kind of backspin that balloons the ball into the wind.

The Old Course at St. Andrews, site of this week's British Open, is hardly a typical golf course, so perhaps it is fitting that ''Play Away Please, The Tale of the Sale of Golf's Greatest Icon'' (Mainstream Publishing) is not your typical golf book. When the starter's box at the Old Course, one of golf's most recognizable structures, was put up for auction during a 2001 renovation, the author, John Peter Hagen, decided to bid on it. It was a dream and a belief in the power of a symbol - the decades-old little box had sent off all the great golfers of the 20th century, countless duffers, and presidents and kings, too. And from it, at the start of every round, came three stately words: Play Away, Please. Hagen, a California-based housing developer and an avid golfer, bought the box on the day before the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11. The rest of the story takes nearly eight years as the weather-beaten box is dismantled and shipped some 7,000 miles. Travails and surprises ensue. This becomes a story that is as much about a place, St. Andrews, and its people, as it is about a distinctive tiny hut. It's about chasing a passion, and it's about the price, literally and figuratively, one can pay for it. Again, this isn't your usual golf book, and it takes a leap of faith. But it is a very romantic, quixotic journey, and in that context, it makes it all about golf.

When Jon Stewart announced on the June 29 episode of ''The Daily Show'' that ''Jezebel thinks I'm a sexist,'' some viewers may have been wondering: who exactly is Jezebel? At least a million and a half people can answer that question; that's how many visited the site, a women's interest blog, last month. Mr. Stewart's comment was a response to Jezebel's recent report on claims by women who say they faced a sexist environment when they were ''Daily Show'' writers and correspondents. The post garnered more than 211,000 page views, over 1,000 comments and a sharp retort from 32 female employees currently with ''The Daily Show.''

New York City's police force, in its fight against crime, has increasingly used a strategy known as ''stop, question and frisk,'' which allows officers to stop someone based on a reasonable suspicion of crime. One expert has estimated New Yorkers are stopped at twice the national rate. The impact on crime is much debated, and critics contend disproportionate stopping of minorities is a result of racial profiling, which police officials dispute.SOUTH BRONX is one of the city's high crime centers: Three precincts in the area rank in the top 10 among 74 precincts* in the city for violent crime. In the 40th Precinct, the southernmost tip, police made more than 15,000 stops last year, third highest per capita in the city. Just 608 resulted in arrests, a 4 percent rate. While watching the British Open this week at the hallowed Old Course at St. Andrews, you may observe some nuances to the Rules of Golf not seen at weekly PGA Tour events. For example, St. Andrews has seven large greens that serve as the same green for two holes. In each case, the hole numbers add up to 18 - the 2nd and the 16th, the 3rd and the 15th, and so on. This can lead to some atypical circumstances, like a player's ball coming to rest in the hole for the 16th while he was playing the 2nd hole. What's the appropriate play from there?

WOLF--Arthur, died peacefully in his sleep on July 11, 2010, at his long-time home in Mamaroneck, NY. Born September 13, 1910 in Vienna, Austria, he was the son of Isidor and Rachel Wolf. He immigrated to the United States in 1938, marrying in 1942. He is survived by his loving wife Rose, his daughters Sandy Wolf Soule and her husband Steve Soule of Riverside CT; Diane Wolf and her husband Lewis Bennett of Wilmington, DE; grandchildren Hilary Soule Shea and her husband David; Jeff Soule and his wife Rebecca; Lisa Bennett and her husband David; Joshua Wolf Bennett and his fiancee Katie Hagan, and great-grandchildren Zachary and Ellie Shea, and Arianna Almog. Arthur's career spanned from his family's shirt factory in Vienna, to a post-war real estate management and development business that he continued well past the age of 90. He was an active member of Larchmont Temple for nearly 60 years, a strong supporter of Israel, and ever grateful to have had the opportunity of being a proud citizen of the United States. His family meant everything to him, and his loving spirit will be a blessed memory forever. The funeral will take place at Larchmont Temple on Monday, July 12, at 12noon. In lieu of flowers, memorial gifts may be sent to the Arthur & Rose Wolf Israel Fund, Larchmont Temple, 75 Larchmont Avenue, Larchmont, NY 10538 or the American Friends of Magen David Adom - ARMDI, 352 Seventh Avenue, Suite 400, New York, NY 10001. Services are being handled by the John J. Fox Funeral Home. www.jjffh.com

Typically, short-haul commercial flights are something to be endured, not enjoyed. In the case of Porter Airlines, however, getting there is half the fun. The Toronto-based boutique fleet's comfy leather seats and seamless service come at the cost of coach but feel like flying private. O.K., maybe I'm getting a little carried away. But on two recent flights from Newark to Toronto, I zipped through check-in, security and customs, and because Porter operates out of Billy Bishop Toronto City Airport, you're only a short ferry ride away from the heart of downtown. Add to this business-class-level lounges (the one at Billy Bishop is particularly well appointed), state-of-the-art equipment (fast, clean and quiet Bombardier 400 turboprops) and a fairly flexible booking structure. Not to mention the adorable uniforms: the female flight attendants wear tailored navy suits and dresses with jaunty pillbox hats from the Canadian label Pink Tartan while serving up the complimentary snacks, soft drinks, beer and wine. It may not be the same as flying on your own G5, but all in all the experience is pretty uplifting.

I grew up a Red Sox fan in the 1980s, when the Sox were pretty good, the Yankees were increasingly lousy, and George Steinbrenner, their bombastic owner, was a national joke. We Sox fans didn't need to hate him; serious Yankee fans did that for us, bemoaning the constant psychodrama, the managerial revolving door, the ill-advised spending sprees and the trades that always seemed to ship off good young players to get veterans who were just about to pass their peak. Those were the Yankees of Steve Trout and Ed Whitson, Andy Hawkins and Mel Hall, the Ken Phelps-for-Jay Buhner trade and the long slow decline of Don Mattingly, their only true 1980s great. And then they were the Yankees of Howard Spira, the gambler who Steinbrenner paid to gather dirt on Dave Winfield, leading to the Yankee owner's suspension from baseball "for life"  in 1990. His team went 67-95 that year, 71-91 the next, and it seemed like Steinbrenner would be remembered as the owner who saved Yankee baseball in the 1970s only to destroy it a decade later.

It could be that the Swedish novelist Stieg Larsson was just weeks and a little more than 100 pages away from finishing the fourth manuscript in his best-selling Millennium series. According to an e-mail message that John-Henri Holmberg, a friend of Mr. Larsson, provided to The Associated Press, Mr. Larsson was 320 pages into a 440-page book when he died at age 50 in November 2004. Mr. Larsson had planned to finish the book by December 2004, Mr. Holmberg added. The manuscript is believed to be in the custody of Eva Gabrielsson, Mr. Larsson's companion, but she has declined to make it public. If published, a fourth novel in the series would almost certainly be a best seller, based on the intense interest in the first three books about Lisbeth Salander and the journalist Mikhael Blomkvist.

These are some of my favorite things - small vessels in glass, ceramic or creamware. I buy them here and there; some are expensive, some cost hardly anything at all. I often buy them for myself with photo shoots in mind, but some of the pieces shown here belong to a client, and the colored glass vases are from William Yeoward. The Metropolitan Opera has made live broadcasts in movie theaters a staple across the malls, multiplexes and art houses of the world. But competitors have emerged, including the Royal Opera House in London. That company is now expanding its offerings through a new deal with Emerging Pictures, a network that provides digital transmissions of events to movie theaters. In an agreement announced on Tuesday, Emerging Pictures will become the North American distributor of shows from the Royal Opera's media arm, Opus Arte. The shows will include live performances of operas and ballets, as well as filmed productions of Shakespeare plays from the Globe Theater, for which Opus Arte has the rights. The first event to be shown under the new arrangement will be the opening-night performance of Mozart's "Così fan Tutte" on Sept. 10 at Covent Garden.

John McTiernan, the director of "Die Hard" and "The Hunt for Red October," has pleaded guilty - again - in a case linked to an investigation of a prominent private detective who worked for Hollywood's rich and famous. Mr. McTiernan admitted on Monday to lying to the F.B.I. and to a judge in connection with a probe of the investigator, Anthony Pellicano, according to The Associated Press. He faces up to a year in prison. The director pleaded guilty four years ago to lying to agents but later successfully moved to have the plea voided. Mr. Pellicano was sentenced to 15 years in prison in December 2008 for illegal wiretapping.
