LONOFF--Evelyn (nee Kushins) of West Palm Beach, FL, died peacefully July 10, 2010 at the age of 87. Born on April 12, 1923 in New York City, she graduated from Hunter College, and taught biology for 35 years in the NYC public schools. She is survived by her devoted husband, Richard, her sons, Marc Lonoff (Alice), of Northbrook, Illinois, and Jon Lonoff of Brooklyn, New York, and her grandchildren, Julie Lonoff, and David Lonoff, whom she adored, and who adored her. Private services will be held in Florida.

The ''Popular Demand'' listing in the Most Wanted chart on June 28, about online searches during the 2010 FIFA World Cup competition, described the action in an accompanying picture incorrectly. It showed Landon Donovan, a member of the United States soccer team, scoring the deciding goal against Algeria in the first round -- not the game-tying goal.

SHEMEL--Shirley, beloved wife of the late Sidney. Cherished mother of Barbara Cushing and Halimah McGee. Adored grandmother of Oriana, Will, Rachel, Rick, Andrew and Benjamin. Loving sister-in-law of Helene Susman. Dear cousin of Richard Pell and David Zinman. Passionate teacher for over forty years. Treasured friend of many. Services Wednesday, July 14, 2010 at the Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza (Opposite the LIRR), Great Neck, NY.

IRVINGS--Irene S.,(nee Stadlen), passed away July 9, 2010, at the age of 87. Beloved wife, best friend, and soulmate of Leo Irvings for 62 years. Much loved mother of Ruth (Amy Shapiro) Irvings and Lisa (Michael Brill) Irvings, and grandmother of Jonah Shapiro, Ari Shapiro, Nathan Brill and Henry Brill. Also survived by brothers Isadore Stadlen and Stanley (Marilyn) Stadlen. Irene was a lifelong New Yorker who moved to Milwaukee with Leo in 2008. A graveside service was held on Sunday, July 11 in Milwaukee. Memorials in Irene's name to COA Youth & Family Centers, 909 E. North Ave., Milwaukee, WI 53212 are appreciated.

WOOD--Dr. Mary McNeal, of Montclair, NJ died at her home on July 10 after a long struggle with cardiomyopathy and heart failure. Dr. Wood was born Mary Caroline McNeal in Lewes, Delaware, April 12, 1925. While in college, during World War II she worked in the chemistry laboratory at Triumph Explosives, a former fireworks factory converted to manufacturing antiaircraft artillery shells. Dr. Wood graduated the University of Pennsylvania School of Medicine in 1950, becoming one of the first women to join the medical profession as a physician at that time. Interning at the University of Pennsylvania Hospital, she met her future husband, a fellow intern. In 1959 Dr. Wood settled in Montclair, where she was successively on the Anesthesia staffs of Orange Memorial Hospital, heading the anesthesia department for a time, and at Mountainside Hospital in Glen Ridge, from which she retired in 1989. Following retirement Dr. Wood enjoyed playing bridge, displaying her life-long prowess at cooking for family and friends, and solving New York Times crossword puzzles. Dr. Wood leaves her husband of 57 years, Dr. Francis A. Wood, three sons, Thomas, Richard, and John, and daughter, Penelope, nine grandchildren, and a brother, James Hector McNeal, Jr. Funeral Services Saturday, 11am at Central Presbyterian Church, 46 Park St. Montclair, NJ. Visiting hours will be Wednesday 2-4 pm and 7-9pm at Shook's Cedar Grove Funeral Home, 486 Pompton Ave., Cedar Grove, NJ. Condolences and memories can be shared at: www.shookscedargrove.com. In lieu of flowers, donation to The Lenox Hill Cardiovascular Foundation, 130 E. 77th Street, New York, NY 10075 is appreciated.

The Supreme Court is being asked to decide whether the House of Representatives should be enlarged to produce a fairer distribution of political power. A group of voters appealed to the court after a special three-judge panel in Mississippi last week rejected their lawsuit seeking to at least double the number of seats in the House in the interest of evening out the sizes of Congressional districts.

LEMBO--Gregory L.,75, of Palm Beach, FL, died on July 11, 2010. Born in Brooklyn, he was long employed with the finance firm of Salomon Brothers, Inc., in New York until 1987; and maintained a summer home in Spring Lake, NJ. A Funeral Mass will be held in Palm Beach on Friday. Quattlebaum Funeral Home: 561-832-517/ www.Quattlebaum.org

AVEDON--Albert B.,MD, born in Paris on July 10, 1908. Died on July 11, 2010. A physician for over 60 years. Served in the US Army as a Major in the medical corps during WWII. Participated in the liberation of Buchenwald Concentration Camp in the creation of the first field hospital to treat the surviving prisoners. He was given the Merit of Honor by the French Government with the title of Chevalier. He was a honorary Police Surgeon of the NYPD with two citations by police commissioners Benjamin Ward and Howard Safir. Survived by his wife, Nora and children Steven (Netta) and Nina (Paul), and granddaughters Danielle and Jennifer. Services today 11:30am at "The Riverside," 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

A small company with a new brain scan for detecting plaque, the hallmark physical sign of Alzheimer's disease, presented its results on Sunday at an international conference in Hawaii, and experts who attended said the data persuaded them that the method works. Until now, the only definitive way to diagnose Alzheimer's has been to search for plaque with a brain autopsy after the patient dies. Scientists hope the new scanning technique, described June 24 in The New York Times's series ''The Vanishing Mind,'' will allow doctors to see plaque while the patient is still alive, improving diagnosis and aiding research on drugs to slow or stop plaque accumulation.

LOVE--Nancy, literary agent, former magazine editor, writer, died on July 10, 2010 at 82 from cancer. Originally from Philadelphia, she graduated Phi Beta Kappa from University of Pennsylvania in 1949. She wrote for many national magazines, was managing editor, Philadelphia Magazine, editor, Boston Magazine, and Cue. In 1983 she started the Nancy Love Literary Agency where she worked until her death. The Agency will continue with the same name. This year three of her writers' books were published: "Reset" by Stephen Kinzer, "Brazil on the Rise" by Larry Rohter and "My Brother My Enemy" by Philip Smucker. Nancy is survived by her children, Judy Love, Steve Love, four grandchildren and two great-grandchildren. In lieu of flowers, send tax deductible contributions to Writers Emergency Assistance Fund, payable to "ASJA Charitable Trust" 1501 Broadway, Suite 302, New York, NY 10036. Memorial service at 1pm, Sunday, July 18, 2010, Temple Adas Israel, Sag Harbor.

Just off New York City lies the Hudson Canyon, a deep gash in the seabed that runs for hundreds of miles. Charter boats and commercial fishermen have long known that the canyon's headwaters swarm with tuna, swordfish, monkfish, tilefish, red crabs and other sea life. Now, scientists have discovered a surprising potential reason for at least part of the canyon's riches -- methane bubbling up from the seabed.

GLASSER--Harold L.,91, died peacefully on July 11, in his home in Highland Beach, Florida. The cause of death was bladder cancer. He was born on August 22, 1918 in New York, NY, the son of the late Herman and Etta Glasser. He earned B.A., J.D. and L.L.M. degrees from New York University, Harvard Law School, Columbia Law School and the New York University Graduate School of Law. From 1959 to 1986, Mr. Glasser enjoyed a career as president of the Miss Universe, Miss USA, and Miss Teen USA Pageants. He also served as General Counsel of the Kayser-Roth Corporation, President of the American Society of Corporate Secretaries, and Mayor of the incorporated Village of Saddle Rock, NY. Active in various philanthropic campaigns of the Anti-Defamation League, Mr. Glasser was the recipient of two Human Rights Awards. He was Chairman of the League's Great Neck Division and New York Lawyers Division. Harold Glasser had a distinguished military career, serving overseas in World War II as Bombardier, 1st Lieutenant. He was awarded 12 combat decorations including the Distinguished Flying Cross and Air Medal with three Oak Leaf Clusters. He was a member of the Air Force Association, Veterans of Foreign Wars, Disabled American Veterans, American Legion and Jewish War Veterans. A book honoring his accomplishments, Courage Takes Flight: The Life and Times of Harold Glasser, by Dr. Patricia Kollander, will be published shortly by The American Life Publishers. He is survived by his loving wife Marny and his son Kerry. Services will be held at Beth Israel Memorial Chapel, Boynton Beach, FL on Sunday, July 18, at 3pm. Memorial contributions may be made, if wished, to the ASPCA.

DEVINE--Louise W. Deeply saddened by the passing of their beloved "Weasie," the family of Louise Williams Devine celebrates her full and happy life and her enduring spirit of optimism and generosity. She died peacefully at age 90 in her beautiful Berkshires. An elegant woman of simple tastes, she enjoyed pastoral views, spotting wildlife, reading, well-worn sweaters, watching tennis, lobster dinners, Christmas shopping in July, and her "Baltimore sandwich" of peanut butter, lettuce and mayonnaise. Throughout her life, she enjoyed the company of her family and a large number of friends in Florida, Massachusetts and New York. She took great pride in her grandchildren, Lydia, Andrew and Meredith. An ardent conservationist and champion of the arts, she quietly enhanced the lives of others through the many causes she supported. Weasie is survived by her sister, Edith W. MacGuire, and her three children: Mallory Culver Devine Norris, Rodney Williams Devine and Ian Clark Devine. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to JerichoProject.org or to WorldWildlife.org. A memorial service will be held at the Meeting House in New Marlborough, MA, on August 7 at 11am.

KLAR--Arnold, died on July 11, 2010 surrounded by his loving family. He was 95. MileMeter likes to think of itself as the "anti-insurance insurance company." It sells auto insurance by the mile -- which means that the less you drive, the less you pay for insurance. And yet, despite that appealing notion, when the global financial crisis hit, the company actually made the decision to shut down -- because it couldn't raise the money to get started. Watch the video below to see how Chris Gay, founder and chief executive, managed to keep the company alive.

An article in The New York Times on Wednesday, "Trapped by Gaza Blockade, Locked in Despair," concerns Palestinians in Gaza, most of whom are descended from refugees of the 1948 war that created Israel. Meet six of the artists, designers and writers (and one opera singer) behind the year-old dismagazine.com. According to its mission statement, the collective is determined to "disrupt the dismal dissemination of fashion discourse." Which explains the kind of fashion shoots they style, sometimes using women's underwear worn below the knee, a men's dress shirt fashioned as a pair of pants or an earring made from a small bag of marijuana. It's as if Dazed & Confused stocked its fashion closet with Etsy.com. "The only thing shallow about style is how people consider it," says Lauren Boyle, member of the collective and its spokeswoman. Next up: an online shop, DisOwn, which will sell its featured products.

As recently as 2005, Steinbrenner had the Kentucky Derby favorite, Bellamy Road, who finished seventh.

A good friend inherited a Victorian circular oak dining table. The table has great sentimental value, but the matching oak and cane chairs - high-back and ornate - needed to go. He wanted something up to date but not hyper-modern (no plastic, no chrome). I suggested a bentwood chair like the ones that Thonet has been manufacturing for years, which would relate to the Victorian design of the table but still feel modern. He liked the idea but not the price tag (the chairs are about $400 a piece), and he was concerned about the sturdiness of the caned seats, an issue he had with the original chairs.

The prodigious productivity of Lil Wayne apparently knows no bounds -- not even a stint in prison will prevent him from putting out new material, even if he's not readily available to promote it. Lil Wayne, who in March was sentenced to a year at Rikers Island  in New York for attempted possession of a weapon after a gun was found on his tour bus in 2007, could be out for good behavior in eight months -- a date that could coordinate nicely with a fourth-quarter release for his next album, "Tha Carter IV." But why wait that long? Cortez Bryant, the chief executive of Lil Wayne's Young Money record label and a co-manager of the rapper, whose real name is Dwayne Carter Jr, told Vibe.com that he is planning to put out a new EP of Lil Wayne material,  "I'm Not a Human Being," even sooner. "I'll probably drop it on his birthday, Sept. 27," Mr. Bryant said, adding that he would probably "put it out virally and maybe package it up for Christmas. Give 'em a hard copy later for fan appreciation."

A majority of the advisory panel of the Food and Drug Administration voted today to restrict the sales of Avandia, a controversial diabetes drug, because of its potential risk for causing heart attacks. The 33-member advisory committee was deeply divided. Twelve voted to remove Avandia from the market altogether; 10 for continued sale but with new label revisions and possible restrictions; 7 to add more warnings and 3 for no change at all. But the votes can also be viewed as a decision by a majority, 21, to continue allowing sales of Avandia, with more restrictions. A final decision will be made by the F.D.A. at a later date.

In 1982, researchers affiliated with the Cooper Institute in Dallas surveyed a large group of well-educated, affluent men. The researchers were interested in the men's exercise habits, but they also asked, almost incidentally, about their indolence. Specifically, they inquired about how many hours each day the men spent watching television or sitting in a car. (This was before you could do both at once.) Over the years, the survey's main results were used to reinforce a growing body of science about the health benefits of regular exercise.

It wasn't just a cold and windy night in early June as Ángel Franco waited; it was raining so hard that water had begun to seeping into his camera equipment. Then came the call: four shootings at West 35th Street and Surf Avenue in Brooklyn - the Coney Island Houses. On his way, Mr. Franco passed a couple of vehicles that had crashed at West 17th Street and Surf Avenue, one of which was evidently the getaway car. A bit farther along, some police officers searched for weapons as others sought brief refuge from the downpour. Not long before, a man and a 16-year-old girl were having a dispute in a courtyard of the housing development when the girl's 19-year-old brother came out to separate them. An argument followed, The Times reported. "Shots rang out moments later, and the mother of the two teenagers, who had just stepped out of the apartment, was struck in the head. The father of the woman identified her as Victoria Rogucki and said she had seven children, including 2-year-old twins. 'She was trying to keep them from fighting,' said the father, Charles Rogucki, 71, adding that Ms. Rogucki is his youngest child. An officer at the crash scene reflected on the disheartening events. "It's only Wednesday," he said, rain running down his face.

SIEPI--Cesare. The opera world mourns the loss of Siepi who died on July 5 at age 87. I treasure my association as his personal secretary during his 23 years at The Met. He possessed the most beautiful voice I ever heard. His personality, charm, tall, handsome appearance on stage, artistry and glorious voice will be remembered forever. I continued our relationship and friendship for 60 years and spoke to him two weeks prior to his death. I extend my heartfelt sympathy to his family. Rita Mottola

COOPER--Howard Morton, Mortgage Broker, Dies at 83. Howard Cooper, a long time mortgage broker, died peacefully at Ellis Hospital in Niskayuna, New York on Monday. He was 83 and lived in New York City and East Hampton, NY. His daughter, Dr. Karen Cooper, said the direct cause of death was mild heart failure after a long and courageous battle with Alzheimer's Disease. Howard Cooper was born in Mt. Vernon, NY on August 21, 1926 to Samuel and Clara Cooper, both Russian immigrants. He was the youngest of four children. After graduating high school he attended Iona College in New Rochelle, NY and left to enlist in the Army in 1945. He served our country as an airplane crew chief with the 25th Tactical Reconnaisance Squadron at Itami Army Air Base in Osaka, Japan. He was responsible for the repair and maintenance of P-51s. Thus began his love of airplanes and flying. In 1947 he returned from the Army with an honorable discharge and began working with his father, Sam, as a salesman at Junior Formals, Inc. In 1951 he went to work with his father-in-law the late and well-loved Nathan J. Sonnenblick at Sonnenblick-Goldman Corp who taught him the business of mortgage brokerage which became one of the true loves of his life. In 1964 Howard co founded Cooper-Horowitz, Inc. which became one of the top respected powerhouses in the Mortgage Brokerage business. His love of airplanes took him soaring to the sky as a pilot in his Cessna and he always found peace at his house in East Hampton, NY where he enjoyed gardening and walks on the beach. His children and grandchildren were a great source of pleasure and he always wanted to be a part of their lives. He will be deeply missed by his children, Peter, Karen and Neal; their spouses, Denny Allen and Jody; his grandchildren, Sasha, Joshua, Casey and Caroline. "The Chief" as he was known to so many touched every one's life who had the great fortune to meet him and will always be remembered for his charismatic personality and love of life. A celebration of life will be Thursday, July 15th at The Riverside, 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave at 11:30am. Interrment will be a 4pm reception at Bobby Vans on 46 St. and Park Ave. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the Alzheimer's Foundation of America at alzfdn.org.

How often in the 21st century does one have the chance to see a 19th-century river wall embedded under a 20th-century highway? Rarely enough that amateur urban archaeologists might want to hasten to the observation gallery in the Winter Garden overlooking the World Trade Center site. For the next few days - but not much longer - a 40-foot-long section will be visible of the massive bulkhead that marked Lower Manhattan's edge until the creation of Battery Park City. What can be seen are several courses of granite blocks, each about two feet high, two feet deep and four feet long. They are arranged in a kind of monumental Flemish bond, with the blocks' long and short sides laid in an alternating pattern.

HAMILTON--Alexander Reid "Pete", of New York City, December 8th, 1920 - July 11, 2010. Born in Paris, France. Attended the Hackley School. Graduated from Hamilton College in 1943. He served as a Lieutenant in the U.S. Navy where he saw action in the Pacific Theater and at D-Day. Graduated from Yale Law School in 1949. Partner in the Law Firm of Satterlee, Stephens, Burke & Burke. He was past President of Clan Hamilton USA, Chairman of Scottish Heritage USA, a member of the St Andrews Society of New York, and Honorary Councillor to the National Trust for Scotland. He is survived by his devoted wife of 59 years Mary Morgan Hamilton, daughter Virginia Hamilton of Sacramento, son Alexander Morgan "Sandy" Hamilton and his wife Linnae Hamilton of New York City, son Bruce Thomas Hamilton and his wife Rosemary M. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in the name of Alexander R. Hamilton to Scottish Heritage USA, PO Box 457, Pinehurst, NC 28370 or the Church of the Heavenly Rest, New York City.

STEINBRENNER--George. On behalf of the Department of Pediatrics and all at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, deep condolences on the passing of Mr. George Steinbrenner, a beloved part of the MSK family. He has been a long-standing, generous donor both through the NY Yankees organization and his own philanthropy. He was a trusted and respected friend of the institution. We are particularly grateful for Mr. Steinbrenner's role in our partnership with Yankees Universe: the resolute advocacy and dedicated philanthropy of the Yankees has helped to speed development of more effective, less toxic pediatric cancer therapies. More significantly, it has provided innumerable smiles, memories, and important moments of relief to countless young patients and their families as they enjoyed special days at Yankee Stadium and personal visits from baseball legends, including Mr. Steinbrenner himself. We are so honored to have been touched by his legacy. Our thoughts and prayers are with the Steinbrenner family and the entire Yankees organization. Richard J. O'Reilly, M.D., Chairman Nina J. Pickett, Administrator

BERLIN -- German companies are realizing that trade with China, more so than with Russia or other countries, is becoming its economic salvation. Germany is China's biggest trading partner by far in Europe, and the trade is increasing by leaps and bounds, especially for high-value electrical and electronic goods. Germany's auto industry, which suffered greatly during the global financial crisis, has recovered thanks in large part to a surge in Chinese demand for the top range of German cars. In fact, BMW raised its 2010 forecasts on Tuesday for that very reason.

SOHNE--Robert F.,born June 13, 1929 passed away on Monday, July 12, 2010, of natural causes. Bob was an original; a semi-celebrity from Williamsburg, Brooklyn; and the time of many people's lives. His true gift was the art of storytelling where the most mundane of events were told with humor, suspense, and emotion. Bob's flair for the dramatic led him to the stage, where he was the star of many plays for the Brooklyn College Players and the Monticello Playhouse at Kiamesha Lake, New York in 1955. His finest hour was his depiction of Willie Loman in Death of a Salesman. All of Bob's reviews garnered glowing praise. While he loved the stage, he decided to partner with his brother Jerry to build what would be a very successful electronic tube distribution business, allowing him to retire at the age of 39. Bob always made choices that were ahead of his time, which allowed him to enjoy life to the fullest with his true love and late wife Evelyn: becoming a health food nut and jogger before they were trendy; delighting in the sparsely populated Hamptons in the 60's; investing in technology startups like IBM and Intel, and crisscrossing the country in the family motor-home during the summers. Bob is survived by his adoring daughters, Abbe Bensimon, Wendy Harris, and Alice Meyer, his three sons-in-law, his seven grandchildren, all of whom he was exceedingly proud of, his devoted brother Jerry Sohne and sister Eleanor Marcus and treasured nieces and nephews. Funeral services will be held for Bob on Wednesday, July 14, 2010 at Gutterman's, 11:30am at 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, NY

There was a day in spring training a dozen years ago, leaving the Yankees' clubhouse at what was then Legends Field, when I turned a corner and walked right into the puffed-out chest of George Steinbrenner. He grumped at me - could have been anybody, really - for being in his space and even let slip a profanity or two, before stepping back, composing himself and extending a hand.

For years I advised George Steinbrenner to get out of town because he dishonored my hometown with his bullying and bombast. Then one strange night in San Diego, I found myself hugging him. Very strange.

LOS ANGELES -- Empirically speaking, geologists are not a particularly irascible group. But those who make their living studying rocks, minerals and gems in California -- and increasingly those scientists beyond the state's borders -- are enraged over a bill in Sacramento that would knock serpentine, the official state rock, off its mantle. The lawmaker and others who would like to see serpentine stripped of its title say the olive green rock found all over the state is a grim symbol of the deadly cancers associated with asbestos, which can be found in the rock. Geologists, who have taken to Twitter on behalf of the rock, assert that serpentine is harmless and is being demonized by advocates for people with asbestos-related diseases and possibly their trial lawyers, too.

On an April day in 2004, I was standing outside the owner's box at Yankee Stadium, sweating through my shirt although it wasn't hot. I was saying a quick prayer because I needed all the help I could get with my first big assignment for the New York Times. My mission? Write a detailed profile of George M. Steinbrenner III, a man who hadn't granted a long interview in several years. Oh yes, that would be easy. I felt doomed.I had never covered baseball as a beat, but I grew up watching the Yankees. I'd seen ''Seinfeld.'' So I knew what kind of snake pit I had been thrown into. Or, at least, I thought I had.
Under George Steinbrenner, the Yankees changed managers more than 20 times and won seven World Series, more than twice as many titles as any other team captured in an era that began in 1973.

JUDELL--Celeste Seymour, on Saturday, July 10, 2010 from Non-Hodgkin's Lymphoma. Born in Beverly Hills, CA and was the daughter of silent film star Jocelyn Lee and Hollywood film director Luther Reed. She was the stepdaughter of James Seymour. A resident of New York City until she married her husband, Harold Judell and relocated to New Orleans. Survived by her children, Victoria Grulich and Valerie Thompsen, and grandchildren Christopher Grulich, Kai and Van Thompsen (Jeffery Thompsen; stepmother of Denise Judell Provosty (Van Provosty). Preceded in death by her brother Dana Seymour, and survived by her sister-in-law Caroline Seymour and nephew Jeffrey Seymour and nieces Melanie Holland (David Holland) and Courtney Seymour. A graduate of Finch Junior College, she was fashion coordinator and account executive for C. J. LaRoche Advertising Agency, later a freelance fashion consultant for television and print advertising, and styled many famous celebrities, including model and actress Jinx Falkenberg. Her New York civic activities include the Lighthouse for the Blind, The Boys Club, Lenox Hill Hospital, Travelers Aid Society and the Manhattan Theatre Club. In New Orleans a board member and past president of the New Orleans Opera Assn. She and her husband served as Co-chairmen for WYES-TV's Producers Circle, she worked as a fashion consultant for the WYES-TV program, "Steppin' Out." She was a Women of Fashion Board Member and Hall of Fame Recipient; St. Elizabeth's Guild Volunteer Activist Award Recipient, a Cancer Crusaders Member and Celebrating Life Award Recipient. She and Harold received the Humanitarian Award from the Crohn's and Colitis Foundation and was selected by the Family Service Center of Greater New Orleans as an honoree at their Ten Outstanding Persons Gala. She will be deeply missed by her dear friend Karen Burnes. Special thanks to caregivers Laura Grulich and Christine Lanoe. Donations to WYES-TV, 111 Veterans Blvd., Suite 250, Metairie, La.70005. Visitation on Thursday, July 15, 2010, from 9am-11 am at Lake Lawn Metairie Funeral Home, 5100 Pontchartrain Blvd. followed by a service at 11am, burial in Metairie Cemetery. To view and sign the guest book, visit www.lakelawnmetairie.com.

Several new journals, and a recent visit to a great little magazine shop in Berlin, again make one think we are entering a differentage of print. (Of special interest is Tony Judt's moving essay "Words" in The New York Review of Books.) Though it's clear that mainstream publications are challenged by the Internet, small magazines keep turning up. One of the funnier, readable fashion mags to come along in a while is I Like My Style Quarterly, a spinoff of ilikemystyle.net, a social network site started two years ago by Adriano Sack. He's a journalist who divides his time between Berlin and New York and writes a style column for the German newspaper Welt am Sonntag. I Like My Style is about the size of a small-town phone book with a ruggedly assured world view of style seekers.

You've doubtless heard that BP has, on the 87th day of the oil gusher and in its 10th try, apparently stopped the flow of oil from its Macondo well (the current stoppage is a test of the new system). That's great news, of course, presuming the tests show that the well, from top to bottom, can hold the immense pressure of the gas and oil still pressing upward from deep in the earth. Otherwise, the process could lead to new leaks beneath the seabed, just as turning off the nozzle on a damaged garden hose causes leaks to spring elsewhere.

"British forces invaded Tibet in 1904 and administered it until 1947. Their aim was to create what they self-consciously called a 'buffer state' to protect their immense interests in India, then run by the British Raj, from potential advances by Russia and China. Tibet was turned into a guard dog for Britain's vast Indian Empire. And the British discovered that the idea of Tibet as a mystical, paranormal land - that is, not a normal state and certainly not a part of those other normal states of China or Russia - was a very useful propaganda tool ... Indeed, it is during that period of the self-serving Orientalism of British rule in Tibet that the popular modern image of Tibet as a mystical, cut-off entity takes shape - most notably in James Hilton's Lost Horizon (1933), which invented the idea of 'Shangri La' ... The writings of the British imperialists, and of their sympathisers, are still regularly cited in the propaganda produced by the Dalai Lama's people, which is designed to prove that Tibet is a unique and special place that only they can and should govern ... What connects the old imperialists with the new Tibetophiles is their desire to have Tibet as a 'buffer state' - only where the imperialists wanted to use Tibet to protect their material interests against China and Russia, the new lot want to use it to protect their emotional interests, to preserve an idea of innocent, childlike humanity so far uncorrupted by modernity."

We awoke early this morning to put in a long day of trapping in the village. The kids should be back in school, so we hoped that we would be able to work without too much disruption. Wilson drove over just after sunrise to begin setting up while I finished getting a few things ready at camp. While walking over to the village a few minutes later, I noticed a large mixed-species flock of starlings foraging on the ground in an enclosed area of houses. Although Wilson had found a few smaller flocks foraging in the village, they were moving around quickly and would be difficult to catch. We decided to move our gear to this new area instead. Within a few minutes of setting out the traps, the birds were cautiously exploring our bait. In under an hour, we caught three birds - all superb starlings. Things were looking up.

.The BP oil gusher has focused attention on just one of many threats to sea turtles. One that is likely far more significant is simply artificial light. I encourage you to watch this video shot earlier this month on the beach in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., showing sea turtle hatchlings emerging from their sandy nests at night and, attracted by the city lights, heading inland instead of out to sea. The city has an ordinance mandating dark beaches, but it's a tough one to enforce, it seems. "I just thought it would be too weird and eccentric for people." To hear for yourself, check out Caribou this Friday, July 16, when he performs on Governors Island. The Moment caught up with the London-based musician who spoke to us by phone from the back of a rental van en route to New York."Swim" is decidedly less pop than your past recordings. How did you arrive at this intensive electronic dance music sound?When I finished "Andorra" [Caribou's 2008 album] and started composing and arranging music for this album, I started making two different records: one with tracks to D.J. that were more dance oriented and another focused on composition. "Christian Marclay: Festival" at the Whitney Museum is aptly titled, since some form of music, much of it live, will be audible at all times during the show's run. In the late 1970s, Mr. Marclay, an artist-composer-performer, became one of the first musicians to use a turntable as an instrument, but he is equally known in the art world for music-related collages and skillfully edited videos. His penchant for placing equal emphasis on the visual and the aural permeates the Whitney show. Most of the works on display - whether they are made of found objects, images, album covers, LPs, clothes, film footage or texts - can be used as musical scores. And they will be used, often several times during the show's run, by a rotating roster of musicians that includes some of the biggest names from the avant-garde music scene. An artist as dedicated to mixing media as Mr. Marclay deserves the attention of critics from more than one discipline. Roberta Smith, the New York Times art critic who reviewed the exhibition on July 8, and Nate Chinen, one of The Times's music critics, discuss his work from their respective perspectives.

Federal agencies would be required to establish policies that encourage more employees to work from home under a bill passed 290 to 131 by the House on Wednesday. The House bill, and a Senate bill approved in May, would provide managers and employees with more guidance on telecommuting, or ''telework,'' as the legislation refers to it. They would also require agencies to put an official in charge of telecommuting policies. The bills also increase oversight of programs that allow employees to work offsite, typically at home or at an approved telecommuting center.

Everyone under 12 knows about Club Penguin, one of the first and most successful virtual worlds for children. On Club Penguin, created in 1995 by three Canadians, children as young as 5 years old can adopt their own pet penguin, decorate their own igloo and type to other penguins (children) on the site. Disney bought the site in 2007.

LAURIE--Marilyn. The Board of Directors, artists and staff of the New York City Ballet family are deeply saddened by the passing of Marilyn Laurie, a long-time and devoted member of our Board and a passionate advocate for our mission. Marilyn's creativity and her exceptional expertise in advertising, marketing and public relations, made her an invaluable asset to the Company. Her generosity and enthusiasm were extraordinary, and she will be greatly missed by us all. We extend our heartfelt condolences to her husband Bob, and the entire Laurie family. John Vogelstein, Chairman David Heleniak, President Peter Martins, Ballet Master in Chief Katherine E. Brown, Executive Director

Eleanor R. Morse, whose enthusiasm for Salvador Dalí led her, with her husband, to amass an important collection of the artist's work and found the Salvador Dalí Museum in St. Petersburg, Fla., died on Thursday at her home in St. Petersburg. She was 97. Her death was confirmed by Dr. Hank Hine, the director of the museum.

WHITE--Mark Thomson, 57, died suddenly of heart failure on July 9th. Mark was the beloved son of the late Thomas S. White Jr. and Helen Lawler White of Westport, Connecticut. The funeral will be held at Trinity Episcopal Church in Southport, CT at 3pm, Saturday, July 17.

A picture caption with the Spare Times entries in some editions on Friday referred incorrectly to the Bastille Day Festival in Manhattan on Sunday. While Bastille Day is a national holiday that commemorates the storming of the Bastille prison in Paris at the start of the French Revolution, it is not France's ''Independence Day.'' (There is no such holiday in France.)
STEINBRENNER--George. The family of William A. Shea extends their heartfelt condolences to the Steinbrenner family. We are thinking of you.

WASHINGTON -- In an echo of the debates over the discredited intelligence that helped make the case for the war in Iraq, the Senate Foreign Relations Committee on Wednesday released more than 1,100 pages of previously classified Vietnam-era transcripts that show senators of the time sharply questioning whether they had been deceived by the White House and the Pentagon over the 1964 Gulf of Tonkin incident. ''If this country has been misled, if this committee, this Congress, has been misled by pretext into a war in which thousands of young men have died, and many more thousands have been crippled for life, and out of which their country has lost prestige, moral position in the world, the consequences are very great,'' Senator Albert Gore Sr. of Tennessee, the father of the future vice president, said in March 1968 in a closed session of the Foreign Relations Committee.

CAIVANO--John Dominick. The Wallack Management family mourns the sudden passing of John Dominick, the beloved son of our devoted Director of Closings, Donna Caivano. Our deepest sympathy to the entire family.

WORSE-THAN-EXPECTED data on jobs, the housing market and retail sales have economists worried that we may be facing this recession's second dip. One other, more tangible, sign provides still more cause for concern. To read it, look down. Elizabeth Semmelhack, the senior curator at the Bata Shoe Museum in Toronto, has observed that during times of financial pressure high fashion brings out the most gravity-defying shoes.

DETROIT -- Toyota said Wednesday that its investigation of about 2,000 vehicles reported to experience sudden acceleration found evidence that sticking accelerator pedals and interference by floor mats -- the subjects of two big recalls -- did indeed cause some of the incidents. It is the first time since the recalls that Toyota has acknowledged that its internal review, which is continuing, found sudden-acceleration complaints to be valid. The carmaker did not disclose how many of the incidents had been caused by the sticky pedals and floor mats.

An obituary on July 7 about the author Ann Waldron misstated the year her husband, the reporter Martin Waldron, was hired by The New York Times. It was 1965, not 1975. The obituary also misidentified the city that the Waldrons moved to in 1975. It was Hightstown, N.J., not Princeton.

BREGMAN--Gertrude, died June 11, 2010 in Maine. Literary agent from New York City. Survived by sons, Jay and Robert, grandchildren Alexandra, Rachel, Nicole and Rebeeca; and six great-grandchildren. Service to be held at a later date.

STEINBRENNER--George. The Modell family and every associate of Modell's Sporting Goods are deeply saddened by the loss of a great humanitarian, baseball icon and close friend. Mr. Steinbrenner was a catalyst who was defined by his ambition and overwhelming passion for success which over the decades helped to redefine the standard for professional sports franchises in America and throughout the world. His will to be the best at all times at anything he did was only matched by his quiet generosity and support for those in need. Our sympathy goes out to the entire Steinbrenner family including his wife Joan, his sons Hal and Hank, his daughters Jennifer and Jessica, his two sisters Susan and Judy and the grandchildren as well as each member of the New York Yankees organization who will carry on the winning legacy that George worked so tirelessly to establish. We will miss him dearly.

I get asked this question fairly often, and my usual answer is a polite, ''Fine!'' I don't like to bore people with the details of my travails, but I've been asked to provide a more thorough answer for my readers, so here goes. How's business? Don't ask me that. It doesn't mean much. When I think about my business, I see it as a collection of different functions that all have to work together. In no particular order, these are: marketing, sales, manufacturing, cash flow, information technology, human resources, and the boss. Over the next few days, I'm going to address them all.

KOPPELMAN--Rae. Beloved wife and best friend of Joseph. Loving father of Robert and Lawrence and mother-in-law of Susan and Elizabeth. Devoted grandmother of Alex, Kate, and Sarah. Dear cousin to many.

BAGHDAD -- The United States plans on Thursday to transfer to the government of Iraq the last American-run prison, another milestone in the winding down of America's war here but also dredging up memories of one of its most serious misdeeds. The United States will retain control over about 200 prisoners, including some former members of Saddam Hussein's government who have already been sentenced to death, and some members of Al Qaeda in Mesopotamia and other militants, Gen. Ray Odierno, the top United States military commander in Iraq, told reporters this week.

HAMILTON--Alexander Reid "Pete", of New York City, December 8th, 1920 - July 11, 2010. Born in Paris, France. Attended the Hackley School. Graduated from Hamilton College in 1943. He served as a Lieutenant in the U.S. Navy where he saw action in the Pacific Theater and at D-Day. Graduated from Yale Law School in 1949. Partner in the Law Firm of Satterlee, Stephens, Burke & Burke. He was past President of Clan Hamilton USA, Chairman of Scottish Heritage USA, a member of the St Andrews Society of New York, and Honorary Councillor to the National Trust for Scotland. He served on the Vestry of the Church of the Heavenly Rest for many years. He is survived by his devoted wife of 59 years Mary Morgan Hamilton, daughter Virginia Hamilton of Sacramento, son Alexander Morgan "Sandy" Hamilton and his wife Linnae Hamilton of New York City, son Bruce Thomas Hamilton and his wife Rosemary M. McAndrew of Boston, and grandchildren Alice Popejoy, Ellen Popejoy, and Angus Hamilton. A funeral service will be held at Church of the Heavenly Rest, New York City Saturday July 17th at 4pm. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in the name of Alexander R. Hamilton to Scottish Heritage USA, PO Box 457, Pinehurst, NC 28370 or the Church of the Heavenly Rest, New York City.

Sugar Minott, a popular Jamaican singer whose joyful, lilting voice bridged four decades of transformation in reggae music, died Saturday in Kingston, the nation's capital. He was 54. The cause has not yet been determined, but Mr. Minott recently suffered heart problems, his wife, Maxine Stowe, said.

Janice Reals Ellig, President

The case study we published last week chronicled the back and forth between Honest Tea and Coca-Cola, its biggest investor. Written by Elizabeth Olson, the piece explained that Coke executives had asked Honest Tea to remove the words ''no high fructose corn syrup'' from its juice pouches because the executives considered them an implicit rebuke of Coke products that do contain the syrup. ''We got a strong request to change the wording,'' said Seth Goldman, co-founder of Honest Tea. In the end, Mr. Goldman held his ground, and Coke -- which owns an option to buy the rest of Honest Tea next year -- accepted the decision. The Honest Kids packaging now on store shelves continues to proclaim, ''no high fructose corn syrup'' (see the photo above). The decision, Mr. Goldman said, ''shows we do stand for something.''

Jessy, the 8-year-old daughter of Clara Claiborne Park, would step around a spot of light on the floor for hours, or incessantly run a chain through her fingers. She would sit and stare through people around her as though they were not there. A word she learned one day would fade from her memory the next. That was more than 40 years ago, when autism was barely understood, much less recognized, as a standard diagnosis. It was considered schizophrenia, or, to some professionals who embraced the term ''refrigerator mother,'' a deep-seated decision to closet consciousness from an unbearable family situation, including an emotionally frigid mother.

On Tuesday morning, workers excavating the site of the underground vehicle security center for the future World Trade Center hit a row of sturdy, upright wood timbers, regularly spaced, sticking out of a briny gray muck flecked with oyster shells.

9 P.M. (13) HAMLET Simon Keenlyside, above center, performs the title role, and Marlis Petersen is Ophélie in this Metropolitan Opera staging by Patrice Caurier and Moshe Leiser of Ambroise Thomas's opera, which was last performed at the Met in 1897. Reviewing this production, presented here by ''Great Performances at the Met,'' Anthony Tommasini wrote in The New York Times in March: ''Musically 'Hamlet' is no masterpiece. But this five-act French opera, which had its premiere in Paris in 1868, is a refined, subtle and, at its best, affectingly understated work, qualities that came through in the sensitive and magisterial conducting of Louis Langrée.'' Of Mr. Keenlyside, whom Mr. Tommasini called ''the Ralph Fiennes of baritones,'' he said: ''His singing was an uncanny amalgam, at once elegant and wrenching, intelligent and fitful,'' adding, ''You could not take your eyes off him.'' 9 P.M. (Discovery Health) BORN ON A BAD DAY Baby Week continues with this special in which three sets of parents talk about the disastrous circumstances in which their children were born. At 10, ''NICU,'' a new series set in the neonatal intensive care units of some of the country's top hospitals, visits Mercy Medical Center in Baltimore, where two newborns struggle with underdeveloped lungs, pneumonia and jaundice. At 10:30 a pair of obese women undergo emergency Caesarean sections, resulting in babies with very different problems: one is too big and the other too small.

An article on Tuesday about the chances of South Africa's sustaining the enthusiasm and unity fostered by its playing host to the World Cup misspelled part of the name of a popular soccer team in the country. The team is Kaizer Chiefs, not Kaiser Chiefs.

STEINBRENNER--George M. Our heartfelt sympathies to the entire Steinbrenner family. George was a very special leader. We will always remember the great moments we were fortunate to share together as members of the Yankees family. Adrianne and Jerry L. Cohen

ROBBENHAAR--John F. Klein, MD 79, of Fairfield, CT and Falmouth, MA, died July 9, 2010 of lung cancer. He was born in Amsterdam, the Netherlands, son of Theresa De Groot and Johannes Klein Robbenhaar and graduated from Saint Ignatius College and from Faculty Genees- kunde University in Amsterdam. John played first team for his soccer club, RKAVIC, and was an active member of his student fraternity, Plato. At the urging of Dr. August Rutten, a life long friend and resident at Meriden Hospital in Meriden, CT, he became a resident there, an instructor at Yale University School of Medicine, and was a fellow in Pathology at Danbury Hospital, Danbury CT. Dr. Robbenhaar served as an Assistant Pathologist and as an Associate and Senior Attending Pathologist at Bridgeport Hospital, Bridgeport from 1967 to 1996. He is survived by his beloved wife of 30 years, Geraldine Sansone Lugert Klein Robbenhaar, and three children by a previous marriage to Lorraine Cook: Melanie Klein Robbenhaar and her husband Brian Loiselle their sons, Brian Jr. and Benjamin; Alison Klein Robbenhaar; John Klein Robbenhaar and his wife Erika Harding, their daughters, Eveline and Grace; and by his brother Anthony. He was predeceased by his brother Rudolph, his nephew Robert and his niece Eveline Klein Robbenhaar. Dr. Robbenhaar was a member of the Black Rock Yacht Club in Bridgeport and the Patterson Club in Fairfield, CT. A fierce supporter and critic of the social policies of his adopted country he followed them daily in the New York Times. He spent summers in Falmouth, MA where he was a member of the Sippewissett Association. He found Woods Hole a sympathetic community where he shared with friends his interests in music and science. John was a voracious reader of Theology, Philosophy, History, Greek Literature, Science and Music, but his greatest passions in life were his wife, family, and classical music. His keen intellect, depth and breadth of knowledge, unfailing sense of humor and deep steadfast devotion to his family and friends is his legacy to all who knew and loved him. His family requests that in lieu of flowers donations be made to the American Cancer Society.

WASHINGTON -- Lawmakers take contributions every day from corporate executives and lobbyists hoping for their votes. The question of whether that represents business as usual in Washington or an ethics breach is at the heart of a far-reaching Congressional ethics investigation that is stirring concerns throughout Washington and Wall Street. The Office of Congressional Ethics has sent corporate donors and fund-raising hosts more than three dozen requests for documents involving eight members who solicited and took large contributions from financial institutions even as they were debating the landmark regulatory bill, according to lawyers involved in the inquiry.

A former congressman who is running for governor of Colorado faced accusations of plagiarism this week for writings on water issues and on North Korea. The candidate, Scott McInnis, a Republican from Glenwood Springs, apologized Tuesday for using passages written by a State Supreme Court judge in articles he wrote under his own name in 2005 and 2006. The accusations were first reported by The Denver Post.

With the expiration of stimulus provisions that made Small Business Administration loans more attractive to borrowers and lenders - and with efforts to renew those provisions stalled in Congress - S.B.A.-backed lending all but collapsed in June. Total approved loans in the S.B.A.'s guaranteed loan programs fell to just $647 million for the month, down two-thirds from $1.9 billion in May, according to figures provided by the agency. It was the worst month for S.B.A. lending in years, perhaps decades. Even during the credit crisis that began in the fall of 2008 the S.B.A. approved more loan dollars than it did last month. (S.B.A. officials were unable to provide figures for the total number of loans approved in the last three months.)

Perhaps the biggest managing move in the All-Star Game was one that Joe Girardi didn't make. When David Ortiz singled to open the bottom of the ninth inning, and with the National League hoping its 3-1 lead wouldn't evaporate like so many others, Girardi had every reason to pinch-run for the lumbering slugger. After all, Ortiz has probably not been allowed to clog the bases in a late-inning situation in an important game since the low minor leagues. Staying out of the double play was vital for the American League, with only three outs left.

Etymotic, best known as the maker of high-end stereo earbuds, has broken from tradition in designing its new Bluetooth headset, the EtyBlu2. While other manufacturers strive to make their headsets smaller and less obtrusive, Etymotic has gone in the other direction. Opting for function, the EtyBlu2 includes a boom mic that wraps around the face, ending in a foam windscreen, tempting onlookers to shout, ''Operators now standing by!'' The result is both desirable, and not. People I called said my voice was very clear, although they could still tell I was on a mobile phone. Another advantage is you won't have to yell to be heard, and therefore don't have to share your conversation with everyone on the bus.

A bevy of ethnic festivals will take place this weekend. On Saturday, the Cool Japan Festival in the East Village (Fourth Avenue between Eighth and Tenth Streets), from 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. will offer sample dishes from a number of restaurants in the neighborhood. Dorina Yuen, who opened Oro, a cafe and wine bar in NoLIta, in 2008, has teamed up with Christiane Celle, Antoine Verglas and Judy Tan to open Lafayette Espresso Bar and Marketplace on July 20. Ms. Celle, the founder of the Calypso clothing stores, now owns the Clic galleries, and is married to Mr. Verglas, a photographer. Lafayette, a 250-square-foot storefront, will serve made-to-order juices, espresso and drip coffee brewed to order, and sell sandwiches and salads, as well as an array of local artisanal food products like Brooklyn Brine pickles, Anarchy in a Jar preserves, vegan Cavemen Cookies and homemade granola.

For decades, logging has eaten away at the Brazilian Amazon, often called the "earth's lungs" for its ability to generate vast amounts of oxygen through photosynthesis. Experts estimate that roughly 20 percent of the rain forest has been destroyed, with much of it turned into ranchland or farms. Other primeval forests around the world, from Indonesia to Cameroon, are similarly threatened.

The National Academies, the country's leading scientific advisory group, has published the latest in a decades-long string of reports laying out the robust science pointing to an increasingly human-influenced climate. This report, "Climate Stabilization Targets: Emissions, Concentrations, and Impacts Over Decades to Millennia," provides a fresh degree-by-degree guide to impacts on river flows, rainfall, coasts and other factors that matter enormously over the next few decades as human populations crest.

Tuli Kupferberg was a Beat poet who became "the world's oldest rock star," an old-school lefty, a ribald comedian and a longtime hero of the counterculture of New York and beyond. On this week's Popcast, Ben Ratliff and Ben Sisario of The Times discuss the life and legacy of Mr. Kupferberg, who died on Monday at age 86. "If you scratch a cynic, you're going to find a sentimentalist," Mr. Ratliff says in the conversation, "and underneath everything Tuli sang about how love was good and war was bad."

The strong winds that greeted us on our first night, nearly blowing the tents over as we slept, never died down. If anything, they have increased in intensity. While this doesn't normally impact catching birds when we use traps, today it seemed to affect our work. We arrived back at the women's cooperative by 6:30 a.m. The birds showed up around 8, but they spent most of the morning in the trees and rarely came to the ground. We think the wind forced them to stay on the branches most of the time. The superb starlings only came to ground once, and didn't approach the traps. Luckily, the white-crowned starlings were a bit more cooperative today, and we managed to catch four. Just like yesterday, they seemed most inquisitive in the early morning, then disappeared by mid-morning.

Two weeks after the package tour -- a revival of Sarah McLachlan's successful woman-centric lineups of the late 1990s -- canceled 10 dates, most likely (but not officially) because of weak ticket sales, Carly Simon has announced her withdrawal from three shows because of an injury. BALSER--Paula. The Trustees and staff of Hudson Guild mourn the passing of Paula Bassett Balser. Mrs. Balser dedicated much of her life to community service, including an extraordinary commitment to Hudson Guild where she served as a staff counselor, advocate, Trustee liaison and later as a Trustee herself. Mrs. Balser was also the mother of Hudson Guild's Chair, Paul F. Balser. Mrs. Balser had a deep impact in the Chelsea community, and in greater New York City, through her work as a Social Worker and in championing the services of Hudson Guild. Her commitment to social justice and community programming will long be remembered. In 2006, the Paula B. Balser Counseling Center at Hudson Guild was named in her honor. Hudson Guild offers its deepest condolences to Paul, and to Mrs. Balser's extensive family and friends.

LAURIE--Marilyn. The Board of Directors, artists and staff of the New York City Ballet family are deeply saddened by the passing of Marilyn Laurie, a long-time and devoted member of our Board and a passionate advocate for our mission. Marilyn's creativity and her exceptional expertise in advertising, marketing and public relations, made her an invaluable asset to the Company. Her generosity and enthusiasm were extraordinary, and she will be greatly missed by us all. We extend our heartfelt condolences to her husband Bob, and the entire Laurie family. John Vogelstein, Chairman David Heleniak, President Peter Martins, Ballet Master in Chief Katherine E. Brown, Executive Director
GLAZER--Simon. Tim dear I miss you more with every passing year. Love, Val

MORAHAN--Thomas. The faculty and staff of the Nathan S. Kline Institute for Psychiatric Research (NKI) mourn the loss of New York State Senator Thomas Morahan. Senator Morahan was a truly exceptional leader, legislator, and advocate for the mental health of all citizens of NYS. Long before he became Chairman of the Senate Committee on Mental Health and Developmental Disabilities, he stood up for mental health reforms. He championed important legislations to improve the lives of residents in Rockland County and the State. He was also an extraordinary supporter of NKI and remained a staunch advocate for our research scientists and their programs. We extend our sincere condolences to his family and all those who knew him.

Roses, M.D. The Jules Leonard Whitehill Professor of Surgery & Oncology, Director of Surgical Oncology. Mrs. Roses was a devoted and beloved teacher of kindergarten children of the Public School System. We extend our deepest condolences to Dr. Roses and his family on their loss. H. Leon Pachter M.D. F.A.C.S The George David Stewart Professor and Chair Department of Surgery NYU School of Medicine

KUNIN--Louis. In loving memory, May 4, 1921 to July 11, 2010. Louis was born in New York to Morris and Sylvia Kunin. He graduated from Queens College New York and Harvard Law School, class of 1947. Louis served as a 1st Lieutenant in the U.S. Army as an air transport radio operator during WWII. Most of his professional life, he practiced trademark and anti-competition law as a partner with von Maltitz, Derenberg, Kunin, Janssen & Giordano. Louis was both an avid tennis player and music composer throughout his retirement. Louis is survived by his wife of over 50 years, Ruth Ingalls Kunin, and their son, John Kunin, and daughter, Elisabeth Ann Cassels, and three grandsons, Jake, Christopher and Kyan. In lieu of flowers, donations in Louis's name may be made to the Rogosin Institute, c/o Susan Spigel, 505 East 70th St., Rm 230, New York, NY 10021, 212-746-1566.

An article on Wednesday about the relatively high incidence of violent crime, drunken driving and substance abuse among soldiers of the Army's Fourth Brigade, First Armored Division after their tours of Iraq misidentified the location in Texas where officers have dropped in to bars to monitor soldiers' behavior. It is Fort Bliss, their home base -- not Fort Worth.

ST. ANDREWS, Scotland - Tiger Woods has received a warm welcome from St. Andrews fans since his arrival Sunday, and he has not encountered anything resembling heckling on the Old Course premises. But early in his round on Thursday there was an orchestrated on-course attempt to either break Woods's concentration or snag some quick publicity by an Irish bookmaker, which in March offered Woods a $75 million sponsorship deal that was quickly rejected.

MORAHAN--Thomas. The Child Mind Institute mourns the loss of New York State Senator Thomas Morahan. An extraordinary legislator and champion of mental health reform, he devoted his career to improving the health and livelihood of New Yorkers. We extend condolences to his family, friends and colleagues. Harold S. Koplewicz, MD, President Brooke Garber Neidich, Chair

An article on Thursday about the transfer of the last American-run prison in Iraq to Iraqi control erroneously included a government post among those once held by Tariq Aziz, a prominent prisoner and a former senior aide to Saddam Hussein. While Mr. Aziz was foreign minister during Iraq's invasion of Kuwait in 1990 and was deputy prime minister during the American-led invasion in 2003 that toppled Mr. Hussein, he was never finance minister.
CAPLOW--Alvin. A very Happy Birthday. With love, M

Expectations are starting to harden for the midterm elections. But less than four months before Election Day, one area remains especially fluid: the money chase. Democrats and Republicans touted their strengths on Thursday -- and played down their underperformers -- as they filed reports detailing their fund-raising over the last three months. Republican Senate candidates vying for open seats outpaced each of their Democratic rivals, a signal of momentum and enthusiasm gathering behind Republicans. Yet incumbent Democratic senators raised more money than their challengers. In House races, several vulnerable Democrats surpassed Republican challengers and expanded their already-sizable campaign accounts.
A slide show about spending 36 hours in Nantucket, focusing on the historical museums and harborside homes of the island. nytimes.com/travel

There were garlicky escargots in ramekins, liquorish-scented pastis in glasses and pommes frites in wax-paper sleeves along the bar at a bistro in TriBeCa on Wednesday night - all tossed back by scores of French and French-loving patrons under a ceiling clustered with blue, white and red balloons. They raised glasses of rose to July 14, Bastille Day. At the bistro, Cercle Rouge, one of several French restaurants that line a three-block stretch of West Broadway, tricolor bunting that elsewhere would have been hokey Americana took on a Parisian flair. Beneath it, patrons drank wine and buttered their baguettes. Servers wore T-shirts emblazoned with ''I heart petanque,'' a French version of bocce. In a Godardesque vignette, a patient little rust-colored dog named Leon sat under a foosball table.

A film review last Friday about ''Predators,'' directed by Nimrod Antal, referred imprecisely to another of his films. While also known as ''Control,'' it was released as ''Kontroll'' and is best known by that title.

Arnold Kramish, a physicist who survived an explosion while working on the Manhattan Project and later became an expert on nuclear proliferation and espionage, died on June 15 in Washington. He was 87 and lived in Reston, Va. The cause was a neurological disorder, his son, Robert, said.

ST. ANDREWS, Scotland - Padraig Harrington will need to turn things around in a hurry if he hopes to get into the weekend with any chance of winning his third British Open. The winner of the 2007 Open at Carnoustie and the 2008 Open at Royal Birkdale, Harrington started with a 73 that included one of two double bogeys made at the easy first hole. Harrington pulled his tee shot left at No. 1 and then pitched his second into the Swilken Burn - the small canal that snakes in front of the green at No. 1. Trying to get a correct yardage from the drop area, Harrington then broad jumped the Burn, making the leap with inches to spare.
International ARGENTINA APPROVES

10 P.M. (TLC) DC CUPCAKES Wielding only their grandmother's recipe, the sisters Sophie LaMontagne (above right) and Katherine Kallinis (left) gave up careers in fashion and private equity and dug into their life savings to open Georgetown Cupcake, a Washington bakery. Soon their concoctions -- like chocolate ganache cake with sunshine frosting, topped with a fondant flower -- had generated a large following. This six-part series follows the women as they prepare to take their local business national, starting with the creation of a Mardi Gras mask made of 1,000 cupcakes for a fund-raiser. At 10:30 the sisters lend their support to an animal rescue organization by turning their confections into a life-size dog centerpiece. They also devise a treat for dogs that they call pupcakes. 8 P.M. (HGTV) THE OUTDOOR ROOM WITH JAMIE DURIE A family in Van Nuys, Calif., asks Mr. Durie to help create backyard privacy. The catch: He can't touch the majestic tree in the center of the yard. After visiting a winter lodge in Jackson Hole, Wyo., Mr. Durie constructs a carved-wood pavilion with large stone pillars and conversation benches, surrounded by forest plants, cobblestones and a high-tech hot tub next to a bar.

Because of an editing error, an article on Wednesday about a dispute in California over removing serpentine as the state's official rock because it contains asbestos misstated the cause of death for the husband of Linda Reinstein, the president of the Asbestos Disease Awareness Organization. Her husband died of mesothelioma, a cancer of the lining of the lungs and other organs that is closely tied to asbestos exposure; he did not die from lung cancer.

An article on Thursday about the release of previously classified Senate transcripts related to the Gulf of Tonkin episode misstated the employment status of Robert J. Hanyok, considered an expert on the incident. He is a retired National Security Agency historian; he does not currently hold that position.

GALVESTON, Tex. -- The crayons and paper were out, but not too many children made it to family day at the Ocean Star Offshore Drilling Rig and Museum. Granted, the exhibits of pipelines and seismic vessels may have been over the heads of many grade-schoolers. And despite a few cheerful displays about marine life around rigs and all the bounty that oil helps provide -- including Barbie dolls and cellphones -- the message of the museum is that offshore drilling is complicated and potentially risky, a big business overseen by grave-looking men whose mostly unsmiling faces line the Hall of Fame.

LAURIE--Marilyn. The Board of Control, staff, students, and members of The Art Students League of New York note with deep sorrow the passing of Marilyn Laurie, a wonderful and valued supporter and friend of the League. Words cannot adequately express our sympathy for her husband Bob and the entire Laurie family she will be missed by all of us. Salvatore Barbieri, President Ira Goldberg, Executive Director The Art Students League of New York.

BENDINER--Alan William. In hopelessly declining health, he was at last liberated in the early evening on Bastille Day. He was the much loved son of Helen and Lawrence Bendiner, the former husband of Joan and companion of Judy. In musical prodigy as a child, he became a man of many passions, particularly in the fields of natural history with an encyclopedic knowledge and love of Ornithology. A memorial service will be held in New York City in September, probably although not definitely on his birthday, the 25th. Those interested in attending, please contact bendiner@earthlink.net or 212-260-5282.
More questions about parents, as well as requests for a G-line repast and some brunch spots. Keep those cards and letters coming! Send your dining questions to dinejournal@nytimes.com.

ST. ANDREWS, SCOTLAND - If the intent was to make a difficult hole more difficult, British Open organizers appear to have succeeded. The modified par-4 17th hole was by far the most challenging hole on the Old Course during the first round of the British Open. That should come as no surprise considering the decision to move the tee back 40 yards this year, increasing the hole's length to 495 yards. With an average score of 4.596, the Road Hole, as it is known, played well over par on Thursday and was well ahead of the course's second-most difficult hole, the par-4 16th, which produced a scoring average of 4.224.

WALDRON--Dorothea D.,92, long time resident of NYC, died July 12, 2010 She was an independent, dedicated, loving and devoted aunt, friend, and community member. She is survived by many loving nieces, grandnieces, nephews and grandnephews including Stephanie, Judy, Kimberly, Alexis, Martin, Arthur, Benjamin, Brandon, Christopher, Marsha and Robin. Services were held July 13 at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel.

de MARAMBEAU--Gilles. Date of Birth: March 26, 1946 in Amiens, France; Date of Death: July 6, 2010, at home (at 348 East 66th Street). Worked for the British Memorial Garden as the senior landscape designer. We are having a Memorial Service on Friday, July 16th, 2010 at 6:30pm. There will be a gathering with food and beverages afterward at the church as well. St Catherine of Siena, 411 East 68th Street at 1st Ave. Phone: (212) 988-8300

Two days after construction workers discovered the keel of a centuries-old wooden ship at the site of the new World Trade Center, New Yorkers continued to speculate about what might have caused the mysterious vessel to come to rest amid layers of landfill. Hundreds of readers weighed in about the ship on the City Room blog. Some fretted that it might have ferried human cargo. Others were convinced that it was a whaling ship. The whaling enthusiasts were confident asserted that a metal arc found on the keel, not far from some loose bricks, might have once belonged to a fire-powered fixture that helped sailors process blubber.

SCHONBAR--Rosalea A.,PhD, The New York State Psychological Association is deeply saddened by the death of a respected friend and accomplished professional, Past-President Rosalea A. Schonbar, PhD. We extend our condolences to her family and all who loved her. She will be missed.
COBB--Buff. Actress, producer died July 12. Granddaughter of Irvin S. Cobb, daughter of Elizabeth Cobb. She is survived by brother Tom Brody.

LAURIE--Marilyn. The Board and staff of New York Public Radio mourn the passing of Marilyn Laurie, a dedicated friend and strong supporter of WNYC and WQXR. We will miss Marilyn's commitment to building vibrant public dialogue, intellectual exploration, and rich cultural offerings throughout New York City. We extend our heartfelt condolences to her family. Herb Scannell, Chair, Board of Trustees; Laura R. Walker, President and CEO

MACKERRAS--Charles. The Metropolitan Opera mourns the death of Sir Charles Mackerras, who made his Met debut conducting Orfeo ed Euridice in 1972. Over the next 30 years, Sir Charles led 60 Met performances, including the Met premiere of Janacek's Kat'a Kabanova, as well as performances of The Makropulos Case and Billy Budd. We offer our sincere condolences to his wife, Judy, family, and friends. Peter Gelb, General Manager James Levine, Music Director

LONDON -- The oil giant BP faced a new furor on Thursday as it confirmed that it had lobbied the British government to conclude a prisoner-transfer agreement that the Libyan government wanted to secure the release of the only person ever convicted for the 1988 Lockerbie airliner bombing over Scotland, which killed 270 people, 189 of them Americans. The acknowledgment came after American legislators, grappling with the controversy over the company's disastrous Gulf of Mexico oil spill, called for an investigation into BP's actions in the case of the freed man, Abdel Basset Ali al-Megrahi.

EMIL--Arthur D. The Trustees and staff of the American Federation of Arts (AFA) are deeply saddened by the loss of our dear friend and former President of the Board, Arthur Emil. We will be forever grateful for his many contributions and leadership during his thirty-five years as a Trustee of the AFA. We extend our sincere condolences to his wife, Lydia, his daughters Jennie and Suzanne, son David, stepdaughter Adrianne and their families. Jeffrey Loewy, Chairman Tom Freudenheim, President George King, Director

MAHLER-MAZUR--Irene (nee Levinson). Beloved mother of Joy, Alan, Beverlee, Laura and Michael. Revered grandmother of Stacey, Yair, Kimberly, Josh, Scott, Bharati, Rachel, Steven, Jessica and Rick. Adoring great-grandmother of Zoe, Skye, Sage, Mason, Noah and Dakoda. Devoted sister of Robert, Ruth, Larry and Joe. Adored aunt to many nieces and nephews. Her valor and courage in triumphing over life challenges, her strength, wisdom, creativity and loving devotion to her entire family and friends will always be cherished. Funeral service Friday, 11:30am at Boulevard Riverside Chapel, Hewlett, NY.

George Steinbrenner had many great players after he took over the Yankees in 1973, and some of them will be back in the Bronx on Saturday at Old-Timers' Day. But who is the greatest of all? If you go by standard measurements, a few candidates come to mind.Bernie Williams leads all Yankees in home runs (287) and runs batted in (1,257) over that period, whileAndy Pettitte leads the team with 203 wins. Each was a part of more than 10 playoff teams and won multiple World Series with the Yankees. But are they the greatest?

The Books of The Times review on June 25, about ''Denial: A Memoir of Terror'' by Jessica Stern, included a quotation from an essay by Joyce Carol Oates in The New York Times Book Review in 1981 on responses to violence in her writing that misstated the final word in a German expression about what some view as the proper concerns for women. The expression, sometimes rendered in slightly different forms, is ''Kirche, Kinder, Küche'' -- ''church, children, kitchen'' -- not ''Kuchen,'' which means cake.

KOPLOW--Dorothy. UJA-Federation of New York mourns the passing of Dorothy Koplow, beloved mother of Meyer Koplow. Meyer, a board member of UJA-Federation, and his wife, Ellen, are dear friends who strengthen the Jewish community through their exceptional generosity and unwavering commitment. We extend our heartfelt sympathies to Meyer and Ellen, and to the entire Koplow family. Jerry W. Levin, President; Alisa R. Doctoroff, Chair of the Board; John S. Ruskay, Exec. VP & CEO

COLLINS--Michael. Former AP writer, champion and chronicler of the Radio profession, he was the Samuel Pepys of our tribe who loved the medium and those who sat before its microphones. By his knowledge and writings, he ennobled our profession. The Radio fraternity was like family to him. His family mourns him. David and William O'Shaughnessy WVOX and WVIP

A music review on Thursday about a performance of Mozart's ''Die Zauberflöte'' by participants in the Prelude to Performance program run by the Martina Arroyo Foundation, using information from the foundation, misidentified the flutist who the review said excelled in an important instrumental role. She is Lisa Dispigno -- not Denise Abner, another flutist in the performance.

A book review on June 22 about ''Never Pure,'' by Steven Shapin, misstated a word that the reviewer cited as an example of the author's ''academese'' usages. The word was ''respecification,'' not ''respectification.''

From Mantle to Matsui, the common thread that linked generations of players who wore Yankees' pinstripes was that Bob Sheppard introduced them all.

My Sunday column looks at new photographs that document the melting of glaciers in the Himalayas. The difference between today's photographs and those of 80 years ago, from the same vantage points, is stunning.

In late May I had a, um, negative reaction to the latest OECD Economic Outlook. Not only did the report call for immediate fiscal austerity; it called for a sharp rise in US interest rates over the next year and a half, even though its own forecasts projected very high unemployment and below-target inflation at the end of 2011. The only justification given for this monetary tightening was the fact that "some long-term measures of inflation expectations have increased." This was a reference to the TIPS spread, the difference between the interest rate on ordinary government bonds and bonds indexed to inflation.

With mortgage rates at record lows, you may be thinking about buying a home or refinancing your existing mortgage. If so, be sure to shop around for the best mortgage rate you can get and even try bargaining. Why? According to Cameron Findlay, LendingTree's chief economist, the difference between the rates lenders are giving consumers and what they are paying investors is much higher than it was back when the recession started, meaning that even while rates seem low, lenders have bigger margins and, therefore, have plenty of wiggle room to offer you an even better rate.

10 P.M. (Cinemax) JENNIFER'S BODY (2009) With its gory set pieces and story ''as full of holes as some of its disemboweled victims,'' this film, ''a bloody high school demonic-possession, serial-killer comedy written by Diablo Cody, directed by Karyn Kusama and starring Megan Fox in the title role, is an unholy mess,'' A.O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. He meant it, he said, as a compliment. Ms. Fox's Jennifer, above, is a dream girl -- the kind other girls envy and all the boys want, at least before she's transformed into a succubus by a run-in with an indie-rock band, and those same young men start dying in droves. Amanda Seyfried plays Jennifer's best friend and social antithesis, Anita, or Needy for short. ''Hell,'' she says, ''is a teenage girl.'' ''Juno,'' written by Ms. Diablo, gave us Ellen Page's sharp-tongued young heroine, and ''Girlfight,'' directed by Ms. Kusama, served up Michelle Rodriguez's bruised protagonist. Needy, ''our Virgil in Ms. Cody and Ms. Kusama's tour of teenage hell, so nimbly personified by Ms. Seyfried, belongs in this company,'' Mr. Scott added. ''She's the main reason to see 'Jennifer's Body.' '' 10:30 A.M. TBS will honor George Steinbrenner next week by showing 10 ''Seinfeld'' episodes that featured a character in the guise of the Yankees' longtime principal owner. The voice of the ''Seinfeld'' Steinbrenner belonged to Larry David, the show's co-creator, and the back and flailing arms were the actor Lee Bear's. The episodes will be shown Monday through Friday at 7 and 7:30 p.m., Eastern time. The tribute will open with ''The Opposite,'' the fifth-season finale, in which George Costanza, played by Jason Alexander, lands a job with the Yankees. On Tuesday night, in ''The Wink,'' Steinbrenner lists all the people he fired. The tribute will end Friday with ''The ''Muffin Tops,'' in which George is traded for chicken concessions at Yankee Stadium.

INTERNATIONAL A headline on Friday about renewed scrutiny of the oil giant BP over questions about its role in the case of Abdel Basset Ali al-Megrahi, the Libyan convicted of the 1988 Lockerbie airliner bombing who was released by the Scottish government last year, misstated the company's account of its actions. As the article correctly reported, BP said it had lobbied the British government about a prisoner-transfer agreement with Libya; it did not confirm that it had a role in Mr. Megrahi's release. The error was repeated in a summary accompanying a second article on Friday.
