ST. ANDREWS, Scotland - The Scottish have embraced Tom Watson for 35 years, dating to his first British Open appearance, at Carnoustie in 1975, when he formed a bond with the people and the country synonymous with the game he loves. And with each of his five British Open titles, the man from Bucyrus, Kan., has become more and more an honorary Scotsman. On Friday night, after doing his best to make the cut and coming up short, Watson, 60, bent to kiss the Swilcan Bridge, a gesture that said the honor was all his. When he walked the 18th fairway at the Old Course for what he said was the final time, a lot went through his mind, he said.

Seven of the Yankees' eight All-Stars were in Anaheim, Calif., when they learned Tuesday morning that George Steinbrenner had died. The other, Mariano Rivera, was on a brief vacation, resting the knee and oblique injuries that compelled him to withdraw from the game. He said he heard about Steinbrenner's death from a variety of channels, but he did not actually believe it. So he called Ben Tuliebitz, the team's traveling secretary, ''to make sure that it was legit.'' ''I wanted to hear it for myself,'' Rivera said. ''It wasn't a pleasant day.''

My Your Money column from last weekend, about the difficult questions that children ask about family finances, generated a number of comments from people who wondered why only one of the five questions I featured was about hard times. VERNICK--Andi. The Lauder family and The Estee Lauder Companies are deeply saddened by the loss of Andi Vernick, a beloved, long-time employee and friend. Andi passed away peacefully and surrounded by family at her home in New Jersey on Thursday, July 15. By the time Andi retired, she'd made a significant mark on our business and a strong and lasting impression on all who worked with her. Her dedication and eagerness for new challenges made her an invaluable resource and expert during the 38 years she spent at our Company. Andi's warm smile, generous heart, friendship and good spirit will be sorely missed by her friends and colleagues. Andi spoke frequently with pride and affection of her mother Ada and her brothers, Jonathan and Laurence, who survive her. Andi is also survived by Jonathan's wife Haleh, and daughter Sasha and Laurence's wife Susan and his daughters Stephanie and Jennifer. A funeral service will be Sunday, July 18 at 11:30am at Menorah Chapels in Union, New Jersey. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made in memory of Andi Vernick to Thoracic Research Fund, Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, Attention, Dr. Mark Kris, 1275 York Avenue, New York, NY, 10065.

SLOANE--Lois N, on July 15, 2010 at home, surrounded by loved ones, after a long illness. A trailblazer in the licensing and merchandising industry, Sloane is credited with being the first to recognize the potential for classic film licensing. A two-term past president of LIMA, the licensing industry trade association, Sloane began her career at International Management Group, was vice-president of Licensing at MGM/ UA, launched Turner Broadcasting's global Consumer Products division in 1988 -- managing all of Turner's film, television and animation properties -- quickly establishing it as one of the top five licensing companies in the world. She created her own company, SloaneVision Unlimited, in 1994. She is a 2003 inductee into LIMA's Murray Altschuler Hall of Fame in recognition of her unique industry contributions. Beloved wife of Allan Sloane. Loving mother to Leslie Sloane Zelnik and Stephanie Sloane. Dear mother-in-law of Cory Zelnik. Treasured grandmother of Bailey Sloane Zelnik. Cherished sister of Joan Rosenblum and husband, Robert Rosenblum. Adored aunt of Carol, Gary and Samantha Levin and Ken and Bette Jedding. Friend to many. Memorial services will be held Monday, July 19, 11:30am, at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th St.

HIRSCH--Murray, 87, passed away Monday July 12, 2010 in Boynton Beach, FL. Beloved husband of Helene (Leni), cherished step-dad and loving grandfather. Chapel services 10:15am Sunday, July 18, 2010 at Beth Shalom Memorial Chapel, Boynton Beach, FL.

After being shown proudly around the campus of a prestigious American university built in gothic style, Bertrand Russell is said to have exclaimed, "Remarkable. As near Oxford as monkeys can make." Much earlier, Immanuel Kant had expressed a less ironic amazement, "Two things fill the mind with ever new and increasing admiration and awe the starry heavens above and the moral law within." Today many who look at morality through a Darwinian lens can't help but find a charming naïveté in Kant's thought. "Yes, remarkable. As near morality as monkeys can make."

I'll be frank: the discussion of fiscal stimulus this past year and a half has filled me with despair over the state of the economics profession. If you believe stimulus is a bad idea, fine; but surely the least one could have expected is that opponents would listen, even a bit, to what proponents were saying. In particular, the case for stimulus has always been highly conditional. Fiscal stimulus is what you do only if two conditions are satisfied: high unemployment, so that the proximate risk is deflation, not inflation; and monetary policy constrained by the zero lower bound.

DeLONG--Thomas A. III, died July 12 in Florida at age 75 from a stroke. He was born in Freeport, LI and was the son of the late Sara and Howard DeLong. He was predeceased by a sister Nancy D. Whiteford. He was a resident of Southport, CT, Palm Beach and New York. He was a graduate of Williams College '57, MA from Columbia University '59 and an MBA from NYU '69. He worked in Corporate Communications for Olin Corporation and Pfizer. He was the author of ten books; mostly on TV, radio and music; as well as four biographies of Paul Whiteman, Frank Munn, John Davis Lodge and Mme Chiang Kai Shek. He was for many years Chairman of the Board of Trustees for the Westport School of Music. He was a U.S. Army Veteran serving on the staff of the Commanding General with the Seventh Army Headquarters in Stuttgart, Germany, 1959-1961. He was a member of the Pequot Yacht Club, Fairfield County Hunt Club, the New York Racquet Club, The Bath and Tennis Club and the Everglades Club in Palm Beach. He is survived by his wife Katharine, and two daughters, Sarah Ingerson of Cheshire, CT and Elizabeth Delvin of College Grove, TN and four grandchildren, Elizabeth and Emma Ingerson and Ryder and Charlotte Delvin. Services to be held at The Southport Congregational Church, 524 Pequot Ave. Southport, CT on Friday, July 23rd at 11am. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to the Westport School of Music, 18 Woods Grove Rd, Westport, CT 06880.

LEPANTO--Annabelle Cobb, 78, longtime resident of Glen Cove, Long Island died June 5, 2010. She was predeceased by husband Arthur B. Lepanto, and survived by daughters Janet Ann Lepanto (Richard Metzinger), Joanne Lepanto (Craig R. Roach), Jeanette Urke (Eric), Jennifer Ferrara (Joseph) and granddaughter Jeanette Ferrara. Annabelle was a former President of the Glen Cove Hospital Auxiliary and a former Churchwarden at St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Glen Cove. A memorial service will be held on Saturday, July 24 at 11am at St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Glen Cove, NY. Donations may be made to Glen Cove Hospital Auxiliary, 101 St. Andrews Lane, or St. Paul's Episcopal Church, 28 Highland Road, both in Glen Cove, NY 11542.
STEINBRENNER--George. The family of William A. Shea extends their heartfelt condolences to the Steinbrenner family. We are thinking of you.

Emirates Airlines is planning to reintroduce its Airbus A380 double-decker jumbo jet to the United States by resuming flights between Kennedy and Dubai on Oct. 31. The flight's amenities include fully enclosed suites for first-class passengers, five-course meals prepared in a private kitchen in Dubai for first- and business-class passengers, and on the upper deck, showers and a full-service cocktail lounge. Round-trip economy fares between New York and Dubai start at $1,350.

The Cultural Studies column on July 4, about a recent series of books advocating thrift, misstated the name of a show on the Bravo cable network. It is ''The Real Housewives of New York City,'' not ''The Real Wives of New York City.''

STEINBRENNER--George M. The Board of Directors and Staff of The ALS Association Greater New York Chapter mourn the loss of George M. Steinbrenner, III, father of our honorary board member Jennifer Steinbrenner. Mr. Steinbrenner's steadfast generosity to our cause and compassion for those living with ALS (Lou Gehrig's Disease) will not be forgotten. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to Jennifer and the entire Steinbrenner and New York Yankees family.

On weekends, King Street West between Spadina Avenue and Bathurst Street is like one long fashion runway, with its see-and-be-seen restaurants, bars and clubs. During the week, it's where a group of particularly creative local residents work, in entertainment and design, and where many live, too, in the loft-style condo developments sprouting up by the day. King West feels like one of those glamorous, tourist-friendly neighborhoods that was once to be avoided, like the meatpacking district in New York. At the turn of the 20th century, King Street was a textile-manufacturing hub, but by the 1980s, many of the sturdy but humble brick buildings sat empty, so the city rezoned the land for mixed development. In the shells of those old factories, a destination neighborhood was born. BRASSAII 461 King Street West (416) 598-4730 brassaii.com This popular restaurant reopened in March after an extensive renovation. The ''interpretive Mediterranean'' menu includes beef carpaccio dumplings (15 Canadian dollars, about the same in U.S. dollars) and lobster wonton ravioli (24 dollars). Around 10:30 p.m. on Wednesdays, Thursdays and Saturdays, the place morphs into a lounge.

When it comes to gentlemen's dress shoes, most brands err on the side of salaryman austerity. But the British cobbler Jeffery-West is bringing back the dapper don one shoe at a time. Founded in 1987, but only recently available Stateside, Jeffery-West - the brainchild of its owners, Guy West, 44, and Mark Jeffery, 45 - has been worn by well-heeled English toffs, including David Bowie, David Beckham and Noel Gallagher. (Even the wizards of Hogwarts were outfitted in the line's pointed brogues in ''Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets.'')

BRIESE--Krista, died July 9, 2010, in Brooklyn, NY. She is survived by her mother, Carolyn Briese, Cincinnati, OH; brother, Eric Briese, Cincinnati, OH, and brother, Craig Briese, Ashland, OR. Also an aunt, Gretchen Calvit, Minneapolis, MN. Services will be held in Cincinnati.

When Lela Rose needs to take her two children to school or pick up a bag of potting soil or transport a large chair, she doesn't grab the keys to the family vehicle. Instead, she hops aboard her cargo-hauling tricycle. ''It's literally a car,'' said Ms. Rose, a fashion designer who regularly commutes on the trike in heels and a dress from her home in TriBeCa to her office in the fashion district. She says the machine has changed her life.

The sound is unlike any other: a dry, scraping noise made by a skateboard's wheels as they roll across a concrete surface - part of the city's summer cacophony. I heard it just the other day, coming up fast behind me as I waited for the light to change at 21st Street and Park Avenue South. Turning quickly, I expected to see a teenager in baggy pants wheeling down the sidewalk, motioning for me to get out of the way. Instead, it was a fortysomething guy who looked like bald, portly Kevin from ''The Office.'' I shouldn't have been surprised. Older Gen Xers and even some baby boomers have been making their way around the city this way for a long time. You see them every day, weaving between pedestrians on the sidewalk or rolling up the bicycle lane on Avenue of the Americas. And they aren't just riding skateboards. Increasingly, the conveyance of choice for these aging commuters is the scooter - not the motorized kind, but a sleeker version of the type that Dennis the Menace rode when he wasn't terrorizing Mr. Wilson.

A film entry in the Week Ahead report last Sunday misstated the genre of the movie ''Mao's Last Dancer.'' It is a feature film adapted from the autobiography of the Chinese ballet dancer Li Cunxin. It is not a documentary.

MORROW FLANAGAN--Sue, 58, passed away at home in Langley, WA on July 6, 2010, after eight years of cancer. Born December 20, 1951 in Oregon City, OR. She became an international journalist covering political events, Third World development, historic preservation, environmental issues and human rights for The Financial Times, The Guardian, The Economist, The Washington Post and the BBC. A longtime resident of New York's Hudson Valley, she was known for her work with Clearwater's Great Hudson River Revival, the National Maritime Historical Society, publishing Water Ways: New York's Waterfront News and founding the Kitchawan Institute. Sue is survived by her husband, Tom Laurenson; daughter, Lisa; son, Ruain; father, Roy Morrow and brother, Dean.
GLICKSMAN--Albert. Aly - dearest husband, missing you every moment since July 18th, 2005, but still sharing my life with you. Love, Fran

TWERSKY--David, died at home July 16 after a long illness, age 60. He was a pioneering kibbutznik, groundbreaking journalist and skilled Track-2 diplomat. Essayist, poet, student leader, soldier, political activist and devoted father, he fought passionately for peace and social justice in America, Israel and the Soviet Union, always clear-eyed, always following his own star. He is survived by his children Michael Twersky and Anna Twersky. Funeral Sunday, July 18, 9:30am at Menorah Chapels, 2950 Vauxhall Road, Vauxhall, NJ 07088. Shiva at his home, 279 DeRose Ct., W. Orange, NJ 07052, Monday-Thursday noon-8pm. Donations to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center or to Kehilat Birkat Shalom at Kibbutz Gezer (kbyonline.org, look for "Birkat Shalom, Gezer").

BONDI--Nate, MD. Madison Avenue Orthopaedic Associates mourns the passing of our beloved founder and senior partner, Nate Bondi, MD. Dr. Bondi graduated from New York Medical College in 1962. He had been a practicing Orthopedic Surgeon for over 40 years. He was a member of the staff at NYU-Hospital for Joint Diseases and a fellow of the American Academy of Orthopedic Surgeons. Dr. Bondi's caring and thoughtfulness for his patients went well beyond medicine. He will be missed by the multitude of patients that he treated throughout the years. His partners and staff will miss his treats in the morning, Frank Sinatra music on the radio, and his indomitable spirit.

CHESTER--John Chapman, "Chips", Diplomat and Equestrian, 80, died peacefully at home on July 9, 2010. He was born and raised in Milwaukee and Oconomowoc, Wisconsin, attended Milwaukee Country Day School, Phillips Exeter Academy, Princeton University, and Georgetown University's School of Foreign Service. Mr. Chester spent his U.S Army career in occupied Germany to oversee War crimes prisoners. After marriage to Clara Paige Mills of Chevy Chase, Maryland in 1956, his career in the Foreign Service led him to stations in Germany, Yugoslavia, and Malawi, where he served as charge d'affaires. In 1970 Mr. Chester came to Capitol Hill where he worked as Senior Staff Consultant for the Foreign Affairs Committee of the House of Representatives. He was the staff facilitator of numerous House and Senate interparliamentary conferences with Europe, Mexico, and Canada, and undertook Committee missions to Asia and Africa in the early 1970s evaluating Peace Corp operations, a subject on which he was a recognized expert. He wrote an autobiography entitled From Foggy Bottom to Capitol Hill: Exploits of a GI, Diplomat and Congressional Aide. In addition to devotedly serving Princeton's Class of '52, Chester was an avid equestrian and took horseback tours throughout the world, including Mongolia, Argentina, Latvia, South Africa, New Zealand, Iceland, as well as several European countries and US states. He was a member of the Fairfax Hunt, serving a term as President, and owned horses competing in international events. He is survived by siblings Marion Read and William Chester, by three children, John Chester, Isabelle Chester, and Charles Chester, by seven grandchildren, and four horses. Memorial donations may be sent to the International Crisis Group (www.crisisgroup.org) or Lift Me Up! (www.liftmeup.org).

To the Sports Editor: I believe Bob Sheppard was admired, especially by out-of-town baseball fans of a certain age, because he loved foremost the game of baseball. The same cannot be said of Yankees announcers on both radio and television who principally worship the Yankees brand. Mark Brady

LAURIE--Marilyn. We are deeply saddened by the loss of our dear friend and former Trustee of NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital, Marilyn Laurie. From 2003 to 2009, Ms. Laurie was an active member of our Hospital Board, where she served as a representative of the Columbia University Board of Trustees. Ms. Laurie's professional achievements and civic participation were considerable. She was one of the most prominent and high-ranking women executives in the telecommunications and public relations industry, as well as a nationally recognized environmentalist. We offer our deepest condolences to her husband, Bob, and the entire Laurie family. John Mack Chairman Board of Trustees Herbert Pardes, M.D. President and CEO NY-Presbyterian Hospital

DEVINE--Louise W. Deeply saddened by the passing of their beloved "Weasie," the family of Louise Williams Devine celebrates her full and happy life and her enduring spirit of optimism and generosity. She died peacefully at age 90 in her beautiful Berkshires. An elegant woman of simple tastes, she enjoyed pastoral views, spotting wildlife, reading, well-worn sweaters, watching tennis, lobster dinners, Christmas shopping in July, and her "Baltimore sandwich" of peanut butter, lettuce and mayonnaise. Throughout her life, she enjoyed the company of her family and a large number of friends in Florida, Massachusetts and New York. She took great pride in her grandchildren, Lydia, Andrew and Meredith. An ardent conservationist and champion of the arts, she quietly enhanced the lives of others through the many causes she supported. Weasie is survived by her sister, Edith W. MacGuire, and her three children: Mallory Culver Devine Norris, Rodney Williams Devine and Ian Clark Devine. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to JerichoProject.org or to WorldWildlife.org. A memorial service will be held at the Meeting House in New Marlborough, MA, on August 7 at 11am.

FARR--Anne. Anne Farr died on July 4th, 2010 at Medford Leas at the age of 89. Her father Web, one of the original barnstormers, was a personal friend of Amelia Earhardt. Anne described her as a beautiful woman with a great sense of humor. Anne met Eleanor Roosevelt through her friend Ruby Hickock, the sister of Hick, ER's press secretary. Anne provided information for Doris Faber's book, "The Life of Lorena Hickock, ER's Friend." A graduate of Barnard College, she served as President of the Cosmopolitan Club of New York City. She was married to Hollon Farr, Clinical Professor of Surgery at Cornell for 55 years. Anne is survived by her sons Charles and James, and her daughter-in-law, Rebecca, and grandchildren Mike, Kevin, and Carrie. Remembrances made to Medford Leas or Cosmopolitan Club of New York City.

Ah, the joys of retirement. No more long days on the job for this dummy. No more slamming into offset barriers at high speed. No more skull fractures or knee replacements. Just a nice quiet spot at the Smithsonian National Museum of American History in Washington, where he can spend the rest of his days in the permanent collection. His name is 50H-1, and he's a General Motors crash-test dummy who is leaving the work force and moving to the museum, where he'll join a variety of other safety and crash-test paraphernalia, including a three-point safety belt from Volvo and the costumes of Vince and Larry from the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration's ''You Could Learn a Lot From a Dummy'' commercials, encouraging drivers and passengers to buckle their safety belts.

FALKENBERG-VIERECK--Betty (Martin) On July 11, 2010 in Seattle, WA. Betty was born in Jacksonville, FL on June 14, 1929. She met Hans-Geert Falkenberg (1919-2005) in Cambridge, MA and moved to Germany for 20 years. She was a longtime arts correspondent of the International Herald Tribune and wrote short stories. In 1972, she married the poet Peter Viereck (1916-2006) and moved to South Hadley, MA. FOR decades, my parents' business, the Mortimer Spiller Company of Buffalo, manufactured newsstand paperweights -- those lushly colored, usually cast-iron billets that bore the insignias of periodicals and corporations. Though they were once as omnipresent as phone booths, the heyday of the cast-iron weights has come and gone. Silk-screened Lucite and Plexiglas models now rule the day. There they are, holding down the latest copies of this newspaper and others, contending eagerly, like young actors hoping to make it big on Broadway, to grab your attention in a crowded, fiercely competitive arena.

EACH spring, the 55 public fountains maintained by the city's Department of Parks and Recreation are brought back to life by an infusion of roughly 1.3 million gallons of water. Then they work their aquatic magic, self-sustained by circulation pumps, powered by hydraulics and in most cases protected by bromine filtration systems. (No chlorine because it's too harsh on century-old stone and bronze statuary.) Pennies from wish-makers are far from the only offerings made to these people magnets. Also tossed in are thousands of other coins, cellphones, jewelry, cameras, shoes, sandwich wrappings and the occasional dead rat. ''Sometimes we fish people out of the fountains, but unlike the rats, they're alive,'' said Al Simoncini, who is responsible for making sure that Brooklyn's three city fountains run properly. ''Technically, it's feasible for someone to drown in one, but to my knowledge no one has.''

In 1982, researchers affiliated with the Cooper Institute in Dallas surveyed a large group of well-educated, affluent men. The researchers were interested in the men's exercise habits, but they also asked, almost incidentally, about their indolence. Specifically, they inquired about how many hours each day the men spent watching television or sitting in a car. (This was before you could do both at once.) Over the years, the survey's main results were used to reinforce a growing body of science about the health benefits of regular exercise. But the information about the amount of time the men spent being inactive remained largely unexplored. Recently, however, scientists from the University of South Carolina and the Pennington Biomedical Research Center in Baton Rouge, La., parsed the full data. In a study published in May in the journal Medicine and Science in Sports and Exercise, they reported that, to no one's surprise, the men who sat the most had the greatest risk of heart problems. Men who spent more than 23 hours a week watching TV and sitting in their cars (as passengers or as drivers) had a 64 percent greater chance of dying from heart disease than those who sat for 11 hours a week or less. What was unexpected was that many of the men who sat long hours and developed heart problems also exercised. Quite a few of them said they did so regularly and led active lifestyles. The men worked out, then sat in cars and in front of televisions for hours, and their risk of heart disease soared, despite the exercise. Their workouts did not counteract the ill effects of sitting.

Whenever I travel abroad, one of my first pit stops is the local farmacia. I'm always in the market for old-school apothecary products or those nifty Birkenstock-like house sandals you can only find in German drug stores. Recently, I hit the mother lode at A Vida Portuguesa, a general store tucked on a side street in Lisbon's Chiado neighborhood. The shop, housed in a former soap factory, features traditional, handcrafted products from all over the country, from toothpaste (the national brand, Couto, comes in a smart-looking orange tube) to countless tinctures and pomades (in handsome green glass bottles). Some of the products, like the pretty Claus Porto soaps, are more popular, while the Bordalo Pinheiro ceramics are harder to come by. Perhaps this amazing archive of authentic Portuguese products is a serious stand against the globalization and fast retailing that seems to have taken over the rest of the E.U. But for me, well, I'm just a sucker for all that hip retro packaging. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

HIRSCH--Helene (Leni), 87, passed away Saturday July 17, 2010 in Boyton Beach, FL. Beloved wife of Murray, loving mother of Jesse (Phyllis) and Lois. Cherished grandmother of Lauren. Preceded in death by her brother, Myron Galewski.

Several new journals, and a recent visit to a great little magazine shop in Berlin, again make one think we are entering a differentage of print. (Of special interest is Tony Judt's moving essay ''Words'' in The New York Review of Books.) Though it's clear that mainstream publications are challenged by the Internet, small magazines keep turning up. One of the funnier, readable fashion mags to come along in a while is I Like My Style Quarterly, a spinoff of ilikemystyle.net, a social network site started two years ago by Adriano Sack. He's a journalist who divides his time between Berlin and New York and writes a style column for the German newspaper Welt am Sonntag. I Like My Style is about the size of a small-town phone book with a ruggedly assured world view of style seekers. The first issue explains its purpose by asking a series of questions followed by answers. The last in the series is ''And who are you guys?'' Answer: ''A bunch of friends from Berlin, New York, Texas, Austria and Hong Kong.'' Mr. Sack says he believes the publication is the first ever user-generated fashion magazine. All of the content is created by users of ilikemystyle.net. The quality of the images is surprisingly good, and the ideas are fresh and interesting. And if some of the pictures are blurry - well, the editors said, that's the way the world looks at times. Immediate, subjective, and fuzzy.

SHERMAN--J. Walter, age 92, died in San Antonio, TX, on July 1, 2010. Formerly of Riverdale, NY and Boca Raton, FL. Born in New York to Louis and Esther Bella Sherman. Survived by son David, daughter-in-law Leslie, grandchildren Eric and Lauren and former wife Ruth, all of Boca Raton. Former member, New York Stock Exchange, and President, brokerage firm of Sherman, Dean & Co. and Sherman, Dean Fund. Past officer, Congregation Rodfei Shalom, San Antonio and past President, Riverdale Jewish Center, New York. Served as Training Coordinator, Office Chief of Ordinance, Washington, DC; Chief Civilian Trainer, Veterans Administration, New York City; Chief, Civilian Training, U.S. Air Forces in Europe and Chief, Civilian Training and Executive Development, Kelly Air Force Base, TX. Developed a training methodology adopted throughout the Air Force that earned him the Air Force Award for Meritorious Civilian Service for Outstanding Performance. Became President of Clover Spinning Mills, SC in 1956. In 1960 became a stockbroker at Shearson, Hammill, New York City. Formed his own firm in 1966. Graveside service and interment took place at the Mount of Olives Cemetery, Jerusa-lem, Israel.

Meet six of the artists, designers and writers (and one opera singer) behind the year-old dismagazine.com. According to its mission statement, the collective is determined to ''disrupt the dismal dissemination of fashion discourse.'' Which explains the kind of fashion shoots they style, sometimes using women's underwear worn below the knee, a men's dress shirt fashioned as a pair of pants or an earring made from a small bag of marijuana. It's as if Dazed & Confused stocked its fashion closet with Etsy.com. ''The only thing shallow about style is how people consider it,'' says Lauren Boyle, member of the collective and its spokeswoman. Next up: an online shop, DisOwn, which will sell its featured products. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

KASNER--Edward. For those who were fortunate enough to know Edward Kasner, you can attest to the fact he, known to us as Murph, was a wonderful man. As a grandfather, he instilled in us values of kindness and the importance of family by which we have lived our lives. At family holidays, he vocalized his love for Jewish tradition and culture, leading the chorus on prayers and imparting bits of wisdom from his years as a devout observer of the Jewish faith. As a friend, he told numerous stories about his life as a Navy officer, his experience at his beloved Penn State University, and the courtship of his wife and our Grandmother, Edna. If you were lucky enough to have experienced a meal with Murph, you surely would have heard one of his signature tales. As a fan, he spent countless hours retelling his time spent watching the famed Knicks teams of the 70's, of which he was almost a part. As a Penn State Nitney Lion power forward in the 1930's, he mastered the art of the rebound, always reminding us of the importance of boxing out during our own basketball endeavors. As a man, he was a truly a man of the people. He befriended anyone in ear distance, whether on the subway, in his factories in Brooklyn, or while making ice cream as a dairy major at Penn State. He inculcated in us the need to work diligently in school, in our jobs, and in our personal lives. Above all else, Murph was an inspiration. He has been, and always will be, a role model. While he is no longer with us, we have been so lucky to have shared so many amazing memories with him that he will be a part of us forever.

Now that London's cycling subculture has reached the level of a populist movement, bike cafes like Container Cafe, Lock 7 and the summer pop-up Rapha Cycle Club are the city's latest hip hangouts. A recent addition is Look Mum No Hands, a bar, cafe and workshop in a lofty garage space on busy Old Street in Shoreditch. If you've visited any other haunts in East London, you can imagine the place: Edison light bulbs, a staff sporting asymmetrical haircuts, old tires and bike parts hanging from exposed ceiling pipes. Vintage bikes and heirloom tomatoes dress up the window displays, and a scattering of desks and built-in benches fill up most of the room. Despite the occasional suit-wearing office worker who wanders in for lunch, Look Mum No Hands functions as a kind of cyclists' salon. Serious riders bring in expensive racing bikes for repairs; bike messengers sit in the attached courtyard fueling up with quinoa salads; and curious commuters lock up their bikes out front and come in to use the free Wi-Fi or study one of the giant cycling maps. There are weekly events, from route planning sessions to bicycle film nights, and the bar stays open until 10 p.m. serving up chilled microbrews from France, Italy and Spain. It's a popular place and a welcome addition to traffic-snarled London, where, incidentally, a new bike-sharing scheme called Barclays Cycle Hire will add 6,000 new bikes at 400 docking stations around town on July 30.

BENDINER--Alan William. In hopelessly declining health, he was at last liberated in the early evening on Bastille Day. A memorial service will be held in New York City in September, probably although not definitely on his birthday, the 25th. Those interested in attending, please contact bendiner@earthlink.net or 212-260-5282.

Now there is even travel tailored to dogs.But Best Friends Pet Care is taking pet travel to new heights - and excess - with a 50,000-square-foot resort at Walt Disney World in Florida for your four-legged friend. An unlikely competitor has joined the mobile app market: the United States government. On the Gadgetwise blog, Bob Tedeschi reports that the government is offering 18 free apps at USA.gov, including My TSA, an iPhone app that essentially puts the knowledge of a Transportation Security Administration agent in your pocket. The app is broken into four categories: Airport Status, Can I Bring, TSA Guide and Security Wait Times. The most detailed, Can I Bring and TSA Guide, help travelers decipher what they can or cannot pack (like gel shoe inserts), the increased ID requirements and the 3-1-1 liquid rules. It also includes tips on packing and dressing to speed through security. Among the suggestions: keep all electronics in one bag, leave the underwire bras at home and wrap gifts when you arrive at your destination. In a video, the Practical Traveler demonstrates the difference between the Perfect Traveler and the Problem Traveler.
THE NEWS Congress approved a sweeping overhaul of the nation's financial regulation system after Democrats finally found the three Republican votes they needed to prevent a filibuster.

The financial misdeeds of Enron executives and Bernard L. Madoff seem to have a modernday cast to them, but when you strip them to their essentials, they are really nothing new. In fact, the world has always featured fraud, deceit and an energetic willingness to take advantage of others for one's own gain. An exhibition at the Museum of American Finance in New York highlights major financial scandals throughout the nation's history, the first involving William Duer, a Washington official whose subsequent financial speculation helped cause the Panic of 1792. Unfortunately, the centuries of scandals remind us that greed taken to extremes is always with us.

VADHEIM--Robert H.,MD, at age 90. Tyler, Minnesota native, accomplished physician, arts patron and passionate preservationist, Bob made his home for the past 46 years in his beloved Brooklyn Heights, 37 of those with his late life partner, Robert Johnson. Survived by his longtime friends and caregivers, Richard Moredock and Jerl Surratt; sister Valbourg Smith; brother Lewis Vadheim, MD; and "Charlie."

BROWN--Ann Que, of Naples, FL, formerly of Skaneateles, NY died peacefully July 14, 2010 surrounded by her family. A native of Cooperstown, NY, Mrs. Brown graduated from Cornell University in 1955. She raised three children with her late husband, Graham A. Brown in Skaneateles, NY and her family was the highlight of her life. Ann enjoyed travel with her husband, completing many cross country trips as well as adventures abroad. She will be deeply missed by all who knew her. A dedicated mother and loving wife, Ann is survived by three children, daughter, Leslie Cohodes of Ross, CA and sons, Graham B. of Katonah, NY and Peter of Skaneateles, NY; and seven grandchildren. Funeral services will be private. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Susan G. Komen for the Cure. For online condolences, please visit www.fullerfuneralhome.com.

To the Sports Editor: George Steinbrenner presided over the dismantling of the greatest sports dynasty in history. Consider that in the 50 seasons from 1923 through 1972, the Yankees won 20 World Series championships, Steinbrenner's oft-repeated standard of success. That's a 40 percent success rate, or two championships every five years.

GEARHART-SCHNABEL--Sally, 71, died peacefully on July 14, 2010 after a long illness. Sally will be remembered by all who had the privilege of knowing her for her larger-than-life acts of kindness and her generosity. Sally was born in Clearfield, PA and graduated the Clearfield Hospital School of Nursing and Marymount Manhattan College. She was an administrator and operator of Crest, Crown and Oak Nursing and Rehabilitation Centers. Her husband George Schnabel predeceased her. A memorial service to celebrate Sally's life will be held on July 25, 2010 at 1:30pm at the Frank E. Campbell Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue, New York City. There will also be a memorial service in Clearfield, PA at a later date. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the American Diabetes Association or any organization dedicated to the health of children or the elderly.

An article last Sunday about the tripling of an estimate of the amount of plutonium buried at the Hanford Nuclear Reservation in Washington State misspelled the surname of a radiation expert in the state's Department of Ecology, which faces decisions about a cleanup of the site. He is Ron Skinnarland, not Skinnerland. The article also misstated part of the name of an environmental group whose executive director recommended a major cleanup. It is Heart of America Northwest, not Hearth of America Northwest.

SLOANE--Lois N, on July 15, 2010 at home, surrounded by loved ones, after a long illness. A trailblazer in the licensing and merchandising industry, Sloane is credited with being the first to recognize the potential for classic film licensing. A two-term past president of LIMA, the licensing industry trade association, Sloane began her career at International Management Group, was vice-president of Licensing at MGM/ UA, launched Turner Broadcasting's global Consumer Products division in 1988 -- managing all of Turner's film, television and animation properties -- quickly establishing it as one of the top five licensing companies in the world. She created her own company, SloaneVision Unlimited, in 1994. She is a 2003 inductee into LIMA's Murray Altschuler Hall of Fame in recognition of her unique industry contributions. Beloved wife of Allan Sloane. Loving mother to Leslie Sloane Zelnik and Stephanie Sloane. Dear mother-in-law of Cory Zelnik. Treasured grandmother of Bailey Sloane Zelnik. Cherished sister of Joan Rosenblum and husband, Robert Rosenblum. Adored aunt of Carol, Gary and Samantha Levin and Ken and Bette Jedding. Friend to many. Memorial services will be held Monday, July 19, 11:30am, at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th St.

KLEIN ROBBENHAAR--John F.,MD 79, of Fairfield, CT and Falmouth, MA, died July 9, 2010 of lung cancer. He was born in Amsterdam, the Netherlands, son of Theresa De Groot and Johannes Klein Robbenhaar and graduated from Saint Ignatius College and from Faculty Genees- kunde University in Amsterdam. John played first team for his soccer club, RKAVIC, and was an active member of his student fraternity, Plato. At the urging of Dr. August Rutten, a life long friend and resident at Meriden Hospital in Meriden, CT, he became a resident there, an instructor at Yale University School of Medicine, and was a fellow in Pathology at Danbury Hospital, Danbury CT. Dr. Robbenhaar served as an Assistant Pathologist and as an Associate and Senior Attending Pathologist at Bridgeport Hospital, Bridgeport from 1967 to 1996. He is survived by his beloved wife of 30 years, Geraldine Sansone Lugert Klein Robbenhaar, and three children by a previous marriage to Lorraine Cook: Melanie Klein Robbenhaar and her husband Brian Loiselle their sons, Brian Jr. and Benjamin; Alison Klein Robbenhaar; John Klein Robbenhaar and his wife Erika Harding, their daughters, Eveline and Grace; and by his brother Anthony. He was predeceased by his brother Rudolph, his nephew Robert and his niece Eveline Klein Robbenhaar. Dr. Robbenhaar was a member of the Black Rock Yacht Club in Bridgeport and the Patterson Club in Fairfield, CT. A fierce supporter and critic of the social policies of his adopted country he followed them daily in the New York Times. He spent summers in Falmouth, MA where he was a member of the Sippewissett Association. He found Woods Hole a sympathetic community where he shared with friends his interests in music and science. John was a voracious reader of Theology, Philosophy, History, Greek Literature, Science and Music, but his greatest passions in life were his wife, family, and classical music. His keen intellect, depth and breadth of knowledge, unfailing sense of humor and deep steadfast devotion to his family and friends is his legacy to all who knew and loved him. His family requests that in lieu of flowers donations be made to the American Cancer Society.

ROLLAND--Rebecca. The New York Woman's Bar Association notes with sadness the passing of our esteemed member, Rebecca Rolland. At a party to celebrate her unwilling retirement in 1992 as Assistant Corporation Council in the Family Court, Rebecca spoke with great pride and compassion of the work she did and the people she had represented. Rebecca continued to attend our meetings and events for many years until her health simply would not permit her to join us. Many will remember Rebecca walking to work, to the theater and our meetings from her Greenwich Village apartment, no matter what the weather to the consternation of much younger friends and colleagues. She was a woman of class, warmth and wit, devoted to her family, friends and loyal to her fellow NYWBA members. She gave so much to so many. She will be remembered with love and a smile and missed by all those who knew her. New York Woman's Bar Association Gretchen Schumann, President

We've worked out an effective routine over the past few days. We spend our mornings at the women's cooperative trying to catch the two species of starlings when they are most active there, and then the afternoons at the mission trying to catch the two species of sparrows and the one species of bulbul. The wind is too strong in the morning for nets, so we rely only on traps. They are proving somewhat effective, at least when the birds are on the ground. Unfortunately, they rarely seem to come to the ground. This behavior has surprised us a lot, but there is not much we can do other than be patient.

Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced a plan Monday to consolidate and modernize portions of New York City's government that he said would save taxpayers $500 million over the next four years and $500 million more each year after, all without cutting services.

The White House on Monday announced that it was forming a new National Ocean Council to try to make sense of the dozens of laws and overlapping agencies governing policy on oceans, coasts and the Great Lakes. The new body, which will include 24 officials from various federal agencies, will not have the power to propose new laws or regulations. Rather it will set broad policy goals and try to referee between conflicting commercial and recreational uses of the nation's aquatic resources.

It wasn't Stefan Ruiz's first time in Istanbul. But the photographer's most recent trip to the Turkish city, which he shot for T, was nonetheless an experience of firsts. He knew of the beauty, the history and the unique meeting of east and west, but Ruiz says he wasn't aware of how the modern the city has become, referring to places like the swirling Kanyon Mall or the modern art museum. "I wouldn't have even gone to the Sakirin Mosque if it weren't for this shoot," he says of the designer Zeynep Fadillioglu's striking modern house of worship, the first in Turkey designed by a woman.

Schneider, a Stanford University climate scientist who for decades built the case that global warming, while laden with complexity, justified an aggressive response, has died. The Obama administration, clearly hoping that pressure tests on the capped BP seabed oil well succeed, is trying to pivot its online narrative on the disaster from response to recovery. On July 7, the government unveiled RestoreTheGulf.gov, a government Web site that will eventually completely supplant the DeepwaterHorizonResponse.com site that was hurriedly created in the spring to provide the latest information on everything from the oil flow to fishery closures. One problem with that site from the start, to my mind, was the mashup of information coming from BP and the federal government. This lack of delineation perhaps reflected the murky, and troubling, sense of who was in charge through the first month or so.

"Wow!" "Amazing!" "Unbelievable!" "What are the chances of that?" Most, if not all of you, have uttered words like this at some time in your life. The paradoxical title of today's Numberplay, then, is true: rare coincidences are really common.

The director Roman Polanski returned to public life beyond his house arrest, days after the Swiss authorities said they were declining a request by the United States to extradite the filmmaker to face sentencing on a 33-year-old sex charge. Reuters reported that Mr. Polanski was seen on Saturday night at the conclusion of the Montreux Jazz Festival, where his wife, Emmanuelle Seigner, performed a concert on Lake Geneva. Mr. Polanski also gave a television interview to the Swiss station TSR in which he thanked the people of Gstaad, where he had been under house arrest in his chalet since December. "I'm not sure what I will do hereafter," Mr. Polanski said, according to Reuters. "For the moment I'm happy to be free."

Many people who never smoked or lived or worked with smokers still get lung cancer, explains Jane Brody in her recent Personal Health column. For anyone with an appropriate skepticism toward meritocracy and its works, there's an obvious critique of my suggestion, in today's column, that America might be better off if our top-flight colleges welcomed more students from demographics - the white working class, rural America, evangelical Christians, etc. - that are currently viewed with suspicion and hostility by the highly-educated elite. Part of the problem with meritocracy is that it homogenizes in the name of diversity: It skims the cream from every race and class and population, puts all of the best and brightest through the same educational conveyor belt, and comes out with a ruling class that's cosmetically diverse but intellectually conformist, and that tends to huddle together rather than spreading out to enrich the country as a whole. This is Christopher Lasch's lament in "The Revolt of the Elites" - that meritocracy co-opts people who might otherwise become its critics, sapping local communities of their intellectual vitality and preventing any kind of rival power centers from emerging. And it's something that Angelo Codevilla gets right (while getting a number of other things wrong) in his recent blast against the American elite:

Brad DeLong wonders why John Harwood makes so much of the supposed excessive rise in unemployment, even given the slump in GDP. Brad argues that the old Okun's Law -- in which a one-point fall in GDP caused only about a half-point rise in unemployment -- didn't hold in the last two recessions, either.

The federal government's position on ethanol fuel is that it must contribute less to global warming than gasoline does, or why bother promoting it. Yet by some calculations, ethanol is worse because it encourages the destruction of forests to make way for new farmland, many assert. Burning trees releases carbon dioxide into the atmosphere; what is more, the trees are no longer there to absorb carbon dioxide.

EATON--Jerome Alvin, died July 12 at age 90. After WWII service in the Air Force, he studied horticulture and worked for Doris Duke readying her New Jersey estate for public opening. Subsequently became director of Old Westbury Gardens for 12 years. Author of several gardening books and numerous articles. Produced a renowned Seyval Blanc at Eaton Vineyards in Gallatin, NY in 1970's. Married 1948 to Shirley Levinson (deceased, 1990.) His beloved friend, Diane Griffith, children Tom and Carol London, and their families will sorely miss him, his great generosity, his radiant smile, and his many enthusiasms.
ZANKEL--Robert Thomas. Always loved, always missed. Judy

SHENFELD--Marvin, age 79, on July 16, 2010, suddenly and peacefully with his devoted and loving wife of 52 years, Sheila (nee Greenblatt), at his side. Beloved father of Steven (Wendy), Robert and David. Adored grandfather of Kyle, Ricki and Michael. Son of Rose (nee Kohn) and Solomon Shenfeld. Brother of Larry. We will miss you.

HERZAN--Dr. Helen Marie, a retired psychiatrist and medical educator, died on July 17, 2010 in New York City. She was 95 years old. Born Ilona M. Szabo in Budapest, Hungary, Dr. Herzan received her medical degree from the University of Budapest in 1945 and immigrated to the United States in 1949. She was the widow of Dr. Francis A. Herzan, chief of radiology at Cambridge City Hospital, in Cambridge, Massachusetts. He died in 1977. Upon coming to the US, Dr. Herzan first practiced at Danvers State Hospital in Danvers, Massachusetts, and then at Metropolitan State Hospital in Waltham, Massachusetts. Subsequently, she worked in community psychiatry at The Wellesley Human Relations Service, and maintained a private practice in Arlington, Massachusetts where she lived for many years. She was assistant clinical professor of psychiatry at Harvard Medical School and also was on the staff of Massachusetts General Hospital, where she taught residents, conducted seminars and did supervisory work. She is survived by her sons, John Herzan of Branford, Connecticut and Paul Herzan of New York City, daughters-in-law, Lauren Brown and Alexandra Herzan, and her beloved granddaughters Charlotte Herzan and Lily Herzan.

BEER--Carl, long time resident of New York City and more recently of Gainesville Florida, born July 23, 1917, passed away on July 17, 2010. He was student council president of New York University, proudly served his country during WW II in the European theater, and was Vice President of the Chateau Martin Wine Company. For 63 years he was the loving husband of Beatrice Greenberg Beer. Devoted father to Bennett and wife Meena, Theodora and husband Jeffery Kirschner, Barry and wife Allie, Claudia and husband Ron Braunstein, and Jacqueline and husband Carlos Vaamonde. Beloved grandfather of 12, and brother to Abraham Beer and to the late Martin and Paul Beer. He will be sorely missed by his family and the many at Castle Village apartments in New York City and The Village community in Gainesville that were fortunate to have called him friend. Graveside funeral service, Wednesday, July 21, 2010, 10:30am, Cedar Park Cemetery, Paramus, New Jersey (201-262-1100). Donations may be made in his honor to the U.S. Holocaust Memorial Museum, P.O.Box 90988, Washington D.C. 20090-0988.

9 P.M. (VH1) THE 2010 VH1 DO SOMETHING AWARDS Jane Lynch, left, hosts this ceremony honoring the best ''world changers'' ages 25 and under, including five who will compete for $100,000. The finalists, voted on by viewers, are Jessica Posner, who founded a free school for girls in a slum of Nairobi, Kenya; Micaela Connery, who began a theater program for developmentally disabled students in New England; Mark Rembert, who started up a sustainable jobs program in Ohio; Wilfredo Perez Jr., who initiated a public health program in Haiti; and Jacqueline Murekatete, who founded a genocide awareness center in New York. Celebrities will earn kudos for philanthropic work in separate categories. Natasha Bedingfield, Travie McCoy and Lifehouse will perform. ''Behind the Music,'' which focuses on the life and career of Usher, leads in at 8. 7 P.M. (13, 49) PBS NEWSHOUR In a three-night series, Paul Solman reports on the Greek debt crisis.

MASLOW--Alice Edith, peacefully passed away on June 2, 2010. She is survived by her loving daughter Lucie Hartley-Urquhart and grandson, Malcolm Hartley-Urquhart. She was much loved and will be deeply missed. Edith will remain in our hearts forever.

It's one thing, in the heat of a campaign, to overlook a taxi receipt buried in the back of a wallet. But how does an elected official who has run several six-figure campaigns in New York fail to include her campaign's largest bill on expense reports filed at the time of her last race? Eleven bills totaling $101,963 have come back to haunt Helen Sears, a thrice-elected councilwoman from Queens who was defeated in September by Daniel P. Dromm in a three-way Democratic primary.

BALSER--Paula Bassett, was born on January 15, 1916 and died peacefully on July 9, 2010 at Broadmead in Baltimore. Mrs. Balser grew up in Camden and Ocean City, New Jersey and in Bronxville, New York, and she graduated from Duke University in 1937, Phi Beta Kappa. At Duke she was very active in social issues of the time, and she served as president of the student government in her senior year. Mrs. Balser received her MSW from New School of Social Work (Columbia University) in 1939 and began her career of service to her community with a position as psychiatric social worker with the Children's Aid Society. She married Dr. Benjamin Balser in 1939 and continued her social work career as a volunteer after her sons were born in 1942, 1943, and 1945. Mrs. Balser traveled extensively with her husband, a Doctor in psychiatry with the U.S. Army during the war and in the postwar period. She was tireless in her devotion to the people of New York City, and became deeply involved with the work of the Hudson Guild in Chelsea. She served there as a counselor, a social advocate, a liaison to the trustees and then a trustee herself. In 2006, a newly refurbished outpatient psychiatric counseling center was named for her in honor of her years of service there. From 1970 to 1977, Mrs. Balser served as a consultant to the New Jersey Juvenile Justice Department. From 1978 until 1989, she served on the City Hospital Visiting Committee, with a special focus on mental health and substance abuse services. In 1989, Mrs. Balser moved to Baltimore to live in the community of Broadmead in Cockeysville. There she was extremely active in social, cultural and intellectual activities, and she served on many committees, primarily those related to health issues, always adding her incisive comments to discussion. Mrs. Balser made many contributions to the social fabric there, and she was deeply committed to the shared values of the community. Mrs. Balser loved to help people and she loved to travel in the U.S. and abroad, but the center of her life was her husband, their three sons and her ever expanding extended family. In the last twenty years she was the central, beloved focus of many gatherings of family and friends. Mrs. Balser was predeceased by her husband, Dr. Benjamin Balser, and by her sister, Helen Bassett. She is survived by her three sons, Paul Balser of New York City, Richard Balser of Portland, Maine and Stephen Balser of Danbury, Connecticut and their wives, by seven grandchildren and by thirteen great-grandchildren. She will be sorely missed by them all.
BONDI--Natale V.,M.D. The Rose family mourns the passing of Dr. Nate Bondi, a dear friend, colleague, and mentor. Heartfelt sympathies are extended to his family. Donald J. Rose, M.D.

Kelly Wallace's move from television to the Internet embodies the lingering differences between the forms. Ms. Wallace spent a decade in front of the camera as a reporter and anchor at CBS and CNN. Then she got the online itch, and this month she joined iVillage with a fancy title, ''chief digital correspondent,'' but a mandate to do much more than that.
YANOFF--Leo, 99, retired judge of the Superior Court of New Jersey. His life was the law, his love was Louise, his wife of 73 years. We will miss his wisdom and his love.

BOBKER--Arlene on July 15, 2010 in her 78th year. Surrounded by her loving family and friends in Coral Springs, FL. She was predeceased by her loving husband Jack Bobker. She leaves behind her children Kenneth and Larry of New York; Jay and Rich Hickman of Coral Springs, FL. and many friends and family. Services Tuesday July 20th 11:15am at "The Riverside" 76th street and Amsterdam. Donations to Vitas Hospice would be greatly appreciated in memory of Arlene Bobker www.vitascharityfund.com

NOVATT--Melvyn C. Our beloved Mel died on July 18th, surrounded by his family. Loving husband of Barbara, adored by his children, Seth, Jedd, Amy and Jane, and their spouses and partners, Priscilla, Anna, Ron and Valerie. Absolutely beloved by his grandchildren, Sarah, Molly, Caleb, Reed and Ilana. A Brooklyn boy, Mel went to Bethany College, and after serving in Korea, started his long career in advertising. Mel was responsible for establishing the Krups appliance business in the U.S., and had great success with many other food and appliance clients. Mel was a gifted creative writer, music, theater, art and dog lover, fencer, Bronx Zoo docent, emergency room volunteer, but was best defined by his great heart, his capacity to love and be loved. The family welcomes friends on Monday, July 19, from noon through the evening, at 55 Morris Lane, Scarsdale. A memorial service will be held on August 19th (time and location TBD). Donations may be made to Doctors Without Borders or the Humane Society. A good man.

KASNER--Edward. We are profoundly saddened by the passing of Edward Kasner, father and grandfather of our cherished friends. Our deepest sympathies and condolences to Edna, Jay, Karen, Brett, Jared and the entire Kasner family. We mourn with you the passing of a beloved gentle man. Jennifer, Susan, and Jeff

BARAN--Annette, born on Jan 7, 1927, in Chicago, Illinois. Died on July 11, 2010 in Santa Monica, California, after a brief illness Daughter of Hyman and Lillian Dolinksy. For 63 years, beloved wife of Ephraim Baran, a prominent Los Angeles architect, now retired. Mother of Joshua, David and Naomi; Grandmother of Ariel and Mark Attended UCLA and USC. MSW from USC, 1946 Licensed Clinical Social Worker. Director of Adoption, Vista Del Mar Child Care Agency, in Los Angeles from the late 1950s to the early 1970s Oversaw the adoption of over 1,000 children during her career. For two decades, Annette was a psychotherapist in private practice in Los Angeles until her retirement. Co-author of two groundbreaking books, The Adoption Triangle and Lethal Secrets. A pioneer in the field of open adoption and unsealing adoption records. Annette's first book and her outspoken work on behalf of open adoption are widely credited with creating a huge change in how adoption is practiced in much of the world. She was widely quoted in the media and appeared on such shows as 60 Minutes, Phil Donahue, MacNeil/Lehrer News Hour and many others. Annette was a brilliant storyteller, psychotherapist, social activist, chef, mentor to countless friends and associates, and world traveler. She was known for her compassion, insight, down to earth guidance and capacity to love and connect with people worldwide. Private memorial gathering will take place in Santa Monica, California on August 1.

KASNER--Edward. Your strength, humor and spirit will be dearly missed. Who will tell your stories, reminding us always of what is important? Karen, Neil, Greg, Evan and Bev

More so than in her playing days, Annika Sorenstam is around amateur golfers at her golf academy in Orlando, Fla., and in charity events. I asked her recently to name the two things she saw amateur players do wrong most often. She said: That's easy. They think their arms are the key to their swings and they lack good posture at the end of the swing.

SIMON--Barry P.,age 67, on July 14, 2010 in Boston surrounded by his loving family after a long and courageous battle with multiple myeloma. He was the adored husband of Hinda, loving father of Alan, John and wife Laura and Eric and wife Chris, devoted brother of Clifford Simon and adoring grandfather of Will, Leo, Maya and Jaina Simon. Barry graduated from Princeton and Yale Law School. His career began in the cable television industry as general counsel of Teleprompter where he was instrumental in developing new copyright laws. He spent the rest of his career in the airline industry, serving as general counsel at Continental, Eastern and Northwest airlines and as head of the International division of Continental Airlines. Barry was an avid reader and loved the arts. He was on the Board of Directors of the Houston Grand Opera and the Board of the literary magazine, Gulf Coast. Memorial service will be held Friday, July 23 at 1:00pm at the Rothko Chapel in Houston, 3900 Yupon Street, followed by a reception. Donations in Barry's memory may be made to the Houston Grand Opera or the Dana Farber Cancer Institute for multiple myeloma research.

EVANS--William Francis, 47, investment banker and musician who lived in New York City, died after a brief illness on Saturday, July 10th. He was born in Towson, Maryland. Bill received B.A. and M.A. degrees in mathematics from Columbia College and University of Pennsylvania, respectively. During that period he played bass in both performance and recording with several jazz and fusion bands. After graduate school, Bill embarked on a 23-year career in the financial services industry where he specialized in the modeling and structuring complex tax-exempt mortgage revenue bond transactions for state housing finance agencies throughout the country for the purpose of financing affordable housing programs. Bill leaves behind former spouse Laura Evans, children Katherine, 15, and Philip, 18, his parents Bernard and Estelle Evans of Baltimore, and brother Robert C. Evans of Colorado. There will be a funeral mass at the Cathedral of Mary Our Queen (Lady Chapel) on Wednesday July 21 at 11am. Interment to follow at Dulaney Valley Memorial. Services by the Ruck Towson Funeral Home, Inc. 1050 York Road, Towson, MD 21204. A memorial service in New York City will be planned for September. The family is establishing a scholarship trust in his name for electric bass studies at the Columbia University Music School. With profound sorrow and deep gratitude for his invaluable contributions to our industry, friends, colleagues and clients in the municipal bond community.

KASNER--Edward. For those who were fortunate enough to know Edward Kasner, you can attest to the fact he, known to us as Murph, was a wonderful man. As a grandfather, he instilled in us values of kindness and the importance of family by which we have lived our lives. At family holidays, he vocalized his love for Jewish tradition and culture, leading the chorus on prayers and imparting bits of wisdom from his years as a devout observer of the Jewish faith. As a friend, he told numerous stories about his life as a Navy officer, his experience at his beloved Penn State University, and the courtship of his wife and our Grandmother, Edna. If you were lucky enough to have experienced a meal with Murph, you surely would have heard one of his signature tales. As a fan, he spent countless hours retelling his time spent watching the famed Knicks teams of the 70's, of which he was almost a part. As a Penn State Nitney Lion power forward in the 1930's, he mastered the art of the rebound, always reminding us of the importance of boxing out during our own basketball endeavors. As a man, he was a truly a man of the people. He befriended anyone in ear distance, whether on the subway, in his factories in Brooklyn, or while making ice cream as a dairy major at Penn State. He inculcated in us the need to work diligently in school, in our jobs, and in our personal lives. Above all else, Murph was an inspiration. He has been, and always will be, a role model. While he is no longer with us, we have been so lucky to have shared so many amazing memories with him that he will be a part of us forever. Brett and Jared

Video on demand is becoming more common, but it hasn't surpassed movie rental on DVD and Blu-ray. According to Rentrak, which monitors film revenue, consumers spent $6.2 billion in 2009 on traditional rentals. By comparison, revenue in 2009 for movies viewed on demand was $963 million. Three on-demand films topped $250 million at the box office: ''New Moon,'' ''The Blind Side'' and ''Sherlock Holmes.'' ''The Hurt Locker,'' above, earned $12.6 million in theaters, but gained a bigger audience after its Oscar for best picture. SHELLY FREIERMAN

From time to time, Acer executives will pound their chests and announce plans for the company to overtake Hewlett-Packard as the world's top computer seller. The proclamations have historically elicited chuckles from the PC peanut gallery, which has viewed such a feat as rather unlikely. Acer, however, may start converting a few more believers as it continues to gain market share quarter after quarter.

Marrack I. Goulding, who for seven years as an under secretary general of the United Nations oversaw peacekeeping missions around the world -- at times coming under fire himself -- died July 9 at a nursing home in Somerset, England. He was 73 and lived in London. The cause was cancer, his daughter, Rachel Nickerson, said.

KASNER--Edward. UJA-Federation of New York mourns the passing of Edward Kasner, beloved father of Jay Kasner and father-in-law of Karen Spar Kasner. Jay and Karen are cherished friends who are greatly admired for their extraordinary leadership and generosity that has touched many lives in New York, in Westchester, and around the world. We extend our deepest sympathies to Edward's beloved wife, Edna; to Jay and Karen; to Edward's grandchildren Brett and Jared; and to the entire family. Jerry W. Levin, President Alisa R. Doctoroff, Chair of the Board John S. Ruskay, Exec. VP & CEO

Welcome as it is, progress toward finally capping the gulf oil leak hasn't resolved the biggest conundrum facing President Obama before the midterm elections. That conundrum, which reclaims center stage in Washington this week, is this: Why is unemployment so high?

GIBBS--Mary B.,passed away on July 17, 2010. Survived by son Benjamine Gibbs, grandchildren Jason (Beth) Gibbs, Mark Gibbs, great-grandchildren Rachael and Chelsea Gibbs. Graveside services will take place on Tuesday July 20, 2010 at 11:30am at Wellwood Cemetery, Farmingdale, NY.

The competition for free online photo storage got a little hotter Tuesday. Google said it had started integrating Picnik, an online photo editing tool that the company purchased in early March, into the Google photo storage Web site, Picasa.

The latest Silicon Valley squabble sounds like an unusually esoteric episode of ''Gossip Girl.'' This one involves a couple of mobile Internet-based phone services. Last week Fring, which sells software that allows people to talk and chat over mobile phones on the Web, announced a fancy new feature to its service: the ability to video-chat using the iPhone 4 over a 3G mobile phone data connection. Currently, the iPhone requires a Wi-Fi connection to use its built-in FaceTime video chat feature.

MARTIN--Victoria Weinberg. At home on July 18, 2010 at age 97. Beloved wife of the late Marc, mother of Francine and Laura, grandmother of Remy and Mariel. Services Monday 1pm at The Riverside, 76th St and Amsterdam Ave. A talented artist, she will be remembered for her generosity, devotion to family, and spirit for life.

Inside a low-slung building off a nondescript road in a quiet central New Jersey suburb is the most powerful room in golf. By the thousands every year, people devise ingenious, revolutionary and bizarre ideas for improving golf - new clubs, balls, tees, gloves and grips - and all of it ends up in this room. These prototypes might represent hours spent tinkering in a garage with an eye on making millions. In the case of major golf manufacturers, they represent millions of dollars already spent on engineering.

BONDI--Natale V, M.D.,The members of the NYU Hospital for Joint Diseases Department of Orthopaedic Surgery deeply mourn the passing of our dear friend and colleague, Dr. Nate Bondi. Dr. Bondi joined HJD in 1980 and for 30 years served as an outstanding orthopaedic surgeon and educator. He was a remarkable man who strongly supported our programs and contributed greatly to all that we have accomplished over the years. Nate was tremendously proud to be a member of our department and one of our proudest moments was to honor him as a recipient of the distinguished Henry Frauenthal Founders Award for his contributions to the Hospital for Joint Diseases. He leaves a grieving hospital community and a profound void at NYUHJD, since his many years of dedicated work at the hospital have touched the lives of countless people. We grieve his passing as we celebrate his exemplary life and extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife, Emily, and to the entire family. Joseph D. Zuckerman, MD, Chairman William L. Jaffe, MD, Vice Chairman

The National Amputee Golf Association announced this year that it was opening its national championships to men and women with disabilities other than a major joint amputation. Blind golfers and golfers with various physical challenges or mobility limitations can now compete as associate members of the amputee association. The national championship and senior championship are Sept. 7-10 in Nashville.

DOHERTY--Edward. A devoted servant of God passed away on July 17, 2010. Beloved husband of Ingrid Ramos, son-in-law of Antonia Ramos. Dear brother of Mary Daly, Patricia Doherty, Agnes Duffy and Peg Bruno. Brother-in-law of Patrick Duffy, Frank Bruno, Vincent Ramos and Catherine Pruse, Lucy and Fred Helfeld, Carlos Antonio Ramos, Raymond and Haydee Ramos and many nieces and nephews. Preceded in death by his parents Mary and William and his brother William (Brother Ignatius, C.F.X.). Ed served as a Xaverian brother for 17 years and as a Brooklyn Diocesan priest for 13 years. He was a language and religion teacher for many years at several New York City schools including: Xaverian High School Brooklyn, St. Joseph-by-the-Sea, S.I., Loyola High School, St. Vincent Ferrer High School, St. David's School and St. Hilda's and St. Hugh's School, New York City. After retirement, Ed became active in prison ministry and volunteer work at St. Anthony of Padua in Red Bank, NJ. He was a man of deep faith, uncompromised principles, commitment, integrity and compassion who also had a wonderful sense of humor. He will be deeply missed but will continue to be in our hearts, minds and love for each other. Visitation will take place on Tuesday, July 20th from 2-4 and 7-9pm at St. Anthony of Padua RC Church, 121 Bridge Ave., Red Bank, NJ. A Mass of Christian Burial will be held Wednesday, July 21st at same location. Interment will immediately follow. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Doctors Without Borders or St. Anthony of Padua RC Church, Red Bank, NJ. Please visit Edward's Memorial website available at www.sidun.com.

If September 2007 was the high point of the hefty fashion magazine, with more than 700 pages of ads in Vogue and about 400 each in Elle and InStyle, then 2009 was more apropos to the ethos of the fashion world: svelte and petite. If the first September 2010 numbers to trickle out are any indication, the fashion magazines seem to be getting off their diets. Glamour, one of the most reliable cash cows at Conde Nast, is reporting that its ad pages are up 57 percent for the month: 241 ad pages for September 2010 compared with 153 for a year earlier.

CAHN--Rosalind, 88, died July 16. Predeceased by Samuel with whom she shared a long and happy marriage. Beloved mother of Howard and Iris, caring grandmother of Jesse and Samantha, gifted soprano and nurturer of causes, family, and friends.

GEARHART-SCHNABEL--Sally, 71, died peacefully on July 14, 2010 after a long illness. Sally will be remembered by all who had the privilege of knowing her for her larger-than-life acts of kindness and her generosity. Sally was born in Clearfield, PA and graduated the Clearfield Hospital School of Nursing and Marymount Manhattan College. She was an administrator and operator of Crest, Crown and Oak Nursing and Rehabilitation Centers. Her husband George Schnabel predeceased her. A memorial service to celebrate Sally's life will be held on July 25, 2010 at 1:30pm at the Frank E. Campbell Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue, New York City. There will also be a memorial service in Clearfield, PA at a later date. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the American Diabetes Association or any organization dedicated to the health of children or the elderly.

ST. ANDREWS, Scotland - Tiger Woods came to St. Andrews thinking he could win the British Open. When he departed Sunday after tying for 23rd, he was satisfied only in that he knew why he never really had a chance to hoist to the claret jug. The man who used to make almost every putt he looked at is adrift on the greens. And no golfer, even Woods, has ever hit the ball well enough to succeed in the face of mediocrity with the putter.

Discovery Kids is entering the educational online gaming business with a twist: one component of its new history and science game, called Seek Your Own Proof, is intended to get children offline and into museums. The secret-agent themed game has been in a trial phase for several months, and won't officially start until fall. But beginning Monday, players can take part in a hunt for clues at the King Tut exhibit at the Discovery Times Square Exposition in New York City. Once children find answers to questions like the type of bird depicted on the handle of Tutankhamun's ceremonial dagger, they unlock a clue that can be entered online to earn online point rewards redeemable for other puzzles and games.

BRAWARSKY--Jack. Loving husband of 63 years of Muriel. Beloved father of Phyllis (Noah), Diane (William), Sandee (Barry). Amazing grandfather and great-grandfather. Most loyal friend. Funeral on Monday, July 19, Plaza Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue (91st Street), 12:30pm.

Days after the Securities and Exchange Commission secured a $550 million settlement from the banking giant Goldman Sachs, the agency’s chairwoman said Tuesday that the S.E.C. was pursuing several other investigations related to the 2008 financial crisis, Edward Wyatt of The New York Times reports from Washington.
A look at the sprawling 195-year-old house and the small village of barns, cottages and carriage houses on the property that family members, friends and tenants share.
A few of the animal-friendly design solutions created by pet owners in their homes.
A view of the day in sports, from heavy weights in Puerto Rico to cooling waters in New Jersey and New Brunswick.

MTV has signed new contracts with its biggest stars: the cast of "Jersey Shore."

I love visiting Colombia, for much the same reasons that I love visiting the Bronx: both are saddled with outdated reputations that scare people away from visiting, which makes for fewer visitors, which makes them even better places to visit.
As states face severe budget shortfalls, many have cut home-care services for the elderly and  the disabled.
It may be hard to remember now, but Alex Rodriguez was viewed with reverence when he played for the Seattle Mariners from 1994 through 2000. A lot has changed since he left.

WEDNESDAY'S PUZZLE - MONET or MANET? Which are you going to go with when you need a five-letter Impressionist painter? Here's my rule of thumb. If the subject is a person like Olympia or the absinthe drinker, it's Manet all the way. For natural settings like haystacks or water lilies, or for buildings, go with Monet. "Manet for mankind" is my mantra. It works today.
