Just to show you how naïve I am: When I first heard about the plan to build a mosque and community center two blocks from the site of the 9/11 attacks, I didn't envision any real opposition to it.
A free blogging site, Blogetery.com, went dark less than two weeks ago, and its disappearance is stirring controversy about the obligations of Internet services and threats to free speech on the Web.

12:19 a.m. | Updated He's back, although the Mets were hardly counting the days until he returned. Oliver Perez rejoined the Mets on Tuesday after a rehabilitation stint in the minor leagues. He threw in the bullpen before the game and told reporters that he was ready to help the Mets in any way they requested.

The record will show that Lou Piniella announced his retirement Tuesday, the day after his starting pitcher gave up five runs in one inning. Piniella, a born hitter, never had much patience for pitchers. Once this tedious Chicago Cubs season ends, they will never torment him again.
The Tea Party has officially entered the United States Congress.
A 19th-century house in Virginia, a solar-domed home in Florida and a town house in California.

Carpenter and chef. Father and son. They paused there, in tranquillity, amid all the construction-site bedlam on a recent morning at the nonexistent west wall of the forthcoming kitchen of Lincoln, the $20 million Italian restaurant scheduled to open this fall at Lincoln Center.
A dispute that dragged on for more than a decade over the ownership of an Egon Schiele painting seized by the Nazis has finally been resolved.
It's official: New York State is drastically reducing sulfur in home heating oil.

KABUL, Afghanistan -- In the opening scenes of Shakespeare's play "Measure for Measure," the Duke of Vienna takes off his fine clothes and disguises himself as an ordinary friar so that he can wander the streets and learn what the common people really think about the governance of his city.

House Democrats sought Tuesday to use a hearing on the Interior Department's role in the Gulf Coast oil spill to blame the Bush administration for regulatory failures that may have contributed to the April 20 explosion of the Deepwater Horizon oil rig.
A three-part PBS series about the Reagan-era Secretary of State George Shultz has come under scrutiny in recent days for its financing ties to his friends and associates.

ALERT: While this week of "Mad Men" posts endeavors to remain spoiler-free, this one is informed by a close advance viewing of the episode to be broadcast Sunday. It describes New York City locations mentioned in the episode and, in doing so, gives away only the most benign plot points, like the location of the main characters' new office. Nonetheless, if you want to go into Sunday's episode knowing absolutely nothing in advance, save this post until next week.

A soldier identified by The Mail Online as 25-year-old Pvt. Pirthraj Thapa of the Gurkhas, who lost his left leg in a mine explosion in Afghanistan, waited for a cortege to pass in Wootton Bassett, England, with four members of the First Battalion, Royal Gurkha Rifles, who were killed by an Afghan soldier last week.
The neighborhood of Gulou, which boasts a pair of brick towers dating back hundreds of years, is about to be turned into a polished tourist attraction.

An outdoor pop-up restaurant will set up shop in the yard of the SoHo Grand hotel Aug. 3 to 6, from 6 p.m. to 10:30 p.m. It's another session of the Hunger, started in the spring by the chef Camille Becerra and the nightlife entrepreneurs Alan Philips and Josh Shames of the Sky Group. An Argentine barbecue, or asado, with assorted grilled meats, will be served and there will be a communal table seating 70. Tango music will add a sexy beat. Reservations, from thehungernyc.com, are $65 including tax and tip. There will also be a cash bar.

The troubled oil giant BP announced Tuesday that it had agreed to sell $7 billion of onshore oil and gas assets in Texas, New Mexico, western Canada and Egypt to the Apache Corporation, Jad Mouawad of The New York Times reports.

The restaurant Aquavit is the subject of this week's review, its fourth such accounting in The New York Times since its arrival in Manhattan in 1987. Bryan Miller took the first shot in 1988, back when it was located in one of the Rockefeller Townhouses, awarding the restaurant two stars. My predecessors Ruth Reichl and William Grimes followed in 1995 and in 2001, respectively, awarding three stars. And when the restaurant moved east, in 2005, Frank Bruni wrote about it in a Diner's Journal column.

Months after discovering that a safety inspector submitted reports attesting that buildings were free of asbestos even though he did not inspect them, a New York City agency says it has sharpened its oversight of inspectors.

5:41 p.m. | Updated The Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee ended the month of June with twice as much money in the bank as the National Republican Congressional Committee, according to fund-raising figures released Tuesday, an advantage that Democratic leaders hope will help protect their majority in the midterm elections.

It's difficult to stand out in the front row, but Diane Pernet's all-black ensemble, towering hair and lace mantilla keep the designer/editor/filmmaker/journalist from blending in among starlets and Voguettes. Pernet is the voice behind "A Shaded View of Fashion," a fashion-forward blog that roots for young designers. Once a women's-wear designer in New York, Pernet started her editorial career only after moving to Paris, her home now for 20 years - and the world's most unforgiving fashion capital. "In New York, anything goes and who cares? People can be their own person and nobody's judging you," she says. "But Paris is judging you constantly."

There are hot tickets, and there are red-hot tickets. "The Merchant of Venice" is the latter. The chance to see Al Pacino as Shylock at the Delacorte Theater in Central Park, for free, has turned Central Park West and the walkway that stretches from the open-air theater to the Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis Reservoir into a 21st-century Hooverville, albeit a well-behaved, well-fed, literarily inclined one.
A government-initiated redevelopment plan will transform one of the oldest neighborhoods in Beijing into a polished tourist attraction.

There are perks to playing in a football stadium not named after another team, and the Jets announced one on Tuesday: the creation of a Ring of Honor when they co-open the New Meadowlands Stadium (at least until they sell the naming rights) with the Giants next month.

GRUNFELD--Rudy, age 91, died on Monday, July 19, 2010 in Palm Beach, Florida. He was born in Presov, Czechoslovakia, where he was admitted to Charles University in Prague. When Hitler invaded Czechoslovakia, he and his family were fortunate to immigrate to the USA. Rudy graduated from Indiana University in two years. During WWII he served for six years in Europe as a Captain in Military Intelligence. A graduate of Columbia Law School, he specialized in Real Estate as a partner in Collins Tuttle & Company. He was a serious amateur tennis player and helped found the Israeli Tennis Program. Predeceased in 2009 by his beloved wife Margaret, and his brothers Armin and Milton. He is survived by a grandson and two great-grandchildren, his sister, Dr. Alice Ginott Cohn, her husband Ted Cohn, and nephews and nieces Marc, Jay, Roz, Mimi, Sharon and Beverly. The funeral service will take place on Wednesday, July 21, at 10am, at Schwartz Brothers Memorial Chapels, 114-03 Queens Blvd., Forest Hills, NY 11375; telephone: 800-690-1646; interment at Beth David Cemetery in Elmont, NY.

Saturday, July 10 We awoke early this morning to start the trapping. I had gotten nearly 10 hours of sleep, more than any amount since my 14-month-old daughter was born. After a quick breakfast, we set out a number of traps where we had seen a few birds come to ground yesterday. We also set a few traps out at camp near our kitchen; we had also seen birds there. Then we waited. And waited. And waited some more. Wilson and I took turns monitoring the traps for over 10 hours. Although a few birds came once, none went to ground. It was a long and unproductive day.

HIRSCH--Helen Davidoff. The Rockefeller University deeply mourns the passing of Helen Davidoff Hirsch, M.D., the beloved wife of our cherished friend and esteemed colleague, Jules Hirsch, M.D., Professor Emeritus and Head, Laboratory of Human Behavior and Metabolism, and Physician-in-Chief Emeritus of The Rockefeller University Hospital. We are enormously saddened for Jules over the loss of his dearest life companion. Helen was a distinguished psychiatrist whose work frequently appeared in the Journal of the American Psychoanalytic Association, one of the world's most respected publications in psychoanalysis. In addition to her own work, she was a steadfast supporter of Jules and the pioneering studies on weight loss he conducted in The Rockefeller University Hospital. Helen was a much loved and highly respected member of the Rockefeller University campus community. We will remember her for her extraordinary warmth, her intellectual brilliance, and her courageous spirit. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Jules and the entire Hirsch family. David Rockefeller, Honorary Chair Russell L. Carson, Chair Paul Nurse, President Torsten N. Wiesel, President Emeritus Barry S. Coller, Physician-in-Chief Marnie Imhoff, Vice President

ROOT--John Buttrick, of New York, died on July 9, 2010, in Los Angeles, CA. The son of Edward Wales Root and Grace Cogswell Root, of Clinton, NY, he was born in New York City on September 2, 1922. He attended Brooks School '40, Hamilton College '44, and S.A.I.S. (now Johns Hopkins University) '48. John served in the US Navy, 1943-46, emerging as Lieutenant (j.g.) and later joined the Foreign Services, stationed principally in Jerusalem from 1948-1953. For most of his professional life, he worked as an executive in the oil business, primarily for Exxon Corp, where he retired as vice president of Esso Africa in 1980. He also worked as general manager for TOTAL (Suisse) and as a consultant for Gatoil. An avid traveler, historian and man of letters, John was a dedicated volunteer for both Brooks School and Hamilton College and a proud member of the Century Association. He is predeceased by his wife of 48 years, Nanda Bourouni, and survived by his loving family: his daughter Melina Root, son in law Michael D. Stevens, and grandchildren Sophia and Guy. Funeral services will be held at the Hamilton College Cemetery on July 29, 2010 at 11am. A memorial service will be held in New York City on September 16, 2010 at a private club. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The John B. Root '44 Exhibition Fund, Hamilton College, 198 College Hill Road, Clinton NY 13323.

In a 2003 television advertisement being shown in a loop with other commercials at the exhibition ''Cars, Culture, and the City,'' a black Lamborghini curls through the streets of New York, inspiring fantasies in anyone lucky enough to gaze at its sleek body and slick maneuvers. The video could also be a portrayal of the car's fantasies about the perfect city: empty, rain-washed streets; roads curving into urban canyons; majestic nocturnal geometry. It is as if New York were this creature's natural habitat. And when the car comes across traffic or crowds, it is more at home than those who get in its way; it is the master, while everyone else is just a spectator.

(49) EL GENERAL (2009) In 1978 Alicia Calles began recording her memoirs with the hope of writing a book about her father, Plutarco Elías Calles, above, a general in the Mexican Revolution and the president of Mexico from 1924 to 1928, who left a controversial legacy. He founded the National Revolutionary Party, which, as the subsequent Institutional Revolutionary Party, governed the country for more than 70 years. He also fiercely oppressed Roman Catholics. Eventually Alicia Calles's granddaughter, Natalia Almada, inherited the tapes, creating not only a snapshot of her family's past but also a backdrop against which to better understand modern Mexico in this centennial year of the start of the revolution in 1910. The documentary, presented here by ''P.O.V.,'' earned Ms. Almada the directing award and a nomination for the grand jury prize at the 2009 Sundance Film Festival. 8 P.M. A picture caption in some editions on Wednesday with an obituary about George Steinbrenner, the principal owner of the New York Yankees, referred incorrectly to the circumstances under which a 1978 photo was taken. It did not show Mr. Steinbrenner introducing Mr. Martin as manager.

JEFFERSON--Denise. The Ailey Board of Trustees, staff, dancers and students mourn the passing of our beloved Denise Jefferson, long-time director of The Ailey School, who died on July 17, 2010. For over three decades, her tireless dedication to Ailey had a profound impact on the world of dance and brought honor to Alvin Ailey's legacy. Her clear vision of the elements required to train world-class dancers shaped generations of performing artists. We will miss Denise's elegant beauty, open heart and keen wit. Whenever a curtain goes up, Denise's light will be cast upon us, and her strength, warmth and smile will be remembered. A scholarship fund has been created in her memory at The Ailey School and a celebratory memorial concert is being planned.

The Japanese have been making reggae almost as long as Jamaicans have been exporting it. This phenomenon could have started as early as the mid-'70s, when the film "The Harder They Come" grafted the crime drama to Kingston's reggae scene and became an international cult classic. Or, more likely, it began sometime around 1979, when Bob Marley landed for the first time in the Land of the Rising Sun. Since then, the reggae scene in Japan has cycled through several styles and sub-subcultures, but only in recent years has one crucial aspect of its identity fully emerged: Finally,  Japanese reggae stars are singing in Japanese.

Airgas on Wednesday rejected a sweetened buyout offer from its competitor, Air Products and Chemicals, and reported that its fiscal first-quarter earnings rose 18 percent, The Associated Press reported.

Nilas Martins, a principal dancer at New York City Ballet, has quietly retired from the company after several seasons of dwindling appearances. The City Ballet spokesman, Rob Daniels, confirmed the departure of Mr. Martins - the son of Peter Martins, the ballet master in chief - after the company's brochure for next season appeared without the dancer's name, although he is still listed on City Ballet's Web site. Four other principals retired this past season, some with fanfare, including the star Darci Kistler, who is the wife of Peter Martins. Nilas Martins decided to leave after being accepted late in the season as a fellow at the DeVos Institute of Arts Management at the Kennedy Center, Mr. Daniels said, adding that Mr.  Martins underwent knee surgery in the winter and performed only a few times in the spring.

If the Jetsons relocated to the Swedish Arctic, they might feel right at home at the new Treehotel, which opened officially a few days ago. The project is a collection of four houses perched among the pine trees in the village of Harads. The husband-and-wife team Britta and Kent Lindvall, along with a few of their architect and designer friends, dreamed up the structures, which range from the outrageous to the opulent. There's the aggressively twiggy Nest and the trippy Mirrorcube, a 13-by-13-foot mass wrapped in mirrored glass (tinted with an ultraviolet, invisible-to-humans color that deflects birds), along with the Cabin, which is situated over the slope of a hill overlooking the Lulea River. The view from the deck changes literally with the wind, but don't worry: urban planning students from the nearby Lulua University can vouch for its safety. The compound also has a tree sauna and a tree breakfast-and-meeting room. Two more houses - the disc-shaped UFO and the self-explanatory Room With a View - are set to open in the fall.

A few years ago, the military began analyzing the shapes of recruits' feet. Injuries during basic training were rampant, and military authorities hoped that by fitting soldiers with running shoes designed for their foot types, injury rates would drop. Trainees obediently began clambering onto a high-tech light table with a mirror beneath it, designed to help outline a subject's foot. Evaluators classified the recruits as having high, normal or low arches, and they passed out running shoes accordingly.

It was Memorial Day evening and the scanner was pretty quiet. I went for coffee and a doughnut in Upper Manhattan when the police dispatcher came over with: explosion - the bomb squad, emergency services unit and Fire Department are rushing to the scene, at Murray Street and 27th Avenue, Queens. There had been cookouts and block parties. People were standing around, watching the firefighters. The majority of homes had American flags draped on them. The air was filled with the sounds of fire engines, walkie-talkies and news reporters asking questions. Neighbors had baffled looks. Police officers stood guard behind the yellow tape, waiting to find out what happened.

DINERMAN--Gloria, 82, passed away on July 17th. Raised in Mt. Vernon, NY by her mother Betty Weinberg Green she graduated Davis High School and attended Brown University. She earned a MLS and started The Library Co-op, which she owned until 2008. She is predeceased by her son Douglas, and is survived by her son Robert, daughter-in-law Linda and their children Kathryn, Gregory, and David of New Providence, NJ; her son Peter, daughter-in-law, Mary and their son Bryan of Lafayette, CA. Donations in her name may be sent to St. Jude Children's Hospital 501 St. Jude Place Memphis, TN 38105. There is a celebration service on Saturday, July 24th, 11am at The New Providence Presbyterian Church 1307 Springfield Avenue, New Providence, NJ 07974.

HAMMER--Marvin P.,of Brooklyn, NY, formerly of Kansas City, MO. On July 20, at age 84. Survived by daughter Melanie, sons Michael and Richard, grandchildren Amy and Corey Eiferman and Angus Hammer, niece Judith Epstein and other nieces and nephews. Retired from long and distinguished career in corporate communications. In lieu of flowers, donations to The Humane Society of the United States or to a charity of your choice.

SWINSKY--Morton. Pioneering bond trader, art collector and multiple Tony Award-winning Broadway producer - died June 19, of prostate cancer. He was 75. Swinsky produced numerous plays and musicals, beginning with 'Eubie' and including hits such as 'Spamalot,' 'Spring Awakening,' David Mamet's 'Race,' 'Guys and Dolls' (Tony), 'Chicago' (Tony), 'Annie Get Your Gun' (Tony),'The Music Man,' 'The Who's Tommy,' 'Hamlet,' 'How to Succeed in Business Without Really Trying,' 'Grey Gardens,' 'Jersey Boys' (Tony), 'A View From the Bridge,' 'Hairspray' (Tony), 'The History Boys,' 'Billy Elliot' (Tony) and, most recently, 'Fela!,' and 'The Addams Family.' Swinsky was the recipient of film and television awards (AFI, Emmy) for 'You Can Count On Me,' 'Boys Don't Cry' and the concert version of 'Sweeney Todd.' With all these successes, Mort seemed devoid of ego and hubris. Backing a quality play or musical is what brought him pleasure. That and collecting art. Recognized by The National Sculpture Society, Swinsky was a patron to artists mostly in the Figurative Arts. Born to immigrant parents of Russian Jewish descent, Swinsky was raised in the Inwood section of Manhattan. While at City College night school, where he met his wife Florence Swinsky (Pincus), he pursued a job with CJ Devine and Co., where his mind, memory, and ability to predict value propelled him to the top of his field. When Merrill Lynch consolidated operations with CJ Devine, the "Devine Boys" created a high percentage of Merrill's revenue, and were granted the autonomy to run Merrill Lynch Government Securities Inc., with Swinsky as Executive Vice President. As a leader and pioneer in the trading of government bonds, Swinsky and his team left in 1980 to join William E. Pollock & Co and in 1990, the "Udder Guys" joined Fuji Securities. He retired from that firm as President. It was during his successful tenure on Wall Street that his eye for talent brought him into the world of Broadway and other arts. Mort touched so many people in his lifetime. He will be remembered and missed. He is survived by Florence, their two daughters Karen and Dana, and five grandchildren, Nikola, Dante and Thanos Carouso and Connor and Harry Cantelmo. A Memorial will be held Monday, July 26 at the Lotos Club, 5 East 66 St, 6:30 -8:30. Additional remembrances can be shared at legacy.com. Contributions in Mort's memory may be made to The National Sculpture Society, and The New York Theater Workshop.

Roosevelt Island has a Dickensian past full of prisons, workhouses and insane asylums, and there have been wisecracks that its governing in more modern times -- it opened as a planned community in 1975 -- has not evolved much past that. It opened as a utopian urban experiment of mixed-income, multiracial residents, but it has hardly been a political utopia, with a long tradition of unrest between residents and the politically appointed officials who run the two-mile sliver of this East River community parallel to Manhattan's Upper East Side.

JEFFERSON--Denise. Fordham University mourns the death of Denise Jefferson, director of the Ailey School and co-founder of the Ailey/Fordham BFA Program in Dance. Jefferson died of ovarian cancer on July 18. A skilled dancer herself, Jefferson had served on the faculty of the internationally acclaimed dance school, affiliated with Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, since 1974 and had been its director since 1984. In 1998, Jefferson collaborated with Edward J. Bristow, Ph.D., professor of history and former dean of Fordham College at Lincoln Center (FCLC), to create the unique degree program at FCLC that offers a blend of liberal arts classes and conservatory training in dance. Jefferson held a bachelor's degree in French from Wheaton College and a master's in French from New York University. She is survived by her mother, Irma Jefferson; her sister Margo Jefferson; and a daughter, Francesca Harper.

ZUKOWSKY--Daniel. Our heartfelt sympathy goes out to our dear friends Paul and Ava, their daughter Rebecca, and the rest of the Zukowsky family on the passing of Paul's father, Dan. We hope your many memories will bring you comfort. Love, Arlene, Ben, Justin and Alexander

The reports over the police radio were alarming: an explosion at 27th Avenue and Murray Street in Queens had critically injured a man. Firefighters, ambulance crews and the bomb squad were dispatched. It was May 31, Memorial Day, and the neighborhood was decked out in American flags and bustling with block parties and backyard cookouts. The police searched the backyard of the house where the blast had occurred, blowing off the garage roof. Outside, walkie-talkie chatter competed with questions from reporters and neighbors. The news was grim: the injured man had suffered burns over 70 percent of his body, and three others were treated at the scene. The authorities suspect that a cloud of fuel ignited when the lights were turned on in the garage. Earlier pictures in the series are at nytimes.com/lens.

JERUSALEM -- The director of the Israel Museum was leading a visitor to see a provocative contemporary sculpture of a naked African youth when, stepping over protective cloths and around an exhibit of late Canaanite sarcophagi, he nearly ran into four workmen carrying the million-year-old horns of a wild bull. The horns are the oldest items in the museum's collection, and something about the juxtaposition of contemporary social consciousness, ancient ceremony and prehistoric beast summed up the museum's refocused mission as it completes a three-year, $100 million renewal. As described by the director, James S. Snyder, the museum offers a series of unexpected aesthetic links across cultures and their histories, like the way 2,000-year-old carved ritual cups that are on view in the museum near the Dead Sea Scrolls are somehow evocative of Brancusi.

Denise Jefferson, an internationally known dance educator who as the longtime director of the Ailey School oversaw the training of generations of world-class performers, died on Saturday in Manhattan. She was 65 and a Manhattan resident. The cause was ovarian cancer, according to the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, of which the Ailey School is the official training academy.

GRUNFELD--Rudy, age 91, died on Monday, July 19, 2010 in Palm Beach, Florida. He was born in Presov, Czechoslovakia, where he was admitted to Charles University in Prague. When Hitler invaded Czechoslovakia, he and his family were fortunate to immigrate to the USA. Rudy graduated from Indiana University in two years. During WWII he served for six years in Europe as a Captain in Military Intelligence. A graduate of Columbia Law School, he specialized in Real Estate as a partner in Collins Tuttle & Company. He was a serious amateur tennis player and helped found the Israeli Tennis Program. Predeceased in 2009 by his beloved wife Margaret, and his brothers Armin and Milton. He is survived by a grandson and two great-grandchildren, his sister, Dr. Alice Ginott Cohn, her husband Ted Cohn, and nephews and nieces Marc, Jay, Roz, Mimi, Sharon and Beverly. The funeral service will take place on Wednesday, July 21, at 10am, at Schwartz Brothers Memorial Chapels, 114-03 Queens Blvd., Forest Hills, NY 11375; telephone: 800-690-1646; interment at Beth David Cemetery in Elmont, NY.

An article last Wednesday about seafood inspections in the Gulf of Mexico misstated the number of testers who need to smell oil or other chemicals in a sample of fish in determining whether fishing grounds are quarantined. It is three out of seven testers, not five out of seven. (If no taint is detected, the sample is sent for laboratory analysis.)

The record will show that Lou Piniella announced his retirement Tuesday, the day after his starting pitcher gave up five runs in one inning. Piniella, a born hitter, never had much patience for pitchers. Once this tedious Chicago Cubs season ends, they will never torment him again. Piniella, who turns 67 next month, batted .291 in an 18-year career spent mostly with the Yankees. He was a favorite of George Steinbrenner, who made him a manager in 1986 and again in 1988. Piniella, who often wore his 1977 Yankees World Series ring, knew better than to ever return, preferring instead to gibe his old friend.

How do you make Chianti Classico riserva a summertime wine? First, you serve it cool, cellar temperature, not room temperature. Then, you pour it with food that has a hot weather vibe. Though steak is what these sturdy wines demand, slabs of thick porterhouse or rib-eye on the grill will do fine for the season, and for Tuscany. To give these steaks sunglasses and a deck chair, a salad goes alongside. The quintessential Tuscan salad is panzanella, made with garden vegetables and pieces of stale bread in a vinaigrette. Taking advantage of a lighted grill, this version of panzanella combines grilled fennel with cucumbers and olives. I even grilled the bread. Some rosemary addresses a dominant herbal flavor in the wine.

BP will most likely move forward with the ''static kill'' that could permanently seal the gusher in a few days. The method is similar to the ''top kill'' that failed in early June and would use existing equipment and plumbing. Company officials said this effort was more likely to succeed because a new cap atop the well had stemmed the flow of oil.

An article on July 13 about new research on the role of microbes in the human body misstated part of the name of a bacterium linked to skin infections in babies delivered by Caesarean section. It is methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus, not ''multiply resistant.''

A music review on Thursday about a concert presented by the Washington Square Music Festival, at St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church in the West Village, misidentified a soloist and one of the instruments played in the Haydn Sinfonia Concertante in B flat. The soloist was Harry Searing, playing bassoon; not Mitchell Kriegler, a clarinetist who also played in the concert. (There is no clarinet in the Haydn work.)

COLLINS--Michael F. A lifelong advocate for life, he left us abruptly. Born in Connecticut, resident most of his life, his dedication to the State's Broadcasters entitled him their historian. No one encouraged and guided more than he the toddlers who were not his children; a mentor, a teacher. By skill and training Michael was a writer. For the Associated Press, newspapers, magazines, the internet, he wrote, all for career; for love, he wrote of the little particulars of the Radio and TV Stations, large and small, and the multitudes who made them play. He was their comprehensive chronicler. His work resides in many places to be read and reviewed by scholars, journalists, and the rest of us who want to remember a time that never passed and a man who never grew up. As we all said back then and must again, "Peace," Michael, "Peace!"
An article last Wednesday about clam bars misspelled part of the name of a town in giving directions to Peter's Clam Bar in Island Park, N.Y. It is Rockville Centre, not Rockville Center.

There are perks to playing in a football stadium not named after another team, and the Jets announced one on Tuesday: the creation of a Ring of Honor when they co-open the New Meadowlands Stadium (at least until they sell the naming rights) with the Giants next month. The initial class consists of five players and one coach, each an integral part of Jets history, from the distant, or more recent, past. The group, in alphabetical order, includes Weeb Ewbank, Winston Hill, Joe Klecko, Curtis Martin, Don Maynard and Joe Namath.

MESSUD--Francois-Michel, died July 19, age 79, in Greenwich, CT. Born in Toulon, France, he grew up in Beirut, Salonica, and Algiers, and came to America on a Fulbright Scholarship at Amherst College in 1952. He received his MA from the Harvard Center for Middle Eastern Studies (1961), and MBA from CEI, Geneva (1963). He worked for many years for Pechiney Corporation, and at his retirement was President of Pechiney World Trade. A lifelong scholar, passionate traveler, fierce lover of life and of his family, a man of abiding humor and greatest integrity, who faced illness in recent years with unflinching courage and optimism, he will be dearly missed. He is survived by his adored wife of 53 years, Margaret; by his sister Denise (of Toulon); his daughters Elizabeth (of Paris) and Claire (of Cambridge, Mass); by his sons-in-law Vassili Efimov and James Wood; and by his four beloved grandchildren.

JEFFERSON--Denise. The Ailey Board of Trustees, staff, dancers and students mourn the passing of our beloved Denise Jefferson, long-time director of The Ailey School, who died on July 17, 2010. For over three decades, her tireless dedication to Ailey had a profound impact on the world of dance and brought honor to Alvin Ailey's legacy. Her clear vision of the elements required to train world-class dancers shaped generations of performing artists. We will miss Denise's elegant beauty, open heart and keen wit. Whenever a curtain goes up, Denise's light will be cast upon us, and her strength, warmth and smile will be remembered. A scholarship fund has been created in her memory at The Ailey School and a celebratory memorial concert is being planned.

Yes, the history teacher with the pictures of Che Guevara and Fidel Castro on his classroom walls really was a communist. After three years of investigation, the New York City special investigator for schools released a report (also see below) on Tuesday about a 2007 spring break trip to Cuba taken by public-school students from selective Beacon High School on the Upper West Side that violated federal restrictions on travel to Cuba.

LAURIE--Marilyn. The President and Trustees of Columbia University express deep sorrow at the passing of Marilyn Laurie. Her leadership as a University Trustee, Trustee officer, and Trustee Emerita was marked by exceptional insight, unfailing decency, and a passionate dedication to Columbia. Columbia University extends its profound sympathy to her husband Robert, and her children Amy and Lisa.

9 P.M. (13) MERLE HAGGARD: LEARNING TO LIVE WITH MYSELF Since 1965 Merle Haggard, above, has led his band the Strangers to 40 No. 1 country hits. He has been called ''the poet of the common man,'' and in 1994 he was inducted into the Country Music Hall of Fame. But his reputation as a hellion was born early. After hopping his first freight train at 10, he was jailed 17 times in his youth for crimes including car theft. His life changed forever, he has said, when, as an inmate at San Quentin, he heard Johnny Cash perform there on New Year's Day 1959. Now 73, Mr. Haggard is touring on behalf of ''I Am What I Am,'' his first solo album since ''The Bluegrass Sessions'' in 2007. Reviewing the album in The New York Times, Jon Caramanica said Mr. Haggard tackled ''songs for which age is an asset, not a liability,'' adding, ''Once again Mr. Haggard is an outlaw.'' This ''American Masters'' presentation from Gandulf Hennig follows Mr. Haggard across three years, from life on his California ranch to his concert tours. The film includes interviews with Robert Duvall, John Fogerty, Billy Gibbons, Kris Kristofferson, Keith Richards, Tanya Tucker, Don Was and Dwight Yoakam. 8 P.M. (Speed TV) STEALTH RIDER The biker Jason Britton plots to make the ultimate stunt movie by surreptitiously filming high jinks in front of well-known backdrops, starting in Detroit, where he'll twist, flip and peel out at Zug Island, Belle Isle, Greektown and Metro Station. ''Intersections,'' a new series at 10, pits two different types of vehicles against each other. First: an 8,000-horsepower hot rod tests its might against an F/A-18 military jet.

Yep, another cool thing coming out of Portland, Ore.: Beckel Canvas Products (beckelcanvas.com; 800-237-3362). Since 1964, the family-run company has been making made-to-order canvas bags and tents for glampers and G.I. Joes and Janes alike. Stylish enough for any adventure, the "possibilities bag" was created by the founder Bob Beckel to "carry whatever you could possibly need," whether you're transporting a picnic or a passel of teacup dogs. Offered in natural white, olive and red, each piece is stamped with "eena" on the label - the Chinook Indian word for beaver (an animal known for its lodge-building skills). For more rough-going adventures, there's the "war bag," which holds, as Beckel explains, "everything you'd need to go to war," as well as miner tents and outhouses.

In late April the family readiness officer, Tina Morgan, began calling and e-mailing each of 48 anxious First Anglico families with news about the company's return to Camp Pendleton. (Anglico units - the name stands for Air Naval Gunfire Liaison Company - are part of the Marine Corps.) And even though a lot of private, superstitious things had been put off by many who were waiting for the good news, I elected to wait a little longer, until I was sure my Marine had both feet on friendly soil. I'd seen enough just-about-to-retire cop movies to know that having the end in sight slows the clock and multiplies the already too plentiful ways that things can go wrong before the actual, final, blessed end of the deployment.

Perhaps you've seen this clip, from last weekend's "Meet the Press," in which Pete Sessions, Republican of Texas, labors to offer any specifics whatsoever when pressed about what the G.O.P. would actually do if it managed to reclaim some share of power this November:

"In the end, perhaps the most penetrating question [Marilynne] Robinson asks in regard to all the modern schools of suspicion is, simply enough: why? That is, if purely material, purely selfish impulses underlie all those behaviors we mistake for selfless altruism or spiritual longing or magnanimity or self-outpouring love, why do they so utterly invert themselves in our conscious minds? Why do they dissimulate themselves as the very opposite of what they are? Let us assume that the conscious mind, with all of its ambiguities and mysteries and abyssal sense of identity, is nothing but the illusory and superficial epiphenomenon of some hidden, unitary, primordial, and amoral material impulse towards survival. Very well, then, but why would it have to hide this fact? Surely it would have no need to deceive itself so elaborately, or to conceal its own genetic interests from itself, unless it already possessed some kind of moral sensitivity to the shame of selfishness. What, then, is that moral self that is there 'before' the Darwinian self, whose conscience must be appeased, needing to believe that it is moved by altruism or disinterested love?"

Researchers who study recreational golf know a lot about our game, and they all agree on one thing: the truly awful shots - hopelessly errant tee shots or short chips that fly over greens - ruin most rounds by average golfers. If 105 is a typical score for you, you are likely to have about eight awful shots per round, while someone who shoots around 80 will probably have just two. That's according to Mark Broadie, a Columbia University professor who has spent years analyzing data from average golfers.

Working with Chris Cannon and his other partners in the Alta Marea restaurant group, he will be executive chef at Ai Fiori, the second-floor restaurant in the Setai Fifth Avenue, 400 Fifth Avenue (37th Street), set to open in late fall. The restaurant will feature the food of the Italian Mediterranean coast, with some French Riviera influences, and have about 185 seats with another 40 at the bar. Though the hotel shares its name with the Setai Wall Street, which also has a second-floor restaurant (SHO Shaun Hergatt), each is owned by a different company.

One report concluded that China's total energy use now tops that of the United States, just a couple of years behind its rise to the top position on lists of emitters of carbon dioxide. (China almost immediately disputed the agency's conclusion.)
Co-vocabularists may be interested to know of a new BBC radio documentary on the genesis and evolution of the almanac - presented by Ben Schott.

In time, history will show that this week was won not by Republicans or Democrats, not by the White House or its political opponents, but by Bill Murray. A few days ago Mr. Murray - who has all but become his whimsical if slightly forlorn "Lost in Translation" character - told GQ magazine that he had accepted his role in the "Garfield" movie because he believed it was being made by the Coen brothers. (So why the sequel, hmm?) For a follow-up, he began his appearance Wednesday on "Late Show With David Letterman" with some literal Dumpster diving - as in, he went for a swim in a waste bin filled with water and what appeared to be some actual garbage. (This seemed to go on for a lot longer on the television broadcast than it does in the above video clip.)

The San Francisco Museum of Modern Art has selected the Norwegian architecture firm Snohetta to design an expansion that will increase its gallery and public space by about 100,000 square feet, the museum is to announce on Thursday. Initial design concepts are to be unveiled next spring.

MOREINIS--Josh, of Croton-on-Hudson, NY, on July 16, 2010, at age 46. Loving husband of Pamela Ivinski, son of Pat Moreinis Dodge and the late Abel Moreinis, brother of Bram Moreinis, step-son of Peter Dodge. Graduate of Columbia University and a Fulbright Scholar in South Korea, he was a Senior Planner at STV Inc. and a landscape painter. His joie de vivre will be deeply missed. Service Sunday, July 25, 2pm, Temple Israel of Northern Westchester, Croton-on-Hudson.

Sony electronics is really pushing 3-D technology in the home, with its 3-D TVs and 3-D video games and movies. This week it brought more dimensionality into the electronics market by announcing a new crop of 3-D pocket cameras, the DSC-TX9 and DSC-WX5. Sony calls these cameras the ''world's smallest'' in the 3-D space and says they can take three-dimensional panoramic images with a new technology, Sweep Panorama. This allows camera owners to press the shutter button on the camera and move across a panoramic scene to create extensive, captivating photos, Sony says.

An answer in the Q&A column on July 13 about the National Weather Service's system for estimating a tornado's strength gave an outdated explanation for part of the process. Since 2007, the standard has been the enhanced Fujita scale, with modified damage assessments and wind speeds -- not the Fujita scale.

The hot weather can make for an unpleasant riding experience -- a thick film of sweat being the obvious result of all but the shortest pedal -- but could it be causing flat tires as well? ''What I've been seeing is that the last couple of weeks of high heat is a lot more flats,'' said Jake Fleischmann at Roy's Sheepshead Cycle on Coney Island Avenue in Brooklyn. He said that during a normal 10-hour day, mechanics at the shop, one of the borough's biggest, would fix about a hundred flats, but that recently he had seen upward of 150 and even 200.

Simple backup has always been an oxymoron. But I just tried a device that could change that: The Clickfree C2N drive can automatically back up Windows PCs and Macs over a home network with real set-it-and-forget-it ease. The 500-gigabyte Clickfree C2N costs $180 (it's $142 at Amazon), and that's definitely a premium over standard 2.5-inch 500-gigabyte external drives, which sell for $120 or less. But the C2N can be a truly digital-life-saving device for those who can't commit to regular backups.

Before the New York Philharmonic presented a concert in Central Park last week, the executive director of the orchestra had an announcement: Audience members could vote for an encore from the evening's soloist by text message. The Chinese melody won, and so did marketers for the soloist, the piano virtuoso Lang Lang. Voters swiftly received a reply offering a discount to ''pre-order'' his new CD set, ''Live in Vienna,'' and an invitation to follow him on Facebook.

THAT'S not the reaper glowering in the photograph at right. It's Ambrosia Mitchell, affecting the menace and shroudlike garb of Xion, a key blade-wielding warrior in Kingdom Hearts, a popular Japanese video game. Ms. Mitchell, who produces anime events in Manhattan, was among the more arresting visions on Saturday at JapanTown, a street fair and kinky fashion masquerade in the East Village. Visitors parading on Fourth Avenue included a phalanx of goth Lolitas, kinky schoolgirls and maids in starched aprons and pinafores. Swarms of self-styled Harajuku girls flaunted a look composed of the requisite clashing prints, mismatched socks and surreally pallid makeup. Devotees of Tokyo street style, with its weirdly sexualized, faintly sinister lure, included Crystal Lonnquist, (bottom, with fan), showing off a lacy scarf and a glove that fastened up the wrist like a corset; and Seiko Dee, daftly subversive in a midi-blouse and mini (left), dressed as Haruhi Suzumiya, his anime idol.

ELLIOTT--Glenn. The partners and staff of Goldfarb & Fleece express our profound sadness on the passing of our friend, Glenn Elliott, and extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife, Cheryl, his children, Brooke and Alana, and the entire Elliott family.

A petite woman with a puff of brown curls wandered around a dimly lighted backyard in Bushwick, Brooklyn, on Tuesday night with a mixing bowl cocked on her hip, stumbling in the dark and stepping on the flip-flop-exposed toes of partygoers lounging on the grass. ''Ouch!'' a seated victim exclaimed. The woman dipped a purple scoop into her bowl and hefted out globules of tofu chocolate pudding spiked with cayenne, and - as she had already done to half the garden party - poured the viscous dessert into the injured guest's mouth. ''This will make it all better,'' she said.

BEIRNE--Rev. Charles, SJ (72), Jesuit educator died on July 14, 2010 at the Jesuit Infirmary on the Fordham campus. Father Beirne was ordained in 1969 and served at Regis High School (Headmaster), Colegio San Ignacio in Puerto Rico (Principal), University of Rafael Landivar (Academic Vice President), Le Moyne College (President) and most recently Fordham University (Visiting Professor). He held a Ph.D. from the University of Chicago and was the recipient of four honorary degrees. The Vigil Service will be Friday, July 23 at 7-9pm in O'Keefe Commons on the Fordham Rosehill campus. Last week, workers at the World Trade Center site discovered a 30-foot section of an 18th-century ship, buried about 20 to 30 feet below street level. It's a remarkable find, but hardly a first for New York. Since the late 1970s, hundreds of archaeological digs around the city have uncovered thousands of artifacts and structures -- each of which have helped to shape our understanding of New York's history. The Op-Ed editors asked 12 local archaeologists to share their most memorable discoveries. Tannery Foley Square Maps show that in the 18th century the Collect Pond, which sat on the north side of Foley Square but was filled in around 1815, was home to the city's tanning industry -- but there were no artifacts to prove it. In 1995, though, I determined that subtle changes in the soil composition under the square were probably caused by rotted bark and organic mats, items that were used in the tanning process. Subsequent excavations yielded goat horns from discarded carcasses and tanning hooks, evidence that tanneries had in fact been on the site. -- JOSEPH SCHULDENREIN, archaeological consultant

Rebtel, which bills itself as the largest mobile Internet phone company, is making international calls between 50 countries free, provided the calls are made between Android phones. LAWRENCE--A. Brewster Jr.,July 16, 1915 to July 16, 2010. Beloved husband and father. A gentle and wise man with a kind word and a smile for everyone. A man who felt at peace in his church. I have been learning a lot about the area and its inhabitants. Kalacha lies at the northern tip of the Chalbi desert, which extends south for probably 60 miles or more. Lake Turkana lies to the west; most of the famous hominid fossils found in Turkana are from the western side of the lake, and not near to where we are. To the north is Ethiopia. Before reaching Ethiopia, however, is a mountain range called the Huri hills. I will not have time to get there on this trip, but they are said to have some of the best grazing land in all of Kenya. The area is green because of continual moisture from clouds. Unfortunately, there is no permanent water source in the hills, so the herdsman move their cattle between the Huris and the springs along the edge of the Chalbi after the water from the rainy season dries up.

SANTA FE, N.M. -- Opera companies typically do not want critics anywhere near a dress rehearsal for a major new production. A dress rehearsal is the last chance to correct musical details and fiddle with staging. It's not a place for critics.

The winners of the National Design Awards, sponsored by the Cooper Hewitt, National Design Museum - along with the finalists and jury members - attended a Teen Design Fair at the Smithsonian American Art Museum's Renwick Gallery, where a sort of speed-dating setup had more than 400 students hopping from table to table learning what is like to be, say, a graphic designer (from this year's honoree in communication design, Stephen Doyle) or an interior designer (William Sofield, another honoree). One juror, Jenna Lyons of J. Crew, drew a crowd at her table, as did the fashion guru and keynote speaker Tim Gunn, who advised the students, "Whatever you do, do it 150 percent."

West Point isn't the most natural environment for a kid like me: a chubby, Indian-born, vegetarian Hindu. Sometimes, I join my friends and family in marveling how on earth I ended up there, perhaps more so how I made it through. But when considering the recipe to my success at the academy, my heart finds the key ingredient in people like First Lt. Christopher Goeke. Then Cadet Goeke, Chris was my dear friend, my West Point classmate, and my polar opposite.

President Obama, fresh from his victory lap after Senate passage of a bill to extend unemployment insurance, called on lawmakers to finish work on a small-business jobs proposal that had been held up by partisan fighting.

"Oh, they'll grow out of it," I said to myself at the National Theater on Thursday, watching the work of two exceptionally bleak young playwrights. In the book-ended full-length plays that I saw in their final double bill at the small Cottesloe Theater, these fledgling dramatists were condemning all their young characters to lonely, trapped, sexually tormented existences from which there was no escape. To borrow a phrase that one of those writers would use elsewhere, the unhappy souls who inhabit "Beyond the Horizon" and "Spring Storm" are destined to live out a life sentence of "solitary confinement inside their own skins."

"I take full responsibility for this amazing weather," said Mayor Bloomberg at last night's annual Prospect Park Summer Soirée. No doubt the guests were thankful for the breeze. Guests at the disco-themed party hosted by the park's junior committee, which was chaired by T editor Sally Singer, boogied down to music by DJ Scott Devendorf of the National - including Chris Taylor of the band Grizzly Bear, Dana Lorenz of Fenton,J. Crew's Jenna Lyons, designers Jeffrey Costello and Robert Tagliapietra, and Suno designers Max Osterweis and Erin Beatty. ("I thought about wearing my white polyester suit, but I thought I'd better not," said the mayor of the evening's theme.) Singer's guests included 2010 CFDA/Vogue Fashion Fund finalists, who could be found chatting in the boathouse: designer Prabal Gurung, jewelry designers Pamela Love and Eddie Borgo (with stylist Keegan Singh close by) and Altuzarra's Joseph Altuzarra (who worked up quite a sweat not on the dance floor but rather from his favorite backpack: "I don't suggest wearing a backpack to a disco party," he said). CFDA alumni Philip Crangi, Sophie Théallet and Vena Cava's Sophie Buhai and Lisa Mayock gave a warm and excited toast to the 2010 gang. Between drinks, dancing and bidding in the fund-raiser auction (a tax-deductible Lanvin shoulder bag!), the far-out draw of the night were the electric boat rides that designer Mandy Coon coined "groovy." We can dig it.
Today, Tropical Storm Bonnie halts spill response efforts, European banks face a stress test, and New Orleans gender-bending bounce rap scene breaks out and goes national.

Fun apps can make for a safer road trip with children, since bickering siblings are one of the more potent distractions for a driver. I wrote about a bunch of apps to keep children entertained on road trips in this week's App Smart column.
Borrowing a strategy from the spring's biggest reality show, "American Idol," the summer's biggest reality show, "America's Got Talent," is taking its top contestants on tour.

Has the theater world found another "Lion King"? For their next stage project, Elton John and Lee Hall are adapting a work about talking animals that no English-language reader of the last 65 years could possibly be unfamiliar with and is still widely taught in schools. Oh, and before you break out your checkbook to buy tickets or to invest, you should also know it's a metaphor for the rise of Stalinism.

Federal oceanographers have released their second report assessing how much of the oil that gushed from the Gulf of Mexico seabed since the blowout of the BP well may have dispersed in ocean depths rather than rising to the surface. The new analysis confirms the previous conclusion that some oil did in fact drift and disperse in waters between 3,300 and 4,300 feet beneath the surface.

Condé Nast announced on Friday that it is splitting the job of its chief executive officer and president in two, the latest in a series of high-level management reshuffling that has shaken the magazine publishing world's crown jewel.

There is a whole language of technical jargon to describe music. Though these words and concepts are very handy to musicians, they tend to mystify non-musicians. Even people who go to concerts all the time, upon being confronted with terms like chromatic harmony, passacaglia and sonata form may have no real idea what they mean.

About an hour south of Lisbon lies Comporta, a quiet stretch of Portuguese coast that some of the country's oldest families as well as designers like Jacques Grange and Christian Louboutin have turned into their secret summer holiday. Dotted with thatched fishermen cottages, pine forests and rice fields, Comporta doesn't look like much at first glance. And that's how sun-seeking summer residents would like to keep it. But a recent tour of the pristine beaches (much of the area is preserved by a private company, Herdade da Comporta), boho-style boutiques and the charming shacks that have been glammed up by families and fashion folks alike revealed that this hidden piece of paradise might be the next "It" destination on the Montauk-Jose Ignacio- Ibiza circuit. The Aman resort is betting on the same - it's opening a property here in 2012.

Karl Rove now tells us that his "biggest mistake" was not fighting back against the perception that the Bush administration deliberately misled us into the Iraq war. His main evidence that nothing like that happened is the fact that a 2005 commission found no wrongdoing.

Sabbar Kashur, a married Palestinian man who was convicted of "rape by deception" by an Israeli court this week, for telling a Jewish woman that he was a Jewish bachelor interested in a long-term relationship before they had consensual sex, will appeal an 18-month prison sentence, according to CNN.

Heard of this television series, "Mad Men"? A few guys and a few gals work in an agency, sell a couple ads, have a couple laughs? Are you so eager for the premiere of its fourth season that you'd leave your home and brave Times Square to watch it an hour before the rest of the East Coast? Or are you so sick to death of that show's rabid fan base that you'd like to arm yourself with a few advance details so you can ruin the surprises for your "Mad Men"-worshiping friends? (Seriously, though, don't do that.) Would you just like to meet the actress who plays Peggy Olsen?

With interest in the ancient Dutch style of gin known as genever growing in cocktail circles, it was only a matter of time before a genever bar opened in New York. There's no easy way to say this, Ecuador, but it's over. It was what it was: a quickie ranchera bus ride from the Peruvian border, a brief swing through Loja, and a flight to Quito before I slipped out your northern door. You deserved so much more.

It appeared dead on Wednesday, but it came back to life on Thursday: A fund to encourage small banks to make loans to small businesses, pulled from the Senate's small-business jobs bill for lack of Republican support, has found its way back into the bill after all. Late Thursday evening, the Senate voted, 60 to 37, to end debate on an amendment that would restore the lending fund to the jobs bill. Two Republicans joined 58 members of the Democratic caucus to overcome a Republican-threatened filibuster. Our colleague David Herszenhorn has the details at The Caucus.

When Thierry Henry first joined Arsenal in 1999, it took the French striker eight games to score his first goal, the lone strike in a 1-0 win over Southampton on Sept. 18, 1999. Then 22, Henry had most of his career ahead of him. Now, a month before his 33rd birthday, his goal-scoring days are more numbered, so he wasted no time opening his account for his new team. He scored Thursday in his New York Red Bulls debut, an exhibition game against Tottenham Hotspur.

SAN DIEGO - There she was, the Academy Award winner Helen Mirren - she was introduced that way - working the crowd in Hall H at Comic-Con here. It really was like the Cannes Film Festival, with bad food. (On the culinary front, the safest bet inside the convention center would appear to be the bananas, but they cost $2.75 each, no kidding). Ms. Mirren, best known for her Oscar-winning turn as Queen Elizabeth II in "The Queen," was radiant, and said all the things an actress is supposed to say. "This miraculously came along for me," she said of her role as a bloody assassin in "Red," Summit Entertainment's movie based on a graphic novel. Ms. Mirren said it was delightful working with a cast that included Bruce Willis, John Malkovich and Karl Urban. "It was an unknown world to me, an unknown gen-re," she said, getting the French pronunciation just right.

HAWKINS--John A.,M.F.A, July 10, after surgery. Professor Emeritus of Art and Design at Queensborough Community College, master printmaker, gifted teacher, trusted mentor, member of Faculty Executive Committee, department chair, one of the founders of and constant donor to the Queensborough Art Gallery, one of the designers of the A.S. degree in Visual and Performing Arts, member of the Atlantic Gallery, theater designer, balletomane. An article last Friday about the connections between Turkey's political elite and I.H.H., the Turkish charity that organized the Gaza-bound aid flotilla stopped by a deadly Israeli raid on May 31, contained several errors. Because of an editing error, the article misstated the effect of a ban on I.H.H. in Germany, where a charity that operates under the same name and was founded by the same people became legally separate in 1997. The ban applied only to the German charity, not the Turkish one. The article also misstated the price paid by the Turkish charity for the lead flotilla vessel, the Mavi Marmara. It was $1.2 million, not $1.8 million. And the article referred incorrectly to the relationship between Istanbul Fast Ferries, the municipal agency that sold the Mavi Marmara to the Turkish charity, and the Istanbul City Municipality Transportation Corporation, another city agency. While both are controlled by Turkey's ruling AK party, the transportation corporation is responsible for land transit; it does not oversee the ferry agency.

SENCHAK--Andrew, of Ocean Grove, died peacefully on July 21 at the age of 93. Andy was born on April 19, 1917 in Youngstown, Ohio, to Michael and Mary Senchak who had emigrated from Lviv, Ukraine. He graduated from Newark College of Engineering with a degree in Mechanical Engineering. Mr. Senchak served during World War II as a Naval Pilot and flight instructor. After the war he was employed by ITT for 35 years, beginning as test pilot and as an engineer in research and development. His projects ranged from missile defense and telecommunications to a precursor of the zip code system. He is survived by his loving family, his wife of 69 years, Evelyn, his sons, Andy and Doug, his daughter, Laurie Ranney and grandchildren, Phoebe and Christopher Banks, Alex C. Senchak, Max Senchak, Adrienne Ranney and Simone Kaplan-Senchak and a great-grand daughter, Ella Rei Banks Frankenburg. He is also survived by his brothers George and Melvin Senchak. Relatives and friends may call on Friday July 23 form 4-8pm and on Saturday from 9am - until funeral services beginning at 11am at the Ocean Grove Memorial Home 118 Main Avenue, Ocean Grove. A memorial service will also be held at a later date. To e-mail a condolence message, please visit: www.ogmhognj.com.

McGONAGLE--Edward F. Fordham Law School is deeply saddened by the loss of Professor Emeritus Edward F. McGonagle. Professor McGonagle joined the Fordham Law faculty in 1964 with an impressive background and wide-ranging intellectual interests. For 42 years, he taught Decedents' Estates, Trusts, Land Use, Future Interests, and Administrative Law. He retired in 2006, and the following year he was elevated to Emeritus status. Professor McGonagle was a superb teacher who combined deep knowledge of his subjects with a gentle wit, and he made the most complex courses accessible and enjoyable. He was extraordinarily thoughtful and decent to all those he came into contact with--an example for all. He would quote to his classes the Quaker saying, "Be present where you are." The saying calls on us to treasure each moment of life as a gift and also to treasure the presence of those around us. Professor McGonagle's life was a testament to the power of this philosophy. William Michael Treanor, Dean, Fordham Law School

HYMAN--Linda. Died peacefully on July 20, 2010 in Indianapolis, Indiana after a brief illness. Her beloved sister Carol and Carol's husband Ronnie were by her side. Linda enthusiastically embraced life and her chosen profession as an art dealer in particular. Linda will be missed by her many friends and colleagues and by her family Carol and Ronnie Sands, her nephew Michael, his wife Diana and their children Lauren and Emily; her niece Margot Rosenstein, her husband Alex and their children Joe and Zeke. Kay Bearman for Carol Sands

8 P.M (Flix) THE 400 BLOWS (1959) Most critics consider François Truffaut's semiautobiographical portrait, which won him the best director award at the 1959 Cannes Film Festival, to be a masterpiece and a landmark New Wave film. About an adolescent boy, Antoine (Jean-Pierre Léaud, above), who finds himself in trouble at school and at home, the film is the first of five movies that Truffaut shot over 20 years about Antoine as he grows older. Praising the cycle, Vincent Canby said in The New York Times that it is ''unlike anything else in cinema.'' 7:35 P.M. (WAM) THE FRESHMAN (1990) Marlon Brando sends up his role in ''The Godfather'' with a rare comedic performance as Carmine Sabatini, a mobster who hires Clark Kellogg (Matthew Broderick, above right, with Mr. Brando), a New York University film student, to make sure an endangered Komodo dragon gets to a $350,000-a-plate dinner where it will be served as the entrée. In The Times, Janet Maslin called this Andrew Bergman film ''a witty and enchanted comedy.'' Bruno Kirby, Maximilian Schell and B. D. Wong make appearances in supporting roles, and the former Miss America host Bert Parks sings a version of ''There She Is'' in honor of the large lizard.
SISLOWITZ--Nancy, on July 22, 2010. Beloved wife of Marcel. Devoted mother of Julie. Loving stepmother of Matthew. Service Monday, 3pm at "The Riverside," 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

BORETZ--Alvin, age 91, in New York City on July 22, 2010. Beloved husband of Lucille for 68 years. Loving father of Jennifer Kahnweiler (Bill), and Carrie Boretz Keating (Edward) and devoted grandfather to Lindsey Goldberg, Jessie Kahnweiler, and Caitlin and Emily Keating. A prolific writer for radio, television, stage and screen spanning five decades, his work first gained prominence during the Golden Age of Television on such shows as "Playhouse 90," "GE Theater," and "Armstrong Circle Theater." His subsequent scripts aired on such popular shows as "The Defenders," "Dr. Kildare," "Kojak" and "ABC Movie of the Week." He wrote the screenplay, "Brass Target," starring Sophia Loren, and the A&E original drama, "I Remember You." Boretz's play, "Made In America" premiered in 1984 at the Mark Taper Forum in Los Angeles. He won the Harcourt Brace Award for best television play in 1957 for "The Trial of Poznan" and numerous prizes for his prolific and diverse body of work, including over 1,000 television plays, many documentaries, and several hundred radio plays. Boretz served in the U.S. Army Air Corps during WWII, was Vice-President of the Writers Guild of America, and was President of the Hewlett-Woodmere Public Library. He was a man who never met a stranger. With his intense blue eyes and penetrating questions, people often bared their souls to him. He once said that, "My ideas come from everywhere and crowd each other out." Funeral services will be private.

MARCUS--Joyce Eisner. Beloved wife of Robert. Loving mom of Peter, Emily and Andrew. Adoring grandma of Jessie, Jimmy, Megan and Jenny. Devoted aunt and caring friend. Sister of the late Nancy Zankel. Sister-in-law of Stephen Marcus. A memorial will be held Friday July 23, 4-7pm at The Harmonie Club, 4 East 60th St., New York City.

GRANET--Lois of Verona, NJ. Loving mother of Dr. Vicki Semel, Gail Granet Velez and Dr. Roger Granet. Devoted grandmother of six and great-grandmother of five. Service private by the family. Contributions in her memory may be made to the Academy of Clinical and Applied Psychoanalysis, Livingston, NJ.

Buff Cobb, who with Mike Wallace, her husband at the time, hosted ''Mike and Buff,'' one of television's first talk shows, died on July 12 at a nursing home in Lebanon, N.H. She was 82. Her death was confirmed by her half brother, Thomas Cobb Brody.

An obituary on Thursday about Lt. Gen. Peter Walls, the last commander of white Rhodesian forces in what is now Zimbabwe, erroneously credited the country's president, Robert Mugabe, with a distinction. Mr. Mugabe is the second -- not the only -- president since the country achieved independence in 1980. (The Rev. Canaan Banana was president and Mr. Mugabe was prime minister from 1980 to 1987.)

An article last Friday about the trial of Rod R. Blagojevich, the former governor of Illinois, misspelled the surname of a defense lawyer. He is Ken Cunniff, not Cuniff. The article also misstated the role of Ronald S. Safer in the Conrad Black case. Mr. Safer, a former assistant United States attorney, was not the lead prosecutor in the Black case, he led the defense team of one of Mr. Black's co-defendants, Mark S. Kipnis.

An article on Thursday about a proposed settlement over price fixing by the electricity provider KeySpan misstated part of the name of an entity that filed comments objecting to the settlement. It is the New York State Consumer Protection Board, not the New York City Consumer Protection Board. (The city's consumer agency is the New York Department of Consumer Affairs.)

WILSON--Theodore. The Board and Staff of Abbott House mourn the loss of Ted Wilson: a wonderful family man, generous civic servant and a devoted member of the Abbott House Board for over 35 years. Ted leaves a legacy of selflessness and service. Our condolences to Tumika and his entire family. Claude B. Meyers, President and CEO, Joseph M. Pastore, Jr., Chairman of the Board.

ROSENBERG--Leon. Our dear and beloved friend, husband of Roberta, father of Galen and Carla, grandfather to Carson and Darby and a veteran, passed away on July 20, 2010. The son of hard-working parents Benjamin and Tanya. He became a Professor of Microbiology at Stanford University. Yok and Bebe Ziebel Perry and Gladys Rosenstein
MARCUS--Joyce. North Shore Country Club records with deep sorrow the passing of our esteemed member, Joyce Marcus. We extend our deepest condolences to her family.

On Morton Street in the West Village lives a small poodle nearly the same color as the pavement upon which he takes his seven-times daily constitutional. He may very well be the oldest dog on the planet. But he may not live long enough to wear his crown. According to a long string of people who have owned the little canine, he is at least 22 years old, possibly 24. The official holder of the title of oldest living dog, as recognized by the Guinness Book of World Records, is a mutt from Victoria, Australia, named Sako, born on Dec. 7, 1988 - a relative puppy at 21.

At the time, 1990 did not seem like a noteworthy year for baseball managers, but in retrospect it was a changing of the guard. At the start of 1990, Whitey Herzog and Tommy Lasorda were the deans of the National League managers and Sparky Anderson was starting his 13th season with the Detroit Tigers.

A music review on Monday about concerts at Tanglewood, including a performance of Mahler's Third Symphony by fellows of the Tanglewood Music Center, misidentified a text sung by the mezzo-soprano Karen Cargill in that symphony. It was the ''Midnight Song'' from Nietzsche's ''Also Sprach Zarathustra'' -- not ''Urlicht,'' which is from a 19th-century folk collection and is used in Mahler's Second Symphony.

Because of an editing error, an article on Wednesday about legal work that John L. Sampson, the New York State Senate leader, did for a Queens real estate broker who was being investigated for fraud misstated the law under which The New York Times requested documents about the broker. It is the state Freedom of Information Law, not the federal Freedom of Information Act.

LAWRENCE--A. Brewster Jr.,July 16, 1915 to July 16, 2010. Beloved husband and father. A gentle and wise man with a kind word and a smile for everyone. A man who felt at peace in his church. He loved tennis, border terriers, and Barbuda. During World War II, he served as Lieutenant Commander in the US Naval Reserve, mostly in India and Brazil. His 41 year career in the oil business with Caltex and Texaco took him all over the world, from Ceylon to Spain, Italy to Scandinavia, but he always returned to Smithtown, Long Island, where he was born. He is survived by his wife Nancy, children Lydie, Val, Bruce, Jeff, and Alec, five grandchildren, and one great-grandchild. A service will be held at 11am on Saturday, July 24 at the First Presbyterian Church of Smithtown. In lieu of flowers, donations in his memory can be sent to the Lawrence scholarship fund at the Frist Presbyterian Church of Smithtown, for the benefit of children at the church.

ROSENTHAL--Gary (1935-2010). Father, grandfather, husband, teacher, athlete, friend. Generous, wise, quick, very funny. A good man, indeed. The lives he brightened include his wife, Janet; children, Alan and Susan, Robert and Rita, Perri and Brett; grandchildren, Nolia and Lily; former wife, Lynne. In lieu of flowers, contribute to: Alan Rosenthal Research Fund, Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, 633 Third Ave., New York, NY 10017.

COSTER--Gerard H.,age 90, died Jacksonville, FL. Captain Retired US Navy. Member of Union and Ontora Club, New York. He leaves behind brother Charles MS Coster and four nephews. Service to be held August 7 at All Souls Church, Tannersville, NY.

One of the seminal works of Will Eisner, the comic book writer and artist, is headed for the big screen. "A Contract with God," a graphic novel composed of four interlocking stories set in the tenements of the Bronx during the Depression, will be written and produced by Darren Dean. The semi-autobiographical work originally had trouble finding a publisher, as Eisner, who died in 2005,  wrote in an essay for The New York Times Book Review in 1990: "It was, in format and style, as great a departure from the comic-book conventions as I could master. It was the story of one man's perception of his relationship with God. The book was rejected by the major publishing houses but was ultimately published in 1978 by a small, now defunct publisher, Baronet Books, which got it into establishment bookstores. It got no reviews, neither was it an instant commercial success. The response from adults who chanced on it, however, was warm and encouraging. I had, at last, connected with a serious adult audience. Ultimately it acquired a word-of-mouth following and remains in print to this day.

SUMMER is the time for travel, adventure -- and getting lost. Losing your way in the wilderness is one thing. Even without a compass, experienced hikers can figure out where they are by following nature's signs indicating north, south, east or west -- the direction of the wind, for example, or tell-tale marks on rocks and trees that show prevailing wind patterns. But people get lost in strange cities, too. And while this is rarely as dangerous as it is in the wilderness, it can still be an inconvenience. Fortunately, the same skills that have allowed adventurers to find their way into and out of the woods for centuries can also help a wayward traveler tame an unfamiliar town. The ancient art of natural navigation is the opposite of using GPS: it is slow and imprecise. But it can also be hugely enjoyable.

Were it not for the large man seated on a folding chair on Thursday night outside a nondescript door in East Williamsburg, Brooklyn, it would have been difficult to tell that the building behind him hosted anything at all, let alone the House of Yes, a school and performance space for acrobats and aerialists. But through the door was a world usually relegated to circus tents. Inside, at 9 p.m., an audience of more than 50 awaited a show of spangled dancers and strong men, lithe contortionists and aerial artists whose medium was the bolts of silk that hung from the 30-foot ceiling.

(Cinemax) (500) DAYS OF SUMMER (2009) Tom Hansen (Joseph Gordon-Levitt, above, with Zooey Deschanel) is an ''unapologetic believer in true love, soul mates and other touchstones of greeting card mythology (and romantic comedy ideology),'' A.O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. Summer Finn (Ms. Deschanel), he said, is ''skeptical of such notions and refuses to promise commitment or even consistency, but she does seem to want more and more of Tom's company, and this leads him to believe that her carefully maintained barriers to intimacy are beginning to fall.'' That pretty much sums up the romance between these two seemingly made-for-each-other semi-hipsters, whose breakup is told in scrambled chronology, with the occasional musical number. Mr. Scott went on to describe this film from Marc Webb, who directed music videos for Miley Cyrus and My Chemical Romance, as a ''shimmering soap bubble,'' a movie ''that is, for the most part, as mopily, winningly seductive as the Regina Spektor songs on the soundtrack and at its best as unexpectedly lovely as the views of Los Angeles captured by Mr. Webb and his director of photography, Eric Steelberg.'' 10 A.M. In an influential article in the Annual Review of Neuroscience, Joshua Gold of the University of Pennsylvania and Michael Shadlen of the University of Washington sum up experiments aimed at discovering the neural basis of decision-making. In one set of experiments, researchers attached sensors to the parts of monkeys' brains responsible for visual pattern recognition. The monkeys were then taught to respond to a cue by choosing to look at one of two patterns. Computers reading the sensors were able to register the decision a fraction of a second before the monkeys' eyes turned to the pattern. As the monkeys were not deliberating, but rather reacting to visual stimuli, researchers were able to plausibly claim that the computer could successfully predict the monkeys' reaction. In other words, the computer was reading the monkeys' minds and knew before they did what their decision would be.

It's no secret that Mumbai, with its economic might and reputation as "the city of dreams," attracts migrants and transplants from all over India. Among this crowd, there's a sizable contingent of Bengalis, homesick for the kabobs and biryanis of Calcutta. Luckily for them -- and for food-curious visitors -- the quickly expanding chain Hangla's (Bengali for "glutton") is making Calcutta-style street food increasingly available, particularly across the city's northern suburbs.

To the Sports Editor: The death of Ralph Houk may remind some Mets fans of the kind of manager the team probably needs right now. Houk was a disciplinarian who wouldn't take any nonsense. A player who had to work hard and hustle just to stay in the big leagues, Houk had no patience for prima donnas who gave less than 100 percent.

As Cathy Lilly folded into downward dog at a workshop in January, a novice instructor, eager to help, lifted Ms. Lilly's thumbs and angled them forward. Her thumbs are still recovering from the strain. Ms. Lilly, 53, a yoga teacher with more than two decades on the mat, also once injured her rotator cuff jumping distractedly into plank pose. And after another instructor suggested she kiss her knee while in heron pose, her hamstring suffered the consequences.

9 P.M. (National Geographic) CLASH OF THE CONTINENTS The scenario: an astronaut passes through a space-time warp that returns him to Earth after 250 million years, above. What would he see? This new series consults with experts about the past so as to better predict the future, including the natural forces that could put an end to human civilization and bring Earth full circle. The journey begins as scientists imagine a brave new world in the form of a supercontinent created by the planet's land masses moving into a new position. At 10, the scientists speculate on whether our species will evolve -- or self-destruct. 10 A.M. (Fox) FOX NEWS SUNDAY WITH CHRIS WALLACE The Rev. Jesse Jackson discusses the forced resignation of Shirley Sherrod from the Department of Agriculture and its effect on race relations in America. The debate continues at 10:30 on CBS and ''Face the Nation'' with Abigail Thernstrom, vice chairwoman of the United States Commission on Civil Rights; Michael Eric Dyson, the Georgetown University sociologist; and Cornel West, the Princeton University professor.

ALEXANDER--Margaret P.,affectionately known as Peggy, died on June 25th 2010 in Summit NJ surrounded by her family. She was 69 years old. She leaves behind husband Peter A. Alexander, daughter Corinne E.N. Alexander, son Marc E.D. Alexander, and brother Ben Powell. Peggy was born on July 25th 1940 in Philadelphia to Gladys Williams and Hickman Powell. She was raised in Tinicum township PA on a farm that is still in the family. She attended Solebury for high school and graduated from Penn State with a degree in social work, and earned a Master's in Social Work from Fordham University. Peggy and Peter married in 1968. They then set off on a forty-two year adventure living in Paris, Jakarta, Tokyo, Summit NJ, and London. Peggy kept the family grounded and created a home during each of the moves and stays. She had an appreciation and fascination with foreign cultures, learning the languages and customs of each country. Peggy was also active in the American Association of University Women, Summit NJ chapter, serving as Membership Chair, Secretary and Co-Chair the Reader's Book Club. She will be missed and her memories will live on with her family and loved ones.
