The fedora popped up two years ago and is now seen everywhere, from the beaches of Fire Island Pines, bottom row, to Manhattan. Most of the hats are straw, bought from pushcart vendors for under $20. Occasionally an authentic man's Panama hat goes by on a stylish woman; these can cost hundreds of dollars. On young men, the fedora is an alternative to the baseball cap, often worn backward, sideways and bashed in, as though the cat had slept on it, left and right. The hat is most appealing worn at a rakish tilt or with a jauntiness one might see in a Reginald Marsh painting.

ADLER--Deirdre S.,died peacefully on July 23 at age 86 after a short illness. A native New Yorker, Deirdre was the first professional development officer at The Chapin School in the early nineteen seventies. Following executive positions at City Center and the Musicians Emergency Fund, Deirdre and her second husband, Julius Ochs Adler (who died in 2003), founded the Canterbury Bookshop, which they operated for seventeen years. She volunteered for many years at Lenox Hill Hospital, Memorial Sloan Kettering, and Chapin, the latter as an alumna and trustee. Deirdre's first husband was the late Osborn Elliott. She is survived by daughters Diana Elliott Lidofsky, Cynthia Elliott, and Dorinda Elliott and their spouses, as well as step-children Douglas Adler, Anne Adler Tarbell, and Mary Adler Malhotra and their spouses, plus thirteen grandchildren and one great-grandson. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made in her memory to Lenox Hill Hospital or The Chapin School.

To the Editor: Regarding ''Creating Sabbath Peace Amid the Noise'' (Sunday Styles, July 18), my wife, our sons and I have the extraordinary good fortune of living in the same small town with the rest of my wife's family. For more than 30 years, we would all gather at my mother-in-law's house every Friday night for Sabbath dinner. It was a warm, golden time I looked forward to every week, filled with hugs, love and laughter as 15 of us stopped to catch our breath at the end of a busy work week. The adults would share their latest news, the cousins would play and my mother-in-law would love/hate the chaos that she tried in vain to control for yet another week. My mother-in-law is gone now, all of our children are grown, many with families of their own, and Sabbath dinners for my wife and I are more often than not quiet affairs. But the memories of those dinners are mine to cherish forever. I thank Judith Shulevitz for her article and urge her readers to create their own Sabbath memories. Steven Pell

As recently as five years ago, ramshackle buildings and empty storefronts in downtown Napa, Calif., prompted some residents to refer to the neighborhood west of Main Street as the Dead End. Today, thanks to the new AVIA Napa boutique hotel, thriving restaurants and tasting rooms and the much-heralded reopening of a classic Art Deco theater, a roughly six-square-block area has re-established itself as the West End, a moniker that invokes London and other great cities around the world. The transformation marks a bold new chapter for downtown Napa; once a drive-by town that visitors would pass on their way from San Francisco and Oakland to wineries elsewhere in the valley, the county seat is now a destination unto itself. MATT VILLANO CEJA VINEYARDS 1248 First Street (707) 255-3954 cejavineyards.com Of course, a trip to Napa wouldn't be complete without a visit to a tasting room, but Ceja offers more than vino at its Wine Tasting Salon, Lounge and Art Gallery. Saturday nights are particularly lively, as servers pour glasses during happy hour (5:30 to 7:30 p.m.), and the owner's son, Ariel Ceja, gives free salsa-dancing lessons at 7:30 (beginners) and 8:30 (intermediate).

If hotel pools aren't enough to cool you down, there's a less crowded alternative for travelers to New York City: outdoor showers. Gansevoort Park, which is scheduled to open 140 of its 249 rooms in early August, will debut a tri-level rooftop lounge on opening day. There, hotel patrons and members of the general public who get overheated will be able to rinse off in a shower that sprays from the floor up.

For more than a decade, Michael Schumacher drove like a metronome, stacking up 91 Formula One victories and seven world titles. No other driver had ever achieved anything like it. But like so many record-breaking sportsmen, Schumacher came across looking like a cold, calculating, ruthless, armor-skinned robot -- with more than a dash of arrogance. So bored and disgusted did many fans of auto racing become with Schumacher's domination that they greeted the German's retirement at the end of 2006 with a sigh of relief. So when at the age of 41 and after three years away from the sport he announced that he would return this year to drive for the Mercedes team -- which bought the reigning champion Brawn team -- many fans said, ''Oh no, not again!''

If you can't quite afford to live like a royal, this is your best chance to at least drive like one. RM Auctions is scheduled to sell a 1984 Daimler Double Six long-wheelbase sedan formerly owned by Queen Elizabeth II. The sale will be held during the annual Sports and Classics of Monterey auction held from Aug. 12-14 in California. The car has 41,000 miles on the odometer, with 12,000 accumulated by the queen during her time behind the wheel. She used the car extensively for trips throughout London, for travel at Windsor and other royal residences, and trips to church on Sunday mornings.

A voyage to Antarctica, a bucket-list trip for many, often requires a five-figure budget. But the travel industry's downturn has forged at least one short-but-sweet deal on departures to the southernmost continent. The expedition cruise specialist AdventureSmith Explorations recently added 11-day sailings to Antarctica on the 124-passenger Expedition starting at $2,795 a person, triple occupancy, a roughly 35 percent savings on standard rates.

HOLDERNESS--Algernon Sidney, Jr.,died of a sudden heart attack on Sunday evening, July 11, 2010 at his home in Bellaire, Texas. A funeral was held at the Oakland Cemetery in Fordyce, Arkansas on Saturday, July 17. He is survived by his loving daughters Claire Crockett Holderness of Brooklyn, New York and Julia Simms Holderness of Cambridge, Massachusetts, and by his grandson Soroush Crockett Vakhshoori, also of Cambridge. He is remembered by his cousin George Malcolm Holderness, of New York, New York. He was preceded in death by his parents, Algernon Sidney Holderness, Sr. and Mary Elizabeth Crockett Holderness of Radnor, Pennsylvania. He was the great-great-great-grandson of the frontiersman David "Davy" Crockett. Born in Wilmington, Delaware on March 31, 1938, Mr. Holderness spent his childhood and early youth in Providence, Rhode Island; Bellaire, Texas; Kansas City, Missouri; and Radnor, Pennsylvania. A lifelong Yale man, he received his BA in History magna cum laude, Phi Beta Kappa, from Yale College in 1959 and his L.L.B. cum laude, Order of the Coif, in 1962 from Yale Law School, where he was a member of the Board of Editors of the Yale Law Journal. He garnered a prestigious federal clerkship under Judge Thomas W. Swan of the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit. Mr. Holderness subsequently specialized in private financing, practicing for many years as a partner at Milbank, Tweed, Hadley & McCloy in New York, and later as a partner at AndrewsKurth LLP, first in New York, and then in Houston. At the time of his death, he was Of Counsel to AndrewsKurth. He was an active member of the American Bar Association, the TriBar Association, the American Law Institute, and the American College of Investment Counsel, which he served as President. His intellectual passion for the law translated into editorial work for publications by the American Bar Association and Tribar Association, and into publications of his own, most notably a Legal Opinion Letters Formbook, co-authored with Brooke Wunnicke, now about to appear in its third edition. In more recent years, he took up teaching as an Adjunct Professor at the South Texas College of Law. Of his work there, one student wrote, "When Professor Holderness talks, I listen." Mr. Holderness devoted what free time he had to his family and public service. He served on the boards of the Brooklyn Heights Association and the Girl Scout Council of Greater New York, and the New York and national boards of the YMCA. After returning to Texas in his later years, he focused his efforts on serving the Presbyterian Church. He was a church Elder, a Stephen Minister, and Clerk of Session. Music was another lifelong passion, especially choral music: he sang bass in the Yale Glee Club, and was an active participant in productions of the Blue Hill Troupe, a Gilbert and Sullivan Society in New York, the annual holiday musicals at Milbank, Tweed, and his church choir in Bellaire. Mr. Holderness was a brilliant man who set high standards for himself and expected the same of those around him. At the same time he had a tremendous sense of humor and took delight in life's absurdities. He literally could not stop moving - he was happiest when he was doing two or three things at a time. At his fiftieth college reunion he looked forward not only to reconnecting with his oldest friends, but to making new friends as well. Had he not experienced physical difficulty in his final weeks, he would have attended his fifty-fifth high school reunion as well, in Kansas City. His zest for life was strong until the end; his final day began with church and ended with a fine dinner. A memorial service will be held on Saturday, August 14 at two o'clock at ChristChurch Presbyterian, 5000 Bellaire Avenue, Bellaire TX. All are welcome. In lieu of flowers, please consider a contribution in his memory to Houston Public Radio, kuhf.org: (713) 743-8443.

The Political Times column last Sunday, about a generational divide over racial attitudes, erroneously linked one example of a racially charged statement to the Tea Party movement. While Tea Party supporters have been connected to a number of such statements, there is no evidence that epithets reportedly directed in March at Representative John Lewis, Democrat of Georgia, outside the Capitol, came from Tea Party members.

An article on July 11 about two brokerages that are using video as a marketing tool misidentified the producers of Halstead Property's videos of listings and market reports. They are produced by Halstead and FlashFrame Productions, an outside vendor -- not by WellcomeMat, which provided technical support for the videos.

SPENCER--Stephen, age 85, of Chastellux Avenue, Newport, RI, formerly of New York, NY, passed away July 21, 2010 surrounded by his family. Born in New York, NY, on April 22, 1925, he was the son of the late Katherine (Force) and Lorillard Spencer. His father was a highly decorated World War I veteran. Mr. Spencer attended the Buckley School in NY, St. Paul's School in NH, and graduated from Harvard in 1947. Mr. Spencer was the President and owner of London Towncars, a chauffeured limousine service based in New York City, which he started in 1959 with a bag of dimes for the parking meters and two London taxis. At his retirement in 2004 the company had a fleet of over 80 vehicles. At the age of 16, he earned his pilot's license before getting his driver's license and flew all around New England. In the 50s, Mr. Spencer ran the ticket office for Eastern Airlines, in Brooklyn, NY. Mr. Spencer also served as a Lieutenant. J. G. in the Navy during World War II. He was a Governor of Bailey's Beach, and Treasurer and Master of Holland Lodge, NY. Mr. Spencer had a passion for gardening around his home in Newport. Mr. Spencer leaves behind his wife of 53 years, Marjorie, a daughter Vivian Spencer Fleuette and her husband Michel, a son Stephen Lorillard Spencer and his wife Irena, and three grandchildren, Andrea S. Ahern, Ian G. Ahern and Olivia M. Ahern, and his brother William H.F. Spencer.Services will be held at 11am on Thursday, July 29, 2010 at Emmanuel Church, 40 Dearborn Street, Newport, Rhode Island. Visiting hours are respectfully omitted. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the Alzheimer's Association, P.O. Box 96011, Washington, DC 20090 and/or the Robert Potter League for Animals, P.O. Box 412, Newport, RI 02840. For more information visit www.onhfh.com

WORN until they turned gray, Nantucket rope bracelets were, for many, a symbol of summer well spent, snipped off come the new school year to expose a superb tan line. Now Roarke, a year-old jewelry label started by Laetitia Stanfield, a former Bergdorf Goodman buyer, and Mignonne Gavigan, once a designer for Marc Jacobs and Asprey, has introduced a decidedly grown-up version. Made from chiffon and woven with leather, chain and mesh, the bracelets come in a variety of colors and look rather sophisticated stacked high. Additionally, a snap closure means you don't have to wait until Labor Day to take them off. Roarke braided bracelets, $60 at Kirna Zabête, 96 Greene Street; and roarkenyc.com.

The board, staff, volunteers, children, adults and families of United Cerebral Palsy of New York City note with sorrow the passing of Norm Chandler Fox, Significant Other of Loreen Arbus. Loreen created UCP/NYC's signature event, Women Who Care, which celebrates the accomplishments of women as caregivers, volunteers and professionals, and has served tirelessly for the past ten years as its Founder and Chair. In so doing, she continues the more than 60 year legacy of her parents, Leonard H. and Isabelle Goldenson, both founders of UCP, and celebrates the memory of her sister Cookie. We extend our deepest sympathy to Loreen, her family and friends. Edward R. Matthews, CEO UCP of New York City

SCHORR--Daniel. The CUNY Graduate School of Journalism offers its condolences to the family and friends of Daniel Schorr. He was a friend and role model for our faculty and students. A son of the Bronx and a graduate of the City College of New York, Dan was one of the first to establish a scholarship fund to support our diverse student body. A veteran newsman, Dan truly cared about the future of journalism. We are grateful for his friendship and will miss him dearly. Stephen B. Shepard, Founding Dean

Three decades after the Supreme Court ruled that immigration violations cannot be used as a basis to deny children equal access to a public school education, one in five school districts in New York State is routinely requiring a child's immigration papers as a prerequisite to enrollment, or asking parents for information that only lawful immigrants can provide. The New York Civil Liberties Union, which culled a list of 139 such districts from hundreds of registration forms and instructions posted online, has not found any children turned away for lack of immigration paperwork. But it warned in a letter to the state's education commissioner on Wednesday that the requirements listed by many registrars, however free of discriminatory intent, ''will inevitably discourage families from enrolling in school for fear that they would be reported to federal immigration authorities.'' [NYT]
Theater Jason Zinoman

For the first time in more than four years, Libya is granting tourist visas to American citizens. There is one caveat: travelers must apply through a handful of Libya-approved tour operators. Jerry Sorkin, the president of one such company, TunisUSA, said that the United States Embassy in Tripoli told him a few weeks ago that he was the first to be granted a visa under the new system, allowing him to take tourists to the country. ''As Libya is essentially governed by one person, decisions frequently come without warning,'' he said. ''In the case of the visas, the change that resulted in the new policy was based on a real change'' (the United States Embassy opened a visa office in Libya last year for the first time since 1980).

KAPLAN--Sandra, MD. The Combined Department of Psychiatry at North Shore University Hospital at Manhasset, NY and Long Island Jewish Medical Center deeply mourn the loss of our esteemed senior colleague. Her 33 year tenure at North Shore included serving as Director of the Division of Child and Adolescent Psychiatry (for 25 years), Vice Chairperson, and most currently as Director of Trauma Psychiatry. In addition, Dr. Kaplan was Professor of Psychiatry at NYU School of Medicine. A nationally-recognized, award-winning pioneer, leader and research contributor in family violence and trauma treatment and prevention, Dr. Kaplan was actively engaged in a unique child abuse treatment program with the Nassau County Department of Social Services. As Program Director of the local initiative of the National Child Traumatic Stress Network (of the US Department of Health's Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration (SAMHSA), Dr. Kaplan's was an important voice in the national dialogue advocating for vulnerable children. A dedicated clinician and beloved friend to her many colleagues and students. Heartfelt condolences to her son, Lawrence. John M. Kane, MD Chairman, Department of Psychiatry; Victor Fornari, MD, Director, Division of Child & Adolescent Psychiatry
Television Mike Hale

BLAME the 90-degree heat, but the notion of wearing skinny jeans right now seems about as appealing as street meat. Fortunately, and rather remarkably on cue, looser, wider trousers are popping up all over the place -- on chic girls around town, on Carine Roitfeld (left) at the couture shows, on the racks at Bergdorf Goodman. Not that the breezy look is solely a summer thing. For fall, a slew of designers sent wide-leg trousers down the runway: At Marc Jacobs, 1970s-style pantsuits hinted of Annie Hall; at Emilio Pucci, it was a more louche version, paired with lots of leather; Chloé's high-waist camel-colored pants exuded a very Charlie girl vibe; and for his debut collection, Reed Krakoff reimagined American sportswear with double-wide pairs that swooshed around the leg with all the ease and elegance of an evening gown.

ELLIOTT--Glenn. On behalf of Thomson Reuters and all its staff, we send our heartfelt condolences and send our deepest sympathies to Cheryl, Brooke, Alana and the entire Elliott family. Glenn made a great contribution to our company, leading our real estate organization from New York City for many years.

BRANCA--Honorable John R.,86, of Deerfield Beach, FL passed away on July 17, 2010. Branca served as the Mt. Vernon, NY Recreation Commissioner from 1962-1981, New York State Assemblyman from 1980-1984, and thereafter Chairman of the New York State Athletic Commission. A star pitcher for AB Davis High School in Mt. Vernon, he was undefeated during his high school varsity career and pitched two no-hitters. In his senior year, he was named the New York State Player of the Year, and lead AB Davis to the New York State Championship. He served in the U.S. Air Force during WWII, and also played ball where he again pitched a no-hitter. He received his undergraduate and master's degrees from New York University, and before becoming Recreation Commissioner, he served as a teacher and coach at Mt. Vernon Edison High School. As Recreation Commissioner, his recreation programs, and his programs specially designed for the handicapped, the disabled, and the elderly, were innovative and were cited by President Kennedy as a model for other communities. As New York State Athletic Commissioner, he brought championship boxing back to Madison Square Garden and instituted national reforms. He is the older brother of Brooklyn Dodger pitcher Ralph Branca. He is survived by his wife, Mildred, and children, John G. Branca, William J. Branca, and Angela Guerra. His son, John Branca, a prominent entertainment attorney, serves as Co-Executor of the Michael Jackson Estate. He is survived by grandchildren, Jessica, Katherine, John Connor, and Dylan Branca. Entombment will take place in Boca Raton, FL, and a memorial service will be held at Forest Lawn, Glendale, CA.

BUCK ELLISON'S new line of linen towels manages to improve on the already perfect concept of sunbathing. Made in India, this chic summer accessory dries quickly, won't stick to sand and can be thrown in the wash. It also doubles as a handsome sarong, tablecloth or bedspread, said Mr. Ellison, a photographer who, inspired by a 1930s image of Belgian soldiers bathing in the Meuse River, made one for a camping trip a couple of years ago. After receiving compliments from friends, he turned it into a business, introducing the first collection in May. Two weeks later, all nine styles, which include Southwestern stripes and a mattress ticking print, had sold out. ''They're filling a niche,'' he said. Albeit not until Aug. 1, when the next delivery arrives.

MIKOLAJCZAK--Boleslaw, PhD, 64, of Dartmouth, died July 22, 2010. Professor Mikolajczak was born June 30, 1946 in Poznan, Poland to Maria and Walenty Mikolajczak. He received an MS in Mathematics from Adam Mickiewich University in 1972 and in 1974 a PhD in Computer Science from the University of Technology in Poznan. Prof. Mikolajczak was a faculty member of the Computer Science Department in the College of Engineering at the University of Massachusetts, Dartmouth from 1986 until his death and chaired that department from 1995 until 2010. In addition, he taught as a Visiting Professor of Computer Science at the University of Dresdent, Germany and Cornell University in Ithaca, New York. He was a recipient of numerous awards and honors for his research and publications in the field of computer science, including an honor from the Polish Academy of Sciences. Prof. Mikolajczak is survived by his wife Urszula, sons Maciej and Wojciech, daughter-in-law Marija and grandson Jordan. Relatives and friends are invited to visiting hours on Monday, July 26, 2010 from 5-8pm in the Waring-Sullivan Home of Memorial Tribute at Dartmouth, 230 Russells Mills Rd., Dartmouth. His Funeral Mass will be held on Tuesday, July 27, 2010 at 10am in St. Julie Billiart Church, 494 Slocum Rd., Dartmouth. Burial will be in South Dartmouth Cemetery. Donations in his memory may be made to UMDF/Mikolajczak Fund, Care of University of Massachusetts Foundation Office. For online registration and facility directions visit: dartmouthfuneralhome.com

Fashion designers have been somewhat slow to embrace the more commercial elements of modern technology, like selling their clothes online or on mobile devices, perhaps hesitant about sullying their brands. Social media, however, they seem to have caught on to right away. ''I've bitten the apple, I've drunk the Kool-Aid, I am so addicted,'' said Norma Kamali, one of the few designers who can boast having had a Web site as far back as the mid-1990s, when most of us were still adapting to the concept of e-mail. ''I am the first online to get all this stuff.''

KAPLAN--Sandra, of Manhattan, died at Sloan Kettering on July 23, 2010. Pediatrician, child psychiatrist, forensic psychiatrist, and, most of all, beloved mother. For nearly 30 years, Dr. Kaplan oversaw the clinical, teaching and research efforts of the Division of Child and Adolescent Psychiatry at the North Shore-Long Island Jewish Health System University Hospital. Mostly recently, she became Director of the Division of Trauma psychiatry, caring for Iraq veterans and family members of 9/11 victims. She was also Professor of Psychiatry at New York University School of Medicine, the recipient of numerous awards and fellowships and editor or author of books and articles that made her one of the first in her field to explore the psychiatric elements of child abuse. Dr. Kaplan was a graduate of the Temple University School of Medicine and fellow at Children's Hospital of Washington, DC. She was the walking embodiment of kindness, loyalty and compassion, a vibrant and truly special person. She is survived by a son, Lawrence, two beloved nephews, Ivan and Noah, and more friends than we can count. Services Sunday July 25, 11.30am at Plaza Memorial Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue.

The five most e-mailed articles from nytimes.com/sports for July 17 to 23. 1. A SURFING ICON EMBRACES A MELLOWER WAVE Gerry Lopez glides along an Oregon river on a stand-up paddleboard, a surfing experience that has expanded the sport's reach to unlikely places and populations. (Published July 19)

JEAN-MICHEL BASQUIAT'S sense of style, much like his work, was wild, colorful, oddly elegant and entirely unique: secondhand flight suits worn with a shaved blond mohawk; Adidas sweatshirts sported under natty pinstriped jackets; loose white shirts paired with suspenders and a silk scarf; and Armani suits, paint-splattered from his work. ''He came up with looks that no one else had seen before, and he had such charisma and held his head so high that he carried them off,'' said Tamra Davis, a filmmaker and close friend of the artist, whose new documentary, ''The Radiant Child,'' includes never-before-seen footage of him. For instance, in the opening scene, Basquiat is shown in his studio, a friend's dog yanking hard on his sweater sleeve.

A couple of months ago, I downloaded CabSense, a new iPhone app that identifies the best corners in New York City to catch a cab. Now I just need an app that helps me avoid being intercepted by transit bandits. I'm referring to those catlike creatures who will snatch your rightfully earned taxi out from under your outstretched arm. One moment, you're this close to opening that yellow door. You can practically feel the leather seats under your backside, hear the deafening sounds of an ''Eyewitness News'' briefing, when - boom! - there you are, standing in a cloud of exhaust, another helpless, cabless loser.

THE NEWS BP and the government decided to leave the cap closed on the company's stricken oil well on the Gulf of Mexico's floor, preventing any oil or gas from escaping the well. BEHIND THE NEWS Initially, the cap's valves were closed as a test to see if the well was intact below the sea floor, and the plan was to reopen them afterward to relieve the pressure, with escaping oil collected at the surface. Methane gas was found seeping up two miles away, but scientists concluded it was a natural occurrence. With the well apparently holding tight under the pressure, Thad W. Allen, the retired Coast Guard admiral in charge of the federal response, approved keeping the cap closed.

ALERT: While this week of ''Mad Men'' posts endeavors to remain spoiler-free, this one is informed by a close advance viewing of the episode to be broadcast Sunday. It describes New York City locations mentioned in the episode and, in doing so, gives away only the most benign plot points, like the location of the main characters' new office. Nonetheless, if you want to go into Sunday's episode knowing absolutely nothing in advance, save this post until next week. In the months following their inauspicious debut in a suite at the Pierre Hotel at the end of Season 3, the principals of Sterling Cooper Draper Pryce, who got the name ''Mad Men'' from their former Madison Avenue headquarters, have decamped to offices in the Time & Life Building at 1271 Avenue of the Americas -- Sixth Avenue -- between West 50th and 51st Streets. It is the perfect location for an upstart firm nurturing an image of being cutting edge.

TORRANCE, Calif. -- Honda's program on the FCX Clarity hydrogen fuel cell vehicle marks the two-year anniversary on Sunday of delivery of the first cars to retail customers. The FCX program, however, has been a bit slower to ramp up than originally envisioned, when it was announced in 2008. Honda had said it planned to place up to 200 of the vehicles, with customers in the United States paying $600 a month on a three-year lease. The lease payment becomes more palatable when one considers that it also covers insurance for collision-related claims, maintenance, roadside assistance and all the hydrogen fuel the car can use.

Q.My wife and I (both senior citizens) would like to spend a week or so in Crete. We don't want to rent a car, so we will be dependent on buses or taxis. Can you provide information on excursions to major tourist attractions? Fredrick Waring, Ramsey, N.J.A.Crete, the largest of the Greek islands, is home to ancient Minoan and Venetian sites (Crete was once ruled by Venice, later by the Ottomans) not to mention endless beaches, magnificent mountains, caves and traditional villages. From Athens, take a 50-minute flight to the capital, Iraklion (or Heraklion), a seaport on the Mediterranean and a good base for reaching major sites and museums on foot, by bus or by taxi. Convenient lodgings include the Atlantis (theatlantishotel.gr), a luxurious hotel with a pool in the center of Iraklion, and the smaller Lato Boutique Hotel (lato.gr). Both are within walking distance of the Archaeological Museum and the city's central bus station.

BARAD--Vera J.,74, who practiced psychotherapy in Boston and Cambridge, Massachusetts, for over 30 years, died of brain cancer on July 22 at her home in Mill Valley, CA. Her strength, wit, vivaciousness, beautiful green eyes, delicious cooking and generous heart will be missed tremendously by her family and many friends. Born in New York City in 1936, Ms. Barad was the daughter of Lillian Symansky Barad and Emil Barad. She was a graduate of Mount Holyoke College and received a Master's degree in social work at Boston University in 1959. Ms. Barad and her late husband, Edward B. Marks, maintained homes in Cambridge and in New York City, were periodic residents of Martha's Vineyard, and traveled widely. In 2001, Ms. Barad and Mr. Marks moved to Mill Valley, CA, to be closer to her family. They shared a joyful life together until Mr. Marks' death in 2005. In California, she was a busy grandma, a prolific knitter and landscape painter, a member of a local hiking group. She continued to travel and enjoy cultural events with her friend Peter Smith. Ms. Barad is survived by her three children, Amelia Barad of St. Helena, CA, Vivian Barad of San Francisco, CA, and Michael Barad of San Carlos, CA; by her devoted friend Peter Smith of Edmonton, Canada; and by her brother Edward Barad of Los Angeles. She was the mother-in-law to Todd Humphries, Jason Thompson and Katie Barad. She was the step-mother of the late Thomas Marks, Lucky Marks and Katherine Marks. She was the loving grandmother of Jethro, Paolo, David, Theo and Vincent Marks, Desmond and Wyatt Humphries, Esther and Moss Barad Thompson, Calvin and Nathaniel Barad. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to the United States Committee for Refugees and Immigrants, 2231 Crystal Drive, Suite 350, Arlington, VA 2202-3711 www.refugees.org

A number of responses to my column on Christian Legal Society v. Martinez - a Supreme Court decision upholding Hastings Law School's right to withhold official recognition from a Christian group that restricted its membership to co-believers who not only talked the talk but walked the walk - complain that there is too much parsing of minutiae and counting of angels dancing on the head of a pin and not enough consideration of the big substantive issues at stake, issues like discrimination against gays and the separation of church and state.

Over a five-decade career, Dennis Hopper earned the well-deserved mantle of the rebellious auteur, actor and all-around American artist. Whether it was post-Depression-era angst, the Beat generation's age of exploration, Vietnam War resistance or 1980s venomous debauchery, Hopper's performances reflected the shifting psyche of America's cultural landscape. On screen he appeared unafraid, even fiercely entrenched in the zeitgeist. Now the late actor's art, much of which is unknown to a large public, is the focus of an exhibition at the Museum of Contemporary Art in Los Angeles entitled "Dennis Hopper Double Standard."

Don't forget the authors. Last week it was the big book publisher and the big literary agent who sparred over who gets to make e-books out of titles that were published before there were such things. Now the Authors Guild has weighed in - with an eye on digital royalty rates for the writers it represents. In a letter to its members on Monday, the Guild said that publishers were largely to blame for the dispute between Random House and the literary agent Andrew Wylie, which came to a head last week when Mr. Wylie announced that he would begin his own venture to sell e-book rights for older books directly to Amazon, bypassing traditional publishers that already released the books in print and have staked a claim to the e-book rights as well. Random House responded on Thursday by saying it would not do business with the Wylie Agency until the situation was resolved.

"Mass unhappiness and mass loneliness triggered the rise of the caring industry. Indeed, it is why the caring industry began its exponential growth during the conservative 1950s rather than in the liberal 1960s ... To some degree the caring industry had no choice but to intervene. The mental health crisis and mass loneliness were revolutionary events that spawned real turmoil. People found themselves with more emotional problems than ever, and no one to talk to. It was an intolerable situation. Thus, the creation of the caring ethos, the caring industry, and the thousands of caring professionals who define it. Forty years ago, in his now-classic book The Triumph of the Therapeutic, sociologist Philip Rieff sensed that a great change had come over the West. A 'therapeutic culture' grounded in psychotherapy, he wrote, had replaced the 'ethos' of traditional society ... What Rieff had observed were the first stirrings of a new social order, one that would rest on a nation-spanning network of caring professionals. Today, countless institutions and millions of people are dependent to one degree or another on the caring industry. Therapy is no longer just a 'culture.' In the form of professional caring, it has become our way of life."

Merce Cunningham's "Xover," which includes a seven-and-a-half minute duet that was one of the longest he composed in his career, will make its New York debut as part of New York City Center's 2010 Fall for Dance Festival, City Center said Monday. The work, whose title is pronounced "crossover" and which was first presented at Dartmouth College in 2007, will be performed by the Merce Cunningham Dance Company as part of the first of five festival programs, on Sept. 28 and 29, and will feature music by John Cage and scenery by Robert Rauschenberg. Other highlights of the festival, which runs through Oct. 9, include a new work by the classical Indian dancer and choreographer Madhavi Mudgal, called "Vistaar," with music by her brother, Madhup Mudgal; the festival debuts of 10 international troupes including Company Rafaela Carrasco of Spain,  Shu-Yi & (Dancers) Company of Taiwan and Tero Saarinen Company of Finland; and the premiere of "Peace of Mind: The Remix," a collaboration between the tap dancer and choreographer Jason Samuels Smith and the hip-hop dancer Mr. Wiggles, performed by Jason Samuels Smith & Friends.

The 20th century ended on Friday, at least in relation to the discourse over what to do about global warming. The end came with the failure of a seven-year effort in the Senate to pass a climate bill centered on a cap-and-trade system for reducing emissions of greenhouse gases. Such a system had worked effectively for easily measured, and mitigated, emissions of conventional pollutants from power plants and other industrial sources. But carbon dioxide, the most important human-generated greenhouse gas, poses an entirely different set of challenges.

SWINSKY--Morton. Pioneering bond trader, art collector and multiple Tony Award-winning Broadway producer - died June 19, of prostate cancer. He was 75. Swinsky produced numerous plays and musicals, beginning with 'Eubie' and including hits such as 'Spamalot,' 'Spring Awakening,' David Mamet's 'Race,' 'Guys and Dolls' (Tony), 'Chicago' (Tony), 'Annie Get Your Gun' (Tony),'The Music Man,' 'The Who's Tommy,' 'Hamlet,' 'How to Succeed in Business Without Really Trying,' 'Grey Gardens,' 'Jersey Boys' (Tony), 'A View From the Bridge,' 'Hairspray' (Tony), 'The History Boys,' 'Billy Elliot' (Tony) and, most recently, 'Fela!,' and 'The Addams Family.' Swinsky was the recipient of film and television awards (AFI, Emmy) for 'You Can Count On Me,' 'Boys Don't Cry' and the concert version of 'Sweeney Todd.' With all these successes, Mort seemed devoid of ego and hubris. Backing a quality play or musical is what brought him pleasure. That and collecting art. Recognized by The National Sculpture Society, Swinsky was a patron to artists mostly in the Figurative Arts. Born to immigrant parents of Russian Jewish descent, Swinsky was raised in the Inwood section of Manhattan. While at City College night school, where he met his wife Florence Swinsky (Pincus), he pursued a job with CJ Devine and Co., where his mind, memory, and ability to predict value propelled him to the top of his field. When Merrill Lynch consolidated operations with CJ Devine, the "Devine Boys" created a high percentage of Merrill's revenue, and were granted the autonomy to run Merrill Lynch Government Securities Inc., with Swinsky as Executive Vice President. As a leader and pioneer in the trading of government bonds, Swinsky and his team left in 1980 to join William E. Pollock & Co and in 1990, the "Udder Guys" joined Fuji Securities. He retired from that firm as President. It was during his successful tenure on Wall Street that his eye for talent brought him into the world of Broadway and other arts. Mort touched so many people in his lifetime. He will be remembered and missed. He is survived by Florence, their two daughters Karen and Dana, and five grandchildren, Nikola, Dante and Thanos Carouso and Connor and Harry Cantelmo. A Memorial will be held Monday, July 26 at the Lotos Club, 5 East 66 St, 6:30 -8:30. Additional remembrances can be shared at legacy.com. Contributions in Mort's memory may be made to The National Sculpture Society, and The New York Theater Workshop.

ADLER--Deirdre S.,died peacefully on July 23 at age 86 after a short illness. A native New Yorker, Deirdre was the first professional development officer at The Chapin School in the early nineteen seventies. Following executive positions at City Center and the Musicians Emergency Fund, Deirdre and her second husband, Julius Ochs Adler (who died in 2003), founded the Canterbury Bookshop, which they operated for seventeen years. She volunteered for many years at Lenox Hill Hospital, Memorial Sloan Kettering, and Chapin, the latter as an alumna and trustee. Deirdre's first husband was the late Osborn Elliott. She is survived by daughters Diana Elliott Lidofsky, Cynthia Elliott, and Dorinda Elliott and their spouses, as well as step-children Douglas Adler, Anne Adler Tarbell, and Mary Adler Malhotra and their spouses, plus thirteen grandchildren and one great-grandson. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made in her memory to Lenox Hill Hospital or The Chapin School.

During a four-ball stroke-play competition, the team of Al and Ben is paired with the team of Carl and Dave. On the green, Al marks the position of Ben's ball and tosses it to Ben. Ben replaces the ball in front of Al's marker and removes the marker. Because Al's putt is on the same line as Ben's, Ben decides to stand on the other side of the hole to watch Al's putt. Al makes the putt, and Ben also makes his after seeing the break in Al's putt. Carl's ball is on a sprinkler head in the rough by the green. He decides to take relief but goes to get a different club. To save time, Dave lifts Carl's ball and drops it within a club length of the nearest point of relief. Carl chips his ball onto the green five feet directly behind Dave's ball. Carl tells Dave to stand on the extension of his line of putt behind the ball to watch his putt. Carl makes his putt, and Dave, having seen the break, also makes his.

MARCUS--Magen Dror, MD, 41, of New Rochelle, NY and New Haven, CT died peacefully in Yale New Haven Hospital on July 25 after year-long battle with kidney cancer. He served as a hospitalist in internal medicine there for the last five years. A graduate of the Ramaz School, Yale College, SUNY Downstate Medical School, the residency program in medicine and pediatrics at Jackson Memorial Hospital in Miami, FL, Magen (pronounced Ma-GAYNE), was the precious son of Judy and Ivan Marcus, beloved brother of Yuval (Elizabeth), Sasson (Beverly), and Ehud. Uncle to Talia, Nathaniel, Caleb, Zachary, Ariella, and Adam. Dear cousin and nephew, good friend to many. Funeral services today, Monday July 26 at 9:00am at the Young Israel of New Rochelle, 1149 North Avenue, New Rochelle.

Researchers who study recreational golf know a lot about our game, and they all agree on one thing: the truly awful shots - hopelessly errant tee shots or short chips that fly over greens - ruin most rounds by average golfers. If 105 is a typical score for you, you are likely to have about eight awful shots per round, while someone who shoots around 80 will probably have just two. That's according to Mark Broadie, a Columbia University professor who has spent years analyzing data from average golfers. O.K., so we know we're inconsistent, but here's the thing: many average golfers also follow up one dreadful shot with an equally dreadful shot. Why? Because we're frustrated and not thinking.

BORDEN--Arthur Murray, 90, of Manhattan, died peacefully July 23, 2010. Long-standing corporate lawyer and adjunct professor at New York Law School, he was a legal pioneer of taking publicly-traded companies private and author of a leading treatise on the subject, 'Going Private'. Mr. Borden was born April 18, 1920 in Brooklyn, and completed Yale College before serving in Europe in the U.S. Army as First Lieutenant. Post-war, he obtained his law degree at Columbia and embarked on a 50-year legal practice at various New York firms, including Borden & Ball; Sage, Gray, Todd & Simms; and Rosenman & Colin. In 1958 he incorporated the not-for-profit African American Students Foundation, which provided scholarships, including one for Barack Obama's father. His enduring interest in public affairs led to numerous articles on politics and a recent book. 'A Better Country: Why America Was Right to Confront Iraq'. An inveterate New Yorker who summered in Lenox, MA, he is survived by a large and adoring family, including his beloved sister Dorothy and brother-in-law Ralph Kaufman; Erica, Mark and Ross, his three children from his first wife, the late Florence Smiley of Brooklyn; Lindsay, Andrew and Anthony, his three children from his second wife, Audrey Poe of Memphis; and eight beautiful grandchildren. Service Wednesday 11:45am at "The Riverside", 76th St and Amsterdam Ave. Interment private. Reception 4pm University Club, 54th and Fifth.

If you're happy and you know it, and you really want to show it, send a tweet. By gauging the mood of messages on Twitter, a group of researchers from the Northeastern University College of Computer and Information Sciences, along with researchers from Harvard Medical School, set out to determine how happy or sad Americans are at different times of the day and week.

A picture caption on Tuesday with an exhibition review of ''Cars, Culture, and the City,'' at the Museum of the City of New York, misidentified the Cadillac shown in an Alfred Eisenstaedt photograph from the exhibition and misidentified the setting. The car was a 1941 Cadillac, not a 1940 (that was the date of the photo) and it was at the New York Auto Show, not in ''an auto showroom.''

Where was Paula Creamer's trademark pink ball when she won this month's United States Women's Open? She was instead using a ball designed for golfers with swing speeds less than 105 miles an hour, the Bridgestone Tour B330-RX, which the company has yet to produce in pink. But there might be a valuable lesson for average golfers in Creamer's ball switch.

A picture caption on Wednesday with an article about the renovation of the Israel Museum in Jerusalem misstated the given name of an artist who has a large installation there and omitted the second part of the work's title. The artist is Carlos Amorales, not Claudio, and the full title is ''Black Cloud (latent studio).''
GRUEN--Robert D.,84, of Englewood, New Jersey, former municipal judge of Teaneck. Wife Rhoda, children John, Deborah, Charles and Jane.

(ABC) THE BACHELORETTE While the two remaining bachelors sweat out the dwindling days until Ali presents the final rose, the season's spurned players -- including Kirk, who was dumped before the overnight dates in Tahiti, and the infamously tattooed Kasey -- reunite to dish the dirt on competing for her affections. Not present: Mr. Rated R himself, the wrestler Justin, who neglected to reveal to Ali (above) that he had not one but two girlfriends waiting for him back home in Canada. This show also offers a glimpse of the season finale and a sneak peak of ''Bachelor Pad,'' to have its premiere on Aug. 9. ''The Stories Behind the Rose,'' an episode of ''20/20'' at 10, delves into the inner workings of ''The Bachelor'' and ''The Bachelorette'' franchises through interviews with Chris Harrison, the shows' host; Mike Fleiss, their creator; and the former players Andrew Firestone, Meredith Phillips and Charlie O'Connell. 8 P.M. (Animal Planet) LAST AMERICAN COWBOY The search for a legacy bearer continues as one cowboy's lack of assertiveness puts his ranch in jeopardy.

ZITTELL--Paul. Born February 20, 1919 to Arthur and Anna Zittell, Died July 25, 2010. A Veteran who enlisted in World War II and served as the First Sergeant of a Fighter Squadron in the 9th Air Force in the European Theatre. He earned among other decorations, seven Battle Stars and a Presidential Unit Citation Badge with an Oak Leaf cluster. Returning to civilian life after three and a half years, he became President of the Boro Park Lodge of B'nai Brith and also President of the Temple Beth Emeth of Flatbush Mens Club. Professionally, he was a Registered Financial Planner, and was nationally recognized and honored by Mass Mutual Life Ins. Co. as an innovative and leading General Agent. He is survived by his adored and loving wife, Barbara, who he claimed to to be the major reason he lived as long and happily as he did. He considered himself an alternate loving parent to Barbara's three children from a previous marriage, Chari Trontz (Richard), Grandson Jesse Lehman (Karina), Great Grandchild Ysabella; Brett Waxgiser (Jeanne), Grandchildren Raechyl and Jacob; Steven Waxgiser (Sandy), Grandchildren Samantha, Ally and Ben. Also surviving are his loving natural sons from his prior marriage, Philip Zittell; Andrew Zittell (Mia Mitchell); Ted Zittell (Bari), Grandchildren Naomi (Jared), Great Grandchild Henry; Miriam, Benjamin and Zach. Funeral Service, Tuesday July 27, 11:15am, Riverside Memorial Chapel.

In a statement, Microsoft and ARM, the chip company, were quick to point out that they have worked together since 1997. Some consumers have seen the fruits of such work appear in the form of a trimmed-down version of Windows that runs on ARM chips found in phones, cars and other devices.

ECKSTEIN--Julius, died at age 86. He was very much loved by wife Evelyn, children Sandy and Andrew, John, Susan, and grandchildren Alan and David. Contributions can be made to the Kidney and Urological Foundation 152 Madison Ave, NY 10016.

After Apple's iPhone 4 press conference last week, Szymon Weglarski and Jon Dorfman, two designers from Brooklyn, decided they would have a little fun with the iPhone 4's antenna problem. They designed tiny bandages that fit perfectly around the edge of the iPhone, opened a store on the marketplace site Etsy, and named their new product Antenn-aid. Now the two partners are rushing to keep up with orders.

Richard K. Lieberman lifted the lid on the piano and asked the roomful of lecturers at LaGuardia Community College, ''Who's going to play?'' No hands went up, but one of the teachers sneaked across the hall and found Eric Anderson, a 26-year-old history major who turned out to be a pretty good pianist. ''This is too cool,'' he said, weaving together melodies like ''The Entertainer,'' the Scott Joplin rag that was used as the theme for the Robert Redford-Paul Newman film ''The Sting,'' and something that sounded like the theme from the old Joe Franklin show. (But who was awake enough when it came on to remember?)

A new paper by Raj Chetty and five other economists - the subject of my column this week - suggests kindergarten can have lasting effects on students. Students who learn more in kindergarten appear to earn more, to be less likely to become teenage parents and even to be less likely to die young.

On Wednesday, Alan Blinder, the Princeton economist and former Federal Reserve vice chairman, and Mark Zandi, chief economist of Moody's Analytics, will release a new analysis of the federal government's response to the Great Recession. As far as I know, it's the first serious attempt at analyzing the effect both of the stimulus programs passed by Congress and of the various financial-market policies put in place by the Fed, the Treasury and Congress. ISLAMABAD, Pakistan - Almost all of the political and current affairs talk shows on Pakistani television news networks took a defensive stance Tuesday on the release of military documents that suggested ties between Pakistan's spy agency and Afghan insurgents. The consensus was this: Pakistan and its intelligence agencies are unjustifiably criticized and painted in a negative light. Hosts and guests rued the fact that while the country has been hit by a devastating and almost unrelenting wave of terrorism, it is not really understood or acknowledged fully by the outside world.

This week's restaurant review is of the Lion, John DeLucie's scene-y new restaurant on Ninth Street, where Village used to be. It has its charms and distractions. You go see what you think, then post a comment below. Of particular interest this week, at least in terms of our discussion below, is the notion of restaurants in which the point of the dining room is as much to see and be seen as it is to eat. As a  historical example, do you remember 44, in the Royalton? The seating there was as rigorously codified as the caste system, at least on first blush. And in addition to some number of restaurants in the meatpacking district, I suppose there are a few restaurants on the Upper East Side as well - Orsay, for instance. So tell us. What are your favorite scene restaurants and why? Or, just as good, your least favorite! Comment approvers are standing by.

BP is concentrating on selling $25 billion to $30 billion in assets that are on the periphery of its huge energy empire as the company becomes leaner. The "more focused" BP described by Tony Hayward, its outgoing chief executive, is likely to see only an 8 to 10 percent decline in its overall energy production because of its asset sales, which are aimed at covering the costs of its disastrous oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico.

Asking people what they think about policy is tricky. Frame the question just so, and you can get just about any answer you want. Just two hours northwest of Paris and an hour or so south of the better-known - and far more crowded - Norman towns of Deauville and Trouville, Etretat feels like a secret weekend escape. Accessed from Paris by an almost absurdly bucolic train ride to Breauté Le Havre (followed by a short bus ride into Etretat; directions are here), the seaside town has just 1,000 inhabitants, many of them erstwhile Parisians who retire there for its spectacular vistas, lovely gardens, mild weather and such local delicacies as goat cheese, Calvados, apple jam and salted caramel.

Celebrity authors were conspicuously absent from the list of 13 finalists for this year's Man Booker Prize for fiction announced on Tuesday. The winner, who will receive a prize of about $77,000, will be named on Oct. 12. Andrew Motion, the chairman of the judges, said in a statement: "Here are 13 exceptional novels - books we have chosen for their intrinsic quality, without reference to the past work of their authors. Wide-ranging in their geography and their concern, they tell powerful stories which make the familiar strange and cover an enormous range of history and feeling." The Booker is Britain's best-known literary award, and brings with it prestige and, of course, an increase in book sales.

Robert Redford, Woody Allen, Ben Affleck and Emilio Estevez are among the actors who have directed films that will appear at the Toronto International Film Festival in September. The festival's officials on Tuesday announced a partial slate of 51 films,  including 25 world premieres. The lineup includes "The Conspirator," directed by Mr. Redford, about the aftermath of the Lincoln assassination; "You Will Meet a Tall Dark Stranger," directed by Mr. Allen, about Londoners in troubled relationships; "The Town," directed by Mr. Affleck, about a heist crew; and "The Way," directed by Mr. Estevez, about a doctor learning lessons as he goes abroad to collect the remains of a dead son. The festival begins on Sept. 9 and ends on Sept. 19. View the current list of announced films here.

"I'm not done yet," the Disabled in Action Singers insisted during a recent performance in a Manhattan church basement. Everything in their renditions of '60s-style protest songs made clear it was so. Decades after they blocked city buses and protested at Metropolitan Transportation Authority meetings -- and 20 years after the passage of the Americans With Disabilities Act -- the singers are still actively pressing for rights and understanding for those who face daily limitations because of personal disabilities and public obstacles. James Estrin captures their recent performance, as well as their colorful history, on the Lens blog. Read and see more at Lens.

There is a definite art to filling bookshelves. I don't think there is any right or wrong way; the only thing that doesn't work for me is when they are empty. While scouring design books, I find that I am always drawn to rooms where an entire wall is devoted to books. Books, quite obviously, give depth to a room, since they are one of the sure signs that someone with a pulse actually lives there, and the colors of the spines give a wall that random pattern that modern interiors so often lack.

CLEVELAND -- The binder that Joe Girardi consults during games is loaded with charts, scouting reports and trends, data that help him make decisions but that none of us will ever see. Therefore, there is no way of knowing exactly which statistics Girardi was looking at Monday when he called on Dave Robertson instead of Joba Chamberlain to face Asdrubal Cabrera with a runner on first, no outs in the eighth and the Yankees leading, 3-2. He said afterward that he liked the matchup -- Cabrera was 0 for 5 against Chamberlain and had never faced Robertson -- and hinted that Robertson seemed more likely to exploit Cabrera's weaknesses, whatever they were.

An article on Friday about a federal report on salaries and bonuses awarded to bankers at the height of the financial crisis in late 2008 and early 2009 erroneously attributed statements implying that the report would single out Citigroup's pay packages. It was two government officials with knowledge of the findings who said that the report's author, Kenneth R. Feinberg, the Obama administration's special master for compensation, had concluded that Citigroup was the biggest offender among the banks that had not yet fully repaid their government bailouts. That assessment was not part of Mr. Feinberg's report, released on Friday.

FARLEY--James H. We mourn the passing of our beloved friend, colleague, and partner, Jim Farley. Anything we have accomplished over the last twenty years would have been impossible without the intelligence, good judgment, and integrity that he brought to every project. These qualities, and his warmth and concern for others, enriched every day we had the privilege of working with him, so much more so during the last three years when, with faith and courage, he battled cancer. Above all, he was dedicated to his family, which was such a source of strength and deserved pride to him. Our hearts go out to Eileen, Hilary, Brendan, Julia, Neil, his mother Cate, and his brothers and sisters. The Stahl Organization Cauldwell Wingate Company LLC The Chanin Building

Warmer temperatures in the Colorado Rockies have produced a population boom of yellow-bellied marmots, at least in one well-studied valley. In an unusual, long-term study, scientists have been tracking marmots there since 1962. A new paper compares marmots from 1976 through 2008 to look for the effects of global warming on the animals.

Herbert G. Quick Sarah T. Quick Jeanette Walrond

ULLMAN--Frank L.,b. October 25, 1913, passed away peacefully on July 26, 2010 at the age of 96. Frank, his wife Emily, who pre-deceased him on October 25, 2000, survived the Holocaust in hiding in Amsterdam, Holland and immigrated to the U.S. with their two sons in 1947. Shortly thereafter, he helped establish the Nassau Stores, a chain of five and ten cent stores on Long Island which closed in the 1980s. Frank then worked for 23 years at the Manhasset (New York) Public Library, where he became the oldest paid library employee in the country prior to his retirement in 2009. He loved music, books, language and his family. He owed much in a long wonderful life to the Unitarian Universalist Congregation, to the Manhasset Public Library, and to many community organizations in Port Washington. He is survived by sons Leo and Henry, six grandchildren, and nine great-grandchildren.

10 P.M. (A&E) GROWING UP TWISTED Perhaps one rock 'n' roll family simply wasn't exciting enough for the people at A&E. Four years after introducing ''Gene Simmons Family Jewels,'' shown on Tuesdays at 9 p.m., A&E has added Dee Snider, above, the frontman for the heavy-metal band Twisted Sister, and his brood to its roster. The tight-knit Long Island clan includes Mr. Snider's wife of nearly 30 years, Suzette, and their four children -- Jesse, a husband, new father and an aspiring rock musician; Shane, a comedian; Cody, a filmmaker; and Cheyenne, who specializes in wrapping Daddy around her finger. The mayhem begins as the elder Sniders prepare to celebrate their wedding anniversary and are nearly undone by a mixed message: He is going to have his ''Suzette Forever'' tattoo re-inked, while she is going to have her ''Dee Forever'' tattoo removed. Ouch. 8 P.M. (National Geographic) SUNKEN TREASURES OF THE NILE Thousands of years ago, enormous boats navigated the Nile, loaded with riches for the royal temples of the pharaohs. Not all of these treasures arrived safely, leading modern-day archaeologists to wonder what might lurk at the river's bottom. This special goes in search of lost artifacts that could fill in some blanks in Egypt's history. In ''Writing the Dead Sea Scrolls,'' at 9, experts examine fragments of the scrolls, the caves in which they were found and a new clue -- a 2,000-year-old cup inscribed with a secret text -- better to determine the scrolls' authors.

SIMON--Jerold Stanton, 79, a trailblazer in the promotion and development of snow skiing for fifty years, and recognized as one of sixteen Founders of Skiing USA, passed away at his Las Vegas home July 24, 2010. Simon productions began with consumer Ski Shows in major U.S. cities. With safety key to the sport, he developed the Skiing Mechanics and Managers Workshops. Simon went on to create the International Ski Film Festival which later awarded "Jerry" statuettes named in his honor. In 1976 Simon organized a ski travel sales tour called SkiGroup. This program became a 30-city sales blitz for ski resorts worldwide and was so invaluable to Austria that its tourist board awarded Simon the Order of the Eagle, delighting in his middle name, St. Anton. Simon has garnered other awards, the BEWI for outstanding contributions to the sport of skiing, NASJA ski writers' Golden Quill, and the Far West Ski's first Snowsports Builder Award. Simon's marriage to his wife Barbara Alley was the first to take place on the peak of Jackson Hole Ski Resort. Simon was born in 1931 in NYC, attended Erasmus High, the University of Southern Mississippi, served in Korea, and came home to graduate Brooklyn College. He is survived by his wife Barbara and a son Jordan of NYC. Donations in his memory may be made to the US Ski & Snowboard Hall of Fame, PO Box 191, Ishpeming MI 49849.

A thousand physicists working at the Fermi National Accelerator Laboratory in Batavia, Ill., reported in Paris on Monday that they had not found the ''God particle,'' yet. But they are beginning to figure out where it is not. Its mass -- in the units preferred by physicists -- is not in the range between 158 billion and 175 billion electron volts, according to a talk by Ben Kilminster of Ohio State at the International Conference on High Energy Physics in Paris.

A picture caption in some editions on Saturday with the Nocturnalist feature, about acrobats and aerialists, misidentified one of the performers in the two center photographs. The woman shown in the dressing room and suspended from the ceiling by silk is Nikki Borodi, not Sarah Lovett.

Lost in the news of Manchester United's tour of North America, the New York Football Challenge and visits by Inter Milan, A.C. Milan, Glasgow Celtic and Real Madrid is the luckless story of Portsmouth's North American sojourn. While Manchester United is scheduled to conclude its top-shelf tour in Houston on Wednesday against the Major League Soccer all-star team, Pompey, as the south coast English club is called, on Saturday concluded its tortured Alms for the Poor Tour. And as United Manager Alex Ferguson joked about performing onstage with Paul McCartney during the former Beatle's tour stop in Kansas City, Mo., Portsmouth was condemned to a 27-hour trip from Edmonton, Alberta, to Washington during which luggage containing its uniforms was lost. So in the sweltering heat on Saturday, Portsmouth (a bankrupt club that was relegated from the Premier League) used a makeshift lineup and D.C. United's white away uniforms (the home team wore black) in a 4-0 loss that included five yellow cards and three ejections.

PEABODY--Judy. The patients and staff of the Center for Special Studies at New York-Presbyterian Hospital mourn the passing of our remarkable friend, Judy Peabody. Judy was one of the heroes of the AIDS epidemic. Outraged by the discrimination against people suffering with AIDS, Judy stayed at the bedside of many whose families had abandoned them, and rallied her friends to support programming intended to help restore dignity as well as health. An elegant, soft-spoken person, Judy found a very powerful voice to advocate for the marginalized and vulnerable. She touched the lives of countless people around the nation through her work and example. Our program was founded with her determination and sustained by her love. We will miss her guidance, inspiration, and, above all, friendship. Our thoughts are with Sam, Elizabeth, and the other members of her family. Jonathan L. Jacobs M.D. Executive Director Samuel T. Merrick M.D. Medical Director

Though ''The Merchant of Venice'' concludes with the resolution of one of literature's most notorious debts, Shylock isn't finished with Antonio - or with New York - just yet. On Monday, the Public Theater said it would transfer its Shakespeare in the Park production of ''The Merchant of Venice'' to Broadway in the fall. Al Pacino will stay on in the role of Shylock, whom he has portrayed during during the play's acclaimed summer run at the Delacorte Theater.

KISSELOFF--Samuel J.,83, the loving husband of Judith Kayloe Kisseloff, died Sunday, July 25, in Lake Worth, FL. He is survived by his sons Alan S. Kisseloff (Nancy) of Ormond Beach, FL and Jeff Kisseloff (Susan) of New Paltz, NY and his four loving grandchildren. Mr. Kisseloff served as President of City and Suburban Federal Savings Bank, as well as its General Counsel. He was also counsel in the law firm of Rosenberg and Estes, P. C. Mr. Kisseloff was a community leader, having served on the Board of his beloved Cold Spring Country Club in every capacity, including President. Other offices he has held include the Chairman of the Board of Trustees of Temple Emanuel in East Meadow, NY where he was a founding member and was later honored as a lifetime trustee. Mr. Kisseloff was an amateur thespian with a fondness for the theater as well as an avid golfer, jogger, and traveler. At the time of his death, he maintained residences in Lake Worth and Vonore, TN.

FINE--Benjamin W.,95, husband of Rosemary Tetreault Fine of New York City died Thursday, July 22, 2010 at New York Presbyterian Hospital. Born in New York City September 9, 1914 Mr. Fine was the son of the late Harry and Gussie Niedle Fine. He received his education in the New York City schools. For many years Mr. Fine owned and operated the Ben W. Fine Company, a jewelry and fine balances distribution firm in New York. He was prominent in the watch industry, consulting with U.S. government agencies regarding weights and measures of precious materials. He enjoyed the camaraderie and respect of colleagues nationwide. Survivors include his wife, Rosemary Tetreault Fine, a sister, Harriet Schumer and two nieces, Helene Weiss and Marion Schumer, all of New York City. The funeral and burial will take place in Bennington, Vermont on Tuesday, July 27, 2010. Memorial services in New York City will be held at a time to be announced.

LONDON -- Robert Dudley, who is expected to be appointed the chief executive of BP on Monday night at a board meeting here, faces a long road to restore confidence in the embattled company -- particularly in the United States, the biggest part of BP's business. Mr. Dudley, an American who has been with BP since it bought Amoco in 1998, faces myriad challenges: dealing with the costs and legal consequences of the spill in the Gulf of Mexico, repairing damaged relations with federal and state authorities, bolstering morale among BP employees and, perhaps critically, winning back investors. His job can be summed up simply as ensuring that BP survives its latest crisis and finds a way to move beyond it.

Manhattan playgrounds are serious stuff. Swings, slides and seesaws are so 20th century, an antiquated approach to child leisure now routinely laughed out of the sandbox of learning theory. These days, child learning experts recommend playgrounds that equip children with ''loose parts'' and other tools to create a ''child directed'' play space.

ADLER--Deirdre S.,died peacefully on July 23 at age 86 after a short illness. A native New Yorker, Deirdre was the first professional development officer at The Chapin School in the early nineteen seventies. Following executive positions at City Center and the Musicians Emergency Fund, Deirdre and her second husband, Julius Ochs Adler (who died in 2003), founded the Canterbury Bookshop, which they operated for seventeen years. She volunteered for many years at Lenox Hill Hospital, Memorial Sloan Kettering, and Chapin, the latter as an alumna and trustee. Deirdre's first husband was the late Osborn Elliott. She is survived by daughters Diana Elliott Lidofsky, Cynthia Elliott, and Dorinda Elliott and their spouses, as well as step-children Douglas Adler, Anne Adler Tarbell, and Mary Adler Malhotra and their spouses, plus thirteen grandchildren and one great-grandson. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made in her memory to Lenox Hill Hospital or The Chapin School.

Lea Brozina is survived by her husband of 53 years, Joseph, her daughter Deborah of New York City, son Mark, daughter-in-law Elizabeth and beloved granddaughter Rachel of Wayne, Pennsylvania. BOADT--Rev. Lawrence, CSP, a leading Catholic biblical scholar and Paulist priest, died at his residence in Mahwah, NJ, on July 24th, 2010. His death was announced by Rev. Mark-David Janus, president of Paulist Press. He stated that Father Boadt, who was 67, passed away after a long battle with cancer. Lawrence Boadt was a longtime professor of biblical studies at several institutions of learning including Fordham University and the Washington Theological Union, a Roman Catholic school of theology in the nation's capitol, where he taught for 21 years. In addition, he was a prolific author of scholarly books and articles and popular studies. His extensive published works included Ezekiel's Oracles Against Egypt, two volumes of commentaries on Jeremiah in the Old Testament Message series, a commentary on "Ezekiel" for the New Jerome Biblical Commentary and almost one hundred articles and reviews in leading biblical journals such as the Catholic Biblical Quarterly, the Journal of Biblical Literature, and Vetus Testamentum. His most popular work is Reading the Old Testament: An Introduction, published by Paulist Press in 1985. It has been the standard introduction to the Hebrew scriptures in numerous colleges and seminaries in English. Lawrence Boadt was born in the Westwood section of Los Angeles, CA, and grew up in the Paulist parish there. He entered the Paulists in 1962 and studied at St. Paul's College in Washington, DC. Following his ordination in 1969, he did graduate work at Catholic University, obtaining degrees in Semitic languages and theology. From 197276 he was a student at the Pontifical Biblical Institute in Rome, where he obtained a licentiate and doctorate in sacred scripture. Father Boadt was a man of boundless energy and enthusiasm for whom the classroom and writing were only a part of his achievements. He often conducted tours of the Holy Land. His favorite tour was through Turkey and Greece in the footsteps of St. Paul. He was the biblical expert on the team established by Walter Burghardt, SJ, which regularly ran workshops/retreats on preaching for diocesan priests. His incredible gift of clarity in his biblical presentations won him numerous admirers. For all the years he lived in Washington, he taught a weekly Bible class to a group of laity, professional people, and government officials. In 1998 he was named president of Paulist Press and served in that post until his final illness. Since 1975 he had been the scripture editor of the Press. As president, he oversaw publication of up to 80 books a year. Once again he brought out numbers of quality books on the Bible. His final contribution was the highly acclaimed Catholic edition of a Lectio Divina Bible. Father Boadt served as president of the Catholic Biblical Association of America and was active in major Catholic and Protestant biblical organizations. He was president of the Stimulus Foundation in recent years which was created to foster dialogue and mutual respect between Christians and Jews through publications dedicated to those goals. "Larry," as he was affectionately known by his many friends, was a convivial person who enjoyed being with people. He was never a reclusive scholar but always available for a good time. His unusual work ethic never excluded time with his Paulist brethren, among whom he was extremely popular. Plans are under way to create a fitting memorial to this highly gifted and dedicated priest who did so much to bring people across the U.S. to a deeper understanding of God's word as it comes to us in the Bible. A funeral Mass of Resurrection will be offered at 10am on Wednesday, July 28, 2010, at the Church of St. Paul the Apostle, 60th Street and Columbus Avenue in New York City. Visitation and wake will take place at the church from 2-5pm and 7-9pm on Tuesday, July 27. Immediately following the funeral, interment will take place in the Paulist Fathers' section of St. Thomas the Apostle Church Cemetery in Oak Ridge, NJ.

MORRIS--Eugene J.,died peacefully on July 24, 2010 at Mt. Sinai Hospital. Born in Manhattan on October 14, 1910, he was the beloved father of Dick Morris. Gene was married to the late Terry Morris for 59 years and to the late Blanche Morris for 14 years. He graduated from City College (1931) and St. John's University School of Law (1934). During World War II, he served in the U.S. Army. After the war, Gene was a founding partner of Demov and Morris, where he practiced real estate law for more than 54 years. He was a pioneer in urban renewal and instrumental in the development of many New York City projects, including Lincoln Center. He was a prolific writer of books and articles, including 26 volumes of Real Property practice books for Matthew Bender and a weekly real estate Column for the New York Law Journal for twenty-five years. He served as a Special Master for N.Y. State Supreme Court Justice Bea Shainswit. He was active in the New York City, New York State, and American Bar Associations. From 1990-2007, he taught real estate Law at N.Y.U. A native New Yorker, he lived in the city he loved and help build all of his life. Gene was an inspiration to everyone who knew him. He was much loved and is already sorely missed. In addition to his son, Dick, he is survived by his daughter-in-law, Eileen McGann, and one granddaughter. Friends and family may call at Frank Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Avenue in Manhattan on Thursday July 29, 2010 from 6-9 and for the funeral service at 11:30am on Friday, July 30, 2010. In lieu of flowers, contributions to City College will be welcomed.

The latest installment of Patient Voices focuses on scleroderma, an autoimmune disease that can lead to hardening and tightening of the skin and connective tissues. The symptoms and severity of scleroderma can vary, making it difficult to accomplish everyday tasks or, in some cases, threatening vital organs.

In the latest Patient Voices series, six men and women talk about scleroderma, a disease that causes gradual hardening of the skin and blood vessels and that can damage the lungs and other organs. Like many autoimmune disorders, scleroderma remains something of a mystery, though researchers are exploring new treatments for the disease.

I'm going to try an experiment here. As regular readers know, a lot of comment inches on every post are taken up by the same few ranters, who say the same thing every time; it kind of degrades the experience for everyone else. But I'm not going to edit out hostile comments (and by the way, neither I nor the various other people who moderate here ever have.) What I'm going to try instead is a three-inch rule: if it takes up more than about 3 inches on my screen, I'm going to tag it as spam. I don't know if the other moderators will follow suit, but I'm suggesting they do.

"Come Fly Away," the Broadway musical that married the choreography of Twyla Tharp with the music of Frank Sinatra, announced it will close at the Marquis Theater on Sunday, Sept. 5. The show will have played 26 previews and 187 regular performances. A national tour is scheduled to open in Chicago next March.

Damon Dash, hip-hop entrepreneur, has fallen on somewhat difficult financial times. Two apartments he owns in TriBeCa had a total of $9 million in liens on them. They were auctioned Wednesday. One, in the Atalanta on North Moore Street, sold for $5.5 million. The other, at the Sugar Warehouse on Laight Street, did not did not draw the $3 million minimum bid the bank would accept. So it now belongs to the bank. Our colleagues in the Real Estate section have the full story.

The White House kicked off Wednesday a month of events intended to mark the reduction of United States forces in Iraq, the culmination of a campaign promise that helped vault Barack Obama to the presidency.

The architect Rafael Viñoly has been chosen to design the Edward M. Kennedy Institute for the United States Senate, a memorial and educational center dedicated to the career of Mr. Kennedy, who died of cancer in 2009, the institute announced Wednesday. A white-and-gray complex overlooking Boston Harbor, the institute will stand beside the John F. Kennedy Presidential Library & Museum on the campus of the University of Massachusetts, Boston. It will include classrooms, a replica of Mr. Kennedy's Senate office and a re-creation of the Senate chamber with interactive desktops to provide information about the senators who have served in those seats and their voting records. Construction is expected to begin in the fall.

Over on City Room, the Dining section's Glenn Collins paid witness to the first letter grade assigned in city health officials' new inspection regime. Spark's Deli in Long Island City, Queens, was the lucky recipient.

General Motors, after announcing on Tuesday that the Chevrolet Volt plug-in hybrid car would cost $41,000, was unfazed by inevitable comparisons to the Nissan Leaf, a battery electric car that will arrive in select markets at the end of the year, around the same time as the Volt. At $32,780, the Leaf is far less expensive.

Jack Roush, the co-owner of Roush Fenway Racing, and a passenger, Brenda Strickland of Plymouth, Mich., were hospitalized Tuesday evening for injuries after a plane he was piloting crashed and split apart while attempting to land at Wittman Regional Airport in Oshkosh, Wis.

The Russian government, which just a few years ago was salting away billions of dollars in oil revenue, is now confronting such a gaping budget deficit that ministers approved a wide-ranging plan Wednesday to sell off state property, senior officials said, according to The New York Times's Andrew E. Kramer.
