Senator Olympia J. Snowe of Maine announced Wednesday that she would vote to confirm Solicitor General Elena Kagan to the Supreme Court, making her the fourth Senate Republican to back Ms. Kagan, President Obama's nominee.

I'd never eaten okra until I lived in England as a student in the 1970s, when I had it in back-street Indian restaurants that probably weren't very good but  offered cheap, very flavorful food. Come to think of it, I'd never eaten Indian food before either - and had never even seen many of its components. I have a clear memory of picking a cardamom pod out of my dinner and asking the waiter what it was. (He kindly gave me a dozen or so pods to put in my pocket and take back to my damp, chilly room, where I happily gnawed on them over the next few days.)

My 16-year-old son has his learner's permit. Which means I am having flashbacks. To my father starting me out between the lines of an empty parking lot in a shopping mall (back when malls were still closed on Sundays). To my mother hanging on to the passenger-side handle and trying not to be obvious about it. To the car simulators and "Death on Prom Night" films that were part of my school's driver-education class (back when school budgets allowed). To the fact that neither my parents nor my instructor wanted to take me on the highway, so the first time I switched lanes in fast-moving traffic was alone after I had my license.

I've been testing two Samsung Galaxy S phones for some weeks -- the Captivate from AT&T and the Vibrant from T-Mobile. Both are great phones. But I noticed something unusual when I tried to use television apps on them.

The joy inside Spark's Deli was not entirely unalloyed on Wednesday, even as the restaurant, in Long Island City, Queens, posted a big blue A - the first letter grade assigned in city health officials' new inspection regime.

The leviathan has landed. The 45-ton set for the Metropolitan Opera's new Wagner "Ring" cycle created by Robert Lepage has arrived at the house. On Wednesday, it passed a key test when it was rolled from a wing onto center stage. The trial run was delayed by several hours when an inspecting engineer found that the metal structure underneath the stage needed some touch-up welding.

Restructuring revenue fell in the second quarter for Lazard, the independent investment bank and one of the biggest players in the reorganization business. But the firm sees that unit picking up steam again soon.

EDISON, N.J. - President Obama met with several small-business owners at a sandwich shop here on Wednesday to promote his economic agenda and additional stimulus measures pending in the Senate, as Democrats seek election-year support from a business group that traditionally allies with Republicans.

Less than a month after the conclusion of a successful World Cup tournament in South Africa, the Brazilian sports minister touted the promise of the 2014 tournament in Brazil and responded to familiar concerns over the readiness of stadiums.

Despite being based in one of America's great centers of entrepreneurship (Silicon Valley), Amanda Keppert and her hot dog business, pictured above, needed the help of a tool more commonly associated with centers of third world poverty: microfinance. Ms. Keppert, as Kristina Shevory writes in a just published article, obtained a $6,500 loan through Kiva, which has lent more than $140 million in 53 countries.

In a year when millionaires are tapping their bank accounts to fuel political campaigns, one candidate in Connecticut hopes to turn his lack of a fortune into an asset.

Four men with a seemingly limitless appetite for office supplies have burglarized Staples stores in Manhattan at least seven times this year, the police say. The police released the above photographs of the suspects Tuesday night.

Eminem fended off a new release by the rapper Rick Ross to remain in the top spot on the Billboard album chart for the fifth week in a row. Eminem's "Recovery" (Aftermath/Interscope) sold 187,000 copies last week, according to Nielsen SoundScan, and Mr. Ross's "Teflon Don" (Maybach Music/Slip-N-Slide/Def Jam) reached No. 2 with 176,000. Sheryl Crow's new album "100 Miles From Memphis" (A&M) opened at No. 3 with 55,000 sales, Drake's "Thank Me Later" (Aspire/Young Money/Cash Money) fell one spot to No. 4 with 47,000, and the new "Kidz Bop 18" (Razor & Tie) is No. 5 with 43,000. Also new this week, the soundtrack to the Jonas Brothers' new television series, "Jonas L.A." (Disney), opened at No. 7 with 32,000.

David Brooks: Gail, as you know, I am often powerless. I mean that in the literal as well as political sense. About four times a year my Maryland neighborhood loses electricity. We lost it for nine days or so during the snow last winter. We stuck it out in the freezing house for three days before fleeing to Embassy Suites. We just lost it for two as a result of a recent summer storm.

As Ben Shpigel pointed out in his report about the Yankees' 4-1 loss to the Cleveland Indians on Tuesday night, the Yankees continued a troubling trend. They have now lost six straight games to pitchers making their major league debut, a streak that stretches to 2004. Here is what the neophytes did against the Yankees, and what they have done since.
